Score: S c o r e "n. A notch or incision; especially  one that is made as a tally mark; hence a mark or line made for the purpose of account.

Score: S c o r e "n. The number twenty  as being marked off by a special score or tally; hence in pl. a large number.

Score: S c o r e "n. A distance of twenty yards; -- a term used in ancient archery and gunnery.

Score: S c o r e "n. A weight of twenty pounds.

Score: S c o r e "n. The number of points gained by the contestants  or either of them in any game as in cards or cricket.

Score: S c o r e "n. A line drawn; a groove or furrow.

Score: S c o r e "n. The original and entire draught  or its transcript of a composition with the parts for all the different instruments or voices written on staves one above another so that they can be read at a glance; -- so called from the bar which in its early use was drawn through all the parts.

Score: S c o r e "v. t. To mark with lines  scratches or notches; to cut notches or furrows in; to notch; to scratch; to furrow; as to score timber for hewing; to score the back with a lash.

Score: S c o r e "v. t. Especially  to mark with significant lines or notches for indicating or keeping account of something; as to score a tally.

Score: S c o r e "v. t. To mark or signify by lines or notches; to keep record or account of; to set down; to record; to charge.

Score: S c o r e "v. t. To engrave  as upon a shield.

Score: S c o r e "v. t. To make a score of  as points runs etc. in a game.

Score: S c o r e "v. t. To write down in proper order and arrangement; as  to score an overture for an orchestra. See Score n. 9.

Score: S c o r e "n. To mark with parallel lines or scratches; as  the rocks of New England and the Western States were scored in the drift epoch.

Scorifier: S c o r i f i e r "n. One who  or that which scorifies; specifically a small flat bowl-shaped cup used in the first heating in assaying to remove the earth and gangue and to concentrate the gold and silver in a lead button.

Scoriform: S c o r i f o r m "a. In the form of scoria.

Scorify: S c o r i f y "v. t. To reduce to scoria or slag; specifically  in assaying to fuse so as to separate the gangue and earthy material with borax lead soda etc. thus leaving the gold and silver in a lead button; hence to separate from or by means of a slag.

Scorodite: S c o r o d i t e "n. A leek-green or brownish mineral occurring in orthorhombic crystals. It is a hydrous arseniate of iron.

Scorpaenoid: S c o r p a e n o i d "a. Of or pertaining to the family Scorpaenidae  which includes the scorpene the rosefish the California rockfishes and many other food fishes. [Written also scorpaenid.] See Illust. under Rockfish.

Scorpene: S c o r p e n e "n. A marine food fish of the genus Scorpaena  as the European hogfish (S. scrofa) and the California species (S. guttata).

Scorpio: S c o r p i o "n. A scorpion.

Scorpio: S c o r p i o "n. The eighth sign of the zodiac  which the sun enters about the twenty-third day of October marked thus [/] in almanacs.

Scorpio: S c o r p i o "n. A constellation of the zodiac containing the bright star Antares. It is drawn on the celestial globe in the figure of a scorpion.

Scorpion: S c o r p i o n "n. The pine or gray lizard (Sceloporus undulatus).

Scorpion: S c o r p i o n "n. The scorpene.

Scotale: S c o t a l e "n. The keeping of an alehouse by an officer of a forest  and drawing people to spend their money for liquor for fear of his displeasure.

Scottering: S c o t t e r i n g "n. The burning of a wad of pease straw at the end of harvest.

Scoundrel: S c o u n d r e l "n. A mean  worthless fellow; a rascal; a villain; a man without honor or virtue.

Scoundrel: S c o u n d r e l "a. Low; base; mean; unprincipled.

Scoundreldom: S c o u n d r e l d o m "n. The domain or sphere of scoundrels; scoundrels  collectively; the state ideas or practices of scoundrels.

Scoundrelism: S c o u n d r e l i s m "n. The practices or conduct of a scoundrel; baseness; rascality.

Scour: S c o u r "v. t. To rub hard with something rough  as sand or Bristol brick especially for the purpose of cleaning; to clean by friction; to make clean or bright; to cleanse from grease dirt etc. as articles of dress.

Scour: S c o u r "v. t. To purge; as  to scour a horse.

Scour: S c o u r "v. t. To remove by rubbing or cleansing; to sweep along or off; to carry away or remove  as by a current of water; -- often with off or away.

Scour: S c o u r "v. t. To pass swiftly over; to brush along; to traverse or search thoroughly; as  to scour the coast.

Scour: S c o u r "v. i. To clean anything by rubbing.

Scour: S c o u r "v. i. To cleanse anything.

Scour: S c o u r "v. i. To be purged freely; to have a diarrhoea.

Scour: S c o u r "v. i. To run swiftly; to rove or range in pursuit or search of something; to scamper.

Scour: S c o u r "n. Diarrhoea or dysentery among cattle.

Scourage: S c o u r a g e "n. Refuse water after scouring.

Scoured: S c o u r e d "imp. & p. p. of Scour

Scourer: S c o u r e r "n. One who  or that which scours.

Scourer: S c o u r e r "n. A rover or footpad; a prowling robber.

Scourge: S c o u r g e "n. Hence  a means of inflicting punishment vengeance or suffering; an infliction of affliction; a punishment.

Scourge: S c o u r g e "n. To whip severely; to lash.

Scourge: S c o u r g e "n. To punish with severity; to chastise; to afflict  as for sins or faults and with the purpose of correction.

Scouse: S c o u s e "n. A sailor's dish. Bread scouse contains no meat; lobscouse contains meat  etc. See Lobscouse.

Scout: S c o u t "n. A swift sailing boat.

Scout: S c o u t "n. A projecting rock.

Scout: S c o u t "v. t. To reject with contempt  as something absurd; to treat with ridicule; to flout; as to scout an idea or an apology.

Scout: S c o u t "n. A person sent out to gain and bring in tidings; especially  one employed in war to gain information of the movements and condition of an enemy.

Scout: S c o u t "n. A college student's or undergraduate's servant; -- so called in Oxford  England; at Cambridge called a gyp; and at Dublin a skip.

Scout: S c o u t "n. A fielder in a game for practice.

Scout: S c o u t "n. The act of scouting or reconnoitering.

Scout: S c o u t "v. t. To observe  watch or look for as a scout; to follow for the purpose of observation as a scout.

Scrag: S c r a g "n. A rawboned person.

Scrag: S c r a g "n. A ragged  stunted tree or branch.

Scrag-necked: S c r a g - n e c k e d "a. Having a scraggy neck.

Scragged: S c r a g g e d "a. Rough with irregular points  or a broken surface; scraggy; as a scragged backbone.

Scragged: S c r a g g e d "a. Lean and rough; scraggy.

Scramble: S c r a m b l e "v. t. To collect by scrambling; as  to scramble up wealth.

Scramble: S c r a m b l e "v. t. To prepare (eggs) as a dish for the table  by stirring the yolks and whites together while cooking.

Scramble: S c r a m b l e "n. The act of scrambling  climbing on all fours or clambering.

Scrap: S c r a p "v. t. Something scraped off; hence  a small piece; a bit; a fragment; a detached incomplete portion.

Scrap: S c r a p "v. t. Specifically  a fragment of something written or printed; a brief excerpt; an unconnected extract.

Scrap: S c r a p "v. t. The crisp substance that remains after drying out animal fat; as  pork scraps.

Scrap: S c r a p "v. t. Same as Scrap iron  below.

Scrapbook: S c r a p b o o k "n. A blank book in which extracts cut from books and papers may be pasted and kept.

Scrape: S c r a p e "v. t. To rub over the surface of (something) with a sharp or rough instrument; to rub over with something that roughens by removing portions of the surface; to grate harshly over; to abrade; to make even  or bring to a required condition or form by moving the sharp edge of an instrument breadthwise over the surface with pressure cutting away excesses and superfluous parts; to make smooth or clean; as to scrape a bone with a knife; to scrape a metal plate to an even surface.

Scrape: S c r a p e "v. t. To remove by rubbing or scraping (in the sense above).

Scrape: S c r a p e "v. t. To collect by  or as by a process of scraping; to gather in small portions by laborious effort; hence to acquire avariciously and save penuriously; -- often followed by together or up; as to scrape money together.

Scrape: S c r a p e "v. t. To express disapprobation of  as a play or to silence as a speaker by drawing the feet back and forth upon the floor; -- usually with down.

Scrape: S c r a p e "v. i. To rub over the surface of anything with something which roughens or removes it  or which smooths or cleans it; to rub harshly and noisily along.

Scrape: S c r a p e "v. i. To occupy one's self with getting laboriously; as  he scraped and saved until he became rich.

Scrape: S c r a p e "v. i. To play awkwardly and inharmoniously on a violin or like instrument.

Scrape: S c r a p e "v. i. To draw back the right foot along the ground or floor when making a bow.

Scrape: S c r a p e "n. The act of scraping; also  the effect of scraping as a scratch or a harsh sound; as a noisy scrape on the floor; a scrape of a pen.

Scrape: S c r a p e "n. A drawing back of the right foot when bowing; also  a bow made with that accompaniment.

Scrape: S c r a p e "n. A disagreeable and embarrassing predicament out of which one can not get without undergoing  as it were a painful rubbing or scraping; a perplexity; a difficulty.

Scraped: S c r a p e d "imp. & p. p. of Scrape

Scrapepenny: S c r a p e p e n n y "n. One who gathers and hoards money in trifling sums; a miser.

Scraper: S c r a p e r "n. An instrument with which anything is scraped.

Scraper: S c r a p e r "n. An instrument by which the soles of shoes are cleaned from mud and the like  by drawing them across it.

Scraper: S c r a p e r "n. An instrument drawn by oxen or horses  used for scraping up earth in making or repairing roads digging cellars canals etc.

Scraper: S c r a p e r "n. An instrument having two or three sharp sides or edges  for cleaning the planks masts or decks of a ship.

Scraper: S c r a p e r "n. In the printing press  a board or blade the edge of which is made to rub over the tympan sheet and thus produce the impression.

Scraper: S c r a p e r "n. One who scrapes.

Scraper: S c r a p e r "n. One who plays awkwardly on a violin.

Scraper: S c r a p e r "n. One who acquires avariciously and saves penuriously.

Scraping: S c r a p i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Scrape

Scraping: S c r a p i n g "n. The act of scraping; the act or process of making even  or reducing to the proper form by means of a scraper.

Scraping: S c r a p i n g "n. Something scraped off; that which is separated from a substance  or is collected by scraping; as the scraping of the street.

Scraping: S c r a p i n g "a. Resembling the act of  or the effect produced by one who or that which scrapes; as a scraping noise; a scraping miser.

Scrappily: S c r a p p i l y "adv. In a scrappy manner; in scraps.

Scrappy: S c r a p p y "a. Consisting of scraps; fragmentary; lacking unity or consistency; as  a scrappy lecture.

Scrat: S c r a t "v. t. To scratch.

Scrat: S c r a t "v. i. To rake; to search.

Scrat: S c r a t "n. An hermaphrodite.

Scratch: S c r a t c h "v. t. To rub and tear or mark the surface of with something sharp or ragged; to scrape  roughen or wound slightly by drawing something pointed or rough across as the claws the nails a pin or the like.

Scratch: S c r a t c h "v. t. To write or draw hastily or awkwardly.

Scratch: S c r a t c h "v. t. To cancel by drawing one or more lines through  as the name of a candidate upon a ballot or of a horse in a list; hence to erase; to efface; -- often with out.

Scratch: S c r a t c h "v. t. To dig or excavate with the claws; as  some animals scratch holes in which they burrow.

Scratch: S c r a t c h "v. i. To use the claws or nails in tearing or in digging; to make scratches.

Scratch: S c r a t c h "v. i. To score  not by skillful play but by some fortunate chance of the game.

Scratch: S c r a t c h "n. A break in the surface of a thing made by scratching  or by rubbing with anything pointed or rough; a slight wound mark furrow or incision.

Scratch: S c r a t c h "n. A line across the prize ring; up to which boxers are brought when they join fight; hence  test trial or proof of courage; as to bring to the scratch; to come up to the scratch.

Scratch: S c r a t c h "n. Minute  but tender and troublesome excoriations covered with scabs upon the heels of horses which have been used where it is very wet or muddy.

Scratch: S c r a t c h "n. A kind of wig covering only a portion of the head.

Scratch: S c r a t c h "n. A shot which scores by chance and not as intended by the player; a fluke.

Scratch: S c r a t c h "a. Made  done or happening by chance; arranged with little or no preparation; determined by circumstances; haphazard; as a scratch team; a scratch crew for a boat race; a scratch shot in billiards.

Scratch coat: S c r a t c h   c o a t " The first coat in plastering; -- called also scratchwork. See Pricking-up.

Scratchback: S c r a t c h b a c k "n. A toy which imitates the sound of tearing cloth  -- used by drawing it across the back of unsuspecting persons.

Scratchbrush: S c r a t c h b r u s h "n. A stiff wire brush for cleaning iron castings and other metal.

Scratchy: S c r a t c h y "a. Characterized by scratches.

Scraw: S c r a w "n. A turf.

Screable: S c r e a b l e "a. Capable of being spit out.

Screak: S c r e a k "v. To utter suddenly a sharp  shrill sound; to screech; to creak as a door or wheel.

Screak: S c r e a k "n. A creaking; a screech; a shriek.

Scream: S c r e a m "v. i. To cry out with a shrill voice; to utter a sudden  sharp outcry or shrill loud cry as in fright or extreme pain; to shriek; to screech.

Scream: S c r e a m "n. A sharp  shrill cry uttered suddenly as in terror or in pain; a shriek; a screech.

Screamed: S c r e a m e d "imp. & p. p. of Scream

Screamer: S c r e a m e r "n. Any one of three species of South American birds constituting the family Anhimidae  and the suborder Palamedeae. They have two spines on each wing and the head is either crested or horned. They are easily tamed and then serve as guardians for other poultry. The crested screamers or chajas belong to the genus Chauna. The horned screamer or kamichi is Palamedea cornuta.

Screaming: S c r e a m i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Scream

Screaming: S c r e a m i n g "a. Uttering screams; shrieking.

Screaming: S c r e a m i n g "a. Having the nature of a scream; like a scream; shrill; sharp.

Scree: S c r e e "n. A pebble; a stone; also  a heap of stones or rocky debris.

Screech: S c r e e c h "v. To utter a harsh  shrill cry; to make a sharp outcry as in terror or acute pain; to scream; to shriek.

Screech: S c r e e c h "n. A harsh  shrill cry as of one in acute pain or in fright; a shriek; a scream.

Screeched: S c r e e c h e d "imp. & p. p. of Screech

Screechers: S c r e e c h e r s "n. pl. The picarian birds  as distinguished from the singing birds.

Screeching: S c r e e c h i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Screech

Screechy: S c r e e c h y "a. Like a screech; shrill and harsh.

Screed: S c r e e d "n. A strip of plaster of the thickness proposed for the coat  applied to the wall at intervals of four or five feet as a guide.

Screed: S c r e e d "n. A wooden straightedge used to lay across the plaster screed  as a limit for the thickness of the coat.

Screed: S c r e e d "n. A fragment; a portion; a shred.

Screed: S c r e e d "n. A breach or rent; a breaking forth into a loud  shrill sound; as martial screeds.

Screed: S c r e e d "n. An harangue; a long tirade on any subject.

Screen: S c r e e n "n. Anything that separates or cuts off inconvenience  injury or danger; that which shelters or conceals from view; a shield or protection; as a fire screen.

Screen: S c r e e n "n. A dwarf wall or partition carried up to a certain height for separation and protection  as in a church to separate the aisle from the choir or the like.

Screen: S c r e e n "n. A surface  as that afforded by a curtain sheet wall etc. upon which an image as a picture is thrown by a magic lantern solar microscope etc.

Screen: S c r e e n "n. A long  coarse riddle or sieve sometimes a revolving perforated cylinder used to separate the coarser from the finer parts as of coal sand gravel and the like.

Screen: S c r e e n "v. t. To provide with a shelter or means of concealment; to separate or cut off from inconvenience  injury or danger; to shelter; to protect; to protect by hiding; to conceal; as fruits screened from cold winds by a forest or hill.

Screen: S c r e e n "v. t. To pass  as coal gravel ashes etc. through a screen in order to separate the coarse from the fine or the worthless from the valuable; to sift.

Screened: S c r e e n e d "imp. & p. p. of Screen

Screening: S c r e e n i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Screen

Screenings: S c r e e n i n g s "n. pl. The refuse left after screening sand  coal ashes etc.

Screw: S c r e w "n. A cylinder  or a cylindrical perforation having a continuous rib called the thread winding round it spirally at a constant inclination so as to leave a continuous spiral groove between one turn and the next -- used chiefly for producing when revolved motion or pressure in the direction of its axis by the sliding of the threads of the cylinder in the grooves between the threads of the perforation adapted to it the former being distinguished as the external or male screw

Screw: S c r e w "n. Specifically  a kind of nail with a spiral thread and a head with a nick to receive the end of the screw-driver. Screws are much used to hold together pieces of wood or to fasten something; -- called also wood screws and screw nails. See also Screw bolt below.

Screw: S c r e w "n. Anything shaped or acting like a screw; esp.  a form of wheel for propelling steam vessels. It is placed at the stern and furnished with blades having helicoidal surfaces to act against the water in the manner of a screw. See Screw propeller below.

Screw: S c r e w "n. A steam vesel propelled by a screw instead of wheels; a screw steamer; a propeller.

Screw: S c r e w "n. An extortioner; a sharp bargainer; a skinflint; a niggard.

Screw: S c r e w "n. An instructor who examines with great or unnecessary severity; also  a searching or strict examination of a student by an instructor.

Screw: S c r e w "n. A small packet of tobacco.

Screw: S c r e w "n. An unsound or worn-out horse  useful as a hack and commonly of good appearance.

Screw: S c r e w "n. A straight line in space with which a definite linear magnitude termed the pitch is associated (cf. 5th Pitch  10 (b)). It is used to express the displacement of a rigid body which may always be made to consist of a rotation about an axis combined with a translation parallel to that axis.

Screw: S c r e w "n. An amphipod crustacean; as  the skeleton screw (Caprella). See Sand screw under Sand.

Screw: S c r e w "v. t. To turn  as a screw; to apply a screw to; to press fasten or make firm by means of a screw or screws; as to screw a lock on a door; to screw a press.

Screw: S c r e w "v. t. To force; to squeeze; to press  as by screws.

Screw: S c r e w "v. t. Hence: To practice extortion upon; to oppress by unreasonable or extortionate exactions.

Screw: S c r e w "v. t. To twist; to distort; as  to screw his visage.

Screw: S c r e w "v. t. To examine rigidly  as a student; to subject to a severe examination.

Screw: S c r e w "v. i. To use violent mans in making exactions; to be oppressive or exacting.

Screw: S c r e w "v. i. To turn one's self uneasily with a twisting motion; as  he screws about in his chair.

Screw-cutting: S c r e w - c u t t i n g "a. Adapted for forming a screw by cutting; as  a screw-cutting lathe.

Screw-driver: S c r e w - d r i v e r "n. A tool for turning screws so as to drive them into their place. It has a thin end which enters the nick in the head of the screw.

Screwed: S c r e w e d "imp. & p. p. of Screw

Screwer: S c r e w e r "n. One who  or that which screws.

Screwing: S c r e w i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Screw

Screwing: S c r e w i n g " a. & n. from Screw  v. t.

Scribable: S c r i b a b l e "a. Capable of being written  or of being written upon.

Scribatious: S c r i b a t i o u s "a. Skillful in  or fond of writing.

Scribbet: S c r i b b e t "n. A painter's pencil.

Scribble: S c r i b b l e "v. t. To card coarsely; to run through the scribbling machine.

Scribble: S c r i b b l e "v. t. To write hastily or carelessly  without regard to correctness or elegance; as to scribble a letter.

Scribble: S c r i b b l e "v. t. To fill or cover with careless or worthless writing.

Scribble: S c r i b b l e "v. i. To write without care  elegance or value; to scrawl.

Scribble: S c r i b b l e "n. Hasty or careless writing; a writing of little value; a scrawl; as  a hasty scribble.

Scribbled: S c r i b b l e d "imp. & p. p. of Scribble

Scribblement: S c r i b b l e m e n t "n. A scribble.

Scribbler: S c r i b b l e r "n. One who scribbles; a petty author; a writer of no reputation; a literary hack.

Scribbling: S c r i b b l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Scribble

Scribbling: S c r i b b l i n g "n. The act or process of carding coarsely.

Scribbling: S c r i b b l i n g "a. Writing hastily or poorly.

Scribbling: S c r i b b l i n g "n. The act of writing hastily or idly.

Scribblingly: S c r i b b l i n g l y "adv. In a scribbling manner.

Scribe: S c r i b e "n. One who writes; a draughtsman; a writer for another; especially  an offical or public writer; an amanuensis or secretary; a notary; a copyist.

Scribe: S c r i b e "n. A writer and doctor of the law; one skilled in the law and traditions; one who read and explained the law to the people.

Scribe: S c r i b e "v. t. To write  engrave or mark upon; to inscribe.

Scribe: S c r i b e "v. t. To cut (anything) in such a way as to fit closely to a somewhat irregular surface  as a baseboard to a floor which is out of level a board to the curves of a molding or the like; -- so called because the workman marks or scribe with the compasses the line that he afterwards cuts.

Scribe: S c r i b e "v. t. To score or mark with compasses or a scribing iron.

Scribe: S c r i b e "v. i. To make a mark.

Scribed: S c r i b e d "imp. & p. p. of Scribe

Scriber: S c r i b e r "n. A sharp-pointed tool  used by joiners for drawing lines on stuff; a marking awl.

Scribing: S c r i b i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Scribe

Scribism: S c r i b i s m "n. The character and opinions of a Jewish scribe in the time of Christ.

Scrid: S c r i d "n. A screed; a shred; a fragment.

Scriggle: S c r i g g l e "v. i. To wriggle.

Scrim: S c r i m "n. A kind of light cotton or linen fabric  often woven in openwork patterns -- used for curtains etc ; -- called also India scrim.

Scrim: S c r i m "n. Thin canvas glued on the inside of panels to prevent shrinking  checking etc.

Scrimer: S c r i m e r "n. A fencing master.

Scrimmage: S c r i m m a g e "n. Formerly  a skirmish; now a general row or confused fight or struggle.

Scrimmage: S c r i m m a g e "n. The struggle in the rush lines after the ball is put in play.

Scrimp: S c r i m p "v. t. To make too small or short; to limit or straiten; to put on short allowance; to scant; to contract; to shorten; as  to scrimp the pattern of a coat.

Scrimp: S c r i m p "a. Short; scanty; curtailed.

Scrimp: S c r i m p "n. A pinching miser; a niggard.

Scrimped: S c r i m p e d "imp. & p. p. of Scrimp

Scrimping: S c r i m p i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Scrimp

Scrimping: S c r i m p i n g " a. & n. from Scrimp  v. t.

Scrimpingly: S c r i m p i n g l y "adv. In a scrimping manner.

Scrimpness: S c r i m p n e s s "n. The state of being scrimp.

Scrimption: S c r i m p t i o n "n. A small portion; a pittance; a little bit.

Scrimshaw: S c r i m s h a w "v. t. To ornament  as shells ivory etc. by engraving and (usually) rubbing pigments into the incised lines.

Scrimshaw: S c r i m s h a w "n. A shell  a whale's tooth or the like that is scrimshawed.

Scrine: S c r i n e "n. A chest  bookcase or other place where writings or curiosities are deposited; a shrine.

Scrine: S c r i n e "v. i. To cringe.

Scringed: S c r i n g e d "imp. & p. p. of Scrine

Scrip: S c r i p "n. A small bag; a wallet; a satchel.

Scrip: S c r i p "n. A small writing  certificate or schedule; a piece of paper containing a writing.

Scrip: S c r i p "n. A preliminary certificate of a subscription to the capital of a bank  railroad or other company or for a share of other joint property or a loan stating the amount of the subscription and the date of the payment of the installments; as insurance scrip consol scrip etc. When all the installments are paid the scrip is exchanged for a bond share certificate.

Scrip: S c r i p "n. Paper fractional currency.

Scrippage: S c r i p p a g e "n. The contents of a scrip  or wallet.

Script: S c r i p t "n. A writing; a written document.

Script: S c r i p t "n. Type made in imitation of handwriting.

Script: S c r i p t "n. An original instrument or document.

Script: S c r i p t "n. Written characters; style of writing.

Scriptoria: S c r i p t o r i a "pl. "of Scriptorium

Scriptorium: S c r i p t o r i u m "n. In an abbey or monastery  the room set apart for writing or copying manuscripts; in general a room devoted to writing.

Scriptory: S c r i p t o r y "a. Of or pertaining to writing; expressed in writing; used in writing; as  scriptory wills; a scriptory reed.

Scriptural: S c r i p t u r a l "a. Contained in the Scriptures; according to the Scriptures  or sacred oracles; biblical; as a scriptural doctrine.

Scripturalism: S c r i p t u r a l i s m "n. The quality or state of being scriptural; literal adherence to the Scriptures.

Scripturalist: S c r i p t u r a l i s t "n. One who adheres literally to the Scriptures.

Scripturally: S c r i p t u r a l l y "adv. In a scriptural manner.

Scripturalness: S c r i p t u r a l n e s s "n. Quality of being scriptural.

Scripture: S c r i p t u r e "n. Anything written; a writing; a document; an inscription.

Scripture: S c r i p t u r e "n. The books of the Old and the new Testament  or of either of them; the Bible; -- used by way of eminence or distinction and chiefly in the plural.

Scripture: S c r i p t u r e "n. A passage from the Bible;; a text.

Scripturian: S c r i p t u r i a n "n. A Scripturist.

Scripturist: S c r i p t u r i s t "n. One who is strongly attached to  or versed in the Scriptures or who endeavors to regulate his life by them.

Scrit: S c r i t "n. Writing; document; scroll.

Scritch: S c r i t c h "n. A screech.

Scrivener: S c r i v e n e r "n. A professional writer; one whose occupation is to draw contracts or prepare writings.

Scrivener: S c r i v e n e r "n. One whose business is to place money at interest; a broker.

Scrivener: S c r i v e n e r "n. A writing master.

Scrobicula: S c r o b i c u l a "n. One of the smooth areas surrounding the tubercles of a sea urchin.

Scrobiculae: S c r o b i c u l a e "pl. "of Scrobicula

Scrobicular: S c r o b i c u l a r "a. Pertaining to  or surrounding scrobiculae; as scrobicular tubercles.

Scrobiculate: S c r o b i c u l a t e "a. Alt. of Scrobiculated

Scrobiculated: S c r o b i c u l a t e d "a. Having numerous small  shallow depressions or hollows; pitted.

Scrod: S c r o d "n. Alt. of Scrode

Scroddled ware: S c r o d d l e d   w a r e " Mottled pottery made from scraps of differently colored clays.

Scrode: S c r o d e "n. A young codfish  especially when cut open on the back and dressed.

Scrofula: S c r o f u l a "n. A constitutional disease  generally hereditary especially manifested by chronic enlargement and cheesy degeneration of the lymphatic glands particularly those of the neck and marked by a tendency to the development of chronic intractable inflammations of the skin mucous membrane bones joints and other parts and by a diminution in the power of resistance to disease or injury and the capacity for recovery. Scrofula is now generally held to be tuberculous in character and may develop into general or local tuberculosis (consumption).

Scrofulide: S c r o f u l i d e "n. Any affection of the skin dependent on scrofula.

Scrofulous: S c r o f u l o u s "a. Pertaining to scrofula  or partaking of its nature; as scrofulous tumors; a scrofulous habit of body.

Scrofulous: S c r o f u l o u s "a. Diseased or affected with scrofula.

Scrog: S c r o g "n. A stunted shrub  bush or branch.

Scroggy: S c r o g g y "a. Abounding in scrog; also  twisted; stunted.

Scroll: S c r o l l "n. A roll of paper or parchment; a writing formed into a roll; a schedule; a list.

Scroll: S c r o l l "n. An ornament formed of undulations giving off spirals or sprays  usually suggestive of plant form. Roman architectural ornament is largely of some scroll pattern.

Scroll: S c r o l l "n. A mark or flourish added to a person's signature  intended to represent a seal and in some States allowed as a substitute for a seal.

Scroll: S c r o l l "n. Same as Skew surface. See under Skew.

Scrolled: S c r o l l e d "a. Formed like a scroll; contained in a scroll; adorned with scrolls; as  scrolled work.

Scrophularia: S c r o p h u l a r i a "n. A genus of coarse herbs having small flowers in panicled cymes; figwort.

Scrophulariaceous: S c r o p h u l a r i a c e o u s "a. Of or pertaining to a very large natural order of gamopetalous plants (Scrophulariaceae  or Scrophularineae) usually having irregular didynamous flowers and a two-celled pod. The order includes the mullein foxglove snapdragon figwort painted cup yellow rattle and some exotic trees as the Paulownia.

Scrotal: S c r o t a l "a. Of or pertaining to the scrotum; as  scrotal hernia.

Scrotiform: S c r o t i f o r m "a. Purse-shaped; pouch-shaped.

Scrotocele: S c r o t o c e l e "n. A rupture or hernia in the scrotum; scrotal hernia.

Scrotum: S c r o t u m "n. The bag or pouch which contains the testicles; the cod.

Scrouge: S c r o u g e "v. t. To crowd; to squeeze.

Scrow: S c r o w "n. A scroll.

Scrow: S c r o w "n. A clipping from skins; a currier's cuttings.

Scroyle: S c r o y l e "n. A mean fellow; a wretch.

Scrub: S c r u b "v. t. To rub hard; to wash with rubbing; usually  to rub with a wet brush or with something coarse or rough for the purpose of cleaning or brightening; as to scrub a floor a doorplate.

Scrub: S c r u b "v. i. To rub anything hard  especially with a wet brush; to scour; hence to be diligent and penurious; as to scrub hard for a living.

Scrub: S c r u b "n. One who labors hard and lives meanly; a mean fellow.

Scrub: S c r u b "n. Something small and mean.

Scrub: S c r u b "n. A worn-out brush.

Scrub: S c r u b "n. A thicket or jungle  often specified by the name of the prevailing plant; as oak scrub palmetto scrub etc.

Scrub: S c r u b "n. One of the common live stock of a region of no particular breed or not of pure breed  esp. when inferior in size etc.

Scrub: S c r u b "a. Mean; dirty; contemptible; scrubby.

Scrubbed: S c r u b b e d "imp. & p. p. of Scrub

Scrubbed: S c r u b b e d "a. Dwarfed or stunted; scrubby.

Scrubber: S c r u b b e r "n. One who  or that which scrubs; esp. a brush used in scrubbing.

Scrubber: S c r u b b e r "n. A gas washer. See under Gas.

Scrubbing: S c r u b b i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Scrub

Scrubboard: S c r u b b o a r d "n. A baseboard; a mopboard.

Scrubby: S c r u b b y "superl. Of the nature of scrub; small and mean; stunted in growth; as  a scrubby cur.

Scrubstone: S c r u b s t o n e "n. A species of calciferous sandstone.

Scruff: S c r u f f "n. Scurf.

Scruff: S c r u f f "n. The nape of the neck; the loose outside skin  as of the back of the neck.

Scrummage: S c r u m m a g e "n. See Scrimmage.

Scrumptious: S c r u m p t i o u s "a. Nice; particular; fastidious; excellent; fine.

Scrunch: S c r u n c h "v. t. & v. i. To scranch; to crunch.

Scruou-lize: S c r u o u - l i z e "v. t. To perplex with scruples; to regard with scruples.

Scruple: S c r u p l e "n. A weight of twenty grains; the third part of a dram.

Scruple: S c r u p l e "n. Hence  a very small quantity; a particle.

Scruple: S c r u p l e "n. Hesitation as to action from the difficulty of determining what is right or expedient; unwillingness  doubt or hesitation proceeding from motives of conscience.

Scruple: S c r u p l e "v. i. To be reluctant or to hesitate  as regards an action on account of considerations of conscience or expedience.

Scruple: S c r u p l e "v. t. To regard with suspicion; to hesitate at; to question.

Scruple: S c r u p l e "v. t. To excite scruples in; to cause to scruple.

Scrupled: S c r u p l e d "imp. & p. p. of Scruple

Scrupler: S c r u p l e r "n. One who scruples.

Scrupulist: S c r u p u l i s t "n. A scrupler.

Scrupulosity: S c r u p u l o s i t y "n. The quality or state of being scruppulous; doubt; doubtfulness respecting decision or action; caution or tenderness from the far of doing wrong or ofending; nice regard to exactness and propierty; precision.

Scrupulous: S c r u p u l o u s "a. Full ofscrupules; inclined to scruple; nicely doubtful; hesitating to determine or to act  from a fear of offending or of doing wrong.

Scrupulous: S c r u p u l o u s "a. Careful; cautious; exact; nice; as  scrupulous abstinence from labor; scrupulous performance of duties.

Scrupulous: S c r u p u l o u s "a. Given to making objections; captious.

Scrupulous: S c r u p u l o u s "a. Liable to be doubted; doubtful; nice.

Scrutable: S c r u t a b l e "a. Discoverable by scrutiny  inquiry or critical examination.

Scrutation: S c r u t a t i o n "n. Search; scrutiny.

Scrutator: S c r u t a t o r "n. One who scrutinizes; a close examiner or inquirer.

Scrutineer: S c r u t i n e e r "n. A scrutinizer; specifically  an examiner of votes as at an election.

Scrutiny: S c r u t i n y "n. Close examination; minute inspection; critical observation.

Scrutiny: S c r u t i n y "n. An examination of catechumens  in the last week of Lent who were to receive baptism on Easter Day.

Scrutiny: S c r u t i n y "n. A ticket  or little paper billet on which a vote is written.

Scrutiny: S c r u t i n y "n. An examination by a committee of the votes given at an election  for the purpose of correcting the poll.

Scrutiny: S c r u t i n y "v. t. To scrutinize.

Scudi: S c u d i "pl. "of Scudo

Scudo: S c u d o "n. A silver coin  and money of account used in Italy and Sicily varying in value in different parts but worth about 4 shillings sterling or about 96 cents; also a gold coin worth about the same.

Scudo: S c u d o "n. A gold coin of Rome  worth 64 shillings 11 pence sterling or about $ 15.70.

Scuff: S c u f f "n. The back part of the neck; the scruff.

Scuff: S c u f f "v. i. To walk without lifting the feet; to proceed with a scraping or dragging movement; to shuffle.

Scuffle: S c u f f l e "v. i. Hence  to strive or contend tumultuously; to struggle confusedly or at haphazard.

Scuffle: S c u f f l e "n. A rough  haphazard struggle or trial of strength; a disorderly wrestling at close quarters.

Scuffle: S c u f f l e "n. Hence  a confused contest; a tumultuous struggle for superiority; a fight.

Scuffle: S c u f f l e "n. A child's pinafore or bib.

Scull: S c u l l "n. The common skua gull.

Scullery: S c u l l e r y "n. A place where dishes  kettles and culinary utensils are cleaned and kept; also a room attached to the kitchen where the coarse work is done; a back kitchen.

Scullery: S c u l l e r y "n. Hence  refuse; filth; offal.

Scullion: S c u l l i o n "n. A scalion.

Sculp: S c u l p "v. t. To sculpture; to carve; to engrave.

Sculpin: S c u l p i n "n. Any one of numerous species of marine cottoid fishes of the genus Cottus  or Acanthocottus having a large head armed with sharp spines and a broad mouth. They are generally mottled with yellow brown and black. Several species are found on the Atlantic coasts of Europe and America.

Sculpin: S c u l p i n "n. A large cottoid market fish of California (Scorpaenichthys marmoratus); -- called also bighead  cabezon scorpion salpa.

Sculpin: S c u l p i n "n. The dragonet  or yellow sculpin of Europe (Callionymus lura).

Sculptile: S c u l p t i l e "a. Formed by carving; graven; as  sculptile images.

Sculptor: S c u l p t o r "n. One who sculptures; one whose occupation is to carve statues  or works of sculpture.

Sculptor: S c u l p t o r "n. Hence  an artist who designs works of sculpture his first studies and his finished model being usually in a plastic material from which model the marble is cut or the bronze is cast.

Sculptress: S c u l p t r e s s "n. A female sculptor.

Sculptural: S c u l p t u r a l "a. Of or pertaining to sculpture.

Sculpture: S c u l p t u r e "n. The art of carving  cutting or hewing wood stone metal etc. into statues ornaments etc. or into figures as of men or other things; hence

Sculpture: S c u l p t u r e "n. Carved work modeled of  or cut upon wood stone metal etc.

Sculpture: S c u l p t u r e "v. t. To form with the chisel on  in or from wood stone or metal; to carve; to engrave.

Sculptured: S c u l p t u r e d "imp. & p. p. of Sculpture

Sculpturesque: S c u l p t u r e s q u e "a. After the manner of sculpture; resembling  or relating to sculpture.

Sculpturing: S c u l p t u r i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Sculpture

Scum: S c u m "v. The extraneous matter or impurities which rise to the surface of liquids in boiling or fermentation  or which form on the surface by other means; also the scoria of metals in a molten state; dross.

Scum: S c u m "v. refuse; recrement; anything vile or worthless.

Scum: S c u m "v. t. To take the scum from; to clear off the impure matter from the surface of; to skim.

Scum: S c u m "v. t. To sweep or range over the surface of.

Scum: S c u m "v. i. To form a scum; to become covered with scum. Also used figuratively.

Scumber: S c u m b e r "v. i. To void excrement.

Scumber: S c u m b e r "n. Dung.

Scumble: S c u m b l e "v. t. To cover lighty  as a painting or a drawing with a thin wash of opaque color or with color-crayon dust rubbed on with the stump or to make any similar additions to the work so as to produce a softened effect.

Scumbled: S c u m b l e d "imp. & p. p. of Scumble

Scumbling: S c u m b l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Scumble

Scumbling: S c u m b l i n g "n. A mode of obtaining a softened effect  in painting and drawing by the application of a thin layer of opaque color to the surface of a painting or part of the surface which is too bright in color or which requires harmonizing.

Scumbling: S c u m b l i n g "n. In crayon drawing  the use of the stump.

Scumbling: S c u m b l i n g "n. The color so laid on. Also used figuratively.

Scummed: S c u m m e d "imp. & p. p. of Scum

Scummer: S c u m m e r "v. i. To scumber.

Scummer: S c u m m e r "n. Excrement; scumber.

Scummer: S c u m m e r "n. An instrument for taking off scum; a skimmer.

Scumming: S c u m m i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Scum

Scumming: S c u m m i n g "n. The act of taking off scum.

Scumming: S c u m m i n g "n. That which is scummed off; skimmings; scum; -- used chiefly in the plural.

Scummy: S c u m m y "a. Covered with scum; of the nature of scum.

Scunner: S c u n n e r "v. t. To cause to loathe  or feel disgust at.

Scunner: S c u n n e r "v. i. To have a feeling of loathing or disgust; hence  to have dislike prejudice or reluctance.

Scunner: S c u n n e r "n. A feeling of disgust or loathing; a strong prejudice; abhorrence; as  to take a scunner against some one.

Scup: S c u p "n. A swing.

Scup: S c u p "n. A marine sparoid food fish (Stenotomus chrysops  or S. argyrops) common on the Atlantic coast of the United States. It appears bright silvery when swimming in the daytime but shows broad blackish transverse bands at night and when dead. Called also porgee paugy porgy scuppaug.

Scuppaug: S c u p p a u g "n. See 2d Scup.

Scupper: S c u p p e r "v. An opening cut through the waterway and bulwarks of a ship  so that water falling on deck may flow overboard; -- called also scupper hole.

Scuppernong: S c u p p e r n o n g "n. An American grape  a form of Vitis vulpina found in the Southern Atlantic States and often cultivated.

Scur: S c u r "v. i. To move hastily; to scour.

Scurf: S c u r f "n. Thin dry scales or scabs upon the body; especially  thin scales exfoliated from the cuticle particularly of the scalp; dandruff.

Scurf: S c u r f "n. Hence  the foul remains of anything adherent.

Scurf: S c u r f "n. Anything like flakes or scales adhering to a surface.

Scurf: S c u r f "n. Minute membranous scales on the surface of some leaves  as in the goosefoot.

Scurff: S c u r f f "n. The bull trout.

Scurfiness: S c u r f i n e s s "n. Quality or state of being scurfy.

Scurfiness: S c u r f i n e s s "n. Scurf.

Scurfy: S c u r f y "superl. Having or producing scurf; covered with scurf; resembling scurf.

Scurrier: S c u r r i e r "n. One who scurries.

Scurrile: S c u r r i l e "a. Such as befits a buffoon or vulgar jester; grossly opprobrious or loudly jocose in language; scurrilous; as  scurrile taunts.

Scurrility: S c u r r i l i t y "n. The quality or state of being scurrile or scurrilous; mean  vile or obscene jocularity.

Scurrility: S c u r r i l i t y "n. That which is scurrile or scurrilous; gross or obscene language; low buffoonery; vulgar abuse.

Scurrilous: S c u r r i l o u s "a. Using the low and indecent language of the meaner sort of people  or such as only the license of buffoons can warrant; as a scurrilous fellow.

Scurrilous: S c u r r i l o u s "a. Containing low indecency or abuse; mean; foul; vile; obscenely jocular; as  scurrilous language.

Scurrit: S c u r r i t "n. the lesser tern (Sterna minuta).

Scurry: S c u r r y "v. i. To hasten away or along; to move rapidly; to hurry; as  the rabbit scurried away.

Scurry: S c u r r y "n. Act of scurring; hurried movement.

Scurvily: S c u r v i l y "adv. In a scurvy manner.

Scurviness: S c u r v i n e s s "n. The quality or state of being scurvy; vileness; meanness.

Scurvy: S c u r v y "n. Covered or affected with scurf or scabs; scabby; scurfy; specifically  diseased with the scurvy.

Scurvy: S c u r v y "n. Vile; mean; low; vulgar; contemptible.

Scurvy: S c u r v y "n. A disease characterized by livid spots  especially about the thighs and legs due to extravasation of blood and by spongy gums and bleeding from almost all the mucous membranes. It is accompanied by paleness languor depression and general debility. It is occasioned by confinement innutritious food and hard labor but especially by lack of fresh vegetable food or confinement for a long time to a limited range of food

Scut: S c u t "n. The tail of a hare  or of a deer or other animal whose tail is short sp. when carried erect; hence sometimes the animal itself.

Scuta: S c u t a "n. pl. See Scutum.

Scuta: S c u t a "pl. "of Scutum

Scutage: S c u t a g e "n. Shield money; commutation of service for a sum of money. See Escuage.

Scutal: S c u t a l "a. Of or pertaining to a shield.

Scutate: S c u t a t e "a. Buckler-shaped; round or nearly round.

Scutate: S c u t a t e "a. Protected or covered by bony or horny plates  or large scales.

Scutch: S c u t c h "v. t. To beat or whip; to drub.

Scutch: S c u t c h "v. t. To separate the woody fiber from (flax  hemp etc.) by beating; to swingle.

Scutch: S c u t c h "v. t. To loosen and dress the fiber of (cotton or silk) by beating; to free (fibrous substances) from dust by beating and blowing.

Scutch: S c u t c h "n. A wooden instrument used in scutching flax and hemp.

Scutch: S c u t c h "n. The woody fiber of flax; the refuse of scutched flax.

Scutch grass: S c u t c h   g r a s s " A kind of pasture grass (Cynodon Dactylon). See Bermuda grass: also Illustration in Appendix.

Scutched: S c u t c h e d "imp. & p. p. of Scutch

Scutcheon: S c u t c h e o n "n. An escutcheon; an emblazoned shield.

Scutcheon: S c u t c h e o n "n. A small plate of metal  as the shield around a keyhole. See Escutcheon 4.

Scutcheoned: S c u t c h e o n e d "a. Emblazoned on or as a shield.

Scutcher: S c u t c h e r "n. One who scutches.

Scutcher: S c u t c h e r "n. An implement or machine for scutching hemp  flax or cotton; etc.; a scutch; a scutching machine.

Scutching: S c u t c h i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Scutch

Scute: S c u t e "n. A small shield.

Scute: S c u t e "n. An old French gold coin of the value of 3s. 4d. sterling  or about 80 cents.

Scute: S c u t e "n. A bony scale of a reptile or fish; a large horny scale on the leg of a bird  or on the belly of a snake.

Scutella: S c u t e l l a "n. pl. See Scutellum.

Scutella: S c u t e l l a "n. See Scutellum  n. 2.

Scutella: S c u t e l l a "pl. "of Scutellum

Scutellate: S c u t e l l a t e "a. Alt. of Scutellated

Scutellated: S c u t e l l a t e d "a. Formed like a plate or salver; composed of platelike surfaces; as  the scutellated bone of a sturgeon.

Scutellated: S c u t e l l a t e d "a. Having the tarsi covered with broad transverse scales  or scutella; -- said of certain birds.

Scutellation: S c u t e l l a t i o n "n. the entire covering  or mode of arrangement of scales as on the legs and feet of a bird.

Scutelle: S c u t e l l e "pl. "of Scutella

Scutelliform: S c u t e l l i f o r m "a. Scutellate.

Scutelliform: S c u t e l l i f o r m "a. Having the form of a scutellum.

Scutelliplantar: S c u t e l l i p l a n t a r "a. Having broad scutella on the front  and small scales on the posterior side of the tarsus; -- said of certain birds.

Scutellum: S c u t e l l u m "n. A rounded apothecium having an elevated rim formed of the proper thallus  the fructification of certain lichens.

Scutellum: S c u t e l l u m "n. The third of the four pieces forming the upper part of a thoracic segment of an insect. It follows the scutum  and is followed by the small postscutellum; a scutella. See Thorax.

Scutellum: S c u t e l l u m "n. One of the transverse scales on the tarsi and toes of birds; a scutella.

Scutibranch: S c u t i b r a n c h "a. Scutibranchiate.

Scutibranch: S c u t i b r a n c h "n. One of the Scutibranchiata.

Scutibranchia: S c u t i b r a n c h i a "n. pl. Same as Scutibranchiata.

Scutibranchian: S c u t i b r a n c h i a n "n. One of the Scutibranchiata.

Scutibranchiata: S c u t i b r a n c h i a t a "n. pl. An order of gastropod Mollusca having a heart with two auricles and one ventricle. The shell may be either spiral or shieldlike.

Scutibranchiate: S c u t i b r a n c h i a t e "a. Having the gills protected by a shieldlike shell; of or pertaining to the Scutibranchiata.

Scutibranchiate: S c u t i b r a n c h i a t e "n. One of the Scutibranchiata.

Scutiferous: S c u t i f e r o u s "a. Carrying a shield or buckler.

Scutiform: S c u t i f o r m "a. Shield-shaped; scutate.

Scutiger: S c u t i g e r "n. Any species of chilopod myriapods of the genus Scutigera. They sometimes enter buildings and prey upon insects.

Scutiped: S c u t i p e d "a. Having the anterior surface of the tarsus covered with scutella  or transverse scales in the form of incomplete bands terminating at a groove on each side; -- said of certain birds.

Scuttle: S c u t t l e "n. A broad  shallow basket.

Scuttle: S c u t t l e "n. A wide-mouthed vessel for holding coal: a coal hod.

Scuttle: S c u t t l e "v. i. To run with affected precipitation; to hurry; to bustle; to scuddle.

Scuttle: S c u t t l e "n. A quick pace; a short run.

Scuttle: S c u t t l e "n. A small opening in an outside wall or covering  furnished with a lid.

Scuttle: S c u t t l e "n. A small opening or hatchway in the deck of a ship  large enough to admit a man and with a lid for covering it also a like hole in the side or bottom of a ship.

Scuttle: S c u t t l e "n. An opening in the roof of a house  with a lid.

Scuttle: S c u t t l e "n. The lid or door which covers or closes an opening in a roof  wall or the like.

Scuttle: S c u t t l e "v. t. To cut a hole or holes through the bottom  deck or sides of (as of a ship) for any purpose.

Scuttle: S c u t t l e "v. t. To sink by making holes through the bottom of; as  to scuttle a ship.

Scuttled: S c u t t l e d "imp. & p. p. of Scuttle

Scuttling: S c u t t l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Scuttle

Scutum: S c u t u m "n. An oblong shield made of boards or wickerwork covered with leather  with sometimes an iron rim; -- carried chiefly by the heavy-armed infantry.

Scutum: S c u t u m "n. A penthouse or awning.

Scutum: S c u t u m "n. The second and largest of the four parts forming the upper surface of a thoracic segment of an insect. It is preceded by the prescutum and followed by the scutellum. See the Illust. under Thorax.

Scutum: S c u t u m "n. One of the two lower valves of the operculum of a barnacle.

Scybala: S c y b a l a "n. pl. Hardened masses of feces.

Scye: S c y e "n. Arm scye  a cutter's term for the armhole or part of the armhole of the waist of a garnment.

Scyle: S c y l e "v. t. To hide; to secrete; to conceal.

Scylla: S c y l l a "n. A dangerous rock on the Italian coast opposite the whirpool Charybdis on the coast of Sicily  -- both personified in classical literature as ravenous monsters. The passage between them was formerly considered perilous; hence the saying Between Scylla and Charybdis  signifying a great peril on either hand.

Scyllaea: S c y l l a e a "n. A genus of oceanic nudibranchiate mollusks having the small branched gills situated on the upper side of four fleshy lateral lobes  and on the median caudal crest.

Scyllarian: S c y l l a r i a n "n. One of a family (Scyllaridae) of macruran Crustacea  remarkable for the depressed form of the body and the broad flat antennae. Also used adjectively.

Scyllite: S c y l l i t e "n. A white crystalline substance of a sweetish taste  resembling inosite and metameric with dextrose. It is extracted from the kidney of the dogfish (of the genus Scylium) the shark and the skate.

Scymetar: S c y m e t a r "n. See Scimiter.

Scypha: S c y p h a "n. See Scyphus  2 (b).

Scyphae: S c y p h a e "pl. "of Scypha

Scyphi: S c y p h i "pl. "of Scyphus

Scyphiform: S c y p h i f o r m "a. Cup-shaped.

Scyphistoma: S c y p h i s t o m a "n. The young attached larva of Discophora in the stage when it resembles a hydroid  or actinian.

Scyphistomae: S c y p h i s t o m a e "pl. "of Scyphistoma

Scyphistomata: S c y p h i s t o m a t a "pl. "of Scyphistoma

Scyphobranchii: S c y p h o b r a n c h i i "n. pl. An order of fishes including the blennioid and gobioid fishes  and other related families.

Scyphomeduse: S c y p h o m e d u s e "n. pl. Same as Acraspeda  or Discophora.

Scyphophori: S c y p h o p h o r i "n. pl. An order of fresh-water fishes inhabiting tropical Africa. They have rudimentary electrical organs on each side of the tail.

Scyphus: S c y p h u s "n. A kind of large drinking cup  -- used by Greeks and Romans esp. by poor folk.

Scyphus: S c y p h u s "n. The cup of a narcissus  or a similar appendage to the corolla in other flowers.

Scyphus: S c y p h u s "n. A cup-shaped stem or podetium in lichens. Also called scypha. See Illust. of Cladonia pyxidata  under Lichen.

Scythe: S c y t h e "n. An instrument for mowing grass  grain or the like by hand composed of a long curving blade with a sharp edge made fast to a long handle called a snath which is bent into a form convenient for use.

Scythe: S c y t h e "n. A scythe-shaped blade attached to ancient war chariots.

Scythe: S c y t h e "v. t. To cut with a scythe; to cut off as with a scythe; to mow.

Scythed: S c y t h e d "a. Armed scythes  as a chariot.

Scytheman: S c y t h e m a n "n. One who uses a scythe; a mower.

Scythemen: S c y t h e m e n "pl. "of Scytheman

Scythestone: S c y t h e s t o n e "n. A stone for sharpening scythes; a whetstone.

Scythewhet: S c y t h e w h e t "n. Wilson's thrush; -- so called from its note.

Scythian: S c y t h i a n "a. Of or pertaining to Scythia (a name given to the northern part of Asia  and Europe adjoining to Asia) or its language or inhabitants.

Scythian: S c y t h i a n "n. A native or inhabitant of Scythia; specifically (Ethnol.)  one of a Slavonic race which in early times occupied Eastern Europe.

Scythian: S c y t h i a n "n. The language of the Scythians.

Scytodermata: S c y t o d e r m a t a "n. pl. Same as Holothurioidea.

Sdan: S d a n "v. & n. Disdain.

Sdeign: S d e i g n "v. t. To disdain.

Sea: S e a "n. One of the larger bodies of salt water  less than an ocean found on the earth's surface; a body of salt water of second rank generally forming part of or connecting with an ocean or a larger sea; as the Mediterranean Sea; the Sea of Marmora; the North Sea; the Carribean Sea.

Sea: S e a "n. An inland body of water  esp. if large or if salt or brackish; as the Caspian Sea; the Sea of Aral; sometimes a small fresh-water lake; as the Sea of Galilee.

Sea: S e a "n. The ocean; the whole body of the salt water which covers a large part of the globe.

Sea: S e a "n. The swell of the ocean or other body of water in a high wind; motion of the water's surface; also  a single wave; a billow; as there was a high sea after the storm; the vessel shipped a sea.

Sea: S e a "n. A great brazen laver in the temple at Jerusalem; -- so called from its size.

Sea: S e a "n. Fig.: Anything resembling the sea in vastness; as  a sea of glory.

Sea acorn: S e a   a c o r n " An acorn barnacle (Balanus).

Sea adder: S e a   a d d e r " The European fifteen-spined stickleback (Gasterosteus spinachia); -- called also bismore.

Sea adder: S e a   a d d e r " The European tanglefish  or pipefish (Syngnathus acus).

Sea amenone: S e a   a m e n o n e " Any one of numerous species of soft-bodied Anthozoa  belonging to the order Actrinaria; an actinian.

Sea anchor: S e a   a n c h o r " See Drag sail  under 4th Drag.

Sea ape: S e a   a p e " The thrasher shark.

Sea ape: S e a   a p e " The sea otter.

Sea apple: S e a   a p p l e " The fruit of a West Indian palm (Manicaria Plukenetii)  often found floating in the sea.

Sea arrow: S e a   a r r o w " A squid of the genus Ommastrephes. See Squid.

Sea bank: S e a   b a n k " The seashore.

Sea bank: S e a   b a n k " A bank or mole to defend against the sea.

Sea barrow: S e a   b a r r o w " A sea purse.

Sea bass: S e a   b a s s " A large marine food fish (Serranus  / Centropristis atrarius) which abounds on the Atlantic coast of the United States. It is dark bluish with black bands and more or less varied with small white spots and blotches. Called also locally blue bass black sea bass blackfish bluefish and black perch.

Sea bass: S e a   b a s s " A California food fish (Cynoscion nobile); -- called also white sea bass  and sea salmon.

Sea bat: S e a   b a t " See Batfish (a).

Sea bean: S e a   b e a n " Same as Florida bean.

Sea bear: S e a   b e a r " Any fur seal. See under Fur.

Sea bear: S e a   b e a r " The white bear.

Sea beast: S e a   b e a s t " Any large marine mammal  as a seal walrus or cetacean.

Sea bird: S e a   b i r d " Any swimming bird frequenting the sea; a sea fowl.

Sea blite: S e a   b l i t e " A plant (Suaeda maritima) of the Goosefoot family  growing in salt marches.

Sea bow: S e a   b o w " See Marine rainbow  under Rainbow.

Sea boy: S e a   b o y " A boy employed on shipboard.

Sea breach: S e a   b r e a c h " A breaking or overflow of a bank or a dike by the sea.

Sea bream: S e a   b r e a m " Any one of several species of sparoid fishes  especially the common European species (Pagellus centrodontus) the Spanish (P. Oweni) and the black sea bream (Cantharus lineatus); -- called also old wife.

Sea brief: S e a   b r i e f " Same as Sea letter.

Sea bug: S e a   b u g " A chiton.

Sea butterfly: S e a   b u t t e r f l y " A pteropod.

Sea cabbage: S e a   c a b b a g e " See Sea kale  under Kale.

Sea calf: S e a   c a l f " The common seal.

Sea canary: S e a   c a n a r y " The beluga  or white whale.

Sea captain: S e a   c a p t a i n " The captain of a vessel that sails upon the sea.

Sea card: S e a   c a r d " Mariner's card  or compass.

Sea cat: S e a   c a t " The wolf fish.

Sea cat: S e a   c a t " Any marine siluroid fish  as Aelurichthys marinus and Arinus felis of the eastern coast of the United States. Many species are found on the coasts of Central and South America.

Sea catfish: S e a   c a t f i s h " Alt. of Sea cat

Sea chart: S e a   c h a r t " A chart or map on which the lines of the shore  islands shoals harbors etc. are delineated.

Sea chickweed: S e a   c h i c k w e e d " A fleshy plant (Arenaria peploides) growing in large tufts in the sands of the northern Atlantic seacoast; -- called also sea sandwort  and sea purslane.

Sea clam: S e a   c l a m " Any one of the large bivalve mollusks found on the open seacoast  especially those of the family Mactridae as the common American species. (Mactra / Spisula solidissima); -- called also beach clam and surf clam.

Sea coal: S e a   c o a l " Coal brought by sea; -- a name by which mineral coal was formerly designated in the south of England  in distinction from charcoal which was brought by land.

Sea cob: S e a   c o b " The black-backed gull.

Sea cock: S e a   c o c k " In a steamship  a cock or valve close to the vessel's side for closing a pipe which communicates with the sea.

Sea cock: S e a   c o c k " The black-bellied plover.

Sea cock: S e a   c o c k " A gurnard  as the European red gurnard (Trigla pini).

Sea cocoa: S e a   c o c o a " A magnificent palm (Lodoicea Sechellarum) found only in the Seychelles Islands. The fruit is an immense two-lobed nut. It was found floating in the Indian Ocean before the tree was known  and called sea cocoanut and double cocoanut.

Sea colander: S e a   c o l a n d e r " A large blackfish seaweed (Agarum Turneri)  the frond of which is punctured with many little holes.

Sea colewort: S e a   c o l e w o r t " Sea cabbage.

Sea compass: S e a   c o m p a s s " The mariner's compass. See under Compass.

Sea coot: S e a   c o o t " A scoter duck.

Sea corn: S e a   c o r n " A yellow cylindrical mass of egg capsule of certain species of whelks (Buccinum)  which resembles an ear of maize.

Sea cow: S e a   c o w " The mantee.

Sea cow: S e a   c o w " The dugong.

Sea cow: S e a   c o w " The walrus.

Sea crawfish: S e a   c r a w f i s h " Alt. of Sea crayfish

Sea crayfish: S e a   c r a y f i s h " Any crustacean of the genus Palinurus and allied genera  as the European spiny lobster (P. vulgaris) which is much used as an article of food. See Lobster.

Sea crow: S e a   c r o w " The chough.

Sea crow: S e a   c r o w " The cormorant.

Sea crow: S e a   c r o w " The blackheaded pewit  and other gulls.

Sea crow: S e a   c r o w " The skua.

Sea crow: S e a   c r o w " The razorbill.

Sea crow: S e a   c r o w " The coot.

Sea cucumber: S e a   c u c u m b e r " Any large holothurian  especially one of those belonging to the genus Pentacta or Cucumaria as the common American and European species. (P. frondosa).

Sea dace: S e a   d a c e " The European sea perch.

Sea daffodil: S e a   d a f f o d i l " A European amarylidaceous plant (Pancratium maritimum).

Sea devil: S e a   d e v i l " Any very large ray  especially any species of the genus Manta or Cepholoptera some of which become more than twenty feet across and weigh several tons. See also Ox ray under Ox.

Sea devil: S e a   d e v i l " Any large cephalopod  as a large Octopus or a giant squid (Architeuthis). See Devilfish.

Sea devil: S e a   d e v i l " The angler.

Sea dog: S e a   d o g " The dogfish.

Sea dog: S e a   d o g " The common seal.

Sea dog: S e a   d o g " An old sailor; a salt.

Sea dotterel: S e a   d o t t e r e l " The turnstone.

Sea dove: S e a   d o v e " The little auk  or rotche. See Illust. of Rotche.

Sea dragon: S e a   d r a g o n " A dragonet  or sculpin.

Sea dragon: S e a   d r a g o n " The pegasus.

Sea drake: S e a   d r a k e " The pewit gull.

Sea duck: S e a   d u c k " Any one of numerous species of ducks which frequent the seacoasts and feed mainly on fishes and mollusks. The scoters  eiders old squaw and ruddy duck are examples. They may be distinguished by the lobate hind toe.

Sea eagle: S e a   e a g l e " Any one of several species of fish-eating eagles of the genus Haliaeetus and allied genera  as the North Pacific sea eagle. (H. pelagicus) which has white shoulders head rump and tail; the European white-tailed eagle (H. albicilla); and the Indian white-tailed sea eagle or fishing eagle (Polioaetus ichthyaetus). The bald eagle and the osprey are also sometimes classed as sea eagles.

Sea eagle: S e a   e a g l e " The eagle ray. See under Ray.

Sea eel: S e a   e e l " The conger eel.

Sea egg: S e a   e g g " A sea urchin.

Sea elephant: S e a   e l e p h a n t " A very large seal (Macrorhinus proboscideus) of the Antarctic seas  much hunted for its oil. It sometimes attains a length of thirty feet and is remarkable for the prolongation of the nose of the adult male into an erectile elastic proboscis about a foot in length. Another species of smaller size (M. angustirostris) occurs on the coast of Lower California but is now nearly extinct.

Sea fan: S e a   f a n " Any gorgonian which branches in a fanlike form  especially Gorgonia flabellum of Florida and the West Indies.

Sea feather: S e a   f e a t h e r " Any gorgonian which branches in a plumelike form.

Sea fennel: S e a   f e n n e l " Samphire.

Sea fern: S e a   f e r n " Any gorgonian which branches like a fern.

Sea fight: S e a   f i g h t " An engagement between ships at sea; a naval battle.

Sea fir: S e a   f i r " A sertularian hydroid  especially Sertularia abietina which branches like a miniature fir tree.

Sea flewer: S e a   f l e w e r " A sea anemone  or any related anthozoan.

Sea foam: S e a   f o a m " Foam of sea water.

Sea foam: S e a   f o a m " Meerschaum; -- called also sea froth.

Sea fowl: S e a   f o w l " Any bird which habitually frequents the sea  as an auk gannet gull tern or petrel; also all such birds collectively.

Sea fox: S e a   f o x " The thrasher shark. See Thrasher.

Sea froth: S e a   f r o t h " See Sea foam  2.

Sea gauge: S e a   g a u g e " See under Gauge  n.

Sea gherkin: S e a   g h e r k i n " Alt. of Sea girkin

Sea ginger: S e a   g i n g e r " A hydroid coral of the genus Millepora  especially M. alcicornis of the West Indies and Florida. So called because it stings the tongue like ginger. See Illust. under Millepore.

Sea girdles: S e a   g i r d l e s " A kind of kelp (Laminaria digitata) with palmately cleft fronds; -- called also sea wand  seaware and tangle.

Sea girkin: S e a   g i r k i n " Any small holothurian resembling in form a gherkin.

Sea god: S e a   g o d " A marine deity; a fabulous being supposed to live in  or have dominion over the sea or some particular sea or part of the sea as Neptune.

Sea goddess: S e a   g o d d e s s " A goddess supposed to live in or reign over the sea  or some part of the sea.

Sea goose: S e a   g o o s e " A phalarope.

Sea gown: S e a   g o w n " A gown or frock with short sleeves  formerly worn by mariners.

Sea grape: S e a   g r a p e " The gulf weed. See under Gulf.

Sea grape: S e a   g r a p e " A shrubby plant (Coccoloba uvifera) growing on the sandy shores of tropical America  somewhat resembling the grapevine.

Sea grape: S e a   g r a p e " The clusters of gelatinous egg capsules of a squid (Loligo).

Sea grass: S e a   g r a s s " Eelgrass.

Sea green: S e a   g r e e n " The green color of sea water.

Sea gudgeon: S e a   g u d g e o n " The European black goby (Gobius niger).

Sea gull: S e a   g u l l " Any gull living on the seacoast.

Sea hare: S e a   h a r e " Any tectibranchiate mollusk of the genus Aplysia. See Aplysia.

Sea hawk: S e a   h a w k " A jager gull.

Sea heath: S e a   h e a t h " A low perennial plant (Frankenia laevis) resembling heath  growing along the seashore in Europe.

Sea hedgehog: S e a   h e d g e h o g " A sea urchin.

Sea hen: S e a   h e n " the common guillemot; -- applied also to various other sea birds.

Sea hog: S e a   h o g " The porpoise.

Sea holly: S e a   h o l l y " An evergeen seashore plant (Eryngium maritimum). See Eryngium.

Sea holm: S e a   h o l m " A small uninhabited island.

Sea holm: S e a   h o l m " Sea holly.

Sea horse: S e a   h o r s e " A fabulous creature  half horse and half fish represented in classic mythology as driven by sea dogs or ridden by the Nereids. It is also depicted in heraldry. See Hippocampus.

Sea horse: S e a   h o r s e " The walrus.

Sea horse: S e a   h o r s e " Any fish of the genus Hippocampus.

Sea hulver: S e a   h u l v e r " Sea holly.

Sea jelly: S e a   j e l l y " A medusa  or jellyfish.

Sea kale: S e a   k a l e " See under Kale.

Sea king: S e a   k i n g " One of the leaders among the Norsemen who passed their lives in roving the seas in search of plunder and adventures; a Norse pirate chief. See the Note under Viking.

Sea laces: S e a   l a c e s " A kind of seaweed (Chorda Filum) having blackish cordlike fronds  often many feet long.

Sea lamprey: S e a   l a m p r e y " The common lamprey.

Sea language: S e a   l a n g u a g e " The peculiar language or phraseology of seamen; sailor's cant.

Sea lark: S e a   l a r k " The rock pipit (Anthus obscurus).

Sea lark: S e a   l a r k " Any one of several small sandpipers and plovers  as the ringed plover the turnstone the dunlin and the sanderling.

Sea lavender: S e a   l a v e n d e r " See Marsh rosemary  under Marsh.

Sea lawyer: S e a   l a w y e r " The gray snapper. See under Snapper.

Sea legs: S e a   l e g s " Legs able to maintain their possessor upright in stormy weather at sea  that is ability stand or walk steadily on deck when a vessel is rolling or pitching in a rough sea.

Sea lemon: S e a   l e m o n " Any one of several species of nudibranchiate mollusks of the genus Doris and allied genera  having a smooth thick convex yellow body.

Sea leopard: S e a   l e o p a r d " Any one of several species of spotted seals  especially Ogmorhinus leptonyx and Leptonychotes Weddelli of the Antarctic Ocean. The North Pacific sea leopard is the harbor seal.

Sea letter: S e a   l e t t e r " The customary certificate of national character which neutral merchant vessels are bound to carry in time of war; a passport for a vessel and cargo.

Sea lettuce: S e a   l e t t u c e " The green papery fronds of several seaweeds of the genus Ulva  sometimes used as food.

Sea level: S e a   l e v e l " The level of the surface of the sea; any surface on the same level with the sea.

Sea lily: S e a   l i l y " A crinoid.

Sea lion: S e a   l i o n " Any one of several large species of seals of the family Otariidae native of the Pacific Ocean  especially the southern sea lion (Otaria jubata) of the South American coast; the northern sea lion (Eumetopias Stelleri) found from California to Japan; and the black or California sea lion (Zalophus Californianus) which is common on the rocks near San Francisco.

Sea loach: S e a   l o a c h " The three-bearded rockling. See Rockling.

Sea louse: S e a   l o u s e " Any one of numerous species of isopod crustaceans of Cymothoa  Livoneca and allied genera mostly parasites on fishes.

Sea mantis: S e a   m a n t i s " A squilla.

Sea marge: S e a   m a r g e " Land which borders on the sea; the seashore.

Sea mat: S e a   m a t " Any bryozoan of the genus Flustra or allied genera which form frondlike corals.

Sea maw: S e a   m a w " The sea mew.

Sea mew: S e a   m e w " A gull; the mew.

Sea mile: S e a   m i l e " A geographical mile. See Mile.

Sea milkwort: S e a   m i l k w o r t " A low  fleshy perennial herb (Glaux maritima) found along northern seashores.

Sea monk: S e a   m o n k " See Monk seal  under Monk.

Sea monster: S e a   m o n s t e r " Any large sea animal.

Sea moss: S e a   m o s s " Any branched marine bryozoan resembling moss.

Sea mouse: S e a   m o u s e " A dorsibranchiate annelid  belonging to Aphrodite and allied genera having long slender hairlike setae on the sides.

Sea mouse: S e a   m o u s e " The dunlin.

Sea mud: S e a   m u d " A rich slimy deposit in salt marshes and along the seashore  sometimes used as a manure; -- called also sea ooze.

Sea needle: S e a   n e e d l e " See Garfish (a).

Sea nettle: S e a   n e t t l e " A jellyfish  or medusa.

Sea onion: S e a   o n i o n " The officinal squill. See Squill.

Sea ooze: S e a   o o z e " Same as Sea mud.

Sea orange: S e a   o r a n g e " A large American holothurian (Lophothuria Fabricii) having a bright orange convex body covered with finely granulated scales. Its expanded tentacles are bright red.

Sea otter: S e a   o t t e r " An aquatic carnivore (Enhydris lutris  / marina) found in the North Pacific Ocean. Its fur is highly valued especially by the Chinese. It is allied to the common otter but is larger with feet more decidedly webbed.

Sea owl: S e a   o w l " The lumpfish.

Sea pad: S e a   p a d " The puffin.

Sea partridge: S e a   p a r t r i d g e " The gilthead (Crenilabrus melops)  a fish of the British coasts.

Sea pass: S e a   p a s s " A document carried by neutral merchant vessels in time of war  to show their nationality; a sea letter or passport. See Passport.

Sea peach: S e a   p e a c h " A beautiful American ascidian (Cynthia  / Halocynthia pyriformis) having the size form velvety surface and color of a ripe peach.

Sea pear: S e a   p e a r " A pedunculated ascidian of the genus Boltonia.

Sea perch: S e a   p e r c h " The European bass (Roccus  / Labrax lupus); -- called also sea dace.

Sea perch: S e a   p e r c h " The cunner.

Sea perch: S e a   p e r c h " The sea bass.

Sea perch: S e a   p e r c h " The name is applied also to other species of fishes.

Sea pheasant: S e a   p h e a s a n t " The pintail duck.

Sea pie: S e a   p i e " The oyster catcher  a limicoline bird of the genus Haematopus.

Sea pie: S e a   p i e " A dish of crust or pastry and meat or fish  etc. cooked together in alternate layers -- a common food of sailors; as a three-decker sea pie.

Sea piet: S e a   p i e t " See 1st Sea pie.

Sea pig: S e a   p i g " A porpoise or dolphin.

Sea pig: S e a   p i g " A dugong.

Sea pigeon: S e a   p i g e o n " The common guillemot.

Sea pike: S e a   p i k e " The garfish.

Sea pike: S e a   p i k e " A large serranoid food fish (Centropomus undecimalis) found on both coasts of America; -- called also robalo.

Sea pike: S e a   p i k e " The merluce.

Sea pincushion: S e a   p i n c u s h i o n " A sea purse.

Sea pincushion: S e a   p i n c u s h i o n " A pentagonal starfish.

Sea pink: S e a   p i n k " See Thrift.

Sea plover: S e a   p l o v e r " the black-bellied plover.

Sea poacher: S e a   p o a c h e r " Alt. of Sea poker

Sea poker: S e a   p o k e r " The lyrie.

Sea pool: S e a   p o o l " A pool of salt water.

Sea poppy: S e a   p o p p y " The horn poppy. See under Horn.

Sea porcupine: S e a   p o r c u p i n e " Any fish of the genus Diodon  and allied genera whose body is covered with spines. See Illust. under Diodon.

Sea pork: S e a   p o r k " An American compound ascidian (Amoraecium stellatum) which forms large whitish masses resembling salt pork.

Sea pudding: S e a   p u d d i n g " Any large holothurian.

Sea purse: S e a   p u r s e " The horny egg case of a skate  and of certain sharks.

Sea purslane: S e a   p u r s l a n e " See under Purslane.

Sea pye: S e a   p y e " See 1st Sea pie.

Sea pyot: S e a   p y o t " See 1st Sea pie.

Sea quail: S e a   q u a i l " The turnstone.

Sea rat: S e a   r a t " A pirate.

Sea rat: S e a   r a t " The chimaera.

Sea raven: S e a   r a v e n " An American cottoid fish (Hemitripterus Americanus) allied to the sculpins  found on the northeren Atlantic coasts.

Sea raven: S e a   r a v e n " The cormorant.

Sea reed: S e a   r e e d " The sea-sand reed. See under Reed.

Sea risk: S e a   r i s k " Risk of injury  destruction or loss by the sea or while at sea.

Sea robber: S e a   r o b b e r " A pirate; a sea rover.

Sea robin: S e a   r o b i n " See under Robin  and Illustration in Appendix.

Sea rocket: S e a   r o c k e t " See under Rocket.

Sea room: S e a   r o o m " Room or space at sea for a vessel to maneuver  drive or scud without peril of running ashore or aground.

Sea rover: S e a   r o v e r " One that cruises or roves the sea for plunder; a sea robber; a pirate; also  a piratical vessel.

Sea salmon: S e a   s a l m o n " A young pollock.

Sea salmon: S e a   s a l m o n " The spotted squeteague.

Sea salmon: S e a   s a l m o n " See Sea bass (b).

Sea salt: S e a   s a l t " Common salt  obtained from sea water by evaporation.

Sea sandpiper: S e a   s a n d p i p e r " The purple sandpiper.

Sea sandwort: S e a   s a n d w o r t " See Sea chickweed.

Sea saurian: S e a   s a u r i a n "n. Any marine saurian; esp. (Paleon.) the large extinct species of Mosasaurus  Icthyosaurus Plesiosaurus and related genera.

Sea scorpion: S e a   s c o r p i o n " A European sculpin (Cottus scorpius) having the head armed with short spines.

Sea scorpion: S e a   s c o r p i o n " The scorpene.

Sea scurf: S e a   s c u r f " Any bryozoan which forms rounded or irregular patches of coral on stones  seaweeds etc.

Sea serpent: S e a   s e r p e n t " Any marine snake. See Sea snake.

Sea serpent: S e a   s e r p e n t " A large marine animal of unknown nature  often reported to have been seen at sea but never yet captured.

Sea slater: S e a   s l a t e r " Any isopod crustacean of the genus Ligia.

Sea slug: S e a   s l u g " A holothurian.

Sea slug: S e a   s l u g " A nudibranch mollusk.

Sea snail: S e a   s n a i l " A small fish of the genus Liparis  having a ventral sucker. It lives among stones and seaweeds.

Sea snail: S e a   s n a i l " Any small creeping marine gastropod  as the species of Littorina Natica etc.

Sea snake: S e a   s n a k e " Any one of many species of venomous aquatic snakes of the family Hydrophidae  having a flattened tail and living entirely in the sea especially in the warmer parts of the Indian and Pacific Oceans. They feed upon fishes and are mostly of moderate size but some species become eight or ten feet long and four inches broad.

Sea snipe: S e a   s n i p e " A sandpiper  as the knot and dunlin.

Sea snipe: S e a   s n i p e " The bellows fish.

Sea spider: S e a   s p i d e r " Any maioid crab; a spider crab. See Maioid  and Spider crab under Spider.

Sea spider: S e a   s p i d e r " Any pycnogonid.

Sea squirt: S e a   s q u i r t " An ascidian. See Illust. under Tunicata.

Sea star: S e a   s t a r " A starfish  or brittle star.

Sea surgeon: S e a   s u r g e o n " A surgeon fish.

Sea swallow: S e a   s w a l l o w " The common tern.

Sea swallow: S e a   s w a l l o w " The storm petrel.

Sea swallow: S e a   s w a l l o w " The gannet.

Sea swallow: S e a   s w a l l o w " See Cornish chough  under Chough.

Sea tang: S e a   t a n g " A kind of seaweed; tang; tangle.

Sea term: S e a   t e r m " A term used specifically by seamen; a nautical word or phrase.

Sea thief: S e a   t h i e f " A pirate.

Sea thongs: S e a   t h o n g s " A kind of blackish seaweed (Himanthalia lorea) found on the northern coasts of the Atlantic. It has a thonglike forking process rising from a top-shaped base.

Sea titling: S e a   t i t l i n g " The rock pipit.

Sea toad: S e a   t o a d " A sculpin.

Sea toad: S e a   t o a d " A toadfish.

Sea toad: S e a   t o a d " The angler.

Sea trout: S e a   t r o u t " Any one of several species of true trouts which descend rivers and enter the sea after spawning  as the European bull trout and salmon trout and the eastern American spotted trout.

Sea trout: S e a   t r o u t " The common squeteague  and the spotted squeteague.

Sea trout: S e a   t r o u t " A California fish of the family Chiridae  especially Hexagrammus decagrammus; -- called also spotted rock trout. See Rock trout under Rock.

Sea trout: S e a   t r o u t " A California sciaenoid fish (Cynoscion nobilis); -- called also white sea bass.

Sea trumpet: S e a   t r u m p e t " A great blackish seaweed of the Southern Ocean  having a hollow and expanding stem and a pinnate frond sometimes twenty feet long.

Sea trumpet: S e a   t r u m p e t " Any large marine univalve shell of the genus Triton. See Triton.

Sea turn: S e a   t u r n " A breeze  gale or mist from the sea.

Sea turtle: S e a   t u r t l e " Any one of several very large species of chelonians having the feet converted into paddles  as the green turtle hawkbill loggerhead and leatherback. They inhabit all warm seas.

Sea turtle: S e a   t u r t l e " The sea pigeon  or guillemot.

Sea unicorn: S e a   u n i c o r n " The narwhal.

Sea urchin: S e a   u r c h i n " Any one of numerous species of echinoderms of the order Echinoidea.

Sea wall: S e a   w a l l " A wall  or embankment to resist encroachments of the sea.

Sea whip: S e a   w h i p " A gorgonian having a simple stem.

Sea widgeon: S e a   w i d g e o n " The scaup duck.

Sea widgeon: S e a   w i d g e o n " The pintail duck.

Sea willow: S e a   w i l l o w " A gorgonian coral with long flexible branches.

Sea wing: S e a   w i n g " A wing shell (Avicula).

Sea withwind: S e a   w i t h w i n d " A kind of bindweed (Convolvulus Soldanella) growing on the seacoast of Europe.

Sea wolf: S e a   w o l f " The wolf fish.

Sea wolf: S e a   w o l f " The European sea perch.

Sea wolf: S e a   w o l f " The sea elephant.

Sea wolf: S e a   w o l f " A sea lion.

Sea wood louse: S e a   w o o d   l o u s e " A sea slater.

Sea woodcock: S e a   w o o d c o c k " The bar-tailed godwit.

Sea wormwood: S e a   w o r m w o o d " A European species of wormwood (Artemisia maritima) growing by the sea.

Sea wrack: S e a   w r a c k " See Wrack.

Sea-bar: S e a - b a r "n. A tern.

Sea-blubber: S e a - b l u b b e r "n. A jellyfish.
