Silvas: S i l v a s "pl. "of Silva

Silvas: S i l v a s "n. pl. Alt. of Selvas

Silvate: S i l v a t e "n. Same as Sylvate.

Silver: S i l v e r "n. A soft white metallic element  sonorous ductile very malleable and capable of a high degree of polish. It is found native and also combined with sulphur arsenic antimony chlorine etc. in the minerals argentite proustite

Silver: S i l v e r "n. Coin made of silver; silver money.

Silver: S i l v e r "n. Anything having the luster or appearance of silver.

Silver: S i l v e r "n. The color of silver.

Silver: S i l v e r "a. Of or pertaining to silver; made of silver; as  silver leaf; a silver cup.

Silver: S i l v e r "a. Resembling silver.

Silver: S i l v e r "a. Bright; resplendent; white.

Silver: S i l v e r "a. Precious; costly.

Silver: S i l v e r "a. Giving a clear  ringing sound soft and clear.

Silver: S i l v e r "a. Sweet; gentle; peaceful.

Silver: S i l v e r "v. t. To cover with silver; to give a silvery appearance to by applying a metal of a silvery color; as  to silver a pin; to silver a glass mirror plate with an amalgam of tin and mercury.

Silver: S i l v e r "v. t. To polish like silver; to impart a brightness to  like that of silver.

Silver: S i l v e r "v. t. To make hoary  or white like silver.

Silver: S i l v e r "v. i. To acquire a silvery color.

Silver-gray: S i l v e r - g r a y "a. Having a gray color with a silvery luster; as  silver-gray hair.

Silverback: S i l v e r b a c k "n. The knot.

Silverberry: S i l v e r b e r r y "n. A tree or shrub (Elaeagnus argentea) with silvery foliage and fruit.

Silverbill: S i l v e r b i l l "n. An Old World finch of the genus Minia  as the M. Malabarica of India and M. cantans of Africa.

Silverboom: S i l v e r b o o m "n. See Leucadendron.

Silvered: S i l v e r e d "imp. & p. p. of Silver

Silverfin: S i l v e r f i n "n. A small North American fresh-water cyprinoid fish (Notropis Whipplei).

Silverfish: S i l v e r f i s h "n. The tarpum.

Silverfish: S i l v e r f i s h "n. A white variety of the goldfish.

Silveriness: S i l v e r i n e s s "n. The state of being silvery.

Silvering: S i l v e r i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Silver

Silvering: S i l v e r i n g "n. The art or process of covering metals  wood paper glass etc. with a thin film of metallic silver or a substance resembling silver; also the firm do laid on; as the silvering of a glass speculum.

Silverize: S i l v e r i z e "v. t. To cover with silver.

Silverized: S i l v e r i z e d "imp. & p. p. of Silverize

Silverizing: S i l v e r i z i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Silverize

Silverless: S i l v e r l e s s "a. Having no silcver; hence  without money; impecunious.

Silverling: S i l v e r l i n g "n. A small silver coin.

Silverly: S i l v e r l y "adv. Like silver in appearance or in sound.

Silvern: S i l v e r n "a. Made of silver.

Silversides: S i l v e r s i d e s "n. Any one of several species of small fishes of the family Atherinidae  having a silvery stripe along each side of the body. The common species of the American coast (Menidia notata) is very abundant. Called also silverside sand smelt friar tailor and tinker.

Silversmith: S i l v e r s m i t h "n. One whose occupation is to manufacture utensils  ornaments etc. of silver; a worker in silver.

Silverspot: S i l v e r s p o t "n. Any one of numerous species of butterflies of the genus Argynnis and allied genera  having silvery spots on the under side of the wings. See Illust. under Aphrodite.

Silverware: S i l v e r w a r e "n. Dishes  vases ornaments and utensils of various sorts made of silver.

Silverweed: S i l v e r w e e d "n. A perennial rosaceous herb (Potentilla Anserina) having the leaves silvery white beneath.

Silvery: S i l v e r y "a. Resembling  or having the luster of silver; grayish white and lustrous; of a mild luster; bright.

Silvery: S i l v e r y "a. Besprinkled or covered with silver.

Silvery: S i l v e r y "a. Having the clear  musical tone of silver; soft and clear in sound; as silvery voices; a silvery laugh.

Silviculture: S i l v i c u l t u r e "n. See Sylviculture.

Sima: S i m a "n. A cyma.

Simagre: S i m a g r e "n. A grimace.

Simar: S i m a r "n. A woman's long dress or robe; also light covering; a scarf.

Simarre: S i m a r r e " See Simar.

Simblot: S i m b l o t "n. The harness of a drawloom.

Simia: S i m i a "n. A Linnaean genus of Quadrumana which included the types of numerous modern genera. By modern writers it is usually restricted to the genus which includes the orang-outang.

Simial: S i m i a l "a. Simian; apelike.

Simian: S i m i a n "a. Of or pertaining to the family Simiadae  which in its widest sense includes all the Old World apes and monkeys; also apelike.

Simian: S i m i a n "n. Any Old World monkey or ape.

Similar: S i m i l a r "a. Exactly corresponding; resembling in all respects; precisely like.

Similar: S i m i l a r "a. Nearly corresponding; resembling in many respects; somewhat like; having a general likeness.

Similar: S i m i l a r "a. Homogenous; uniform.

Similar: S i m i l a r "n. That which is similar to  or resembles something else as in quality form etc.

Similarity: S i m i l a r i t y "n. The quality or state of being similar; likeness; resemblance; as  a similarity of features.

Similarly: S i m i l a r l y "adv. In a similar manner.

Similary: S i m i l a r y "a. Similar.

Similative: S i m i l a t i v e "a. Implying or indicating likeness or resemblance.

Simile: S i m i l e "n. A word or phrase by which anything is likened  in one or more of its aspects to something else; a similitude; a poetical or imaginative comparison.

Similes: S i m i l e s "pl. "of Simile

Similiter: S i m i l i t e r "n. The technical name of the form by which either party  in pleading accepts the issue tendered by his opponent; -- called sometimes a joinder in issue.

Similitude: S i m i l i t u d e "n. The quality or state of being similar or like; resemblance; likeness; similarity; as  similitude of substance.

Similitude: S i m i l i t u d e "n. The act of likening  or that which likens one thing to another; fanciful or imaginative comparison; a simile.

Similitude: S i m i l i t u d e "n. That which is like or similar; a representation  semblance or copy; a facsimile.

Similitudinary: S i m i l i t u d i n a r y "a. Involving or expressing similitude.

Similize: S i m i l i z e "v. t. To liken; to compare; as  to similize a person thing or act.

Similor: S i m i l o r "n. An alloy of copper and zinc  resembling brass but of a golden color.

Simitar: S i m i t a r "n. See Scimiter.

Simmer: S i m m e r "v. i. To boil gently  or with a gentle hissing; to begin to boil.

Simmer: S i m m e r "v. t. To cause to boil gently; to cook in liquid heated almost or just to the boiling point.

Simmered: S i m m e r e d "imp. & p. p. of Simmer

Simmering: S i m m e r i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Simmer

Simnel: S i m n e l "n. A kind of cake made of fine flour; a cracknel.

Simnel: S i m n e l "n. A kind of rich plum cake  eaten especially on Mid-Lent Sunday.

Simoniac: S i m o n i a c "n. One who practices simony  or who buys or sells preferment in the church.

Simoniacal: S i m o n i a c a l "a. Of or pertaining to simony; guilty of simony; consisting of simony.

Simonial: S i m o n i a l "a. Simoniacal.

Simonian: S i m o n i a n "n. One of the followers of Simon Magus; also  an adherent of certain heretical sects in the early Christian church.

Simonious: S i m o n i o u s "a. Simoniacal.

Simonist: S i m o n i s t "n. One who practices simony.

Simony: S i m o n y "n. The crime of buying or selling ecclesiastical preferment; the corrupt presentation of any one to an ecclesiastical benefice for money or reward.

Simoom: S i m o o m "n. Alt. of Simoon

Simoon: S i m o o n "n. A hot  dry suffocating dust-laden wind that blows occasionally in Arabia Syria and neighboring countries generated by the extreme heat of the parched deserts or sandy plains.

Simous: S i m o u s "a. Having a very flat or snub nose  with the end turned up.

Simpai: S i m p a i "n. A long-tailed monkey (Semnopitchecus melalophus) native of Sumatra. It has a crest of black hair. The forehead and cheeks are fawn color  the upper parts tawny and red the under parts white. Called also black-crested monkey and sinpae.

Simper: S i m p e r "v. i. To smile in a silly  affected or conceited manner.

Simper: S i m p e r "v. i. To glimmer; to twinkle.

Simper: S i m p e r "n. A constrained  self-conscious smile; an affected silly smile; a smirk.

Simpered: S i m p e r e d "imp. & p. p. of Simper

Simperer: S i m p e r e r "n. One who simpers.

Simpering: S i m p e r i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Simper

Simpering: S i m p e r i n g " a. &. n. from Simper  v.

Simperingly: S i m p e r i n g l y "adv. In a simpering manner.

Simple: S i m p l e "a. Single; not complex; not infolded or entangled; uncombined; not compounded; not blended with something else; not complicated; as  a simple substance; a simple idea; a simple sound; a simple machine; a simple problem; simple tasks.

Simple: S i m p l e "a. Plain; unadorned; as  simple dress.

Simple: S i m p l e "a. Mere; not other than; being only.

Simple: S i m p l e "a. Not given to artifice  stratagem or duplicity; undesigning; sincere; true.

Simple: S i m p l e "a. Artless in manner; unaffected; unconstrained; natural; inartificial;; straightforward.

Simple: S i m p l e "a. Direct; clear; intelligible; not abstruse or enigmatical; as  a simple statement; simple language.

Simple: S i m p l e "a. Weak in intellect; not wise or sagacious; of but moderate understanding or attainments; hence  foolish; silly.

Simple: S i m p l e "a. Not luxurious; without much variety; plain; as  a simple diet; a simple way of living.

Simple: S i m p l e "a. Humble; lowly; undistinguished.

Simple: S i m p l e "a. Without subdivisions; entire; as  a simple stem; a simple leaf.

Simple: S i m p l e "a. Not capable of being decomposed into anything more simple or ultimate by any means at present known; elementary; thus  atoms are regarded as simple bodies. Cf. Ultimate a.

Simple: S i m p l e "a. Homogenous.

Simple: S i m p l e "a. Consisting of a single individual or zooid; as  a simple ascidian; -- opposed to compound.

Simple: S i m p l e "a. Something not mixed or compounded.

Simple: S i m p l e "a. A medicinal plant; -- so called because each vegetable was supposed to possess its particular virtue  and therefore to constitute a simple remedy.

Simple: S i m p l e "a. A drawloom.

Simple: S i m p l e "a. A part of the apparatus for raising the heddles of a drawloom.

Simple: S i m p l e "a. A feast which is not a double or a semidouble.

Simple: S i m p l e "v. i. To gather simples  or medicinal plants.

Simple-hearted: S i m p l e - h e a r t e d "a. Sincere; inguenuous; guileless.

Simple-minded: S i m p l e - m i n d e d "a. Artless; guileless; simple-hearted; undesigning; unsuspecting; devoid of duplicity.

Simpleness: S i m p l e n e s s "n. The quality or state of being simple; simplicity.

Simpler: S i m p l e r "n. One who collects simples  or medicinal plants; a herbalist; a simplist.

Simpless: S i m p l e s s "n. Simplicity; silliness.

Simpleton: S i m p l e t o n "n. A person of weak intellect; a silly person.

Simplician: S i m p l i c i a n "n. One who is simple.

Simplicity: S i m p l i c i t y "n. The quality or state of being simple  unmixed or uncompounded; as the simplicity of metals or of earths.

Simplicity: S i m p l i c i t y "n. The quality or state of being not complex  or of consisting of few parts; as the simplicity of a machine.

Simplicity: S i m p l i c i t y "n. Artlessness of mind; freedom from cunning or duplicity; lack of acuteness and sagacity.

Simplicity: S i m p l i c i t y "n. Freedom from artificial ornament  pretentious style or luxury; plainness; as simplicity of dress of style or of language; simplicity of diet; simplicity of life.

Simplicity: S i m p l i c i t y "n. Freedom from subtlety or abstruseness; clearness; as  the simplicity of a doctrine; the simplicity of an explanation or a demonstration.

Simplicity: S i m p l i c i t y "n. Weakness of intellect; silliness; folly.

Simplification: S i m p l i f i c a t i o n "n. The act of simplifying.

Simplified: S i m p l i f i e d "imp. & p. p. of Simplify

Simplify: S i m p l i f y "v. t. To make simple; to make less complex; to make clear by giving the explanation for; to show an easier or shorter process for doing or making.

Simplifying: S i m p l i f y i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Simplify

Simplist: S i m p l i s t "n. One skilled in simples  or medicinal plants; a simpler.

Simplistic: S i m p l i s t i c "a. Of or pertaining to simples  or a simplist.

Simplity: S i m p l i t y "n. Simplicity.

Simploce: S i m p l o c e "n. See Symploce.

Simply: S i m p l y "adv. In a simple manner or state; considered in or by itself; without addition; along; merely; solely; barely.

Simply: S i m p l y "adv. Plainly; without art or subtlety.

Simply: S i m p l y "adv. Weakly; foolishly.

Simulacher: S i m u l a c h e r "n. Alt. of Simulachre

Simulachre: S i m u l a c h r e "n. See Simulacrum.

Simulacra: S i m u l a c r a "pl. "of Simulacrum

Simulacrum: S i m u l a c r u m "n. A likeness; a semblance; a mock appearance; a sham; -- now usually in a derogatory sense.

Simular: S i m u l a r "n. One who pretends to be what he is not; one who  or that which simulates or counterfeits something; a pretender.

Simular: S i m u l a r "a. False; specious; counterfeit.

Simulate: S i m u l a t e "a. Feigned; pretended.

Simulate: S i m u l a t e "v. t. To assume the mere appearance of  without the reality; to assume the signs or indications of falsely; to counterfeit; to feign.

Simulated: S i m u l a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Simulate

Simulating: S i m u l a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Simulate

Simulation: S i m u l a t i o n "n. The act of simulating  or assuming an appearance which is feigned or not true; -- distinguished from dissimulation which disguises or conceals what is true.

Simulator: S i m u l a t o r "n. One who simulates  or feigns.

Simulatory: S i m u l a t o r y "a. Simulated  or capable of being simulated.

Simultaneity: S i m u l t a n e i t y "n. The quality or state of being simultaneous; simultaneousness.

Simultaneous: S i m u l t a n e o u s "a. Existing  happening or done at the same time; as simultaneous events.

Simulty: S i m u l t y "n. Private grudge or quarrel; as  domestic simulties.

Sin: S i n "adv. prep.  & conj. Old form of Since.

Sin: S i n "n. Transgression of the law of God; disobedience of the divine command; any violation of God's will  either in purpose or conduct; moral deficiency in the character; iniquity; as sins of omission and sins of commission.

Sin: S i n "n. An offense  in general; a violation of propriety; a misdemeanor; as a sin against good manners.

Sin: S i n "n. A sin offering; a sacrifice for sin.

Sin: S i n "n. An embodiment of sin; a very wicked person.

Sin: S i n "n. To depart voluntarily from the path of duty prescribed by God to man; to violate the divine law in any particular  by actual transgression or by the neglect or nonobservance of its injunctions; to violate any known rule of duty; -- often followed by against.

Sin: S i n "n. To violate human rights  law or propriety; to commit an offense; to trespass; to transgress.

Sinaic: S i n a i c "a. Alt. of Sinaitic

Sinaitic: S i n a i t i c "a. Of or pertaining to Mount Sinai; given or made at Mount Sinai; as  the Sinaitic law.

Sinalbin: S i n a l b i n "n. A glucoside found in the seeds of white mustard (Brassica alba  formerly Sinapis alba) and extracted as a white crystalline substance.

Sinamine: S i n a m i n e "n. A bitter white crystalline nitrogenous substance  obtained indirectly from oil of mustard and ammonia; -- called also allyl melamine.

Sinapate: S i n a p a t e "n. A salt of sinapic acid.

Sinapic: S i n a p i c "a. Of or pertaining to sinapine; specifically  designating an acid (C11H12O5) related to gallic acid and obtained by the decomposition of sinapine as a white crystalline substance.

Sinapine: S i n a p i n e "n. An alkaloid occuring in the seeds of mustard. It is extracted  in combination with sulphocyanic acid as a white crystalline substance having a hot bitter taste. When sinapine is isolated it is unstable and undergoes decomposition.

Sinapis: S i n a p i s "n. A disused generic name for mustard; -- now called Brassica.

Sinapisin: S i n a p i s i n "n. A substance extracted from mustard seed and probably identical with sinalbin.

Sinapism: S i n a p i s m "n. A plaster or poultice composed principally of powdered mustard seed  or containing the volatile oil of mustard seed. It is a powerful irritant.

Sinapoleic: S i n a p o l e i c "a. Of or pertaining to mustard oil; specifically  designating an acid of the oleic acid series said to occur in mistard oil.

Sinapoline: S i n a p o l i n e "n. A nitrogenous base  CO.(NH.C3H5)2 related to urea extracted from mustard oil and also produced artifically as a white crystalline substance; -- called also diallyl urea.

Sincaline: S i n c a l i n e "n. Choline.

Since: S i n c e "adv. From a definite past time until now; as  he went a month ago and I have not seen him since.

Since: S i n c e "adv. In the time past  counting backward from the present; before this or now; ago.

Since: S i n c e "adv. When or that.

Since: S i n c e "prep. From the time of; in or during the time subsequent to; subsequently to; after; -- usually with a past event or time for the object.

Since: S i n c e "conj. Seeing that; because; considering; -- formerly followed by that.

Sincere: S i n c e r e "superl. Pure; unmixed; unadulterated.

Sincere: S i n c e r e "superl. Whole; perfect; unhurt; uninjured.

Sincere: S i n c e r e "superl. Being in reality what it appears to be; having a character which corresponds with the appearance; not falsely assumed; genuine; true; real; as  a sincere desire for knowledge; a sincere contempt for meanness.

Sincere: S i n c e r e "superl. Honest; free from hypocrisy or dissimulation; as  a sincere friend; a sincere person.

Sincerely: S i n c e r e l y "adv. In a sincere manner.

Sincerely: S i n c e r e l y "adv. Purely; without alloy.

Sincerely: S i n c e r e l y "adv. Honestly; unfeignedly; without dissimulation; as  to speak one's mind sincerely; to love virtue sincerely.

Sincereness: S i n c e r e n e s s "n. Same as Sincerity.

Sincerity: S i n c e r i t y "n. The quality or state of being sincere; honesty of mind or intention; freedom from simulation  hypocrisy disguise or false pretense; sincereness.

Sinch: S i n c h "n. A saddle girth made of leather  canvas woven horsehair or woven grass.

Sinch: S i n c h "v. t. To gird with a sinch; to tighten the sinch or girth of (a saddle); as  to sinch up a sadle.

Sincipital: S i n c i p i t a l "a. Of or pertaining to the sinciput; being in the region of the sinciput.

Sinciput: S i n c i p u t "n. The fore part of the head.

Sinciput: S i n c i p u t "n. The part of the head of a bird between the base of the bill and the vertex.

Sindon: S i n d o n "n. A wrapper.

Sindon: S i n d o n "n. A small rag or pledget introduced into the hole in the cranium made by a trephine.

Sine: S i n e "n. The length of a perpendicular drawn from one extremity of an arc of a circle to the diameter drawn through the other extremity.

Sine: S i n e "n. The perpendicular itself. See Sine of angle  below.

Sine: S i n e "prep. Without.

Sinecural: S i n e c u r a l "a. Of or pertaining to a sinecure; being in the nature of a sinecure.

Sinecure: S i n e c u r e "n. An ecclesiastical benefice without the care of souls.

Sinecure: S i n e c u r e "n. Any office or position which requires or involves little or no responsibility  labor or active service.

Sinecure: S i n e c u r e "v. t. To put or place in a sinecure.

Sinecurism: S i n e c u r i s m "n. The state of having a sinecure.

Sinecurist: S i n e c u r i s t "n. One who has a sinecure.

Sinew: S i n e w "n. A tendon or tendonous tissue. See Tendon.

Sinew: S i n e w "n. Muscle; nerve.

Sinew: S i n e w "n. Fig.: That which supplies strength or power.

Sinew: S i n e w "v. t. To knit together  or make strong with or as with sinews.

Sinew-shrunk: S i n e w - s h r u n k "a. Having the sinews under the belly shrunk by excessive fatigue.

Sinewed: S i n e w e d "imp. & p. p. of Sinew

Sinewed: S i n e w e d "a. Furnished with sinews; as  a strong-sinewed youth.

Sinewed: S i n e w e d "a. Fig.: Equipped; strengthened.

Sinewiness: S i n e w i n e s s "n. Quality of being sinewy.

Sinewing: S i n e w i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Sinew

Sinewish: S i n e w i s h "a. Sinewy.

Sinewless: S i n e w l e s s "a. Having no sinews; hence  having no strength or vigor.

Sinewous: S i n e w o u s "a. Sinewy.

Sinewy: S i n e w y "a. Pertaining to  consisting of or resembling a sinew or sinews.

Sinewy: S i n e w y "a. Well braced with  or as if with sinews; nervous; vigorous; strong; firm; tough; as the sinewy Ajax.

Sinful: S i n f u l "a. Tainted with  or full of sin; wicked; iniquitous; criminal; unholy; as sinful men; sinful thoughts.

Sing: S i n g "v. i. To utter sounds with musical inflections or melodious modulations of voice  as fancy may dictate or according to the notes of a song or tune or of a given part (as alto tenor etc.) in a chorus or concerted piece.

Sing: S i n g "v. i. To utter sweet melodious sounds  as birds do.

Sing: S i n g "v. i. To make a small  shrill sound; as the air sings in passing through a crevice.

Sing: S i n g "v. i. To tell or relate something in numbers or verse; to celebrate something in poetry.

Sing: S i n g "v. i. Ti cry out; to complain.

Sing: S i n g "v. t. To utter with musical infections or modulations of voice.

Sing: S i n g "v. t. To celebrate is song; to give praises to in verse; to relate or rehearse in numbers  verse or poetry.

Sing: S i n g "v. t. To influence by singing; to lull by singing; as  to sing a child to sleep.

Sing: S i n g "v. t. To accompany  or attend on with singing.

Sing-sing: S i n g - s i n g "n. The kob.

Singe: S i n g e "v. t. To burn slightly or superficially; to burn the surface of; to burn the ends or outside of; as  to singe the hair or the skin.

Singe: S i n g e "v. t. To remove the nap of (cloth)  by passing it rapidly over a red-hot bar or over a flame preliminary to dyeing it.

Singe: S i n g e "v. t. To remove the hair or down from (a plucked chicken or the like) by passing it over a flame.

Singe: S i n g e "n. A burning of the surface; a slight burn.

Singed: S i n g e d "imp. & p. p. of Singe

Singeing: S i n g e i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Singe

Singer: S i n g e r "n. One who  or that which singes.

Singer: S i n g e r "n. One employed to singe cloth.

Singer: S i n g e r "n. A machine for singeing cloth.

Singer: S i n g e r "n. One who sings; especially  one whose profession is to sing.

Singeress: S i n g e r e s s "n. A songstress.

Singhalese: S i n g h a l e s e "n. & a. Same as Cingalese.

Singing: S i n g i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Sing

Singing: S i n g i n g " a. & n. from Sing  v.

Singingly: S i n g i n g l y "adv. With sounds like singing; with a kind of tune; in a singing tone.

Single: S i n g l e "a. One only  as distinguished from more than one; consisting of one alone; individual; separate; as a single star.

Single: S i n g l e "a. Alone; having no companion.

Single: S i n g l e "a. Hence  unmarried; as a single man or woman.

Single: S i n g l e "a. Not doubled  twisted together or combined with others; as a single thread; a single strand of a rope.

Single: S i n g l e "a. Performed by one person  or one on each side; as a single combat.

Single: S i n g l e "a. Uncompounded; pure; unmixed.

Single: S i n g l e "a. Not deceitful or artful; honest; sincere.

Single: S i n g l e "a. Simple; not wise; weak; silly.

Single: S i n g l e "v. t. To select  as an individual person or thing from among a number; to choose out from others; to separate.

Single: S i n g l e "v. t. To sequester; to withdraw; to retire.

Single: S i n g l e "v. t. To take alone  or one by one.

Single: S i n g l e "v. i. To take the irrregular gait called single-foot;- said of a horse. See Single-foot.

Single: S i n g l e "n. A unit; one; as  to score a single.

Single: S i n g l e "n. The reeled filaments of silk  twisted without doubling to give them firmness.

Single: S i n g l e "n. A handful of gleaned grain.

Single: S i n g l e "n. A game with but one player on each side; -- usually in the plural.

Single: S i n g l e "n. A hit by a batter which enables him to reach first base only.

Single-acting: S i n g l e - a c t i n g "a. Having simplicity of action; especially (Mach.)  acting or exerting force during strokes in one direction only; -- said of a reciprocating engine pump etc.

Single-breasted: S i n g l e - b r e a s t e d "a. Lapping over the breast only far enough to permit of buttoning  and having buttons on one edge only; as a single-breasted coast.

Single-foot: S i n g l e - f o o t "n. An irregular gait of a horse; -- called also single-footed pace. See Single  v. i.

Single-handed: S i n g l e - h a n d e d "a. Having but one hand  or one workman; also alone; unassisted.

Single-hearted: S i n g l e - h e a r t e d "a. Having an honest heart; free from duplicity.

Single-minded: S i n g l e - m i n d e d "a. Having a single purpose; hence  artless; guileless; single-hearted.

Singled: S i n g l e d "imp. & p. p. of Single

Singleness: S i n g l e n e s s "n. The quality or state of being single  or separate from all others; the opposite of doubleness complication or multiplicity.

Singleness: S i n g l e n e s s "n. Freedom from duplicity  or secondary and selfish ends; purity of mind or purpose; simplicity; sincerity; as singleness of purpose; singleness of heart.

Singles: S i n g l e s "n. pl. See Single  n. 2.

Singlestick: S i n g l e s t i c k "n. In England and Scotland  a cudgel used in fencing or fighting; a backsword.

Singlestick: S i n g l e s t i c k "n. The game played with singlesticks  in which he who first brings blood from his adversary's head is pronounced victor; backsword; cudgeling.

Singlet: S i n g l e t "n. An unlined or undyed waistcoat; a single garment; -- opposed to doublet.

Singleton: S i n g l e t o n "n. In certain games at cards  as whist a single card of any suit held at the deal by a player; as to lead a singleton.

Singletree: S i n g l e t r e e "n. The pivoted or swinging bar to which the traces of a harnessed horse are fixed; a whiffletree.

Singling: S i n g l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Single

Singly: S i n g l y "adv. Individually; particularly; severally; as  to make men singly and personally good.

Singly: S i n g l y "adv. Only; by one's self; alone.

Singly: S i n g l y "adv. Without partners  companions or associates; single-handed; as to attack another singly.

Singly: S i n g l y "adv. Honestly; sincerely; simply.

Singly: S i n g l y "adv. Singularly; peculiarly.

Singsong: S i n g s o n g "n. Bad singing or poetry.

Singsong: S i n g s o n g "n. A drawling or monotonous tone  as of a badly executed song.

Singsong: S i n g s o n g "a. Drawling; monotonous.

Singsong: S i n g s o n g "v. i. To write poor poetry.

Singster: S i n g s t e r "n. A songstress.

Singular: S i n g u l a r "a. Separate or apart from others; single; distinct.

Singular: S i n g u l a r "a. Engaged in by only one on a side; single.

Singular: S i n g u l a r "a. Existing by itself; single; individual.

Singular: S i n g u l a r "a. Each; individual; as  to convey several parcels of land all and singular.

Singular: S i n g u l a r "a. Denoting one person or thing; as  the singular number; -- opposed to dual and plural.

Singular: S i n g u l a r "a. Standing by itself; out of the ordinary course; unusual; uncommon; strange; as  a singular phenomenon.

Singular: S i n g u l a r "a. Distinguished as existing in a very high degree; rarely equaled; eminent; extraordinary; exceptional; as  a man of singular gravity or attainments.

Singular: S i n g u l a r "a. Departing from general usage or expectations; odd; whimsical; -- often implying disapproval or consure.

Singular: S i n g u l a r "a. Being alone; belonging to  or being that of which there is but one; unique.

Singular: S i n g u l a r "n. An individual instance; a particular.

Singular: S i n g u l a r "n. The singular number  or the number denoting one person or thing; a word in the singular number.

Singularist: S i n g u l a r i s t "n. One who affects singularity.

Singularities: S i n g u l a r i t i e s "pl. "of Singularity

Singularity: S i n g u l a r i t y "n. The quality or state of being singular; some character or quality of a thing by which it is distinguished from all  or from most others; peculiarity.

Singularity: S i n g u l a r i t y "n. Anything singular  rare or curious.

Singularity: S i n g u l a r i t y "n. Possession of a particular or exclusive privilege  prerogative or distinction.

Singularity: S i n g u l a r i t y "n. Celibacy.

Singularize: S i n g u l a r i z e "v. t. To make singular or single; to distinguish.

Singularly: S i n g u l a r l y "adv. In a singular manner; in a manner  or to a degree not common to others; extraordinarily; as to be singularly exact in one's statements; singularly considerate of others.

Singularly: S i n g u l a r l y "adv. Strangely; oddly; as  to behave singularly.

Singularly: S i n g u l a r l y "adv. So as to express one  or the singular number.

Singult: S i n g u l t "n. A sigh or sobbing; also  a hiccough.

Singultous: S i n g u l t o u s "a. Relating to  or affected with hiccough.

Singultus: S i n g u l t u s "n. Hiccough.

Siniate: S i n i a t e "a. Having the margin alternately curved inward and outward; having rounded lobes separated by rounded sinuses; sinuous; wavy.

Sinical: S i n i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to a sine; employing  or founded upon sines; as a sinical quadrant.

Sinigrin: S i n i g r i n "n. A glucoside found in the seeds of black mustard (Brassica nigra  formerly Sinapis nigra) It resembles sinalbin and consists of a potassium salt of myronic acid.

Sinister: S i n i s t e r "a. On the left hand  or the side of the left hand; left; -- opposed to dexter or right.

Sinister: S i n i s t e r "a. Unlucky; inauspicious; disastrous; injurious; evil; -- the left being usually regarded as the unlucky side; as  sinister influences.

Sinister: S i n i s t e r "a. Wrong  as springing from indirection or obliquity; perverse; dishonest; corrupt; as sinister aims.

Sinister: S i n i s t e r "a. Indicative of lurking evil or harm; boding covert danger; as  a sinister countenance.

Sinister-handed: S i n i s t e r - h a n d e d "a. Left-handed; hence  unlucky.

Sinisterly: S i n i s t e r l y "adv. In a sinister manner.

Sinistrad: S i n i s t r a d "adv. Toward the left side; sinistrally.

Sinistral: S i n i s t r a l "a. Of or pertaining to the left  inclining to the left; sinistrous; -- opposed to dextral.

Sinistral: S i n i s t r a l "a. Having the whorls of the spire revolving or rising to the left; reversed; -- said of certain spiral shells.

Sinistrality: S i n i s t r a l i t y "n. The quality or state of being sinistral.

Sinistrally: S i n i s t r a l l y "adv. Toward the left; in a sinistral manner.

Sinistrin: S i n i s t r i n "n. A mucilaginous carbohydrate  resembling achroodextrin extracted from squill as a colorless amorphous substance; -- so called because it is levorotatory.

Sinistrorsal: S i n i s t r o r s a l "a. Rising spirally from right to left (of the spectator); sinistrorse.

Sinistrorse: S i n i s t r o r s e "a. Turning to the left (of the spectator) in the ascending line; -- the opposite of dextrorse. See Dextrorse.

Sinistrous: S i n i s t r o u s "a. Being on the left side; inclined to the left; sinistral.

Sinistrous: S i n i s t r o u s "a. Wrong; absurd; perverse.

Sinistrously: S i n i s t r o u s l y "adv. In a sinistrous manner; perversely; wrongly; unluckily.

Sinistrously: S i n i s t r o u s l y "adv. With a tendency to use the left hand.

Sink: S i n k "v. i. To fall by  or as by the force of gravity; to descend lower and lower; to decline gradually; to subside; as a stone sinks in water; waves rise and sink; the sun sinks in the west.

Sink: S i n k "v. i. To enter deeply; to fall or retire beneath or below the surface; to penetrate.

Sink: S i n k "v. i. Hence  to enter so as to make an abiding impression; to enter completely.

Sink: S i n k "v. i. To be overwhelmed or depressed; to fall slowly  as so the ground from weakness or from an overburden; to fail in strength; to decline; to decay; to decrease.

Sink: S i n k "v. i. To decrease in volume  as a river; to subside; to become diminished in volume or in apparent height.

Sink: S i n k "v. t. To cause to sink; to put under water; to immerse or submerge in a fluid; as  to sink a ship.

Sink: S i n k "v. t. Figuratively: To cause to decline; to depress; to degrade; hence  to ruin irretrievably; to destroy as by drowping; as to sink one's reputation.

Sink: S i n k "v. t. To make (a depression) by digging  delving or cutting etc.; as to sink a pit or a well; to sink a die.

Sink: S i n k "v. t. To bring low; to reduce in quantity; to waste.

Sink: S i n k "v. t. To conseal and appropriate.

Sink: S i n k "v. t. To keep out of sight; to suppress; to ignore.

Sink: S i n k "v. t. To reduce or extinguish by payment; as  to sink the national debt.

Sink: S i n k "n. A drain to carry off filthy water; a jakes.

Sink: S i n k "n. A shallow box or vessel of wood  stone iron or other material connected with a drain and used for receiving filthy water etc. as in a kitchen.

Sink: S i n k "n. A hole or low place in land or rock  where waters sink and are lost; -- called also sink hole.

Sinker: S i n k e r "n. One who  or that which sinks.

Sinker: S i n k e r "n. A weight on something  as on a fish line to sink it.

Sinker: S i n k e r "n. In knitting machines  one of the thin plates blades or other devices that depress the loops upon or between the needles.

Sinking: S i n k i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Sink

Sinking: S i n k i n g " a. & n. from Sink.

Sinless: S i n l e s s "a. Free from sin.

Sinned: S i n n e d "imp. & p. p. of Sin

Sinner: S i n n e r "n. One who has sinned; especially  one who has sinned without repenting; hence a persistent and incorrigible transgressor; one condemned by the law of God.

Sinner: S i n n e r "v. i. To act as a sinner.

Sinneress: S i n n e r e s s "n. A woman who sins.

Sinnet: S i n n e t "n. See Sennit .

Sinning: S i n n i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Sin

Sinological: S i n o l o g i c a l "a. Relating to the Chinese language or literature.

Sinologist: S i n o l o g i s t "n. A sinologue.

Sinologue: S i n o l o g u e "n. A student of Chinese; one versed in the Chinese language  literature and history.

Sinology: S i n o l o g y "n. That branch of systemized knowledge which treats of the Chinese  their language literature etc.

Sinoper: S i n o p e r "n. Sinople.

Sinopia: S i n o p i a "n. Alt. of Sinopis

Sinopis: S i n o p i s "n. A red pigment made from sinopite.

Sinopite: S i n o p i t e "n. A brickred ferruginous clay used by the ancients for red paint.

Sinople: S i n o p l e "n. Ferruginous quartz  of a blood-red or brownish red color sometimes with a tinge of yellow.

Sinople: S i n o p l e "n. The tincture vert; green.

Sinque: S i n q u e "n. See Cinque.

Sinsring: S i n s r i n g "n. Same as Banxring.

Sinter: S i n t e r "n. Dross  as of iron; the scale which files from iron when hammered; -- applied as a name to various minerals.

Sinto: S i n t o " Alt. of Sintoist

Sintoc: S i n t o c "n. A kind of spice used in the East Indies  consisting of the bark of a species of Cinnamomum.

Sintoism: S i n t o i s m " Alt. of Sintoist

Sintoist: S i n t o i s t " See Shinto  etc.

Sintu: S i n t u " Alt. of Sintoist

Sinuate: S i n u a t e "v. i. To bend or curve in and out; to wind; to turn; to be sinusous.

Sinuated: S i n u a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Sinuate

Sinuated: S i n u a t e d "a. Same as Sinuate.

Sinuating: S i n u a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Sinuate

Sinuation: S i n u a t i o n "n. A winding or bending in and out.

Sinuose: S i n u o s e "a. Sinuous.

Sinuosities: S i n u o s i t i e s "pl. "of Sinuosity

Sinuosity: S i n u o s i t y "n. Quality or state of being sinuous.

Sinuosity: S i n u o s i t y "n. A bend  or a series of bends and turns; a winding or a series of windings; a wave line; a curve.

Sinuous: S i n u o u s "a. Bending in and out; of a serpentine or undulating form; winding; crooked.

Sinupalliate: S i n u p a l l i a t e "a. Having a pallial sinus. See under Sinus.

Sinus: S i n u s "pl. "of Sinus

Sinus: S i n u s "n. An opening; a hollow; a bending.

Sinus: S i n u s "n. A bay of the sea; a recess in the shore.

Sinus: S i n u s "n. A cavity; a depression.

Sinus: S i n u s "n. A cavity in a bone or other part  either closed or with a narrow opening.

Sinus: S i n u s "n. A dilated vessel or canal.

Sinus: S i n u s "n. A narrow  elongated cavity in which pus is collected; an elongated abscess with only a small orifice.

Sinus: S i n u s "n. A depression between adjoining lobes.

Sinuses: S i n u s e s "pl. "of Sinus

Sinusoid: S i n u s o i d "n. The curve whose ordinates are proportional to the sines of the abscissas  the equation of the curve being y = a sin x. It is also called the curve of sines.

Sinusoidal: S i n u s o i d a l "a. Of or pertaining to a sinusoid; like a sinusoid.

Siogoon: S i o g o o n "n. See Shogun.

Siogoonate: S i o g o o n a t e "n. See Shogunate.

Sioux: S i o u x "n. sing. & pl. See Dakotas.

Sip: S i p "v. t. To drink or imbibe in small quantities; especially  to take in with the lips in small quantities as a liquid; as to sip tea.

Sip: S i p "v. t. To draw into the mouth; to suck up; as  a bee sips nectar from the flowers.

Sip: S i p "v. t. To taste the liquor of; to drink out of.

Sip: S i p "v. i. To drink a small quantity; to take a fluid with the lips; to take a sip or sips of something.

Sip: S i p "n. The act of sipping; the taking of a liquid with the lips.

Sip: S i p "n. A small draught taken with the lips; a slight taste.

Sip: S i p "v. i. See Seep.

Sipage: S i p a g e "n. Water that seeped or oozed through a porous soil.

Sipage: S i p a g e "n. See Seepage.

Sipe: S i p e "v. i. To run or soak through fine pores and interstices; to ooze.

Siphilis: S i p h i l i s "n. Syphilis.

Siphoid: S i p h o i d "n. A siphon bottle. See under Siphon  n.

Siphon: S i p h o n "n. A device  consisting of a pipe or tube bent so as to form two branches or legs of unequal length by which a liquid can be transferred to a lower level as from one vessel to another over an intermediate elevation by the action of the pressure of the atmosphere in forcing the liquid up the shorter branch of the pipe immersed in it while the continued excess of weight of the liquid in the longer branch (when once filled) causes a continuous flow. The flow takes place only when the discharging extremity of the pipe ia lower than the higher liquid surface and when no part of the pipe is higher above the surface than the same liquid will rise by atmospheric pressure; that is about 33 feet for water and 30 inches for mercury near the sea level.

Siphon: S i p h o n "n. One of the tubes or folds of the mantle border of a bivalve or gastropod mollusk by which water is conducted into the gill cavity. See Illust. under Mya  and Lamellibranchiata.

Siphon: S i p h o n "n. The anterior prolongation of the margin of any gastropod shell for the protection of the soft siphon.

Siphon: S i p h o n "n. The tubular organ through which water is ejected from the gill cavity of a cephaloid. It serves as a locomotive organ  by guiding and confining the jet of water. Called also siphuncle. See Illust. under Loligo and Dibranchiata.

Siphon: S i p h o n "n. The siphuncle of a cephalopod shell.

Siphon: S i p h o n "n. The sucking proboscis of certain parasitic insects and crustaceans.

Siphon: S i p h o n "n. A sproutlike prolongation in front of the mouth of many gephyreans.

Siphon: S i p h o n "n. A tubular organ connected both with the esophagus and the intestine of certain sea urchins and annelids.

Siphon: S i p h o n "n. A siphon bottle.

Siphon: S i p h o n "v. t. To convey  or draw off by means of a siphon as a liquid from one vessel to another at a lower level.

Siphonage: S i p h o n a g e "n. The action of a siphon.

Siphonal: S i p h o n a l "a. Of or pertaining to a siphon; resembling a siphon.

Siphonarid: S i p h o n a r i d "n. Any one of numerous species of limpet-shaped pulmonate gastropods of the genus Siphonaria. They cling to rocks between high and low water marks and have both lunglike organs and gills.

Siphonata: S i p h o n a t a "n. pl. A tribe of bivalve mollusks in which the posterior mantle border is prolonged into two tubes or siphons. Called also Siphoniata. See Siphon  2 (a) and Quahaug.

Siphonate: S i p h o n a t e "a. Having a siphon or siphons.

Siphonate: S i p h o n a t e "a. Belonging to the Siphonata.

Siphonet: S i p h o n e t "n. One of the two dorsal tubular organs on the hinder part of the abdomen of aphids. They give exit to the honeydew. See Illust. under Aphis.

Siphonia: S i p h o n i a "n. A former name for a euphorbiaceous genus (Hevea) of South American trees  the principal source of caoutchouc.

Siphonia: S i p h o n i a "pl. "of Siphonium

Siphoniata: S i p h o n i a t a "n. pl. Same as Siphonata.

Siphonic: S i p h o n i c "a. Of or pertaining to a siphon.

Siphonifer: S i p h o n i f e r "n. Any cephalopod having a siphonate shell.

Siphoniferous: S i p h o n i f e r o u s "a. Siphon-bearing  as the shell of the nautilus and other cephalopods.

Siphonium: S i p h o n i u m "n. A bony tube which  in some birds connects the tympanium with the air chambers of the articular piece of the mandible.

Siphonobranchiata: S i p h o n o b r a n c h i a t a "n. pl. A tribe of gastropods having the mantle border  on one or both sides prolonged in the form of a spout through which water enters the gill cavity. The shell itself is not always siphonostomatous in this group.

Siphonobranchiate: S i p h o n o b r a n c h i a t e "a. Having a siphon  or siphons to convey water to the gills; belonging or pertaining to the Siphonobranchiata.

Siphonobranchiate: S i p h o n o b r a n c h i a t e "n. One of the Siphonobranchiata.

Siphonoglyphe: S i p h o n o g l y p h e "n. A gonidium.

Siphonophora: S i p h o n o p h o r a "n. pl. An order of pelagic Hydrozoa including species which form complex free-swimming communities composed of numerous zooids of various kinds  some of which act as floats or as swimming organs others as feeding or nutritive zooids and others as reproductive zooids. See Illust. under Physallia and Porpita.

Siphonophoran: S i p h o n o p h o r a n "a. Belonging to the Siphonophora.

Siphonophoran: S i p h o n o p h o r a n "n. One of the Siphonophora.

Siphonophore: S i p h o n o p h o r e "n. One of the Siphonophora.

Siphonopoda: S i p h o n o p o d a "n. pl. A division of Scaphopoda including those in which the foot terminates in a circular disk.

Siphonostomata: S i p h o n o s t o m a t a "n. pl. A tribe of parasitic copepod Crustacea including a large number of species that are parasites of fishes  as the lerneans. They have a mouth adapted to suck blood.

Siphonostomata: S i p h o n o s t o m a t a "n. pl. An artificial division of gastropods including those that have siphonostomatous shells.

Siphonostomatous: S i p h o n o s t o m a t o u s "a. Having the front edge of the aperture of the shell prolonged in the shape of a channel for the protection of the siphon; -- said of certain gastropods.

Siphonostomatous: S i p h o n o s t o m a t o u s "a. Pertaining to the Siphonostomata.

Siphonostome: S i p h o n o s t o m e "n. Any parasitic entomostracan of the tribe Siphonostomata.

Siphonostome: S i p h o n o s t o m e "n. A siphonostomatous shell.

Siphorhinal: S i p h o r h i n a l "a. Having tubular nostrils  as the petrels.

Siphorhinian: S i p h o r h i n i a n "n. A siphorhinal bird.

Siphuncle: S i p h u n c l e "n. The tube which runs through the partitions of chambered cephalopod shells.

Siphuncled: S i p h u n c l e d "a. Having a siphuncle; siphunculated.

Siphuncular: S i p h u n c u l a r "a. Of or pertaining to the siphuncle.

Siphunculated: S i p h u n c u l a t e d "a. Having a siphuncle.

Sipid: S i p i d "a. Having a taste or flavorl savory; sapid.

Sipped: S i p p e d "imp. & p. p. of Sip

Sipper: S i p p e r "n. One whi sips.

Sippet: S i p p e t "n. A small sop; a small  thin piece of toasted bread soaked in milk broth or the like; a small piece of toasted or fried bread cut into some special shape and used for garnishing.

Sipping: S i p p i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Sip

Sipple: S i p p l e "v. i. To sip often.

Sippling: S i p p l i n g "a. Sipping often.

Sipunculacea: S i p u n c u l a c e a "n. pl. A suborder of Gephyrea  including those which have the body unarmed and the intestine opening anteriorly.

Sipunculoid: S i p u n c u l o i d "a. Pertaining to the Sipunculoidea.

Sipunculoid: S i p u n c u l o i d "n. One of the Sipunculoidea.

Sipunculoidea: S i p u n c u l o i d e a "n. pl. Same as Gephyrea.

Sipunculoidea: S i p u n c u l o i d e a "n. pl. In a restricted sense  same as Sipunculacea.

Sipy: S i p y "a. Oozy; -- applied to land under cultivation that is not well drained.

Sir: S i r "n. A man of social authority and dignity; a lord; a master; a gentleman; -- in this sense usually spelled sire.

Sir: S i r "n. A title prefixed to the Christian name of a knight or a baronet.

Sir: S i r "n. An English rendering of the LAtin Dominus  the academical title of a bachelor of arts; -- formerly colloquially and sometimes contemptuously applied to the clergy.

Sir: S i r "n. A respectful title  used in addressing a man without being prefixed to his name; -- used especially in speaking to elders or superiors; sometimes also used in the way of emphatic formality.

Siraskier: S i r a s k i e r "n. See Seraskier.

Siraskierate: S i r a s k i e r a t e "n. See Seraskierate.

Sirbonian: S i r b o n i a n "a. See Serbonian.

Sircar: S i r c a r "n. A Hindoo clerk or accountant.

Sircar: S i r c a r "n. A district or province; a circar.

Sircar: S i r c a r "n. The government; the supreme authority of the state.

Sirdar: S i r d a r "n. A native chief in Hindostan; a headman.

Sire: S i r e "n. A lord  master or other person in authority. See Sir.

Sire: S i r e "n. A tittle of respect formerly used in speaking to elders and superiors  but now only in addressing a sovereign.

Sire: S i r e "n. A father; the head of a family; the husband.

Sire: S i r e "n. A creator; a maker; an author; an originator.

Sire: S i r e "n. The male parent of a beast; -- applied especially to horses; as  the horse had a good sire.

Sire: S i r e "v. t. To beget; to procreate; -- used of beasts  and especially of stallions.

Sired: S i r e d "imp. & p. p. of Sire

Siredon: S i r e d o n "n. The larval form of any salamander while it still has external gills; especially  one of those which like the axolotl (Amblystoma Mexicanum) sometimes lay eggs while in this larval state but which under more favorable conditions lose their gills and become normal salamanders. See also Axolotl.

Siren: S i r e n "n. One of three sea nymphs  -- or according to some writers of two -- said to frequent an island near the coast of Italy and to sing with such sweetness that they lured mariners to destruction.

Siren: S i r e n "n. An enticing  dangerous woman.

Siren: S i r e n "n. Something which is insidious or deceptive.

Siren: S i r e n "n. A mermaid.

Siren: S i r e n "n. Any long  slender amphibian of the genus Siren or family Sirenidae destitute of hind legs and pelvis and having permanent external gills as well as lungs. They inhabit the swamps lagoons and ditches of the Southern United States. The more common species (Siren lacertina) is dull lead-gray in color and becames two feet long.

Siren: S i r e n "n. An instrument for producing musical tones and for ascertaining the number of sound waves or vibrations per second which produce a note of a given pitch. The sounds are produced by a perforated rotating disk or disks. A form with two disks operated by steam or highly compressed air is used sounding an alarm to vessels in fog.

Siren: S i r e n "a. Of or pertaining to a siren; bewitching  like a siren; fascinating; alluring; as a siren song.

Sirene: S i r e n e "n. See Siren  6.

Sirenia: S i r e n i a "n. pl. An order of large aquatic herbivorous mammals  including the manatee dugong rytina and several fossil genera.

Sirenian: S i r e n i a n "n. Any species of Sirenia.

Sirenical: S i r e n i c a l "a. Like  or appropriate to a siren; fascinating; deceptive.

Sirenize: S i r e n i z e "v. i. To use the enticements of a siren; to act as a siren; to fascinate.

Siriasis: S i r i a s i s "n. A sunstroke.

Siriasis: S i r i a s i s "n. The act of exposing to a sun bath. [Obs.] Cf. Insolation.

Siring: S i r i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Sire

Sirius: S i r i u s "n. The Dog Star. See Dog Star.

Sirkeer: S i r k e e r "n. Any one of several species of Asiatic cuckoos of the genus Taccocua  as the Bengal sirkeer (T. sirkee).

Sirloin: S i r l o i n "n. A loin of beef  or a part of a loin.

Sirname: S i r n a m e "n. See Surname.

Siroc: S i r o c "n. See Sirocco.

Sirocco: S i r o c c o "n. An oppressive  relaxing wind from the Libyan deserts chiefly experienced in Italy Malta and Sicily.

Siroccos: S i r o c c o s "pl. "of Sirocco

Sirrah: S i r r a h "n. A term of address implying inferiority and used in anger  contempt reproach or disrespectful familiarity addressed to a man or boy but sometimes to a woman. In sililoquies often preceded by ah. Not used in the plural.

Sirt: S i r t "n. A quicksand.

Sirup: S i r u p "n. Alt. of Syrup

Siruped: S i r u p e d "a. Alt. of Syruped

Sirupy: S i r u p y "a. Alt. of Syrupy

Sirvente: S i r v e n t e "n. A peculiar species of poetry  for the most part devoted to moral and religious topics and commonly satirical -- often used by the troubadours of the Middle Ages.

Sis: S i s "n. A colloquial abbreviation of Sister.

Sis: S i s "n. Six. See Sise.

Sisal grass: S i s a l   g r a s s " Alt. of Sisal hemp

Sisal hemp: S i s a l   h e m p " The prepared fiber of the Agave Americana  or American aloe used for cordage; -- so called from Sisal a port in Yucatan. See Sisal hemp under Hemp.

Siscowet: S i s c o w e t "n. A large  fat variety of the namaycush found in Lake Superior; -- called also siskawet siskiwit.

Sise: S i s e "n. An assize.

Sise: S i s e "n. Six; the highest number on a die; the cast of six in throwing dice.

Sisel: S i s e l "n. The suslik.

Siser: S i s e r "n. Cider. See Sicer.

Siserara: S i s e r a r a "n. Alt. of Siserary

Siserary: S i s e r a r y "n. A hard blow.

Siskin: S i s k i n "n. A small green and yellow European finch (Spinus spinus  or Carduelis spinus); -- called also aberdevine.

Siskin: S i s k i n "n. The American pinefinch (S. pinus); -- called also pine siskin. See Pinefinch.

Siskiwit: S i s k i w i t "n. The siscowet.

Sismograph: S i s m o g r a p h "n. See Seismograph.

Sismometer: S i s m o m e t e r "n. See Seismometer.

Siss: S i s s "v. i. To make a hissing sound; as  a flatiron hot enough to siss when touched with a wet finger.

Siss: S i s s "n. A hissing noise.

Sissoo: S i s s o o "n. A leguminous tree (Dalbergia Sissoo) of the northern parts of India; also  the dark brown compact and durable timber obtained from it. It is used in shipbuilding and for gun carriages railway ties etc.

Sist: S i s t "v. t. To stay  as judicial proceedings; to delay or suspend; to stop.

Sist: S i s t "v. t. To cause to take a place  as at the bar of a court; hence to cite; to summon; to bring into court.

Sist: S i s t "n. A stay or suspension of proceedings; an order for a stay of proceedings.

Sister: S i s t e r "n. A female who has the same parents with another person  or who has one of them only. In the latter case she is more definitely called a half sister. The correlative of brother.

Sister: S i s t e r "n. A woman who is closely allied to  or assocciated with another person as in the sdame faith society order or community.

Sister: S i s t e r "n. One of the same kind  or of the same condition; -- generally used adjectively; as sister fruits.

Sister: S i s t e r "v. t. To be sister to; to resemble closely.

Sister-in-law: S i s t e r - i n - l a w "n. The sister of one's husband or wife; also  the wife of one's brother; sometimes the wife of one's husband's or wife's brother.

Sisterhood: S i s t e r h o o d "n. The state or relation of being a sister; the office or duty of a sister.

Sisterhood: S i s t e r h o o d "n. A society of sisters; a society of women united in one faith or order; sisters  collectively.

Sistering: S i s t e r i n g "a. Contiguous.

Sisterly: S i s t e r l y "a. Like a sister; becoming a sister  affectionate; as sisterly kindness; sisterly remorse.

Sisters-in-law: S i s t e r s - i n - l a w "pl. "of Sister-in-law

Sistine: S i s t i n e "a. Of or pertaining to Pope Sixtus.

Sistren: S i s t r e n "n. pl. Sisters.

Sistrum: S i s t r u m " An instrument consisting of a thin metal frame  through which passed a number of metal rods and furnished with a handle by which it was shaken and made to rattle. It was peculiarly Egyptian and used especially in the worship of Isis. It is still used in Nubia.

Sisyphean: S i s y p h e a n "a. Relating to Sisyphus; incessantly recurring; as  Sisyphean labors.

Sisyphus: S i s y p h u s "n. A king of Corinth  son of Aeolus famed for his cunning. He was killed by Theseus and in the lower world was condemned by Pluto to roll to the top of a hill a huge stone which constantly rolled back again making his task incessant.

Sit: S i t " obs. 3d pers. sing. pres. of Sit  for sitteth.

Sit: S i t "v. t. To rest upon the haunches  or the lower extremity of the trunk of the body; -- said of human beings and sometimes of other animals; as to sit on a sofa on a chair or on the ground.

Sit: S i t "v. t. To perch; to rest with the feet drawn up  as birds do on a branch pole etc.

Sit: S i t "v. t. To remain in a state of repose; to rest; to abide; to rest in any position or condition.

Sit: S i t "v. t. To lie  rest or bear; to press or weigh; -- with on; as a weight or burden sits lightly upon him.

Sit: S i t "v. t. To be adjusted; to fit; as  a coat sts well or ill.

Sit: S i t "v. t. To suit one well or ill  as an act; to become; to befit; -- used impersonally.

Sit: S i t "v. t. To cover and warm eggs for hatching  as a fowl; to brood; to incubate.

Sit: S i t "v. t. To have position  as at the point blown from; to hold a relative position; to have direction.

Sit: S i t "v. t. To occupy a place or seat as a member of an official body; as  to sit in Congress.

Sit: S i t "v. t. To hold a session; to be in session for official business; -- said of legislative assemblies  courts etc.; as the court sits in January; the aldermen sit to-night.

Sit: S i t "v. t. To take a position for the purpose of having some artistic representation of one's self made  as a picture or a bust; as to sit to a painter.

Sit: S i t "v. t. To sit upon; to keep one's seat upon; as  he sits a horse well.

Sit: S i t "v. t. To cause to be seated or in a sitting posture; to furnish a seat to; -- used reflexively.

Sit: S i t "v. t. To suit (well / ill); to become.

Site: S i t e "n. The place where anything is fixed; situation; local position; as  the site of a city or of a house.

Site: S i t e "n. A place fitted or chosen for any certain permanent use or occupation; as  a site for a church.

Site: S i t e "n. The posture or position of a thing.

Sited: S i t e d "a. Having a site; situated.

Sitfast: S i t f a s t "a. Fixed; stationary; immovable.

Sitfast: S i t f a s t "n. A callosity with inflamed edges  on the back of a horse under the saddle.

Sith: S i t h "prep. adv.  & conj. Since; afterwards; seeing that.

Sith: S i t h "n. Alt. of Sithe

Sithe: S i t h e "n. Time.

Sithe: S i t h e "v. i. To sigh.

Sithe: S i t h e "n. A scythe.

Sithe: S i t h e "v. t. To cut with a scythe; to scythe.

Sithed: S i t h e d "a. Scythed.

Sitheman: S i t h e m a n "n. A mower.

Sithen: S i t h e n "adv. & conj. Since; afterwards. See 1st Sith.

Sithence: S i t h e n c e "adv. & conj. Alt. of Sithens

Sithens: S i t h e n s "adv. & conj. Since. See Sith  and Sithen.

Siththen: S i t h t h e n "adv. & conj. See Sithen.

Sitology: S i t o l o g y "n. A treatise on the regulation of the diet; dietetics.

Sitophobia: S i t o p h o b i a "n. A version to food; refusal to take nourishment.

Sitten: S i t t e n " of Sit

Sitten: S i t t e n " p. p. of Sit  for sat.

Sitter: S i t t e r "n. One who sits; esp.  one who sits for a portrait or a bust.

Sitter: S i t t e r "n. A bird that sits or incubates.

Sittine: S i t t i n e "a. Of or pertaining to the family Sittidae  or nuthatches.

Sitting: S i t t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Sit

Sitting: S i t t i n g "a. Being in the state  or the position of one who or that which sits.

Sitting: S i t t i n g "n. The state or act of one who sits; the posture of one who occupies a seat.

Sitting: S i t t i n g "n. A seat  or the space occupied by or allotted for a person in a church theater etc.; as the hall has 800 sittings.

Sitting: S i t t i n g "n. The act or time of sitting  as to a portrait painter photographer etc.

Sitting: S i t t i n g "n. The actual presence or meeting of any body of men in their seats  clothed with authority to transact business; a session; as a sitting of the judges of the King's Bench or of a commission.

Sitting: S i t t i n g "n. The time during which one sits while doing something  as reading a book playing a game etc.

Sitting: S i t t i n g "n. A brooding over eggs for hatching  as by fowls.

Situate: S i t u a t e "a. Alt. of Situated

Situate: S i t u a t e "v. t. To place.

Situated: S i t u a t e d "a. Having a site  situation or location; being in a relative position; permanently fixed; placed; located; as a town situated or situate on a hill or on the seashore.

Situated: S i t u a t e d "a. Placed; residing.

Situation: S i t u a t i o n "n. Manner in which an object is placed; location  esp. as related to something else; position; locality site; as a house in a pleasant situation.

Situation: S i t u a t i o n "n. Position  as regards the conditions and circumstances of the case.

Situation: S i t u a t i o n "n. Relative position; circumstances; temporary state or relation at a moment of action which excites interest  as of persons in a dramatic scene.

Situation: S i t u a t i o n "n. Permanent position or employment; place; office; as  a situation in a store; a situation under government.

Situs: S i t u s "n. The method in which the parts of a plant are arranged; also  the position of the parts.

Sitz bath: S i t z   b a t h " A tub in which one bathes in a sitting posture; also  a bath so taken; a hip bath.

Siva: S i v a "n. One of the triad of Hindoo gods. He is the avenger or destroyer  and in modern worship symbolizes the reproductive power of nature.

Sivan: S i v a n "n. The third month of the Jewish ecclesiastical year; -- supposed to correspond nearly with our month of June.

Sivatherium: S i v a t h e r i u m "n. A genus of very large extinct ruminants found in the Tertiary formation of India. The snout was prolonged in the form of a proboscis. The male had four horns  the posterior pair being large and branched. It was allied to the antelopes but very much larger than any exsisting species.

Siver: S i v e r "v. i. To simmer.

Sivvens: S i v v e n s "n. See Sibbens.

Siwin: S i w i n "n. Same as Sewen.

Six: S i x "a. One more than five; twice three; as  six yards.

Six: S i x "n. The number greater by a unit than five; the sum of three and three; six units or objects.

Six: S i x "n. A symbol representing six units  as 6 vi. or VI.

Six-footer: S i x - f o o t e r "n. One who is six feet tall.

Six-shooter: S i x - s h o o t e r "n. A pistol or other firearm which can be fired six times without reloading especially  a six-chambered revolver.

Sixfold: S i x f o l d "a. Six times repeated; six times as much or as many.

Sixpence: S i x p e n c e "n. An English silver coin of the value of six pennies; half a shilling  or about twelve cents.

Sixpences: S i x p e n c e s "pl. "of Sixpence

Sixpenny: S i x p e n n y "a. Of the value of  or costing sixpence; as a sixpenny loaf.

Sixscore: S i x s c o r e "a. & n. Six times twenty; one hundred and twenty.

Sixteen: S i x t e e n "a. Six and ten; consisting of six and ten; fifteen and one more.

Sixteen: S i x t e e n "n. The number greater by a unit than fifteen; the sum of ten and six; sixteen units or objects.

Sixteen: S i x t e e n "n. A symbol representing sixteen units  as 16 or xvi.

Sixteenmo: S i x t e e n m o "n. See Sextodecimo.

Sixteenmos: S i x t e e n m o s "pl. "of Sixteenmo

Sixteenth: S i x t e e n t h "a. Sixth after the tenth; next in order after the fifteenth.

Sixteenth: S i x t e e n t h "a. Constituting or being one of sixteen equal parts into which anything is divided.

Sixteenth: S i x t e e n t h "n. The quotient of a unit divided by sixteen; one of sixteen equal parts of one whole.

Sixteenth: S i x t e e n t h "n. The next in order after the fifteenth; the sixth after the tenth.

Sixteenth: S i x t e e n t h "n. An interval comprising two octaves and a second.

Sixth: S i x t h "a. First after the fifth; next in order after the fifth.

Sixth: S i x t h "a. Constituting or being one of six equal parts into which anything is divided.

Sixth: S i x t h "n. The quotient of a unit divided by six; one of six equal parts which form a whole.

Sixth: S i x t h "n. The next in order after the fifth.

Sixth: S i x t h "n. The interval embracing six diatonic degrees of the scale.

Sixthly: S i x t h l y "adv. In the sixth place.

Sixties: S i x t i e s "pl. "of Sixty

Sixtieth: S i x t i e t h "a. Next in order after the fifty-ninth.

Sixtieth: S i x t i e t h "a. Constituting or being one one of sixty equal parts into which anything is divided.

Sixtieth: S i x t i e t h "n. The quotient of a unit divided by sixty; one of sixty equal parts forming a whole.

Sixtieth: S i x t i e t h "n. The next in order after the fifty-ninth; the tenth after the fiftieth.

Sixty: S i x t y "a. Six times ten; fifty-nine and one more; threescore.

Sixty: S i x t y "n. The sum of six times ten; sixty units or objects.

Sixty: S i x t y "n. A symbol representing sixty units  as 60 lx. or LX.

Sixty-fourth: S i x t y - f o u r t h "a. Constituting or being one of sixty-four equal parts into which a thing is divided.

Sizable: S i z a b l e "a. Of considerable size or bulk.

Sizable: S i z a b l e "a. Being of reasonable or suitable size; as  sizable timber; sizable bulk.

Sizar: S i z a r "n. One of a body of students in the universities of Cambridge (Eng.) and Dublin  who having passed a certain examination are exempted from paying college fees and charges. A sizar corresponded to a servitor at Oxford.

Sizarship: S i z a r s h i p "n. The position or standing of a sizar.

Size: S i z e "n. Six.

Size: S i z e "v. i. A thin  weak glue used in various trades as in painting bookbinding paper making etc.

Size: S i z e "v. i. Any viscous substance  as gilder's varnish.

Size: S i z e "v. t. To cover with size; to prepare with size.

Size: S i z e "n. A settled quantity or allowance. See Assize.

Size: S i z e "n. An allowance of food and drink from the buttery  aside from the regular dinner at commons; -- corresponding to battel at Oxford.

Size: S i z e "n. Extent of superficies or volume; bulk; bigness; magnitude; as  the size of a tree or of a mast; the size of a ship or of a rock.

Size: S i z e "n. Figurative bulk; condition as to rank  ability character etc.; as the office demands a man of larger size.

Size: S i z e "n. A conventional relative measure of dimension  as for shoes gloves and other articles made up for sale.

Size: S i z e "n. An instrument consisting of a number of perforated gauges fastened together at one end by a rivet  -- used for ascertaining the size of pearls.

Size: S i z e "v. t. To fix the standard of.

Size: S i z e "v. t. To adjust or arrange according to size or bulk.

Size: S i z e "v. t. To take the height of men  in order to place them in the ranks according to their stature.

Size: S i z e "v. t. To sift  as pieces of ore or metal in order to separate the finer from the coarser parts.

Size: S i z e "v. t. To swell; to increase the bulk of.

Size: S i z e "v. t. To bring or adjust anything exactly to a required dimension  as by cutting.

Size: S i z e "v. i. To take greater size; to increase in size.

Size: S i z e "v. i. To order food or drink from the buttery; hence  to enter a score as upon the buttery book.

Sized: S i z e d "imp. & p. p. of Size

Sized: S i z e d "a. Adjusted according to size.

Sized: S i z e d "a. Having a particular size or magnitude; -- chiefly used in compounds; as  large-sized; common-sized.

Sizel: S i z e l "n. Same as Scissel  2.

Sizer: S i z e r "n. See Sizar.

Sizer: S i z e r "n. An instrument or contrivance to size articles  or to determine their size by a standard or to separate and distribute them according to size.

Sizer: S i z e r "n. An instrument or tool for bringing anything to an exact size.

Siziness: S i z i n e s s "n. The quality or state of being sizy; viscousness.

Sizing: S i z i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Size

Sizing: S i z i n g "n. Act of covering or treating with size.

Sizing: S i z i n g "n. A weak glue used in various trades; size.

Sizing: S i z i n g "n. The act of sorting with respect to size.

Sizing: S i z i n g "n. The act of bringing anything to a certain size.

Sizing: S i z i n g "n. Food and drink ordered from the buttery by a student.

Sizy: S i z y "a. Sizelike; viscous; glutinous; as  sizy blood.

Sizzle: S i z z l e "v. i. To make a hissing sound; to fry  or to dry and shrivel up with a hissing sound.

Sizzle: S i z z l e "n. A hissing sound  as of something frying over a fire.

Skaddle: S k a d d l e "n. Hurt; damage.

Skaddle: S k a d d l e "a. Hurtful.

Skaddon: S k a d d o n "n. The larva of a bee.

Skag: S k a g "n. An additional piece fastened to the keel of a boat to prevent lateral motion. See Skeg.

Skain: S k a i n "n. See Skein.

Skain: S k a i n "n. See Skean.

Skainsmate: S k a i n s m a t e "n. A messmate; a companion.

Skaith: S k a i t h "n. See Scatch.

Skald: S k a l d "n. See 5th Scald.

Skaldic: S k a l d i c "a. See Scaldic.

Skaling: S k a l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Seal

Skall: S k a l l "v. t. To scale; to mount.

Skar: S k a r "a. Alt. of Skare

Skare: S k a r e "a. Wild; timid; shy.

Skart: S k a r t "n. The shag.

Skate: S k a t e "n. A metallic runner with a frame shaped to fit the sole of a shoe  -- made to be fastened under the foot and used for moving rapidly on ice.

Skate: S k a t e "v. i. To move on skates.

Skate: S k a t e "n. Any one of numerous species of large  flat elasmobranch fishes of the genus Raia having a long slender tail terminated by a small caudal fin. The pectoral fins which are large and broad and united to the sides of the body and head give a somewhat rhombic form to these fishes. The skin is more or less spinose.

Skated: S k a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Skate

Skater: S k a t e r "n. One who skates.

Skater: S k a t e r "n. Any one of numerous species of hemipterous insects belonging to Gerris  Pyrrhocoris Prostemma and allied genera. They have long legs and run rapidly over the surface of the water as if skating.

Skating: S k a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Skate

Skatol: S k a t o l "n. A constituent of human faeces formed in the small intestines as a product of the putrefaction of albuminous matter. It is also found in reduced indigo. Chemically it is methyl indol  C9H9N.

Skayles: S k a y l e s "n. [ 159.] Skittles.

Skean: S k e a n "n. A knife or short dagger  esp. that in use among the Highlanders of Scotland. [Variously spelt.]

Skedaddle: S k e d a d d l e "v. i. To betake one's self to flight  as if in a panic; to flee; to run away.

Skedaddled: S k e d a d d l e d "imp. & p. p. of Skedaddle

Skedaddling: S k e d a d d l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Skedaddle

Skee: S k e e "n. A long strip of wood  curved upwards in front used on the foot for sliding.

Skeed: S k e e d "n. See Skid.

Skeel: S k e e l "n. A shallow wooden vessel for holding milk or cream.

Skeelduck: S k e e l d u c k "n. Alt. of Skeelgoose

Skeelgoose: S k e e l g o o s e "n. The common European sheldrake.

Skeet: S k e e t "n. A scoop with a long handle  used to wash the sides of a vessel and formerly to wet the sails or deck.

Skeg: S k e g "n. A sort of wild plum.

Skeg: S k e g "n. A kind of oats.

Skeg: S k e g "n. The after part of the keel of a vessel  to which the rudder is attached.

Skegger: S k e g g e r "n. The parr.

Skein: S k e i n "n. A quantity of yarn  thread or the like put up together after it is taken from the reel -- usually tied in a sort of knot.

Skein: S k e i n "n. A metallic strengthening band or thimble on the wooden arm of an axle.

Skein: S k e i n "n. A flight of wild fowl (wild geese or the like).

Skeine: S k e i n e "n. See Skean.

Skelder: S k e l d e r "v. t. & i. To deceive; to cheat; to trick.

Skelder: S k e l d e r "n. A vagrant; a cheat.

Skeldrake: S k e l d r a k e "n. Alt. of Skieldrake

Skelet: S k e l e t "n. A skeleton. See Scelet.

Skeletal: S k e l e t a l "a. Pertaining to the skeleton.

Skeletogenous: S k e l e t o g e n o u s "a. Forming or producing parts of the skeleton.

Skeletology: S k e l e t o l o g y "n. That part of anatomy which treats of the skeleton; also  a treatise on the skeleton.

Skeleton: S k e l e t o n "n. The bony and cartilaginous framework which supports the soft parts of a vertebrate animal.

Skeleton: S k e l e t o n "n. The more or less firm or hardened framework of an invertebrate animal.

Skeleton: S k e l e t o n "n. A very thin or lean person.

Skeleton: S k e l e t o n "n. The framework of anything; the principal parts that support the rest  but without the appendages.

Skeleton: S k e l e t o n "n. The heads and outline of a literary production  especially of a sermon.

Skeleton: S k e l e t o n "a. Consisting of  or resembling a skeleton; consisting merely of the framework or outlines; having only certain leading features of anything; as a skeleton sermon; a skeleton crystal.

Skeletonize: S k e l e t o n i z e "v. t. To prepare a skeleton of; also  to reduce as a leaf to its skeleton.

Skeletonized: S k e l e t o n i z e d "imp. & p. p. of Skeletonize

Skeletonizer: S k e l e t o n i z e r "n. Any small moth whose larva eats the parenchyma of leaves  leaving the skeleton; as the apple-leaf skeletonizer.

Skeletonizing: S k e l e t o n i z i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Skeletonize

Skellum: S k e l l u m "n. A scoundrel.

Skelly: S k e l l y "v. i. To squint.

Skelly: S k e l l y "n. A squint.

Skelp: S k e l p "n. A blow; a smart stroke.

Skelp: S k e l p "n. A squall; also  a heavy fall of rain.

Skelp: S k e l p "v. t. To strike; to slap.

Skelp: S k e l p "n. A wrought-iron plate from which a gun barrel or pipe is made by bending and welding the edges together  and drawing the thick tube thus formed.

Skelter: S k e l t e r "v. i. To run off helter-skelter; to hurry; to scurry; -- with away or off.

Sken: S k e n "v. i. To squint.

Skene: S k e n e "n. See Skean.

Skep: S k e p "n. A coarse round farm basket.

Skep: S k e p "n. A beehive.

Skeptic: S k e p t i c "n. One who is yet undecided as to what is true; one who is looking or inquiring for what is true; an inquirer after facts or reasons.

Skeptic: S k e p t i c "n. A doubter as to whether any fact or truth can be certainly known; a universal doubter; a Pyrrhonist; hence  in modern usage occasionally a person who questions whether any truth or fact can be established on philosophical grounds; sometimes a critical inquirer in opposition to a dogmatist.

Skeptic: S k e p t i c "n. A person who doubts the existence and perfections of God  or the truth of revelation; one who disbelieves the divine origin of the Christian religion.

Skeptic: S k e p t i c "a. Alt. of Skeptical

Skeptical: S k e p t i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to a sceptic or skepticism; characterized by skepticism; hesitating to admit the certainly of doctrines or principles; doubting of everything.

Skeptical: S k e p t i c a l "a. Doubting or denying the truth of revelation  or the sacred Scriptures.

Skepticism: S k e p t i c i s m "n. An undecided  inquiring state of mind; doubt; uncertainty.

Skepticism: S k e p t i c i s m "n. The doctrine that no fact or principle can be certainly known; the tenet that all knowledge is uncertain; Pyrrohonism; universal doubt; the position that no fact or truth  however worthy of confidence can be established on philosophical grounds; critical investigation or inquiry as opposed to the positive assumption or assertion of certain principles.

Skepticism: S k e p t i c i s m "n. A doubting of the truth of revelation  or a denial of the divine origin of the Christian religion or of the being perfections or truth of God.

Skepticize: S k e p t i c i z e "v. i. To doubt; to pretend to doubt of everything.

Skerries: S k e r r i e s "pl. "of Skerry

Skerry: S k e r r y "n. A rocky isle; an insulated rock.

Sketch: S k e t c h "n. An outline or general delineation of anything; a first rough or incomplete draught or plan of any design; especially  in the fine arts such a representation of an object or scene as serves the artist's purpose by recording its chief features; also a preliminary study for an original work.

Sketch: S k e t c h "n. To draw the outline or chief features of; to make a rought of.

Sketch: S k e t c h "n. To plan or describe by giving the principal points or ideas of.

Sketch: S k e t c h "v. i. To make sketches  as of landscapes.

Sketchbook: S k e t c h b o o k "n. A book of sketches or for sketches.

Sketched: S k e t c h e d "imp. & p. p. of Sketch

Sketcher: S k e t c h e r "n. One who sketches.

Sketchily: S k e t c h i l y "adv. In a sketchy or incomplete manner.

Sketchiness: S k e t c h i n e s s "n. The quality or state of being sketchy; lack of finish; incompleteness.

Sketching: S k e t c h i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Sketch

Sketchy: S k e t c h y "a. Containing only an outline or rough form; being in the manner of a sketch; incomplete.

Skew: S k e w "adv. Awry; obliquely; askew.

Skew: S k e w "a. Turned or twisted to one side; situated obliquely; skewed; -- chiefly used in technical phrases.

Skew: S k e w "n. A stone at the foot of the slope of a gable  the offset of a buttress or the like cut with a sloping surface and with a check to receive the coping stones and retain them in place.

Skew: S k e w "v. i. To walk obliquely; to go sidling; to lie or move obliquely.

Skew: S k e w "v. i. To start aside; to shy  as a horse.

Skew: S k e w "v. i. To look obliquely; to squint; hence  to look slightingly or suspiciously.

Skew: S k e w "adv. To shape or form in an oblique way; to cause to take an oblique position.

Skew: S k e w "adv. To throw or hurl obliquely.

Skewbald: S k e w b a l d "a. Marked with spots and patches of white and some color other than black; -- usually distinguished from piebald  in which the colors are properly white and black. Said of horses.

Skewed: S k e w e d "imp. & p. p. of Skew

Skewer: S k e w e r "n. A pin of wood or metal for fastening meat to a spit  or for keeping it in form while roasting.

Skewer: S k e w e r "v. t. To fasten with skewers.

Skewered: S k e w e r e d "imp. & p. p. of Skewer

Skewering: S k e w e r i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Skewer

Skewing: S k e w i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Skew

Skid: S k i d "n. A shoe or clog  as of iron attached to a chain and placed under the wheel of a wagon to prevent its turning when descending a steep hill; a drag; a skidpan; also by extension a hook attached to a chain and used for the same purpose.

Skid: S k i d "n. A piece of timber used as a support  or to receive pressure.

Skid: S k i d "n. Large fenders hung over a vessel's side to protect it in handling a cargo.

Skid: S k i d "n. One of a pair of timbers or bars  usually arranged so as to form an inclined plane as form a wagon to a door along which anything is moved by sliding or rolling.

Skid: S k i d "n. One of a pair of horizontal rails or timbers for supporting anything  as a boat a barrel etc.

Skid: S k i d "v. t. To protect or support with a skid or skids; also  to cause to move on skids.

Skid: S k i d "v. t. To check with a skid  as wagon wheels.

Skiddaw: S k i d d a w "n. The black guillemot.

Skidded: S k i d d e d "imp. & p. p. of Skid

Skidding: S k i d d i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Skid

Skieldrake: S k i e l d r a k e "n. The common European sheldrake.

Skieldrake: S k i e l d r a k e "n. The oyster catcher.

Skiey: S k i e y "a. See Skyey.

Skiff: S k i f f "n. A small  light boat.
