Skilder: S k i l d e r "v. i. To beg; to pilfer; to skelder.

Skilful: S k i l f u l "a. See Skilful.

Skill: S k i l l "n. Discrimination; judgment; propriety; reason; cause.

Skill: S k i l l "n. Knowledge; understanding.

Skill: S k i l l "n. The familiar knowledge of any art or science  united with readiness and dexterity in execution or performance or in the application of the art or science to practical purposes; power to discern and execute; ability to perceive and perform; expertness; aptitude; as the skill of a mathematician physician surgeon mechanic etc.

Skill: S k i l l "n. Display of art; exercise of ability; contrivance; address.

Skill: S k i l l "n. Any particular art.

Skill: S k i l l "v. t. To know; to understand.

Skill: S k i l l "v. i. To be knowing; to have understanding; to be dexterous in performance.

Skill: S k i l l "v. i. To make a difference; to signify; to matter; -- used impersonally.

Skill-less: S k i l l - l e s s "a. Wanting skill.

Skilled: S k i l l e d "a. Having familiar knowledge united with readiness and dexterity in its application; familiarly acquainted with; expert; skillful; -- often followed by in; as  a person skilled in drawing or geometry.

Skillet: S k i l l e t "n. A small vessel of iron  copper or other metal with a handle used for culinary purpose as for stewing meat.

Skillful: S k i l l f u l "a. Discerning; reasonable; judicious; cunning.

Skillful: S k i l l f u l "a. Possessed of  or displaying skill; knowing and ready; expert; well-versed; able in management; as a skillful mechanic; -- often followed by at in or of; as skillful at the organ; skillful in drawing.

Skilligalee: S k i l l i g a l e e "n. A kind of thin  weak broth or oatmeal porridge served out to prisoners and paupers in England; also a drink made of oatmeal sugar and water sometimes used in the English navy or army.

Skilling: S k i l l i n g "n. A bay of a barn; also  a slight addition to a cottage.

Skilling: S k i l l i n g "n. A money od account in Sweden  Norwey Denmark and North Germany and also a coin. It had various values from three fourths of a cent in Norway to more than two cents in Lubeck.

Skilts: S k i l t s "n. pl. A kind of large  coarse short trousers formerly worn.

Skilty: S k i l t y "n. The water rail.

Skim: S k i m "v. t. To clear (a liquid) from scum or substance floating or lying thereon  by means of a utensil that passes just beneath the surface; as to skim milk; to skim broth.

Skim: S k i m "v. t. To take off by skimming; as  to skim cream.

Skim: S k i m "v. t. To pass near the surface of; to brush the surface of; to glide swiftly along the surface of.

Skim: S k i m "v. t. Fig.: To read or examine superficially and rapidly  in order to cull the principal facts or thoughts; as to skim a book or a newspaper.

Skim: S k i m "v. i. To pass lightly; to glide along in an even  smooth course; to glide along near the surface.

Skim: S k i m "v. i. To hasten along with superficial attention.

Skim: S k i m "v. i. To put on the finishing coat of plaster.

Skim: S k i m "a. Contraction of Skimming and Skimmed.

Skimback: S k i m b a c k "n. The quillback.

Skimble-scamble: S k i m b l e - s c a m b l e "a. Rambling; disorderly; unconnected.

Skimitry: S k i m i t r y "n. See Skimmington.

Skimmed: S k i m m e d "imp. & p. p. of Skim

Skimmer: S k i m m e r "n. One who  or that which skims; esp. a utensil with which liquids are skimmed.

Skimmer: S k i m m e r "n. Any species of longwinged marine birds of the genus Rhynchops  allied to the terns but having the lower mandible compressed and much longer than the upper one. These birds fly rapidly along the surface of the water with the lower mandible immersed thus skimming out small fishes. The American species (R. nigra) is common on the southern coasts of the United States. Called also scissorbill and shearbill.

Skimmer: S k i m m e r "n. Any one of several large bivalve shells  sometimes used for skimming milk as the sea clams and large scallops.

Skimmerton: S k i m m e r t o n "n. See Skimmington.

Skimming: S k i m m i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Skim

Skimming: S k i m m i n g "n. The act of one who skims.

Skimming: S k i m m i n g "n. That which is skimmed from the surface of a liquid; -- chiefly used in the plural; as  the skimmings of broth.

Skimmingly: S k i m m i n g l y "adv. In a skimming manner.

Skimmington: S k i m m i n g t o n "n. A word employed in the phrase  To ride Skimmington; that is to ride on a horse with a woman but behind her facing backward carrying a distaff and accompanied by a procession of jeering neighbors making mock music; a cavalcade in ridicule of a henpecked man. The custom was in vogue in parts of England.

Skimp: S k i m p "v. t. To slight; to do carelessly; to scamp.

Skimp: S k i m p "v. t. To make insufficient allowance for; to scant; to scrimp.

Skimp: S k i m p "v. i. To save; to be parsimonious or niggardly.

Skimp: S k i m p "a. Scanty.

Skimped: S k i m p e d "imp. & p. p. of Skimp

Skimping: S k i m p i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Skimp

Skin: S k i n "n. The external membranous integument of an animal.

Skin: S k i n "n. The hide of an animal  separated from the body whether green dry or tanned; especially that of a small animal as a calf sheep or goat.

Skin: S k i n "n. A vessel made of skin  used for holding liquids. See Bottle 1.

Skin: S k i n "n. The bark or husk of a plant or fruit; the exterior coat of fruits and plants.

Skin: S k i n "n. That part of a sail  when furled which remains on the outside and covers the whole.

Skin: S k i n "n. The covering  as of planking or iron plates outside the framing forming the sides and bottom of a vessel; the shell; also a lining inside the framing.

Skin: S k i n "v. t. To strip off the skin or hide of; to flay; to peel; as  to skin an animal.

Skin: S k i n "v. t. To cover with skin  or as with skin; hence to cover superficially.

Skin: S k i n "v. t. To strip of money or property; to cheat.

Skin: S k i n "v. i. To become covered with skin; as  a wound skins over.

Skin: S k i n "v. i. To produce  in recitation examination etc. the work of another for one's own or to use in such exercise cribs memeoranda etc. which are prohibited.

Skin-deep: S k i n - d e e p "a. Not deeper than the skin; hence  superficial.

Skinbound: S k i n b o u n d "a. Having the skin adhering closely and rigidly to the flesh; hidebound.

Skinch: S k i n c h "v. t. & i. To give scant measure; to squeeze or pinch in order to effect a saving.

Skinful: S k i n f u l "n. As much as a skin can hold.

Skinfuls: S k i n f u l s "pl. "of Skinful

Skink: S k i n k "n. Any one of numerous species of regularly scaled harmless lizards of the family Scincidae  common in the warmer parts of all the continents.

Skink: S k i n k "v. t. To draw or serve  as drink.

Skink: S k i n k "v. i. To serve or draw liquor.

Skink: S k i n k "n. Drink; also  pottage.

Skinless: S k i n l e s s "a. Having no skin  or a very thin skin; as skinless fruit.

Skip: S k i p "n. A basket. See Skep.

Skip: S k i p "n. A basket on wheels  used in cotton factories.

Skip: S k i p "n. An iron bucket  which slides between guides for hoisting mineral and rock.

Skip: S k i p "n. A charge of sirup in the pans.

Skip: S k i p "n. A beehive; a skep.

Skip: S k i p "v. i. To leap lightly; to move in leaps and hounds; -- commonly implying a sportive spirit.

Skip: S k i p "v. i. Fig.: To leave matters unnoticed  as in reading speaking or writing; to pass by or overlook portions of a thing; -- often followed by over.

Skip: S k i p "v. t. To leap lightly over; as  to skip the rope.

Skip: S k i p "v. t. To pass over or by without notice; to omit; to miss; as  to skip a line in reading; to skip a lesson.

Skip: S k i p "v. t. To cause to skip; as  to skip a stone.

Skip: S k i p "n. A light leap or bound.

Skip: S k i p "n. The act of passing over an interval from one thing to another; an omission of a part.

Skip: S k i p "n. A passage from one sound to another by more than a degree at once.

Skipjack: S k i p j a c k "n. An upstart.

Skipjack: S k i p j a c k "n. An elater; a snap bug  or snapping beetle.

Skipjack: S k i p j a c k "n. A name given to several kinds of a fish  as the common bluefish the alewife the bonito the butterfish the cutlass fish the jurel the leather jacket the runner the saurel the saury the threadfish

Skipjack: S k i p j a c k "n. A shallow sailboat with a rectilinear or V-shaped cross section.

Skipper: S k i p p e r "n. Any one of numerous species of small butterflies of the family Hesperiadae; -- so called from their peculiar short  jerking flight.

Skipper: S k i p p e r "n. The master of a fishing or small trading vessel; hence  the master or captain of any vessel.

Skipper: S k i p p e r "n. A ship boy.

Skirling: S k i r l i n g "n. A small trout or salmon; -- a name used loosely.

Skirret: S k i r r e t "n. An umbelliferous plant (Sium  / Pimpinella Sisarum). It is a native of Asia but has been long cultivated in Europe for its edible clustered tuberous roots which are very sweet.

Skitty: S k i t t y "n. A rail; as  the water rail (called also skitty cock and skitty coot); the spotted crake (Porzana maruetta) and the moor hen.

Skive: S k i v e "n. The iron lap used by diamond polishers in finishing the facets of the gem.

Skive: S k i v e "v. t. To pare or shave off the rough or thick parts of (hides or leather).

Skiver: S k i v e r "n. An inferior quality of leather  made of split sheepskin tanned by immersion in sumac and dyed. It is used for hat linings pocketbooks bookbinding etc.

Skiver: S k i v e r "n. The cutting tool or machine used in splitting leather or skins  as sheepskins.

Skiving: S k i v i n g "n. The act of paring or splitting leather or skins.

Skiving: S k i v i n g "n. A piece made in paring or splitting leather; specifically  the part from the inner or flesh side.

Skulk: S k u l k "v. i. To hide  or get out of the way in a sneaking manner; to lie close or to move in a furtive way; to lurk.

Skull: S k u l l "n. The skeleton of the head of a vertebrate animal  including the brain case or cranium and the bones and cartilages of the face and mouth. See Illusts. of Carnivora of Facial angles under Facial and of Skeleton in Appendix.

Skull: S k u l l "n. The head or brain; the seat of intelligence; mind.

Skull: S k u l l "n. A covering for the head; a skullcap.

Skull: S k u l l "n. A sort of oar. See Scull.

Skullcap: S k u l l c a p "n. A cap which fits the head closely; also  formerly a headpiece of iron sewed inside of a cap for protection.

Skullcap: S k u l l c a p "n. Any plant of the labiate genus Scutellaria  the calyx of whose flower appears when inverted like a helmet with the visor raised.

Skullcap: S k u l l c a p "n. The Lophiomys.

Skullfish: S k u l l f i s h "n. A whaler's name for a whale more than two years old.

Skulpin: S k u l p i n "n. See Sculpin.

Skun: S k u n "n. & v. See Scum.

Skunk: S k u n k "n. Any one of several species of American musteline carnivores of the genus Mephitis and allied genera. They have two glands near the anus  secreting an extremely fetid liquid which the animal ejects at pleasure as a means of defense.

Skunk: S k u n k "v. t. In games of chance and skill: To defeat (an opponent) (as in cards) so that he fails to gain a point  or (in checkers) to get a king.

Skunkball: S k u n k b a l l "n. The surf duck.

Skunkhead: S k u n k h e a d "n. The surf duck.

Skunkhead: S k u n k h e a d "n. A duck (Camptolaimus Labradorus) which formerly inhabited the Atlantic coast of New England. It is now supposed to be extinct. Called also Labrador duck  and pied duck.

Skunkish: S k u n k i s h "a. Like the skunk  especially in odor.

Skunktop: S k u n k t o p "n. The surf duck.

Skunkweed: S k u n k w e e d "n. Skunk cabbage.

Skurry: S k u r r y "n. & v. See Scurry.

Skute: S k u t e "n. A boat; a small vessel.

Skutterudite: S k u t t e r u d i t e "n. A mineral of a bright metallic luster and tin-white to pale lead-gray color. It consists of arsenic and cobalt.

Sky: S k y "n. A cloud.

Sky: S k y "n. Hence  a shadow.

Sky: S k y "n. The apparent arch  or vault of heaven which in a clear day is of a blue color; the heavens; the firmament; -- sometimes in the plural.

Sky: S k y "n. The wheather; the climate.

Sky: S k y "v. t. To hang (a picture on exhibition) near the top of a wall  where it can not be well seen.

Sky: S k y "v. t. To throw towards the sky; as  to sky a ball at cricket.

Sky-blue: S k y - b l u e "a. Having the blue color of the sky; azure; as  a sky-blue stone.

Skyed: S k y e d "a. Surrounded by sky.

Skyey: S k y e y "a. Like the sky; ethereal; being in the sky.

Skying: S k y i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Sky

Skyish: S k y i s h "a. Like the sky  or approaching the sky; lofty; ethereal.

Skylark: S k y l a r k "n. A lark that mounts and sings as it files  especially the common species (Alauda arvensis) found in Europe and in some parts of Asia and celebrated for its melodious song; -- called also sky laverock. See under Lark.

Skylarking: S k y l a r k i n g "n. The act of running about the rigging of a vessel in sport; hence  frolicking; scuffing; sporting; carousing.

Skylight: S k y l i g h t "n. A window placed in the roof of a building  in the ceiling of a room or in the deck of a ship for the admission of light from above.

Skyrocket: S k y r o c k e t "n. A rocket that ascends high and burns as it flies; a species of fireworks.

Skysail: S k y s a i l "n. The sail set next above the royal. See Illust. under Sail.

Skyward: S k y w a r d "a. & adv. Toward the sky.

Slack: S l a c k "n. A valley  or small shallow dell.

Slack: S l a c k "superl. Lax; not tense; not hard drawn; not firmly extended; as  a slack rope.

Slack: S l a c k "superl. Weak; not holding fast; as  a slack hand.

Slack: S l a c k "superl. Remiss; backward; not using due diligence or care; not earnest or eager; as  slack in duty or service.

Slack: S l a c k "superl. Not violent  rapid or pressing; slow; moderate; easy; as business is slack.

Slack: S l a c k "adv. Slackly; as  slack dried hops.

Slack: S l a c k "n. The part of anything that hangs loose  having no strain upon it; as the slack of a rope or of a sail.

Slacken: S l a c k e n "a. To become slack; to be made less tense  firm or rigid; to decrease in tension; as a wet cord slackens in dry weather.

Slacken: S l a c k e n "a. To be remiss or backward; to be negligent.

Slacken: S l a c k e n "a. To lose cohesion or solidity by a chemical combination with water; to slake; as  lime slacks.

Slacken: S l a c k e n "a. To abate; to become less violent.

Slacken: S l a c k e n "a. To lose rapidity; to become more slow; as  a current of water slackens.

Slacken: S l a c k e n "a. To languish; to fail; to flag.

Slacken: S l a c k e n "a. To end; to cease; to desist; to slake.

Slacken: S l a c k e n "v. t. To render slack; to make less tense or firm; as  to slack a rope; to slacken a bandage.

Slacken: S l a c k e n "v. t. To neglect; to be remiss in.

Slacken: S l a c k e n "v. t. To deprive of cohesion by combining chemically with water; to slake; as  to slack lime.

Slacken: S l a c k e n "v. t. To cause to become less eager; to repress; to make slow or less rapid; to retard; as  to slacken pursuit; to slacken industry.

Slacken: S l a c k e n "v. t. To cause to become less intense; to mitigate; to abate; to ease.

Slacken: S l a c k e n "n. A spongy  semivitrifled substance which miners or smelters mix with the ores of metals to prevent their fusion.

Slam: S l a m "v. t. To strike with some implement with force; hence  to beat or cuff.

Slander: S l a n d e r "n. Disgrace; reproach; dishonor; opprobrium.

Slander: S l a n d e r "n. Formerly  defamation generally whether oral or written; in modern usage defamation by words spoken; utterance of false malicious and defamatory words tending to the damage and derogation of another; calumny. See the Note under Defamation.

Slander: S l a n d e r "v. t. To defame; to injure by maliciously uttering a false report; to tarnish or impair the reputation of by false tales maliciously told or propagated; to calumniate.

Slav: S l a v "n. One of a race of people occupying a large part of Eastern and Northern Europe  including the Russians Bulgarians Roumanians Servo-Croats Slovenes Poles Czechs Wends or Sorbs Slovaks etc.

Slave: S l a v e "n. See Slav.

Slave: S l a v e "n. A person who is held in bondage to another; one who is wholly subject to the will of another; one who is held as a chattel; one who has no freedom of action  but whose person and services are wholly under the control of another.

Slave: S l a v e "n. One who has lost the power of resistance; one who surrenders himself to any power whatever; as  a slave to passion to lust to strong drink to ambition.

Slave: S l a v e "n. A drudge; one who labors like a slave.

Slave: S l a v e "n. An abject person; a wretch.

Slave: S l a v e "v. i. To drudge; to toil; to labor as a slave.

Slave: S l a v e "v. t. To enslave.

Slaveborn: S l a v e b o r n "a. Born in slavery.

Slaved: S l a v e d "imp. & p. p. of Slave

Slaveholder: S l a v e h o l d e r "n. One who holds slaves.

Slaveholding: S l a v e h o l d i n g "a. Holding persons in slavery.

Slaveocracy: S l a v e o c r a c y "n. See Slavocracy.

Slaver: S l a v e r "n. A vessel engaged in the slave trade; a slave ship.

Slaver: S l a v e r "n. A person engaged in the purchase and sale of slaves; a slave merchant  or slave trader.

Slaver: S l a v e r "v. i. To suffer spittle  etc. to run from the mouth.

Slaver: S l a v e r "v. i. To be besmeared with saliva.

Slaver: S l a v e r "v. t. To smear with saliva issuing from the mouth; to defile with drivel; to slabber.

Slavering: S l a v e r i n g "a. Drooling; defiling with saliva.

Slavery: S l a v e r y "n. The condition of a slave; the state of entire subjection of one person to the will of another.

Slavery: S l a v e r y "n. A condition of subjection or submission characterized by lack of freedom of action or of will.

Slavery: S l a v e r y "n. The holding of slaves.

Slavey: S l a v e y "n. A maidservant.

Slavic: S l a v i c "a. Slavonic.

Slavic: S l a v i c "n. The group of allied languages spoken by the Slavs.

Slaving: S l a v i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Slave

Slavish: S l a v i s h "a. Of or pertaining to slaves; such as becomes or befits a slave; servile; excessively laborious; as  a slavish life; a slavish dependance on the great.

Slavism: S l a v i s m "n. The common feeling and interest of the Slavonic race.

Slavocracy: S l a v o c r a c y "n. The persons or interest formerly representing slavery politically  or wielding political power for the preservation or advancement of slavery.

Slavonian: S l a v o n i a n "a. Alt. of Slavonic

Slavonian: S l a v o n i a n "n. A native or inhabitant of Slavonia; ethnologically  a Slav.

Slavonic: S l a v o n i c "a. Of or pertaining to Slavonia  or its inhabitants.

Slavonic: S l a v o n i c "a. Of or pertaining to the Slavs  or their language.

Slavophil: S l a v o p h i l "n. Alt. of Slavophile

Slavophile: S l a v o p h i l e "n. One  not being a Slav who is interested in the development and prosperity of that race.

Slavs: S l a v s "pl. "of Slav

Sled: S l e d "n. A vehicle on runners  used for conveying loads over the snow or ice; -- in England called sledge.

Sled: S l e d "n. A small  light vehicle with runners used mostly by young persons for sliding on snow or ice.

Sledge: S l e d g e "n. A strong vehicle with low runners or low wheels; or one without wheels or runners  made of plank slightly turned up at one end used for transporting loads upon the snow ice or bare ground; a sled.

Sledge: S l e d g e "n. A sleigh.

Sleep: S l e e p " imp. of Sleep. Slept.

Sleep: S l e e p "v. i. To take rest by a suspension of the voluntary exercise of the powers of the body and mind  and an apathy of the organs of sense; to slumber.

Sleep: S l e e p "v. i. To be careless  inattentive or uncouncerned; not to be vigilant; to live thoughtlessly.

Sleep: S l e e p "v. i. To be dead; to lie in the grave.

Sleep: S l e e p "v. i. To be  or appear to be in repose; to be quiet; to be unemployed unused or unagitated; to rest; to lie dormant; as a question sleeps for the present; the law sleeps.

Sleep: S l e e p "v. t. To be slumbering in; -- followed by a cognate object; as  to sleep a dreamless sleep.

Sleep: S l e e p "v. t. To give sleep to; to furnish with accomodations for sleeping; to lodge.

Sleep: S l e e p "v. i. A natural and healthy  but temporary and periodical suspension of the functions of the organs of sense as well as of those of the voluntary and rational soul; that state of the animal in which there is a lessened acuteness of sensory perception a confusion of ideas and a loss of mental control followed by a more or less unconscious state.

Sleep-at-noon: S l e e p - a t - n o o n "n. A plant (Tragopogon pratensis) which closes its flowers at midday; a kind of goat's beard.

Sleep-charged: S l e e p - c h a r g e d "a. Heavy with sleep.

Sleeper: S l e e p e r "n. One who sleeps; a slumberer; hence  a drone or lazy person.

Sleeper: S l e e p e r "n. That which lies dormant  as a law.

Sleeper: S l e e p e r "n. A sleeping car.

Sleeper: S l e e p e r "n. An animal that hibernates  as the bear.

Sleeper: S l e e p e r "n. A large fresh-water gobioid fish (Eleotris dormatrix).

Sleeper: S l e e p e r "n. A nurse shark. See under Nurse.

Sleeper: S l e e p e r "n. Something lying in a reclining posture or position.

Sleeper: S l e e p e r "n. One of the pieces of timber  stone or iron on or near the level of the ground for the support of some superstructure to steady framework to keep in place the rails of a railway etc.; a stringpiece.

Sleeper: S l e e p e r "n. One of the joists  or roughly shaped timbers laid directly upon the ground to receive the flooring of the ground story.

Sleeper: S l e e p e r "n. One of the knees which connect the transoms to the after timbers on the ship's quarter.

Sleeper: S l e e p e r "n. The lowest  or bottom tier of casks.

Slide: S l i d e "v. t. To move along the surface of any body by slipping  or without walking or rolling; to slip; to glide; as snow slides down the mountain's side.

Slide: S l i d e "v. t. Especially  to move over snow or ice with a smooth uninterrupted motion as on a sled moving by the force of gravity or on the feet.

Slide: S l i d e "v. t. To pass inadvertently.

Slide: S l i d e "v. t. To pass along smoothly or unobservedly; to move gently onward without friction or hindrance; as  a ship or boat slides through the water.

Slide: S l i d e "v. t. To slip when walking or standing; to fall.

Slide: S l i d e "v. t. To pass from one note to another with no perceptible cassation of sound.

Slide: S l i d e "v. t. To pass out of one's thought as not being of any consequence.

Slide: S l i d e "v. t. To cause to slide; to thrust along; as  to slide one piece of timber along another.

Slide: S l i d e "v. t. To pass or put imperceptibly; to slip; as  to slide in a word to vary the sense of a question.

Slide: S l i d e "n. The act of sliding; as  a slide on the ice.

Slide: S l i d e "n. Smooth  even passage or progress.

Slide: S l i d e "n. That on which anything moves by sliding.

Slide: S l i d e "n. An inclined plane on which heavy bodies slide by the force of gravity  esp. one constructed on a mountain side for conveying logs by sliding them down.

Slide: S l i d e "n. A surface of ice or snow on which children slide for amusement.

Slide: S l i d e "n. That which operates by sliding.

Slide: S l i d e "n. A cover which opens or closes an aperture by sliding over it.

Slide: S l i d e "n. A moving piece which is guided by a part or parts along which it slides.

Slide: S l i d e "n. A clasp or brooch for a belt  or the like.

Slide: S l i d e "n. A plate or slip of glass on which is a picture or delineation to be exhibited by means of a magic lantern  stereopticon or the like; a plate on which is an object to be examined with a microscope.

Slide: S l i d e "n. The descent of a mass of earth  rock or snow down a hill or mountain side; as a land slide or a snow slide; also the track of bare rock left by a land slide.

Slide: S l i d e "n. A small dislocation in beds of rock along a line of fissure.

Slide: S l i d e "n. A grace consisting of two or more small notes moving by conjoint degrees  and leading to a principal note either above or below.

Slide: S l i d e "n. An apparatus in the trumpet and trombone by which the sounding tube is lengthened and shortened so as to produce the tones between the fundamental and its harmonics.

Slide: S l i d e "n. A sound which  by a gradual change in the position of the vocal organs passes imperceptibly into another sound.

Slide: S l i d e "n. Same as Guide bar  under Guide.

Slide: S l i d e "n. A slide valve.

Slider: S l i d e r "n. The red-bellied terrapin (Pseudemys rugosa).

Sliding: S l i d i n g "a. That slides or slips; gliding; moving smoothly.

Sliding: S l i d i n g "a. Slippery; elusory.

Slight: S l i g h t "superl. Not decidedly marked; not forcible; inconsiderable; unimportant; insignificant; not severe; weak; gentle; -- applied in a great variety of circumstances; as  a slight (i. e. feeble) effort; a slight (i. e. perishable) structure; a slight (i. e. not deep) impression; a slight (i. e. not convincing) argument; a slight (i. e. not thorough) examination; slight (i. e. not severe) pain and the like.

Slight: S l i g h t "superl. Foolish; silly; weak in intellect.

Sling: S l i n g "v. t. An instrument for throwing stones or other missiles  consisting of a short strap with two strings fastened to its ends or with a string fastened to one end and a light stick to the other. The missile being lodged in a hole in the strap the ends of the string are taken in the hand and the whole whirled rapidly round until by loosing one end the missile is let fly with centrifugal force.

Sling: S l i n g "v. t. The act or motion of hurling as with a sling; a throw; figuratively  a stroke.

Sling: S l i n g "v. t. A contrivance for sustaining anything by suspension

Sling: S l i n g "v. t. A kind of hanging bandage put around the neck  in which a wounded arm or hand is supported.

Sling: S l i n g "v. t. A loop of rope  or a rope or chain with hooks for suspending a barrel bale or other heavy object in hoisting or lowering.

Sling: S l i n g "v. t. A strap attached to a firearm  for suspending it from the shoulder.

Sling: S l i n g "v. t. A band of rope or iron for securing a yard to a mast; -- chiefly in the plural.

Sling: S l i n g "v. t. To throw with a sling.

Sling: S l i n g "v. t. To throw; to hurl; to cast.

Sling: S l i n g "v. t. To hang so as to swing; as  to sling a pack.

Sling: S l i n g "v. t. To pass a rope round  as a cask gun etc. preparatory to attaching a hoisting or lowering tackle.

Sling: S l i n g "n. A drink composed of spirit (usually gin) and water sweetened.

Slinger: S l i n g e r "n. One who slings  or uses a sling.

Slinging: S l i n g i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Sling

Slink: S l i n k "a. To creep away meanly; to steal away; to sneak.

Slink: S l i n k "a. To miscarry; -- said of female beasts.

Slink: S l i n k "v. t. To cast prematurely; -- said of female beasts; as  a cow that slinks her calf.

Slink: S l i n k "a. Produced prematurely; as  a slink calf.

Slink: S l i n k "a. Thin; lean.

Slink: S l i n k "n. The young of a beast brought forth prematurely  esp. a calf brought forth before its time.

Slink: S l i n k "n. A thievish fellow; a sneak.

Slip: S l i p "n. To move along the surface of a thing without bounding  rolling or stepping; to slide; to glide.

Slip: S l i p "n. To slide; to lose one's footing or one's hold; not to tread firmly; as  it is necessary to walk carefully lest the foot should slip.

Slip: S l i p "n. To move or fly (out of place); to shoot; -- often with out  off etc.; as a bone may slip out of its place.

Slip: S l i p "n. To depart  withdraw enter appear intrude or escape as if by sliding; to go or come in a quiet furtive manner; as some errors slipped into the work.

Slip: S l i p "n. To err; to fall into error or fault.

Slip: S l i p "v. t. To cause to move smoothly and quickly; to slide; to convey gently or secretly.

Slip: S l i p "v. t. To omit; to loose by negligence.

Slip: S l i p "v. t. To cut slips from; to cut; to take off; to make a slip or slips of; as  to slip a piece of cloth or paper.

Slip: S l i p "v. t. To let loose in pursuit of game  as a greyhound.

Slip: S l i p "v. t. To cause to slip or slide off  or out of place; as a horse slips his bridle; a dog slips his collar.

Slip: S l i p "v. t. To bring forth (young) prematurely; to slink.

Slip: S l i p "n. The act of slipping; as  a slip on the ice.

Slip: S l i p "n. An unintentional error or fault; a false step.

Slip: S l i p "n. A twig separated from the main stock; a cutting; a scion; hence  a descendant; as a slip from a vine.

Slip: S l i p "n. A slender piece; a strip; as  a slip of paper.

Slip: S l i p "n. A leash or string by which a dog is held; -- so called from its being made in such a manner as to slip  or become loose by relaxation of the hand.

Slip: S l i p "n. An escape; a secret or unexpected desertion; as  to give one the slip.

Slip: S l i p "n. A portion of the columns of a newspaper or other work struck off by itself; a proof from a column of type when set up and in the galley.

Slip: S l i p "n. Any covering easily slipped on.

Slip: S l i p "n. A loose garment worn by a woman.

Slip: S l i p "n. A child's pinafore.

Slip: S l i p "n. An outside covering or case; as  a pillow slip.

Slip: S l i p "n. The slip or sheath of a sword  and the like.

Slip: S l i p "n. A counterfeit piece of money  being brass covered with silver.

Slip: S l i p "n. Matter found in troughs of grindstones after the grinding of edge tools.

Slip: S l i p "n. Potter's clay in a very liquid state  used for the decoration of ceramic ware and also as a cement for handles and other applied parts.

Slip: S l i p "n. A particular quantity of yarn.

Slip: S l i p "n. An inclined plane on which a vessel is built  or upon which it is hauled for repair.

Slip: S l i p "n. An opening or space for vessels to lie in  between wharves or in a dock; as Peck slip.

Slip: S l i p "n. A narrow passage between buildings.

Slip: S l i p "n. A long seat or narrow pew in churches  often without a door.

Slip: S l i p "n. A dislocation of a lead  destroying continuity.

Slip: S l i p "n. The motion of the center of resistance of the float of a paddle wheel  or the blade of an oar through the water horozontally or the difference between a vessel's actual speed and the speed which she would have if the propelling instrument acted upon a solid; also the velocity relatively to still water of the backward current of water produced by the propeller.

Slip: S l i p "n. A fish  the sole.

Slip: S l i p "n. A fielder stationed on the off side and to the rear of the batsman. There are usually two of them  called respectively short slip and long slip.

Slip-on: S l i p - o n "n. A kind of overcoat worn upon the shoulders in the manner of a cloak.

Slipboard: S l i p b o a r d "n. A board sliding in grooves.

Slipcoat cheese: S l i p c o a t   c h e e s e " A rich variety of new cheese  resembling butter but white.

Slipes: S l i p e s "v. Sledge runners on which a skip is dragged in a mine.

Slipknot: S l i p k n o t "n. knot which slips along the rope or line around which it is made.

Slippage: S l i p p a g e "n. The act of slipping; also  the amount of slipping.

Slipper: S l i p p e r "n. One who  or that which slips.

Slipper: S l i p p e r "n. A kind of light shoe  which may be slipped on with ease and worn in undress; a slipshoe.

Slipper: S l i p p e r "n. A kind of apron or pinafore for children.

Slipper: S l i p p e r "n. A kind of brake or shoe for a wagon wheel.

Slipper: S l i p p e r "n. A piece  usually a plate applied to a sliding piece to receive wear and afford a means of adjustment; -- also called shoe and gib.

Slipper: S l i p p e r "a. Slippery.

Slipperwort: S l i p p e r w o r t "n. See Calceolaria.

Slippery: S l i p p e r y "a. Having the quality opposite to adhesiveness; allowing or causing anything to slip or move smoothly  rapidly and easily upon the surface; smooth; glib; as oily substances render things slippery.

Slippery: S l i p p e r y "a. Not affording firm ground for confidence; as  a slippery promise.

Slippery: S l i p p e r y "a. Not easily held; liable or apt to slip away.

Slippery: S l i p p e r y "a. Liable to slip; not standing firm.

Slippery: S l i p p e r y "a. Unstable; changeable; mutable; uncertain; inconstant; fickle.

Slippery: S l i p p e r y "a. Uncertain in effect.

Slippery: S l i p p e r y "a. Wanton; unchaste; loose in morals.

Slit-shell: S l i t - s h e l l "n. Any species of Pleurotomaria  a genus of beautiful pearly spiral gastropod shells having a deep slit in the outer lip. Many fossil species are known and a few living ones are found in deep water in tropical seas.

Sloe: S l o e "n. A small  bitter wild European plum the fruit of the blackthorn (Prunus spinosa); also the tree itself.

Slogan: S l o g a n "n. The war cry  or gathering word of a Highland clan in Scotland; hence any rallying cry.

Sloo: S l o o "n. Alt. of Slue

Sloom: S l o o m "n. Slumber.

Sloomy: S l o o m y "a. Sluggish; slow.

Sloop: S l o o p "n. A vessel having one mast and fore-and-aft rig  consisting of a boom-and-gaff mainsail jibs staysail and gaff topsail. The typical sloop has a fixed bowsprit topmast and standing rigging while those of a cutter are capable of being readily shifted. The sloop usually carries a centerboard and depends for stability upon breadth of beam rather than depth of keel. The two types have rapidly approximated since 1880. One radical distinction is that a slop may carry a centerboard. See Cutter and Illustration in Appendix.

Slop: S l o p "n. Water or other liquid carelessly spilled or thrown aboyt  as upon a table or a floor; a puddle; a soiled spot.

Slop: S l o p "n. Mean and weak drink or liquid food; -- usually in the plural.

Slop: S l o p "n. Dirty water; water in which anything has been washed or rinsed; water from wash-bowls  etc.

Slop: S l o p "v. t. To cause to overflow  as a liquid by the motion of the vessel containing it; to spill.

Slop: S l o p "v. t. To spill liquid upon; to soil with a liquid spilled.

Slop: S l o p "v. i. To overflow or be spilled as a liquid  by the motion of the vessel containing it; -- often with over.

Slop: S l o p "v. i. Any kind of outer garment made of linen or cotton  as a night dress or a smock frock.

Slop: S l o p "v. i. A loose lower garment; loose breeches; chiefly used in the plural.

Slop: S l o p "v. i. Ready-made clothes; also  among seamen clothing bedding and other furnishings.

Slope: S l o p e "v. i. An oblique direction; a line or direction including from a horizontal line or direction; also  sometimes an inclination as of one line or surface to another.

Slope: S l o p e "v. i. Any ground whose surface forms an angle with the plane of the horizon.

Slope: S l o p e "a. Sloping.

Slope: S l o p e "adv. In a sloping manner.

Slope: S l o p e "v. i. To take an oblique direction; to be at an angle with the plane of the horizon; to incline; as  the ground slopes.

Slope: S l o p e "v. i. To depart; to disappear suddenly.

Sloth: S l o t h "n. Slowness; tardiness.

Sloth: S l o t h "n. Disinclination to action or labor; sluggishness; laziness; idleness.

Sloth: S l o t h "n. Any one of several species of arboreal edentates constituting the family Bradypodidae  and the suborder Tardigrada. They have long exserted limbs and long prehensile claws. Both jaws are furnished with teeth (see Illust. of Edentata) and the ears and tail are rudimentary. They inhabit South and Central America and Mexico.

Sloth: S l o t h "v. i. To be idle.

Slothful: S l o t h f u l "a. Addicted to sloth; inactive; sluggish; lazy; indolent; idle.

Slough: S l o u g h "a. Slow.

Slough: S l o u g h "n. A place of deep mud or mire; a hole full of mire.

Slough: S l o u g h " imp. of Slee  to slay. Slew.

Slough: S l o u g h "n. The skin  commonly the cast-off skin of a serpent or of some similar animal.

Slough: S l o u g h "n. The dead mass separating from a foul sore; the dead part which separates from the living tissue in mortification.

Slough: S l o u g h "v. i. To form a slough; to separate in the form of dead matter from the living tissues; -- often used with off  or away; as a sloughing ulcer; the dead tissues slough off slowly.

Sloughy: S l o u g h y "a. Resembling  or of the nature of a slough or the dead matter which separates from living flesh.

Sloven: S l o v e n "n. A man or boy habitually negligent of neathess and order; -- the correlative term to slattern  or slut.

Slow: S l o w " imp. of Slee  to slay. Slew.

Slow: S l o w "superl. Moving a short space in a relatively long time; not swift; not quick in motion; not rapid; moderate; deliberate; as  a slow stream; a slow motion.

Slow: S l o w "superl. Not happening in a short time; gradual; late.

Slow: S l o w "superl. Not ready; not prompt or quick; dilatory; sluggish; as  slow of speech and slow of tongue.

Slow: S l o w "superl. Not hasty; not precipitate; acting with deliberation; tardy; inactive.

Slow: S l o w "superl. Behind in time; indicating a time earlier than the true time; as  the clock or watch is slow.

Slow: S l o w "superl. Not advancing or improving rapidly; as  the slow growth of arts and sciences.

Slow: S l o w "superl. Heavy in wit; not alert  prompt or spirited; wearisome; dull.

Slow: S l o w "adv. Slowly.

Slow: S l o w "v. t. To render slow; to slacken the speed of; to retard; to delay; as  to slow a steamer.

Slow: S l o w "v. i. To go slower; -- often with up; as  the train slowed up before crossing the bridge.

Slow: S l o w "n. A moth.

Slow-witted: S l o w - w i t t e d "a. Dull of apprehension; not possessing quick intelligence.

Slue: S l u e "n. A slough; a run or wet place. See 2d Slough  2.

Slue: S l u e "v. t. To turn about a fixed point  usually the center or axis as a spar or piece of timber; to turn; -- used also of any heavy body.

Slue: S l u e "v. t. In general  to turn about; to twist; -- often used reflexively and followed by round.

Slug: S l u g "n. A drone; a slow  lazy fellow; a sluggard.

Slug: S l u g "n. A hindrance; an obstruction.

Slug: S l u g "n. Any one of numerous species of terrestrial pulmonate mollusks belonging to Limax and several related genera  in which the shell is either small and concealed in the mantle or altogether wanting. They are closely allied to the land snails.

Slug: S l u g "n. Any smooth  soft larva of a sawfly or moth which creeps like a mollusk; as the pear slug; rose slug.

Slug: S l u g "n. A ship that sails slowly.

Slug: S l u g "n. An irregularly shaped piece of metal  used as a missile for a gun.

Slug: S l u g "n. A thick strip of metal less than type high  and as long as the width of a column or a page -- used in spacing out pages and to separate display lines etc.

Slug: S l u g "v. i. To move slowly; to lie idle.

Slug: S l u g "v. t. To make sluggish.

Slug: S l u g "v. t. To load with a slug or slugs; as  to slug a gun.

Slug: S l u g "v. t. To strike heavily.

Slug: S l u g "v. i. To become reduced in diameter  or changed in shape by passing from a larger to a smaller part of the bore of the barrel; -- said of a bullet when fired from a gun pistol or other firearm.

Slug-horn: S l u g - h o r n "a. An erroneous form of the Scotch word slughorne  or sloggorne meaning slogan.

Slugabed: S l u g a b e d "n. One who indulges in lying abed; a sluggard.

Sluggard: S l u g g a r d "n. A person habitually lazy  idle and inactive; a drone.

Sluggard: S l u g g a r d "a. Sluggish; lazy.

Sluggardize: S l u g g a r d i z e "v. t. To make lazy.

Sluggardy: S l u g g a r d y "n. The state of being a sluggard; sluggishness; sloth.

Slugged: S l u g g e d "imp. & p. p. of Slug

Slugger: S l u g g e r "n. One who strikes heavy blows; hence  a boxer; a prize fighter.

Slugging: S l u g g i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Slug

Sluggish: S l u g g i s h "a. Habitually idle and lazy; slothful; dull; inactive; as  a sluggish man.

Sluggish: S l u g g i s h "a. Slow; having little motion; as  a sluggish stream.

Sluggish: S l u g g i s h "a. Having no power to move one's self or itself; inert.

Sluggish: S l u g g i s h "a. Characteristic of a sluggard; dull; stupid; tame; simple.

Sluggy: S l u g g y "a. Sluggish.

Slugs: S l u g s "n. pl. Half-roasted ore.

Slugworm: S l u g w o r m "n. Any caterpillar which has the general appearance of a slug  as do those of certain moths belonging to Limacodes and allied genera and those of certain sawflies.

Sluice: S l u i c e "n. An artifical passage for water  fitted with a valve or gate as in a mill stream for stopping or regulating the flow; also a water gate or flood gate.

Sluice: S l u i c e "n. Hence  an opening or channel through which anything flows; a source of supply.

Sluice: S l u i c e "n. The stream flowing through a flood gate.

Sluice: S l u i c e "n. A long box or trough through which water flows  -- used for washing auriferous earth.

Sluice: S l u i c e "v. t. To emit by  or as by flood gates.

Sluice: S l u i c e "v. t. To wet copiously  as by opening a sluice; as to sluice meadows.

Sluice: S l u i c e "v. t. To wash with  or in a stream of water running through a sluice; as to sluice eart or gold dust in mining.

Sluiced: S l u i c e d "imp. & p. p. of Sluice

Sluiceway: S l u i c e w a y "n. An artificial channel into which water is let by a sluice; specifically  a trough constructed over the bed of a stream so that logs lumber or rubbish can be floated down to some convenient place of delivery.

Sluicy: S l u i c y "a. Falling copiously or in streams  as from a sluice.

Slum: S l u m "n. A foul back street of a city  especially one filled with a poor dirty degraded and often vicious population; any low neighborhood or dark retreat; -- usually in the plural; as Westminster slums are haunts for theives.

Slum: S l u m "n. Same as Slimes.

Slush: S l u s h "n. The refuse grease and fat collected in cooking  especially on shipboard.

Slush: S l u s h "n. A mixture of white lead and lime  with which the bright parts of machines such as the connecting rods of steamboats are painted to be preserved from oxidation.

Smack: S m a c k "n. A small sailing vessel  commonly rigged as a sloop used chiefly in the coasting and fishing trade.

Smack: S m a c k "v. i. Taste or flavor  esp. a slight taste or flavor; savor; tincture; as a smack of bitter in the medicine. Also used figuratively.

Smack: S m a c k "v. i. A small quantity; a taste.

Smack: S m a c k "v. i. A loud kiss; a buss.

Smack: S m a c k "v. i. A quick  sharp noise as of the lips when suddenly separated or of a whip.

Smack: S m a c k "v. i. A quick  smart blow; a slap.

Smack: S m a c k "adv. As if with a smack or slap.

Smack: S m a c k "n. To have a smack; to be tinctured with any particular taste.

Smack: S m a c k "n. To have or exhibit indications of the presence of any character or quality.

Smack: S m a c k "n. To kiss with a close compression of the lips  so as to make a sound when they separate; to kiss with a sharp noise; to buss.

Smack: S m a c k "n. To make a noise by the separation of the lips after tasting anything.

Smack: S m a c k "v. t. To kiss with a sharp noise; to buss.

Smack: S m a c k "v. t. To open  as the lips with an inarticulate sound made by a quick compression and separation of the parts of the mouth; to make a noise with as the lips by separating them in the act of kissing or after tasting.

Smack: S m a c k "v. t. To make a sharp noise by striking; to crack; as  to smack a whip.

Smacking: S m a c k i n g "a. Making a sharp  brisk sound; hence brisk; as a smacking breeze.

Small: S m a l l "superl. Having little size  compared with other things of the same kind; little in quantity or degree; diminutive; not large or extended in dimension; not great; not much; inconsiderable; as a small man; a small river.

Small: S m a l l "superl. Being of slight consequence; feeble in influence or importance; unimportant; trivial; insignificant; as  a small fault; a small business.

Small: S m a l l "superl. Envincing little worth or ability; not large-minded; -- sometimes  in reproach paltry; mean.

Small: S m a l l "superl. Not prolonged in duration; not extended in time; short; as  after a small space.

Small: S m a l l "superl. Weak; slender; fine; gentle; soft; not loud.

Small: S m a l l "adv. In or to small extent  quantity or degree; little; slightly.

Small: S m a l l "adv. Not loudly; faintly; timidly.

Small: S m a l l "n. The small or slender part of a thing; as  the small of the leg or of the back.

Smallage: S m a l l a g e "n. A biennial umbelliferous plant (Apium graveolens) native of the seacoats of Europe and Asia. When deprived of its acrid and even poisonous properties by cultivation  it becomes celery.

Smallclothes: S m a l l c l o t h e s "n. pl. A man's garment for the hips and thighs; breeches. See Breeches.

Smallish: S m a l l i s h "a. Somewhat small.

Smallness: S m a l l n e s s "n. The quality or state of being small.

Smallpox: S m a l l p o x "n. A contagious  constitutional febrile disease characterized by a peculiar eruption; variola. The cutaneous eruption is at first a collection of papules which become vesicles (first flat subsequently umbilicated) and then pustules and finally thick crusts which slough after a certain time often leaving a pit or scar.

Smalls: S m a l l s "n. pl. See Small  n. 2 3.

Smallsword: S m a l l s w o r d "n. A light sword used for thrusting only; especially  the sword worn by civilians of rank in the eighteenth century.

Smally: S m a l l y "adv. In a small quantity or degree; with minuteness.

Smalt: S m a l t "v. t. A deep blue pigment or coloring material used in various arts. It is a vitreous substance made of cobalt  potash and calcined quartz fused and reduced to a powder.

Smalt-blue: S m a l t - b l u e "a. Deep blue  like smalt.

Smaltine: S m a l t i n e "n. Alt. of Smaltite

Smaltite: S m a l t i t e "n. A tin-white or gray mineral of metallic luster. It is an arsenide of cobalt  nickel and iron. Called also speiskobalt.

Smaragdite: S m a r a g d i t e "n. A green foliated kind of amphibole  observed in eclogite and some varietis of gabbro.

Smart: S m a r t "v. t. To cause a smart in.

Smart: S m a r t "v. i. Marked by acuteness or shrewdness; quick in suggestion or reply; vivacious; witty; as  a smart reply; a smart saying.

Smart: S m a r t "v. i. Pretentious; showy; spruce; as  a smart gown.

Smart: S m a r t "v. i. Brisk; fresh; as  a smart breeze.

Smartweed: S m a r t w e e d "n. An acrid plant of the genus Polygonum (P. Hydropiper)  which produces smarting if applied where the skin is tender.

Smelt: S m e l t "n. Any one of numerous species of small silvery salmonoid fishes of the genus Osmerus and allied genera  which ascend rivers to spawn and sometimes become landlocked in lakes. They are esteemed as food and have a peculiar odor and taste.

Smilax: S m i l a x "n. A genus of perennial climbing plants  usually with a prickly woody stem; green brier or cat brier. The rootstocks of certain species are the source of the medicine called sarsaparilla.

Smilax: S m i l a x "n. A delicate trailing plant (Myrsiphyllum asparagoides) much used for decoration. It is a native of the Cape of Good Hope.

Smile: S m i l e "v. i. A somewhat similar expression of countenance  indicative of satisfaction combined with malevolent feelings as contempt scorn etc; as a scornful smile.

Smite: S m i t e "v. t. To strike; to inflict a blow upon with the hand  or with any instrument held in the hand or with a missile thrown by the hand; as to smite with the fist with a rod sword spear or stone.

Smite: S m i t e "v. t. To cause to strike; to use as an instrument in striking or hurling.

Smite: S m i t e "v. t. To destroy the life of by beating  or by weapons of any kind; to slay by a blow; to kill; as to smite one with the sword or with an arrow or other instrument.

Smite: S m i t e "v. t. To put to rout in battle; to overthrow by war.

Smithsonite: S m i t h s o n i t e "n. Native zinc carbonate. It generally occurs in stalactitic  reniform or botryoidal shapes of a white to gray green or brown color. See Note under Calamine.

Smoke: S m o k e "n. The visible exhalation  vapor or substance that escapes or expelled from a burning body especially from burning vegetable matter as wood coal peat or the like.

Smoke: S m o k e "n. That which resembles smoke; a vapor; a mist.

Smoke: S m o k e "n. Anything unsubstantial  as idle talk.

Smoke: S m o k e "n. The act of smoking  esp. of smoking tobacco; as to have a smoke.

Smoke: S m o k e "n. To emit smoke; to throw off volatile matter in the form of vapor or exhalation; to reek.

Smoke: S m o k e "n. Hence  to burn; to be kindled; to rage.

Smoke: S m o k e "n. To raise a dust or smoke by rapid motion.

Smoke: S m o k e "n. To draw into the mouth the smoke of tobacco burning in a pipe or in the form of a cigar  cigarette etc.; to habitually use tobacco in this manner.

Smoke: S m o k e "n. To suffer severely; to be punished.

Smoke: S m o k e "v. t. To fill or scent with smoke; hence  to fill with incense; to perfume.

Smoke: S m o k e "v. t. To smell out; to hunt out; to find out; to detect.

Smoke: S m o k e "v. t. To ridicule to the face; to quiz.

Smut: S m u t "v. t. Foul matter  like soot or coal dust; also a spot or soil made by such matter.

Smut: S m u t "v. t. Bad  soft coal containing much earthy matter found in the immediate locality of faults.

Smut: S m u t "v. t. An affection of cereal grains producing a swelling which is at length resolved into a powdery sooty mass. It is caused by parasitic fungi of the genus Ustilago. Ustilago segetum  or U. Carbo is the commonest kind; that of Indian corn is Ustilago maydis.

Smut: S m u t "v. t. Obscene language; ribaldry; obscenity.

Smut: S m u t "v. t. To stain or mark with smut; to blacken with coal  soot or other dirty substance.

Smut: S m u t "v. t. To taint with mildew  as grain.

Smut: S m u t "v. t. To blacken; to sully or taint; to tarnish.

Smut: S m u t "v. t. To clear of smut; as  to smut grain for the mill.

Smut: S m u t "v. i. To gather smut; to be converted into smut; to become smutted.

Smut: S m u t "v. i. To give off smut; to crock.

Snag: S n a g "n. A tooth projecting beyond the rest; contemptuously  a broken or decayed tooth.

Snag: S n a g "n. A tree  or a branch of a tree fixed in the bottom of a river or other navigable water and rising nearly or quite to the surface by which boats are sometimes pierced and sunk.

Snag: S n a g "n. One of the secondary branches of an antler.

Snail: S n a i l "n. Any one of numerous species of terrestrial air-breathing gastropods belonging to the genus Helix and many allied genera of the family Helicidae. They are abundant in nearly all parts of the world except the arctic regions  and feed almost entirely on vegetation; a land snail.

Snail: S n a i l "n. Any gastropod having a general resemblance to the true snails  including fresh-water and marine species. See Pond snail under Pond and Sea snail.

Snail: S n a i l "n. Hence  a drone; a slow-moving person or thing.

Snail: S n a i l "n. A spiral cam  or a flat piece of metal of spirally curved outline used for giving motion to or changing the position of another part as the hammer tail of a striking clock.

Snail: S n a i l "n. A tortoise; in ancient warfare  a movable roof or shed to protect besiegers; a testudo.

Snail: S n a i l "n. The pod of the sanil clover.

Snail-like: S n a i l - l i k e "a. Like or suiting a snail; as  snail-like progress.

Snail-like: S n a i l - l i k e "adv. In the manner of a snail; slowly.

Snail-paced: S n a i l - p a c e d "a. Slow-moving  like a snail.

Snailfish: S n a i l f i s h "n. See Sea snail (a).

Snake: S n a k e "n. Any species of the order Ophidia; an ophidian; a serpent  whether harmless or venomous. See Ophidia and Serpent.

Snake: S n a k e "v. t. To drag or draw  as a snake from a hole; -- often with out.

Snake: S n a k e "v. t. To wind round spirally  as a large rope with a smaller or with cord the small rope lying in the spaces between the strands of the large one; to worm.

Snake: S n a k e "v. i. To crawl like a snake.

Snake's-head: S n a k e ' s - h e a d "n. The Guinea-hen flower; -- so called in England because its spotted petals resemble the scales of a snake's head.

Snake's-tongue: S n a k e ' s - t o n g u e "n. Same as Adder's-tongue.

Snakebird: S n a k e b i r d "n. Any one of four species of aquatic birds of the genus Anhinga or Plotus. They are allied to the gannets and cormorants  but have very long slender flexible necks and sharp bills.

Snakebird: S n a k e b i r d "n. The wryneck.

Snakefish: S n a k e f i s h "n. The band fish.

Snakefish: S n a k e f i s h "n. The lizard fish.

Snakehead: S n a k e h e a d "n. A loose  bent-up end of one of the strap rails or flat rails formerly used on American railroads. It was sometimes so bent by the passage of a train as to slip over a wheel and pierce the bottom of a car.

Snakehead: S n a k e h e a d "n. The turtlehead.

Snakehead: S n a k e h e a d "n. The Guinea-hen flower. See Snake's-head  and under Guinea.

Snakeneck: S n a k e n e c k "n. The snakebird  1.

Snakeroot: S n a k e r o o t "n. Any one of several plants of different genera and species  most of which are (or were formerly) reputed to be efficacious as remedies for the bites of serpents; also the roots of any of these.

Snakestone: S n a k e s t o n e "n. A kind of hone slate or whetstone obtained in Scotland.

Snakestone: S n a k e s t o n e "n. An ammonite; -- so called from its form  which resembles that of a coiled snake.

Snakeweed: S n a k e w e e d "n. A kind of knotweed (Polygonum Bistorta).

Snakeweed: S n a k e w e e d "n. The Virginia snakeroot. See Snakeroot.

Snakewood: S n a k e w o o d "n. An East Indian climbing plant (Strychnos colubrina) having a bitter taste  and supposed to be a remedy for the bite of the hooded serpent.

Snakewood: S n a k e w o o d "n. An East Indian climbing shrub (Ophioxylon serpentinum) which has the roots and stems twisted so as to resemble serpents.

Snakewood: S n a k e w o o d "n. Same as Trumpetwood.

Snakewood: S n a k e w o o d "n. A tropical American shrub (Plumieria rubra) which has very fragrant red blossoms.

Snakewood: S n a k e w o o d "n. Same as Letterwood.

Snakish: S n a k i s h "a. Having the qualities or characteristics of a snake; snaky.

Snaky: S n a k y "a. Of or pertaining to a snake or snakes; resembling a snake; serpentine; winding.

Snaky: S n a k y "a. Covered with serpents; having serpents; as  a snaky rod or wand.

Snap: S n a p "n. To break at once; to break short  as substances that are brittle.

Snap: S n a p "n. To strike  to hit or to shut with a sharp sound.

Snap: S n a p "n. To bite or seize suddenly  especially with the teeth.

Snap: S n a p "n. To break upon suddenly with sharp  angry words; to treat snappishly; -- usually with up.

Snap: S n a p "n. To crack; to cause to make a sharp  cracking noise; as to snap a whip.

Snap: S n a p "n. To project with a snap.

Snap: S n a p "v. i. To break short  or at once; to part asunder suddenly; as a mast snaps; a needle snaps.

Snap: S n a p "v. i. To give forth  or produce a sharp cracking noise; to crack; as blazing firewood snaps.

Snap: S n a p "v. i. To make an effort to bite; to aim to seize with the teeth; to catch eagerly (at anything); -- often with at; as  a dog snapsat a passenger; a fish snaps at the bait.

Snap: S n a p "v. i. To utter sharp  harsh angry words; -- often with at; as to snap at a child.

Snap: S n a p "v. i. To miss fire; as  the gun snapped.

Snap: S n a p "v. t. A sudden breaking or rupture of any substance.

Snap: S n a p "v. t. A sudden  eager bite; a sudden seizing or effort to seize as with the teeth.

Snap: S n a p "v. t. A sudden  sharp motion or blow as with the finger sprung from the thumb or the thumb from the finger.

Snap: S n a p "v. t. A sharp  abrupt sound as that made by the crack of a whip; as the snap of the trigger of a gun.

Snap: S n a p "v. t. A greedy fellow.

Snap: S n a p "v. t. That which is  or may be snapped up; something bitten off seized or obtained by a single quick movement; hence a bite morsel or fragment; a scrap.

Snap: S n a p "v. t. A sudden severe interval or spell; -- applied to the weather; as  a cold snap.

Snap: S n a p "v. t. A small catch or fastening held or closed by means of a spring  or one which closes with a snapping sound as the catch of a bracelet necklace clasp of a book etc.

Snap: S n a p "v. t. A snap beetle.

Snap: S n a p "v. t. A thin  crisp cake usually small and flavored with ginger; -- used chiefly in the plural.

Snap: S n a p "v. t. Briskness; vigor; energy; decision.

Snap: S n a p "v. t. Any circumstance out of which money may be made or an advantage gained.

Snapdragon: S n a p d r a g o n "n. Any plant of the scrrophulariaceous genus Antirrhinum  especially the cultivated A. majus whose showy flowers are fancifully likened to the face of a dragon.

Snapdragon: S n a p d r a g o n "n. A West Indian herb (Ruellia tuberosa) with curiously shaped blue flowers.

Snapdragon: S n a p d r a g o n "n. A play in which raisins are snatched from a vessel containing burning brandy  and eaten; also that which is so eaten. See Flapdragon.

Snape: S n a p e "v. t. To bevel the end of a timber to fit against an inclined surface.

Snaphance: S n a p h a n c e "n. A spring lock for discharging a firearm; also  the firearm to which it is attached.

Snaphance: S n a p h a n c e "n. A trifling or second-rate thing or person.

Snaphead: S n a p h e a d "n. A hemispherical or rounded head to a rivet or bolt; also  a swaging tool with a cavity in its face for forming such a rounded head.

Snapped: S n a p p e d "imp. & p. p. of Snap

Snapper: S n a p p e r "n. One who  or that which snaps; as a snapper up of trifles; the snapper of a whip.

Snapper: S n a p p e r "n. Any one of several species of large sparoid food fishes of the genus Lutjanus  abundant on the southern coasts of the United States and on both coasts of tropical America.

Snapper: S n a p p e r "n. A snapping turtle; as  the alligator snapper.

Snapper: S n a p p e r "n. The green woodpecker  or yaffle.

Snapper: S n a p p e r "n. A snap beetle.

Snar: S n a r "v. i. To snarl.

Snare: S n a r e "n. A contrivance  often consisting of a noose of cord or the like by which a bird or other animal may be entangled and caught; a trap; a gin.

Snare: S n a r e "n. Hence  anything by which one is entangled and brought into trouble.

Snare: S n a r e "n. The gut or string stretched across the lower head of a drum.

Snare: S n a r e "n. An instrument  consisting usually of a wireloop or noose for removing tumors etc. by avulsion.

Snare: S n a r e "v. t. To catch with a snare; to insnare; to entangle; hence  to bring into unexpected evil perplexity or danger.

Snarl: S n a r l "v. t. To entangle; to complicate; to involve in knots; as  to snarl a skein of thread.

Snarl: S n a r l "v. t. To embarrass; to insnare.

Snarl: S n a r l "n. A knot or complication of hair  thread or the like difficult to disentangle; entanglement; hence intricate complication; embarrassing difficulty.

Snarl: S n a r l "v. i. To growl  as an angry or surly dog; to gnarl; to utter grumbling sounds.

Sneezing: S n e e z i n g "n. The act of violently forcing air out through the nasal passages while the cavity of the mouth is shut off from the pharynx by the approximation of the soft palate and the base of the tongue.

Snobbery: S n o b b e r y "n. The quality of being snobbish; snobbishness.

Snore: S n o r e "v. i. To breathe with a rough  hoarse nasal voice in sleep.

Snore: S n o r e "n. A harsh nasal noise made in sleep.

Snored: S n o r e d "imp. & p. p. of Snore

Snorer: S n o r e r "n. One who snores.

Snoring: S n o r i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Snore

Snoring: S n o r i n g "n. The act of respiring through the open mouth so that the currents of inspired and expired air cause a vibration of the uvula and soft palate  thus giving rise to a sound more or less harsh. It is usually unvoluntary but may be produced voluntarily.

Snort: S n o r t "v. i. To force the air with violence through the nose  so as to make a noise as do high-spirited horsed in prancing and play.

Snort: S n o r t "v. i. To snore.

Snort: S n o r t "v. i. To laugh out loudly.

Snort: S n o r t "n. The act of snorting; the sound produced in snorting.

Snort: S n o r t "v. t. To expel throught the nostrils with a snort; to utter with a snort.

Snorter: S n o r t e r "n. The wheather; -- so called from its cry.

Snorting: S n o r t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Snort

Snot: S n o t "n. Mucus secreted in  or discharged from the nose.

Snot: S n o t "n. A mean  insignificant fellow.

Snot: S n o t "v. t. To blow  wipe or clear as the nose.

Snotter: S n o t t e r "v. i. To snivel; to cry or whine.

Snotter: S n o t t e r "n. A rope going over a yardarm  used to bend a tripping line to in sending down topgallant and royal yards in vessels of war; also the short line supporting the heel of the sprit in a small boat.

Snottery: S n o t t e r y "n. Filth; abomination.

Snotty: S n o t t y "a. Foul with snot; hence  mean; dirty.

Snout: S n o u t "n. The long  projecting nose of a beast as of swine.

Snout: S n o u t "n. The nose of a man; -- in contempt.

Snout: S n o u t "n. The nozzle of a pipe  hose etc.

Snout: S n o u t "n. The anterior prolongation of the head of a gastropod; -- called also rostrum.

Snout: S n o u t "n. The anterior prolongation of the head of weevils and allied beetles.

Snout: S n o u t "v. t. To furnish with a nozzle or point.

Snouty: S n o u t y "a. Resembling a beast's snout.

Snow: S n o w "n. A square-rigged vessel  differing from a brig only in that she has a trysail mast close abaft the mainmast on which a large trysail is hoisted.

Snow: S n o w "n. Watery particles congealed into white or transparent crystals or flakes in the air  and falling to the earth exhibiting a great variety of very beautiful and perfect forms.

Snow: S n o w "n. Fig.: Something white like snow  as the white color (argent) in heraldry; something which falls in or as in flakes.

Snow: S n o w "v. i. To fall in or as snow; -- chiefly used impersonally; as  it snows; it snowed yesterday.

Snow: S n o w "v. t. To scatter like snow; to cover with  or as with snow.

Snow-blind: S n o w - b l i n d "a. Affected with blindness by the brilliancy of snow.

Snow-bound: S n o w - b o u n d "a. Enveloped in  or confined by snow.

Snow-broth: S n o w - b r o t h "n. Snow and water mixed  or snow just melted; very cold liquor.

Snow-capped: S n o w - c a p p e d "a. Having the top capped or covered with snow; as  snow-capped mountains.

Snow-white: S n o w - w h i t e "a. White as snow; very white.

Snowball: S n o w b a l l "n. A round mass of snow pressed or roller together  or anything resembling such a mass.

Snowball: S n o w b a l l "n. The Guelder-rose.

Snowball: S n o w b a l l "v. t. To pelt with snowballs; to throw snowballs at.

Snowball: S n o w b a l l "v. i. To throw snowballs.

Snowballed: S n o w b a l l e d "imp. & p. p. of Snowball

Snowballing: S n o w b a l l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Snowball

Snowberry: S n o w b e r r y "n. A name of several shrubs with white berries; as  the Symphoricarpus racemosus of the Northern United States and the Chiococca racemosa of Florida and tropical America.

Snowbird: S n o w b i r d "n. An arctic finch (Plectrophenax  / Plectrophanes nivalis) common in winter both in Europe and the United States and often appearing in large flocks during snowstorms. It is partially white but variously marked with chestnut and brown. Called also snow bunting snowflake snowfleck and snowflight.

Snowbird: S n o w b i r d "n. Any finch of the genus Junco which appears in flocks in winter time  especially J. hyemalis in the Eastern United States; -- called also blue snowbird. See Junco.

Snowbird: S n o w b i r d "n. The fieldfare.

Snowcap: S n o w c a p "n. A very small humming bird (Microchaera albocoronata) native of New Grenada.

Snowdrift: S n o w d r i f t "n. A bank of drifted snow.

Snowdrop: S n o w d r o p "n. A bulbous plant (Galanthus nivalis) bearing white flowers  which often appear while the snow is on the ground. It is cultivated in gardens for its beauty.

Snowed: S n o w e d "imp. & p. p. of Snow

Snowflake: S n o w f l a k e "n. A flake  or small filmy mass of snow.

Snowflake: S n o w f l a k e "n. See Snowbird  1.

Snowflake: S n o w f l a k e "n. A name given to several bulbous plants of the genus Leucoium (L. vernum  aestivum etc.) resembling the snowdrop but having all the perianth leaves of equal size.

Snowfleck: S n o w f l e c k "n. See Snowbird  1.

Snowplow: S n o w p l o w "n. Alt. of Snowplough

Snowshed: S n o w s h e d "n. A shelter to protect from snow  esp. a long roof over an exposed part of a railroad.

Snowshoe: S n o w s h o e "n. A slight frame of wood three or four feet long and about one third as wide  with thongs or cords stretched across it and having a support and holder for the foot; -- used by persons for walking on soft snow.

Snowshoeing: S n o w s h o e i n g "n. Traveling on snowshoes.

Snowshoer: S n o w s h o e r "n. One who travels on snowshoes; an expert in using snowshoes.

Snowslip: S n o w s l i p "n. A large mass or avalanche of snow which slips down the side of a mountain  etc.

Snowstorm: S n o w s t o r m "n. A storm with falling snow.

Snowy: S n o w y "a. White like snow.

Snowy: S n o w y "a. Abounding with snow; covered with snow.

Snowy: S n o w y "a. Fig.: Pure; unblemished; unstained; spotless.

Snuff: S n u f f "v. i. To inhale air through the nose with violence or with noise  as do dogs and horses.

Snuff: S n u f f "v. i. To turn up the nose and inhale air  as an expression of contempt; hence to take offense.

Snuff: S n u f f "n. The act of snuffing; perception by snuffing; a sniff.

Snuff: S n u f f "n. Pulverized tobacco  etc. prepared to be taken into the nose; also the amount taken at once.

Snuff: S n u f f "n. Resentment  displeasure or contempt expressed by a snuffing of the nose.

So: S o "adv. In that manner or degree; as  indicated (in any way) or as implied or as supposed to be known.

So: S o "adv. In like manner or degree; in the same way; thus; for like reason; whith equal reason; -- used correlatively  following as to denote comparison or resemblance; sometimes also following inasmuch as.

So: S o "adv. In such manner; to such degree; -- used correlatively with as or that following; as  he was so fortunate as to escape.

So: S o "adv. Very; in a high degree; that is  in such a degree as can not well be expressed; as he is so good; he planned so wisely.

So: S o "adv. In the same manner; as has been stated or suggested; in this or that condition or state; under these circumstances; in this way; -- with reflex reference to something just asserted or implied; used also with the verb to be  as a predicate.

So: S o "adv. The case being such; therefore; on this account; for this reason; on these terms; -- used both as an adverb and a conjuction.

So: S o "adv. It is well; let it be as it is  or let it come to pass; -- used to express assent.

So: S o "adv. Well; the fact being as stated; -- used as an expletive; as  so the work is done is it?

So: S o "adv. Is it thus? do you mean what you say? -- with an upward tone; as  do you say he refuses? So?

So: S o "adv. About the number  time or quantity specified; thereabouts; more or less; as I will spend a week or so in the country; I have read only a page or so.

So: S o "conj. Provided that; on condition that; in case that; if.

So: S o "interj. Be as you are; stand still; stop; that will do; right as you are; -- a word used esp. to cows; also used by sailors.

So-called: S o - c a l l e d "a. So named; called by such a name (but perhaps called thus with doubtful propriety).

So-so: S o - s o "a. Neither very good nor very bad; middling; passable; tolerable; indifferent.

So-so: S o - s o "adv. Tolerably; passably.

Soak: S o a k "v. t. To cause or suffer to lie in a fluid till the substance has imbibed what it can contain; to macerate in water or other liquid; to steep  as for the purpose of softening or freshening; as to soak cloth; to soak bread; to soak salt meat salt fish or the like.

Soak: S o a k "v. t. To drench; to wet thoroughly.

Soak: S o a k "v. t. To draw in by the pores  or through small passages; as a sponge soaks up water; the skin soaks in moisture.

Soak: S o a k "v. t. To make (its way) by entering pores or interstices; -- often with through.

Soak: S o a k "v. t. Fig.: To absorb; to drain.

Soak: S o a k "v. i. To lie steeping in water or other liquid; to become sturated; as  let the cloth lie and soak.

Soak: S o a k "v. i. To enter (into something) by pores or interstices; as  water soaks into the earth or other porous matter.

Soak: S o a k "v. i. To drink intemperately or gluttonously.

Soaker: S o a k e r "n. A hard drinker.

Soaking: S o a k i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Soak

Soaking: S o a k i n g "a. Wetting thoroughly; drenching; as  a soaking rain.

Soaky: S o a k y "a. Full of moisture; wet; soppy.

Soal: S o a l "n. A dirty pond.

Soam: S o a m "n. A chain by which a leading horse draws a plow.

Soap: S o a p "n. A substance which dissolves in water  thus forming a lather and is used as a cleansing agent. Soap is produced by combining fats or oils with alkalies or alkaline earths usually by boiling and consists of salts of sodium potassium etc. with the fatty acids (oleic stearic palmitic etc.). See the Note below and cf. Saponification. By extension

Soap: S o a p "v. t. To rub or wash over with soap.

Soap: S o a p "v. t. To flatter; to wheedle.

Soapberry tree: S o a p b e r r y   t r e e " Any tree of the genus Sapindus  esp. Sapindus saponaria the fleshy part of whose fruit is used instead of soap in washing linen; -- also called soap tree.

Soaped: S o a p e d "imp. & p. p. of Soap

Soapfish: S o a p f i s h "n. Any serranoid fish of the genus Rhypticus; -- so called from the soapy feeling of its skin.

Soapiness: S o a p i n e s s "n. Quality or state of being soapy.

Soaping: S o a p i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Soap

Soaproot: S o a p r o o t "n. A perennial herb (Gypsophila Struthium) the root of which is used in Spain as a substitute for soap.

Soapstone: S o a p s t o n e "n. See Steatite  and Talc.

Soapsuds: S o a p s u d s "n. pl. Suds made with soap.

Soapwort: S o a p w o r t "n. A common plant (Saponaria officinalis) of the Pink family; -- so called because its bruised leaves  when agitated in water produce a lather like that from soap. Called also Bouncing Bet.

Soapy: S o a p y "superl. Resembling soap; having the qualities of  or feeling like soap; soft and smooth.

Soapy: S o a p y "superl. Smeared with soap; covered with soap.

Sobbing: S o b b i n g "n. A series of short  convulsive inspirations the glottis being suddenly closed so that little or no air enters into the lungs.

Sober: S o b e r "superl. Temperate in the use of spirituous liquors; habitually temperate; as  a sober man.

Sober: S o b e r "superl. Not intoxicated or excited by spirituous liquors; as  the sot may at times be sober.

Sober: S o b e r "superl. Not mad or insane; not wild  visionary or heated with passion; exercising cool dispassionate reason; self-controlled; self-possessed.

Sober: S o b e r "superl. Not proceeding from  or attended with passion; calm; as sober judgment; a man in his sober senses.

Soc: S o c "n. The lord's power or privilege of holding a court in a district  as in manor or lordship; jurisdiction of causes and the limits of that jurisdiction.

Soc: S o c "n. Liberty or privilege of tenants excused from customary burdens.

Soc: S o c "n. An exclusive privilege formerly claimed by millers of grinding all the corn used within the manor or township which the mill stands.

Socage: S o c a g e "n. A tenure of lands and tenements by a certain or determinate service; a tenure distinct from chivalry or knight's service  in which the obligations were uncertain. The service must be certain in order to be denominated socage as to hold by fealty and twenty shillings rent.

Socager: S o c a g e r "n. A tennant by socage; a socman.

Sociability: S o c i a b i l i t y "n. The quality of being sociable; sociableness.

Sociable: S o c i a b l e "n. A gathering of people for social purposes; an informal party or reception; as  a church sociable.

Sociable: S o c i a b l e "n. A carriage having two double seats facing each other  and a box for the driver.

Sociableness: S o c i a b l e n e s s "n. The quality of being sociable.

Sociably: S o c i a b l y "adv. In a sociable manner.

Social: S o c i a l "a. Of or pertaining to society; relating to men living in society  or to the public as an aggregate body; as social interest or concerns; social pleasure; social benefits; social happiness; social duties.

Social: S o c i a l "a. Ready or disposed to mix in friendly converse; companionable; sociable; as  a social person.

Social: S o c i a l "a. Consisting in union or mutual intercourse.

Social: S o c i a l "a. Naturally growing in groups or masses; -- said of many individual plants of the same species.

Social: S o c i a l "a. Living in communities consisting of males  females and neuters as do ants and most bees.

Social: S o c i a l "a. Forming compound groups or colonies by budding from basal processes or stolons; as  the social ascidians.

Socialism: S o c i a l i s m "n. A theory or system of social reform which contemplates a complete reconstruction of society  with a more just and equitable distribution of property and labor. In popular usage the term is often employed to indicate any lawless revolutionary social scheme. See Communism Fourierism Saint-Simonianism forms of socialism.

Socialist: S o c i a l i s t "n. One who advocates or practices the doctrines of socialism.

Socialist: S o c i a l i s t "a. Alt. of Socialistic

Socialistic: S o c i a l i s t i c "a. Pertaining to  or of the nature of socialism.

Sociality: S o c i a l i t y "n. The quality of being social; socialness.

Socialize: S o c i a l i z e "v. t. To render social.

Socialize: S o c i a l i z e "v. t. To subject to  or regulate by socialism.

Socially: S o c i a l l y "adv. In a social manner; sociably.

Socialness: S o c i a l n e s s "n. The quality or state of being social.

Sociate: S o c i a t e "a. Associated.

Societies: S o c i e t i e s "pl. "of Society

Society: S o c i e t y "n. The relationship of men to one another when associated in any way; companionship; fellowship; company.

Society: S o c i e t y "n. Connection; participation; partnership.

Society: S o c i e t y "n. A number of persons associated for any temporary or permanent object; an association for mutual or joint usefulness  pleasure or profit; a social union; a partnership; as a missionary society.

Society: S o c i e t y "n. The persons  collectively considered who live in any region or at any period; any community of individuals who are united together by a common bond of nearness or intercourse; those who recognize each other as associates friends and acquaintances.

Society: S o c i e t y "n. Specifically  the more cultivated portion of any community in its social relations and influences; those who mutually give receive formal entertainments.

Socinian: S o c i n i a n "a. Of or pertaining to Socinus  or the Socinians.

Socinian: S o c i n i a n "n. One of the followers of Socinus; a believer in Socinianism.

Socinianism: S o c i n i a n i s m "n. The tenets or doctrines of Faustus Socinus  an Italian theologian of the sixteenth century who denied the Trinity the deity of Christ the personality of the Devil the native and total depravity of man the vicarious atonement and the eternity of future punishment. His theory was that Christ was a man divinely commissioned who had no existence before he was conceived by the Virgin Mary; that human sin was the imitation of Adam's sin and that human salvation was the imitation and adoption of Christ's virtue; that the Bible was to be interpreted by human reason; and that its language was metaphorical and not to be taken literally.

Socinianize: S o c i n i a n i z e "v. t. To cause to conform to Socinianism; to regulate by  or imbue with the principles of Socinianism.

Socinianized: S o c i n i a n i z e d "imp. & p. p. of Socinianize

Socinianizing: S o c i n i a n i z i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Socinianize

Sociologic: S o c i o l o g i c "a. Alt. of Sociological

Sociological: S o c i o l o g i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to sociology  or social science.

Sociologist: S o c i o l o g i s t "n. One who treats of  or devotes himself to the study of sociology.

Sociology: S o c i o l o g y "n. That branch of philosophy which treats of the constitution  phenomena and development of human society; social science.

Sock: S o c k "n. A plowshare.

Sock: S o c k "n. The shoe worn by actors of comedy in ancient Greece and Rome  -- used as a symbol of comedy or of the comic drama as distinguished from tragedy which is symbolized by the buskin.

Sock: S o c k "n. A knit or woven covering for the foot and lower leg; a stocking with a short leg.

Sock: S o c k "n. A warm inner sole for a shoe.

Sockdolager: S o c k d o l a g e r "n. A combination of two hooks which close upon each other  by means of a spring as soon as the fish bites.

Socket: S o c k e t "n. Especially  the hollow tube or place in which a candle is fixed in the candlestick.
