Spent: S p e n t "a. Exhausted of spawn or sperm; -- said especially of fishes.

Sper: S p e r "v. t. Alt. of Sperre

Sperable: S p e r a b l e "a. Within the range of hpe; proper to be hoped for.

Sperable: S p e r a b l e "n. See Sperable.

Sperage: S p e r a g e "n. Asperagus.

Sperate: S p e r a t e "a. Hoped for  or to be hoped for.

Spere: S p e r e "v. i. To search; to pry; to ask; to inquire.

Spere: S p e r e "n. A sphere.

Sperge: S p e r g e "n. A charge of wash for the still.

Sperling: S p e r l i n g "n. A smelt; a sparling.

Sperling: S p e r l i n g "n. A young herring.

Sperm: S p e r m "n. The male fecundating fluid; semen. See Semen.

Sperm: S p e r m "n. Spermaceti.

Sperm whale: S p e r m   w h a l e " A very large toothed whale (Physeter macrocephalus)  having a head of enormous size. The upper jaw is destitute of teeth. In the upper part of the head above the skull there is a large cavity or case filled with oil and spermaceti. This whale sometimes grows to the length of more than eighty feet. It is found in the warmer parts of all the oceans. Called also cachalot and spermaceti whale.

Spermaceti: S p e r m a c e t i "n. A white waxy substance obtained from cavities in the head of the sperm whale  and used making candles oilments cosmetics etc. It consists essentially of ethereal salts of palmitic acid with ethal and other hydrocarbon bases. The substance of spermaceti after the removal of certain impurities is sometimes called cetin.

Spermalist: S p e r m a l i s t "n. See Spermist.

Spermaphore: S p e r m a p h o r e "n. That part of the ovary from which the ovules arise; the placenta.

Spermary: S p e r m a r y "n. An organ in which spermatozoa are developed; a sperm gland; a testicle.

Spermatheca: S p e r m a t h e c a "n. A small sac connected with the female reproductive organs of insects and many other invertebrates  serving to receive and retain the spermatozoa.

Spermathecae: S p e r m a t h e c a e "pl. "of Spermatheca

Spermatia: S p e r m a t i a "pl. "of Spermatium

Spermatic: S p e r m a t i c "a. Of or pertaining to semen; as  the spermatic fluid the spermatic vessels etc.

Spermatical: S p e r m a t i c a l "a. Spermatic.

Spermatin: S p e r m a t i n "n. A substance allied to alkali albumin and to mucin  present in semen to which it is said to impart the mucilaginous character.

Spermatism: S p e r m a t i s m "n. The emission of sperm  or semen.

Spermatium: S p e r m a t i u m "n. One of the motionless spermatozoids in the conceptacles of certain fungi.

Spermatize: S p e r m a t i z e "v. i. To yield seed; to emit seed  or sperm.

Spermato-: S p e r m a t o - " Alt. of Spermo-

Spermatoa: S p e r m a t o a "pl. "of Spermatoon

Spermatoblast: S p e r m a t o b l a s t "n. Same as Spermoblast.

Spermatocyte: S p e r m a t o c y t e "n. Same as Spermoblast.

Spermatogemma: S p e r m a t o g e m m a "n. Same as Spermosphere.

Spermatogenesis: S p e r m a t o g e n e s i s "n. The development of the spermatozoids.

Spermatogenetic: S p e r m a t o g e n e t i c "a. Relating to  or connected with spermatogenesis; as spermatogenetic function.

Spermatogenous: S p e r m a t o g e n o u s "a. Sperm-producing.

Spermatogonium: S p e r m a t o g o n i u m "n. A primitive seminal cell  occuring in masses in the seminal tubules. It divides into a mass (spermosphere) of small cells (spermoblast) which in turn give rise to spermatozoids.

Spermatoid: S p e r m a t o i d "a. Spermlike; resembling sperm  or semen.

Spermatoon: S p e r m a t o o n "n. A spermoblast.

Spermatophore: S p e r m a t o p h o r e "n. Same as Spermospore.

Spermatophore: S p e r m a t o p h o r e "n. A capsule or pocket inclosing a number of spermatozoa. They are present in many annelids  brachiopods mollusks and crustaceans. In cephalopods the structure of the capsule is very complex.

Spermatophorous: S p e r m a t o p h o r o u s "a. Producing seed  or sperm; seminiferous; as the so-called spermatophorous cells.

Spermatorrhea: S p e r m a t o r r h e a "n. Alt. of Spermatorrhoea

Spermatorrhoea: S p e r m a t o r r h o e a "n. Abnormally frequent involuntary emission of the semen without copulation.

Spermatospore: S p e r m a t o s p o r e "n. Same as Spermospore.

Spermatozoa: S p e r m a t o z o a "pl. "of Spermatozoon

Spermatozoid: S p e r m a t o z o i d "n. The male germ cell in animals and plants  the essential element in fertilization; a microscopic animalcule-like particle usually provided with one or more cilia by which it is capable of active motion. In animals the familiar type is that of a small more or less ovoid head with a delicate threadlike cilium or tail. Called also spermatozoon. In plants the more usual term is antherozoid.

Spermatozooid: S p e r m a t o z o o i d "n. A spermatozoid.

Spermatozoon: S p e r m a t o z o o n "n. Same as Spermatozoid.

Spermic: S p e r m i c "a. Of or pertaining to sperm  or semen.

Spermidia: S p e r m i d i a "pl. "of Spermidium

Spermidium: S p e r m i d i u m "n. An achenium.

Spermist: S p e r m i s t "n. A believer in the doctrine  formerly current of encasement in the male (see Encasement) in which the seminal thread or spermatozoid was considered as the real animal germ the head being the true animal head and the tail the body.

Spermo-: S p e r m o - " Combining forms from Gr. spe`rma  -atos seed sperm semen (of plants or animals); as spermatoblast spermoblast.

Spermoblast: S p e r m o b l a s t "n. One of the cells formed by the division of the spermospore  each of which is destined to become a spermatozoid; a spermatocyte; a spermatoblast.

Spermococcus: S p e r m o c o c c u s "n. The nucleus of the sperm cell.

Spermoderm: S p e r m o d e r m "n. The covering of a seed; -- sometimes limited to the outer coat or testa.

Spermogonium: S p e r m o g o n i u m "n. A conceptacle of certain lichens  which contains spermatia.

Spermologist: S p e r m o l o g i s t "n. One who treats of  or collects seeds.

Spermophile: S p e r m o p h i l e "n. Any ground squirrel of the genus Spermophilus; a gopher. See Illust. under Gopher.

Spermophore: S p e r m o p h o r e "n. A spermatophore.

Spermophyta: S p e r m o p h y t a "n. pl. Plants which produce seed; phaenogamia. These plants constitute the highest grand division of the vegetable kingdom.

Spermophyte: S p e r m o p h y t e "n. Any plant which produces true seeds; -- a term recently proposed to replace ph/nogam.

Spermophytic: S p e r m o p h y t i c "a. Capable of producing seeds; ph/nogamic.

Spermoplasma: S p e r m o p l a s m a "n. The protoplasm of the sperm cell.

Spermosphere: S p e r m o s p h e r e "n. A mass or ball of cells formed by the repeated division of a male germinal cell (spermospore)  each constituent cell (spermoblast) of which is converted into a spermatozoid; a spermatogemma.

Spermospore: S p e r m o s p o r e "n. The male germinal or seminal cell  from the breaking up of which the spermoblasts are formed and ultimately the spermatozoids; a spermatospore.

Spermule: S p e r m u l e "n. A sperm cell.

Sperre: S p e r r e "v. t. To shut in; to support; to inclose; to fasten.

Sperrylite: S p e r r y l i t e "n. An arsenide of platinum occuring in grains and minute isometric crystals of tin-white color. It is found near Sudbury  Ontario Canada and is the only known compound of platinum occuring in nature.

Sperse: S p e r s e "v. t. To disperse.

Spessartite: S p e s s a r t i t e "n. A manganesian variety of garnet.

Spet: S p e t "v. t. To spit; to throw out.

Spet: S p e t "n. Spittle.

Spetches: S p e t c h e s "n. pl. Parings and refuse of hides  skins etc. from which glue is made.

Spew: S p e w "v. t. To eject from the stomach; to vomit.

Spew: S p e w "v. t. To cast forth with abhorrence or disgust; to eject.

Spew: S p e w "v. i. To vomit.

Spew: S p e w "v. i. To eject seed  as wet land swollen with frost.

Spew: S p e w "n. That which is vomited; vomit.

Spewed: S p e w e d "imp. & p. p. of Spew

Spewer: S p e w e r "n. One who spews.

Spewiness: S p e w i n e s s "n. The state of being spewy.

Spewing: S p e w i n g "p. pr.& vb. n. of Spew

Spewy: S p e w y "a. Wet; soggy; inclined to spew.

Sphacel: S p h a c e l "n. Gangrene.

Sphacelate: S p h a c e l a t e "v. t. To affect with gangrene.

Sphacelate: S p h a c e l a t e "a. Alt. of Sphacelated

Sphacelated: S p h a c e l a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Spacelate

Sphacelated: S p h a c e l a t e d "a. Affected with gangrene; mortified.

Sphacelating: S p h a c e l a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Spacelate

Sphacelation: S p h a c e l a t i o n "n. The process of becoming or making gangrenous; mortification.

Sphacelus: S p h a c e l u s "n. Gangrenous part; gangrene; slough.

Sphaerenchyma: S p h a e r e n c h y m a "n. Vegetable tissue composed of thin-walled rounded cells  -- a modification of parenchyma.

Sphaeridia: S p h a e r i d i a "pl. "of Sphaeridium

Sphaeridium: S p h a e r i d i u m "n. A peculiar sense organ found upon the exterior of most kinds of sea urchins  and consisting of an oval or sherical head surmounting a short pedicel. It is generally supposed to be an olfactory organ.

Sphaerospore: S p h a e r o s p o r e "n. One of the nonsexual spores found in red algae; a tetraspore.

Sphaerulite: S p h a e r u l i t e "n. Same as Spherulite.

Sphagnicolous: S p h a g n i c o l o u s "a. Growing in moss of the genus Sphagnum.

Sphagnous: S p h a g n o u s "a. Pertaining to moss of the genus Sphagnum  or bog moss; abounding in peat or bog moss.

Sphagnum: S p h a g n u m "n. A genus of mosses having white leaves slightly tinged with red or green and found growing in marshy places; bog moss; peat moss.

Sphalerite: S p h a l e r i t e "n. Zinc sulphide; -- called also blende  black-jack false galena etc. See Blende (a).

Sphene: S p h e n e "n. A mineral found usually in thin  wedge-shaped crystals of a yellow or green to black color. It is a silicate of titanium and calcium; titanite.

Sphenethmoid: S p h e n e t h m o i d "a. Of or pertaining to both the sphenoidal and the ethmoidal regions of the skull  or the sphenethmoid bone; sphenethmoidal.

Sphenethmoid: S p h e n e t h m o i d "n. The sphenethmoid bone.

Sphenethmoidal: S p h e n e t h m o i d a l "a. Relating to the sphenoethmoid bone; sphenoethmoid.

Spheniscan: S p h e n i s c a n "n. Any species of penguin.

Spheno-: S p h e n o - " A combining form used in anatomy to indicate connection with  or relation to the sphenoid bone; as in sphenomaxillary sphenopalatine.

Sphenodon: S p h e n o d o n "n. Same as Hatteria.

Sphenoethmoidal: S p h e n o e t h m o i d a l "a. Sphenethmoid.

Sphenogram: S p h e n o g r a m "n. A cuneiform  or arrow-headed character.

Sphenographer: S p h e n o g r a p h e r "n. One skilled in sphenography; a sphenographist.

Sphenographic: S p h e n o g r a p h i c "a. Of or pertaining to sphenography.

Sphenographist: S p h e n o g r a p h i s t "n. A sphenographer.

Sphenography: S p h e n o g r a p h y "n. The art of writing in cuneiform characters  or of deciphering inscriptions made in such characters.

Sphenoid: S p h e n o i d "a. Wedge-shaped; as  a sphenoid crystal.

Sphenoid: S p h e n o i d "a. Of or pertaining to the sphenoid bone.

Sphenoid: S p h e n o i d "n. A wedge-shaped crystal bounded by four equal isosceles triangles. It is the hemihedral form of a square pyramid.

Sphenoid: S p h e n o i d "n. The sphenoid bone.

Sphenoidal: S p h e n o i d a l "a. Sphenoid.

Sphenoidal: S p h e n o i d a l "a. Pertaining to  or resembling a sphenoid.

Sphenotic: S p h e n o t i c "a. Of  pertaining to or designating the sphenotic bone.

Sphenotic: S p h e n o t i c "n. The sphenotic bone.

Spheral: S p h e r a l "a. Of or pertaining to a sphere or the spheres.

Spheral: S p h e r a l "a. Rounded like a sphere; sphere-shaped; hence  symmetrical; complete; perfect.

Sphere: S p h e r e "n. A body or space contained under a single surface  which in every part is equally distant from a point within called its center.

Sphere: S p h e r e "n. Hence  any globe or globular body especially a celestial one as the sun a planet or the earth.

Sphere: S p h e r e "n. The apparent surface of the heavens  which is assumed to be spherical and everywhere equally distant in which the heavenly bodies appear to have their places and on which the various astronomical circles as of right ascension and declination the equator ecliptic etc. are conceived to be drawn; an ideal geometrical sphere with the astronomical and geographical circles in their proper positions on it.

Sphere: S p h e r e "n. In ancient astronomy  one of the concentric and eccentric revolving spherical transparent shells in which the stars sun planets and moon were supposed to be set and by which they were carried in such a manner as to produce their apparent motions.

Sphere: S p h e r e "n. The extension of a general conception  or the totality of the individuals or species to which it may be applied.

Sphere: S p h e r e "n. Circuit or range of action  knowledge or influence; compass; province; employment; place of existence.

Sphere: S p h e r e "n. Rank; order of society; social positions.

Sphere: S p h e r e "n. An orbit  as of a star; a socket.

Sphere: S p h e r e "v. t. To place in a sphere  or among the spheres; to insphere.

Sphere: S p h e r e "v. t. To form into roundness; to make spherical  or spheral; to perfect.

Sphered: S p h e r e d "imp. & p. p. of Sphere

Spheric: S p h e r i c "a. Having the form of a sphere; like a sphere; globular; orbicular; as  a spherical body.

Spheric: S p h e r i c "a. Of or pertaining to a sphere.

Spheric: S p h e r i c "a. Of or pertaining to the heavenly orbs  or to the sphere or spheres in which according to ancient astronomy and astrology they were set.

Spherical: S p h e r i c a l "a. Alt. of Spheric

Sphericity: S p h e r i c i t y "n. The quality or state of being spherial; roundness; as  the sphericity of the planets or of a drop of water.

Sphericle: S p h e r i c l e "n. A small sphere.

Spherics: S p h e r i c s "n. The doctrine of the sphere; the science of the properties and relations of the circles  figures and other magnitudes of a sphere produced by planes intersecting it; spherical geometry and trigonometry.

Sphering: S p h e r i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Sphere

Spherobacteria: S p h e r o b a c t e r i a "n. pl. See the Note under Microbacteria.

Spheroconic: S p h e r o c o n i c "n. A nonplane curve formed by the intersection of the surface of an oblique cone with the surface of a sphere whose center is at the vertex of the cone.

Spherograph: S p h e r o g r a p h "n. An instrument for facilitating the practical use of spherics in navigation and astronomy  being constructed of two cardboards containing various circles and turning upon each other in such a manner that any possible spherical triangle may be readily found and the measures of the parts read off by inspection.

Spheroid: S p h e r o i d "n. A body or figure approaching to a sphere  but not perfectly spherical; esp. a solid generated by the revolution of an ellipse about one of its axes.

Spheroidal: S p h e r o i d a l "a. Having the form of a spheroid.

Spheroidic: S p h e r o i d i c "a. Alt. of Spheroidical

Spheroidical: S p h e r o i d i c a l "a. See Spheroidal.

Spheroidicity: S p h e r o i d i c i t y "n. Alt. of Spheroidity

Spheroidity: S p h e r o i d i t y "n. The quality or state of being spheroidal.

Spheromere: S p h e r o m e r e "n. Any one of the several symmetrical segments arranged around the central axis and composing the body of a radiate anmal.

Spherometer: S p h e r o m e t e r "n. An instrument for measuring the curvature of spherical surface  as of lenses for telescope etc.

Spherosiderite: S p h e r o s i d e r i t e "n. Siderite occuring in spheroidal masses.

Spherosome: S p h e r o s o m e "n. The body wall of any radiate animal.

Spherulate: S p h e r u l a t e "a. Covered or set with spherules; having one or more rows of spherules  or minute tubercles.

Spherule: S p h e r u l e "n. A little sphere or spherical body; as  quicksilver when poured upon a plane divides itself into a great number of minute spherules.

Spherulite: S p h e r u l i t e "n. A minute spherical crystalline body having a radiated structure  observed in some vitreous volcanic rocks as obsidian and pearlstone.

Spherulitic: S p h e r u l i t i c "a. Of or pertaining to a spherulite; characterized by the presence of spherulites.

Sphery: S p h e r y "a. Round; spherical; starlike.

Sphery: S p h e r y "a. Of or pertaining to the spheres.

Sphex: S p h e x "n. Any one of numerous species of sand wasps of the genus Sphex and allied genera. These wasps have the abdomen attached to the thorax by a slender pedicel. See Illust. of Sand wasp  under Sand.

Sphigmometer: S p h i g m o m e t e r "n. See Sphygmometer.

Sphincter: S p h i n c t e r "n. A muscle which surrounds  and by its contraction tends to close a natural opening; as the sphincter of the bladder.

Sphincter: S p h i n c t e r "a. Of  pertaining to or designating a sphincter; as a sphincter muscle.

Sphingid: S p h i n g i d "n. A sphinx.

Sphingid: S p h i n g i d "a. Of or pertaining to a sphinx  or the family Sphingidae.

Sphinx: S p h i n x "n. In Egyptian art  an image of granite or porphyry having a human head or the head of a ram or of a hawk upon the wingless body of a lion.

Sphinx: S p h i n x "n. On Greek art and mythology  a she-monster usually represented as having the winged body of a lion and the face and breast of a young woman.

Sphinx: S p h i n x "n. Hence: A person of enigmatical character and purposes  especially in politics and diplomacy.

Sphinx: S p h i n x "n. Any one of numerous species of large moths of the family Sphingidae; -- called also hawk moth.

Sphinx: S p h i n x "n. The Guinea  or sphinx baboon (Cynocephalus sphinx).

Sphragide: S p h r a g i d e "n. Lemnian earth.

Sphragistics: S p h r a g i s t i c s "n. The science of seals  their history age distinctions etc. esp. as verifying the age and genuiness of documents.

Sphrigosis: S p h r i g o s i s "n. A condition of vegetation in which there is too abundant growth of the stem and leaves  accompanied by deficiency of flowers and fruit.

Sphygmic: S p h y g m i c "a. Of or pertaining to the pulse.

Sphygmogram: S p h y g m o g r a m "n. A tracing  called a pulse tracing consisting of a series of curves corresponding with the beats of the heart obtained by the application of the sphygmograph.

Sphygmograph: S p h y g m o g r a p h "n. An instrument which  when applied over an artery indicates graphically the movements or character of the pulse. See Sphygmogram.

Sphygmographic: S p h y g m o g r a p h i c "a. Relating to  or produced by a sphygmograph; as a sphygmographic tracing.

Sphygmometer: S p h y g m o m e t e r "n. An instrument for measuring the strength of the pulse beat; a sphygmograph.

Sphygmophone: S p h y g m o p h o n e "n. An electrical instrument for determining by the ear the rhythm of the pulse of a person at a distance.

Sphygmoscope: S p h y g m o s c o p e "n. Same as Sphygmograph.

Sphyraenoid: S p h y r a e n o i d "a. Of or pertaining to the Sphyraenidae  a family of marine fishes including the barracudas.

Spial: S p i a l "n. A spy; a scout.

Spica: S p i c a "n. A kind of bandage passing  by successive turns and crosses from an extremity to the trunk; -- so called from its resemblance to a spike of a barley.

Spica: S p i c a "n. A star of the first magnitude situated in the constellation Virgo.

Spicae: S p i c a e "pl. "of Spica

Spicate: S p i c a t e "a. Alt. of Spicated

Spicated: S p i c a t e d "a. Having the form of a spike  or ear; arranged in a spike or spikes.

Spiccato: S p i c c a t o "a. Detached; separated; -- a term indicating that every note is to be performed in a distinct and pointed manner.

Spice: S p i c e "n. Species; kind.

Spice: S p i c e "n. A vegetable production of many kinds  fragrant or aromatic and pungent to the taste as pepper cinnamon nutmeg mace allspice ginger cloves etc. which are used in cookery and to flavor sauces pickles

Spice: S p i c e "n. Figuratively  that which enriches or alters the quality of a thing in a small degree as spice alters the taste of food; that which gives zest or pungency; a slight flavoring; a relish; hence a small quantity or admixture; a sprinkling; as a spice of mischief.

Spice: S p i c e "v. t. To season with spice  or as with spice; to mix aromatic or pungent substances with; to flavor; to season; as to spice wine; to spice one's words with wit.

Spice: S p i c e "v. t. To fill or impregnate with the odor of spices.

Spice: S p i c e "v. t. To render nice or dainty; hence  to render scrupulous.

Spicebush: S p i c e b u s h "n. Spicewood.

Spiced: S p i c e d "imp. & p. p. of Spice

Spicenut: S p i c e n u t " A small crisp cake  highly spiced.

Spicer: S p i c e r "n. One who seasons with spice.

Spicer: S p i c e r "n. One who deals in spice.

Spicery: S p i c e r y "n. Spices  in general.

Spicery: S p i c e r y "n. A repository of spices.

Spicewood: S p i c e w o o d "n. An American shrub (Lindera Benzoin)  the bark of which has a spicy taste and odor; -- called also Benjamin wild allspice and fever bush.

Spiciferous: S p i c i f e r o u s "a. Bearing ears  or spikes; spicate.

Spiciform: S p i c i f o r m "a. Spike-shaped.

Spicily: S p i c i l y "adv. In a spicy manner.

Spiciness: S p i c i n e s s "n. The quality or state of being spicy.

Spicing: S p i c i n g "p. p. & vb. n. of Spice

Spick: S p i c k "n. A spike or nail.

Spicknel: S p i c k n e l "n. An umbelliferous herb (Meum Athamanticum) having finely divided leaves  common in Europe; -- called also baldmoney mew and bearwort.

Spicose: S p i c o s e "a. Having spikes  or ears like corn spikes.

Spicosity: S p i c o s i t y "n. The state of having  or being full of ears like corn.

Spicous: S p i c o u s "a. See Spicose.

Spicula: S p i c u l a "n. A little spike; a spikelet.

Spicula: S p i c u l a "n. A pointed fleshy appendage.

Spicula: S p i c u l a "pl. "of Spiculum

Spiculae: S p i c u l a e "pl. "of Spicula

Spicular: S p i c u l a r "a. Resembling a dart; having sharp points.

Spiculate: S p i c u l a t e "a. Covered with  or having spicules.

Spiculate: S p i c u l a t e "a. Covered with minute spiculae  or pointed fleshy appendages; divided into small spikelets.

Spiculate: S p i c u l a t e "v. t. To sharpen to a point.

Spicule: S p i c u l e "n. A minute  slender granule or point.

Spicule: S p i c u l e "n. Same as Spicula.

Spicule: S p i c u l e "n. Any small calcareous or siliceous body found in the tissues of various invertebrate animals  especially in sponges and in most Alcyonaria.

Spiculiform: S p i c u l i f o r m "a. Having the shape of a spicule.

Spiculigenous: S p i c u l i g e n o u s "a. Producing or containing spicules.

Spiculispongiae: S p i c u l i s p o n g i a e "n. pl. A division of sponges including those which have independent siliceous spicules.

Spiculum: S p i c u l u m "n. Same as Spicule.

Spicy: S p i c y "superl. Flavored with  or containing spice or spices; fragrant; aromatic; as spicy breezes.

Spicy: S p i c y "superl. Producing  or abounding with spices.

Spicy: S p i c y "superl. Fig.: Piquant; racy; as  a spicy debate.

Spider: S p i d e r "n. Any one of numerous species of arachnids comprising the order Araneina. Spiders have the mandibles converted into poison fangs  or falcers. The abdomen is large and not segmented with two or three pairs of spinnerets near the end by means of which they spin threads of silk to form cocoons or nests to protect their eggs and young. Many species spin also complex webs to entrap the insects upon which they prey. The eyes are usually eight in number (rarely six) and are situated on the back of the cephalothorax. See Illust. under Araneina.

Spider: S p i d e r "n. Any one of various other arachnids resembling the true spiders  especially certain mites as the red spider (see under Red).

Spider: S p i d e r "n. An iron pan with a long handle  used as a kitchen utensil in frying food. Originally it had long legs and was used over coals on the hearth.

Spider: S p i d e r "n. A trevet to support pans or pots over a fire.

Spider: S p i d e r "n. A skeleton  or frame having radiating arms or members often connected by crosspieces; as a casting forming the hub and spokes to which the rim of a fly wheel or large gear is bolted; the body of a piston head; a frame for strengthening a core or mold for a casting etc.

Spider web: S p i d e r   w e b " Alt. of Spider's web

Spider's web: S p i d e r ' s   w e b " The silken web which is formed by most kinds of spiders  particularly the web spun to entrap their prey. See Geometric spider Triangle spider under Geometric and Triangle.

Spidered: S p i d e r e d "a. Infested by spiders; cobwebbed.

Spiderlike: S p i d e r l i k e "a. Like a spider.

Spiderwort: S p i d e r w o r t "n. An American endogenous plant (Tradescantia Virginica)  with long linear leaves and ephemeral blue flowers. The name is sometimes extended to other species of the same genus.

Spied: S p i e d " imp. & p. p. of Spy.

Spied: S p i e d "imp. & p. p. of Spy

Spiegel iron: S p i e g e l   i r o n " A fusible white cast iron containing a large amount of carbon (from three and a half to six per cent) and some manganese. When the manganese reaches twenty-five per cent and upwards it has a granular structure  and constitutes the alloy ferro manganese largely used in the manufacture of Bessemer steel. Called also specular pig iron spiegel and spiegeleisen.

Spiegeleisen: S p i e g e l e i s e n "n. See Spiegel iron.

Spies: S p i e s "pl. "of Spy

Spight: S p i g h t "n. & v. Spite.

Spight: S p i g h t "n. A woodpecker. See Speight.

Spignel: S p i g n e l "n. Same as Spickenel.

Spignet: S p i g n e t "n. An aromatic plant of America. See Spikenard.

Spigot: S p i g o t "n. A pin or peg used to stop the vent in a cask; also  the plug of a faucet or cock.

Spigurnel: S p i g u r n e l "n. Formerly the title of the sealer of writs in chancery.

Spike: S p i k e "n. A sort of very large nail; also  a piece of pointed iron set with points upward or outward.

Spike: S p i k e "n. Anything resembling such a nail in shape.

Spike: S p i k e "n. An ear of corn or grain.

Spike: S p i k e "n. A kind of flower cluster in which sessile flowers are arranged on an unbranched elongated axis.

Spike: S p i k e "v. t. To fasten with spikes  or long large nails; as to spike down planks.

Spike: S p i k e "v. t. To set or furnish with spikes.

Spike: S p i k e "v. t. To fix on a spike.

Spike: S p i k e "v. t. To stop the vent of (a gun or cannon) by driving a spike nail  or the like into it.

Spike: S p i k e "n. Spike lavender. See Lavender.

Spikebill: S p i k e b i l l "n. The hooded merganser.

Spikebill: S p i k e b i l l "n. The marbled godwit (Limosa fedoa).

Spiked: S p i k e d "imp. & p. p. of Spike

Spiked: S p i k e d "a. Furnished or set with spikes  as corn; fastened with spikes; stopped with spikes.

Spikefish: S p i k e f i s h "n. See Sailfish (a)

Spikelet: S p i k e l e t "n. A small or secondary spike; especially  one of the ultimate parts of the in florescence of grasses. See Illust. of Quaking grass.

Spikenard: S p i k e n a r d "n. An aromatic plant. In the United States it is the Aralia racemosa  often called spignet and used as a medicine. The spikenard of the ancients is the Nardostachys Jatamansi a native of the Himalayan region. From its blackish roots a perfume for the hair is still prepared in India.

Spikenard: S p i k e n a r d "n. A fragrant essential oil  as that from the Nardostachys Jatamansi.

Spiketail: S p i k e t a i l "n. The pintail duck.

Spiking: S p i k i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Spike

Spiky: S p i k y "a. Like a spike; spikelike.

Spiky: S p i k y "a. Having a sharp point  or sharp points; furnished or armed with spikes.

Spile: S p i l e "n. A small plug or wooden pin  used to stop a vent as in a cask.

Spile: S p i l e "n. A small tube or spout inserted in a tree for conducting sap  as from a sugar maple.

Spile: S p i l e "n. A large stake driven into the ground as a support for some superstructure; a pile.

Spile: S p i l e "v. t. To supply with a spile or a spigot; to make a small vent in  as a cask.

Spilikin: S p i l i k i n "n. One of a number of small pieces or pegs of wood  ivory bone or other material for playing a game or for counting the score in a game as in cribbage. In the plural (spilikins

spilikins: s p i l i k i n s "pl. "of Spilikin

Spill: S p i l l "n. A bit of wood split off; a splinter.

Spill: S p i l l "n. A slender piece of anything.

Spill: S p i l l "n. A peg or pin for plugging a hole  as in a cask; a spile.

Spill: S p i l l "n. A metallic rod or pin.

Spill: S p i l l "n. A small roll of paper  or slip of wood used as a lamplighter etc.

Spill: S p i l l "n. One of the thick laths or poles driven horizontally ahead of the main timbering in advancing a level in loose ground.

Spill: S p i l l "n. A little sum of money.

Spill: S p i l l "v. t. To cover or decorate with slender pieces of wood  metal ivory etc.; to inlay.

Spill: S p i l l "v. t. To destroy; to kill; to put an end to.

Spill: S p i l l "v. t. To mar; to injure; to deface; hence  to destroy by misuse; to waste.

Spill: S p i l l "v. t. To suffer to fall or run out of a vessel; to lose  or suffer to be scattered; -- applied to fluids and to substances whose particles are small and loose; as to spill water from a pail; to spill quicksilver from a vessel; to spill powder from a paper; to spill sand or flour.

Spill: S p i l l "v. t. To cause to flow out and be lost or wasted; to shed  or suffer to be shed as in battle or in manslaughter; as a man spills another's blood or his own blood.

Spill: S p i l l "v. t. To relieve a sail from the pressure of the wind  so that it can be more easily reefed or furled or to lessen the strain.

Spill: S p i l l "v. i. To be destroyed  ruined or wasted; to come to ruin; to perish; to waste.

Spill: S p i l l "v. i. To be shed; to run over; to fall out  and be lost or wasted.

Spilled: S p i l l e d "imp. & p. p. of Spill

Spiller: S p i l l e r "n. One who  or that which spills.

Spiller: S p i l l e r "n. A kind of fishing line with many hooks; a boulter.

Spillet fishing: S p i l l e t   f i s h i n g " Alt. of Spilliard fishing

Spilliard fishing: S p i l l i a r d   f i s h i n g " A system or method of fishing by means of a number of hooks set on snoods all on one line; -- in North America  called trawl fishing bultow or bultow fishing and long-line fishing.

Spillikin: S p i l l i k i n "n. See Spilikin.

Spilling: S p i l l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Spill

Spilling: S p i l l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Spill

Spillway: S p i l l w a y "n. A sluiceway or passage for superfluous water in a reservoir  to prevent too great pressure on the dam.

Spilt: S p i l t "imp. & p. p. of Spill

Spilt: S p i l t " of Spill

Spilt: S p i l t " imp. & p. p. of Spill. Spilled.

Spilter: S p i l t e r "n. Any one of the small branches on a stag's head.

Spilth: S p i l t h "n. Anything spilt  or freely poured out; slop; effusion.

Spin: S p i n "v. t. To draw out  and twist into threads either by the hand or machinery; as to spin wool cotton or flax; to spin goat's hair; to produce by drawing out and twisting a fibrous material.

Spin: S p i n "v. t. To draw out tediously; to form by a slow process  or by degrees; to extend to a great length; -- with out; as to spin out large volumes on a subject.

Spin: S p i n "v. t. To protract; to spend by delays; as  to spin out the day in idleness.

Spin: S p i n "v. t. To cause to turn round rapidly; to whirl; to twirl; as  to spin a top.

Spin: S p i n "v. t. To form (a web  a cocoon silk or the like) from threads produced by the extrusion of a viscid transparent liquid which hardens on coming into contact with the air; -- said of the spider the silkworm etc.

Spin: S p i n "v. t. To shape  as malleable sheet metal into a hollow form by bending or buckling it by pressing against it with a smooth hand tool or roller while the metal revolves as in a lathe.

Spin: S p i n "v. i. To practice spinning; to work at drawing and twisting threads; to make yarn or thread from fiber; as  the woman knows how to spin; a machine or jenny spins with great exactness.

Spin: S p i n "v. i. To move round rapidly; to whirl; to revolve  as a top or a spindle about its axis.

Spin: S p i n "v. i. To stream or issue in a thread or a small current or jet; as  blood spinsfrom a vein.

Spin: S p i n "v. i. To move swifty; as  to spin along the road in a carriage on a bicycle etc.

Spin: S p i n "n. The act of spinning; as  the spin of a top; a spin a bicycle.

Spin: S p i n "n. Velocity of rotation about some specified axis.

Spina bifida: S p i n a   b i f i d a " A congenital malformation in which the spinal column is cleft at its lower portion  and the membranes of the spinal cord project as an elastic swelling from the gap thus formed.

Spinaceous: S p i n a c e o u s "a. Of  pertaining to or resembling the plant spinach or the family of plants to which it belongs.

Spinach: S p i n a c h "n. Alt. of Spinage

Spinage: S p i n a g e "n. A common pot herb (Spinacia oleracea) belonging to the Goosefoot family.

Spinal: S p i n a l "a. Of  pertaining to or in the region of the backbone or vertebral column; rachidian; vertebral.

Spinal: S p i n a l "a. Of or pertaining to a spine or spines.

Spinate: S p i n a t e "a. Bearing a spine; spiniform.

Spindle: S p i n d l e "n. The long  round slender rod or pin in spinning wheels by which the thread is twisted and on which when twisted it is wound; also the pin on which the bobbin is held in a spinning machine or in the shuttle of a loom.

Spindle: S p i n d l e "n. A slender rod or pin on which anything turns; an axis; as  the spindle of a vane.

Spindle: S p i n d l e "n. The shaft  mandrel or arbor in a machine tool as a lathe or drilling machine etc. which causes the work to revolve or carries a tool or center etc.

Spindle: S p i n d l e "n. The vertical rod on which the runner of a grinding mill turns.

Spindle: S p i n d l e "n. A shaft or pipe on which a core of sand is formed.

Spindle: S p i n d l e "n. The fusee of a watch.

Spindle: S p i n d l e "n. A long and slender stalk resembling a spindle.

Spindle: S p i n d l e "n. A yarn measure containing  in cotton yarn 15 120 yards; in linen yarn 14 400 yards.

Spindle: S p i n d l e "n. A solid generated by the revolution of a curved line about its base or double ordinate or chord.

Spindle: S p i n d l e "n. Any marine univalve shell of the genus Rostellaria; -- called also spindle stromb.

Spindle: S p i n d l e "n. Any marine gastropod of the genus Fusus.

Spindle: S p i n d l e "v. i. To shoot or grow into a long  slender stalk or body; to become disproportionately tall and slender.

Spindle-legged: S p i n d l e - l e g g e d "a. Having long  slender legs.

Spindle-shanked: S p i n d l e - s h a n k e d "a. Having long  slender legs.

Spindle-shaped: S p i n d l e - s h a p e d "a. Having the shape of a spindle.

Spindle-shaped: S p i n d l e - s h a p e d "a. Thickest in the middle  and tapering to both ends; fusiform; -- applied chiefly to roots.

Spindled: S p i n d l e d "imp. & p. p. of Spindle

Spindlelegs: S p i n d l e l e g s "n. A spindleshanks.

Spindleshanks: S p i n d l e s h a n k s "n. A person with slender shanks  or legs; -- used humorously or in contempt.

Spindletail: S p i n d l e t a i l "n. The pintail duck.

Spindleworm: S p i n d l e w o r m "n. The larva of a noctuid mmoth (Achatodes zeae) which feeds inside the stalks of corn (maize)  sometimes causing much damage. It is smooth with a black head and tail and a row of black dots across each segment.

Spindling: S p i n d l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Spindle

Spindling: S p i n d l i n g "a. Long and slender  or disproportionately tall and slender; as a spindling tree; a spindling boy.

Spine: S p i n e "n. A sharp appendage to any of a plant; a thorn.

Spine: S p i n e "n. A rigid and sharp projection upon any part of an animal.

Spine: S p i n e "n. One of the rigid and undivided fin rays of a fish.

Spine: S p i n e "n. The backbone  or spinal column of an animal; -- so called from the projecting processes upon the vertebrae.

Spine: S p i n e "n. Anything resembling the spine or backbone; a ridge.

Spine-finned: S p i n e - f i n n e d "a. Having fine supported by spinous fin rays; -- said of certain fishes.

Spine-tailed: S p i n e - t a i l e d "a. Having the tail quills ending in sharp  naked tips.

Spineback: S p i n e b a c k "n. A fish having spines in  or in front of the dorsal fins.

Spinebill: S p i n e b i l l "n. Any species of Australian birds of the genus Acanthorhynchus. They are related to the honey eaters.

Spined: S p i n e d "a. Furnished with spines; spiny.

Spinel: S p i n e l "n. Alt. of Spinelle

Spinel: S p i n e l "n. Bleached yarn in making the linen tape called inkle; unwrought inkle.

Spineless: S p i n e l e s s "a. Having no spine.

Spinelle: S p i n e l l e "n. A mineral occuring in octahedrons of great hardness and various colors  as red green blue brown and black the red variety being the gem spinel ruby. It consist essentially of alumina and magnesia but commonly contains iron and sometimes also chromium.

Spinescent: S p i n e s c e n t "a. Becoming hard and thorny; tapering gradually to a rigid  leafless point; armed with spines.

Spinet: S p i n e t "n. A keyed instrument of music resembling a harpsichord  but smaller with one string of brass or steel wire to each note sounded by means of leather or quill plectrums or jacks. It was formerly much used.

Spinet: S p i n e t "n. A spinny.

Spinetail: S p i n e t a i l "n. Any one or several species of swifts of the genus Acanthylis  or Chaetura and allied genera in which the shafts of the tail feathers terminate in rigid spines.

Spinetail: S p i n e t a i l "n. Any one of several species of South American and Central American clamatorial birds belonging to Synallaxis and allied genera of the family Dendrocolaptidae. They are allied to the ovenbirds.

Spinetail: S p i n e t a i l "n. The ruddy duck.

Spineted: S p i n e t e d "a. Slit; cleft.

Spiniferous: S p i n i f e r o u s "a. Producing spines; bearing thorns or spines; thorny; spiny.

Spiniform: S p i n i f o r m "a. Shaped like a spine.

Spinigerous: S p i n i g e r o u s "a. Bearing a spine or spines; thorn-bearing.

Spinii-spirulate: S p i n i i - s p i r u l a t e "a. Having spines arranged spirally. See Spicule.

Spininess: S p i n i n e s s "n. Quality of being spiny.

Spink: S p i n k "n. The chaffinch.

Spinnaker: S p i n n a k e r "n. A large triangular sail set upon a boom  -- used when running before the wind.

Spinner: S p i n n e r "n. One who  or that which spins one skilled in spinning; a spinning machine.

Spinner: S p i n n e r "n. A spider.

Spinner: S p i n n e r "n. A goatsucker; -- so called from the peculiar noise it makes when darting through the air.

Spinner: S p i n n e r "n. A spinneret.

Spinneret: S p i n n e r e t "n. One of the special jointed organs situated on the under side  and near the end of the abdomen of spiders by means of which they spin their webs. Most spiders have three pairs of spinnerets but some have only two pairs. The ordinary silk line of the spider is composed of numerous smaller lines jointed after issuing from the spinnerets.

Spinnerule: S p i n n e r u l e "n. One of the numerous small spinning tubes on the spinnerets of spiders.

Spinney: S p i n n e y "n. Same as Spinny.

Spinneys: S p i n n e y s "pl. "of Spinney

Spinnies: S p i n n i e s "pl. "of Spinny

Spinning: S p i n n i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Spin

Spinning: S p i n n i n g " a. & n. from Spin.

Spinny: S p i n n y "n. A small thicket or grove with undergrowth; a clump of trees.

Spinny: S p i n n y "a. Thin and long; slim; slender.

Spinose: S p i n o s e "a. Full of spines; armed with thorns; thorny.

Spinosity: S p i n o s i t y "n. The quality or state of being spiny or thorny; spininess.

Spinous: S p i n o u s "a. Spinose; thorny.

Spinous: S p i n o u s "a. Having the form of a spine or thorn; spinelike.

Spinozism: S p i n o z i s m "n. The form of Pantheism taught by Benedict Spinoza  that there is but one substance or infinite essence in the universe of which the so-called material and spiritual beings and phenomena are only modes and that one this one substance is God.

Spinozist: S p i n o z i s t "n. A believer in Spinozism.

Spinster: S p i n s t e r "n. A woman who spins  or whose occupation is to spin.

Spinster: S p i n s t e r "n. A man who spins.

Spinster: S p i n s t e r "n. An unmarried or single woman; -- used in legal proceedings as a title  or addition to the surname.

Spinster: S p i n s t e r "n. A woman of evil life and character; -- so called from being forced to spin in a house of correction.

Spinstress: S p i n s t r e s s "n. A woman who spins.

Spinstry: S p i n s t r y "n. The business of one who spins; spinning.

Spinule: S p i n u l e "n. A minute spine.

Spinulescent: S p i n u l e s c e n t "a. Having small spines; somewhat thorny.

Spinulose: S p i n u l o s e "a. Alt. of Spinulous

Spinulous: S p i n u l o u s "a. Covered with small spines.

Spiny: S p i n y "a. Full of spines; thorny; as  a spiny tree.

Spiny: S p i n y "a. Like a spine in shape; slender.

Spiny: S p i n y "a. Fig.: Abounding with difficulties or annoyances.

Spiny: S p i n y "n. See Spinny.

Spiodea: S p i o d e a "n. pl. An extensive division of marine Annelida  including those that are without oral tentacles or cirri and have the gills when present mostly arranged along the sides of the body. They generally live in burrows or tubes.

Spirable: S p i r a b l e "a. Capable of being breathed; respirable.

Spiracle: S p i r a c l e "n. The nostril  or one of the nostrils of whales porpoises and allied animals.

Spiracle: S p i r a c l e "n. One of the external openings communicating with the air tubes or tracheae of insects  myriapods and arachnids. They are variable in number and are usually situated on the sides of the thorax and abdomen a pair to a segment. These openings are usually elliptical and capable of being closed. See Illust. under Coleoptera.

Spiracle: S p i r a c l e "n. A tubular orifice communicating with the gill cavity of certain ganoid and all elasmobranch fishes. It is the modified first gill cleft.

Spiracle: S p i r a c l e "n. Any small aperture or vent for air or other fluid.

Spiracular: S p i r a c u l a r "a. Of or pertaining to a spiracle.

Spiraea: S p i r a e a "n. A genus of shrubs or perennial herbs including the meadowsweet and the hardhack.

Spiraeic: S p i r a e i c "a. Of  pertaining to or derived from the meadowsweet (Spiraea); formerly designating an acid which is now called salicylic acid.

Spiral: S p i r a l "a. Winding or circling round a center or pole and gradually receding from it; as  the spiral curve of a watch spring.

Spiral: S p i r a l "a. Winding round a cylinder or imaginary axis  and at the same time rising or advancing forward; winding like the thread of a screw; helical.

Spiral: S p i r a l "a. Of or pertaining to a spiral; like a spiral.

Spiral: S p i r a l "a. A plane curve  not reentrant described by a point called the generatrix moving along a straight line according to a mathematical law while the line is revolving about a fixed point called the pole. Cf. Helix.

Spiral: S p i r a l "a. Anything which has a spiral form  as a spiral shell.

Spirality: S p i r a l i t y "n. The quality or states of being spiral.

Spirally: S p i r a l l y "adv. In a spiral form  manner or direction.

Spiralozooid: S p i r a l o z o o i d "n. One of the special defensive zooids of certain hydroids. They have the form of long  slender tentacles and bear lasso cells.

Spirant: S p i r a n t "n. A term used differently by different authorities; -- by some as equivalent to fricative  -- that is as including all the continuous consonants except the nasals m n ng; with the further exception by others of the liquids r l and the semivowels w y; by others limited to f v

Spiranthy: S p i r a n t h y "n. The occasional twisted growth of the parts of a flower.

Spiration: S p i r a t i o n "n. The act of breathing.

Spire: S p i r e "v. i. To breathe.

Spire: S p i r e "n. A slender stalk or blade in vegetation; as  a spire grass or of wheat.

Spire: S p i r e "n. A tapering body that shoots up or out to a point in a conical or pyramidal form. Specifically (Arch.)  the roof of a tower when of a pyramidal form and high in proportion to its width; also the pyramidal or aspiring termination of a tower which can not be said to have a roof such as that of Strasburg cathedral; the tapering part of a steeple or the steeple itself.

Spire: S p i r e "n. A tube or fuse for communicating fire to the chargen in blasting.

Spire: S p i r e "n. The top  or uppermost point of anything; the summit.

Spire: S p i r e "v. i. To shoot forth  or up in or as if in a spire.

Spire: S p i r e "n. A spiral; a curl; a whorl; a twist.

Spire: S p i r e "n. The part of a spiral generated in one revolution of the straight line about the pole. See Spiral  n.

Spired: S p i r e d "imp. & p. p. of Spire

Spired: S p i r e d "a. Having a spire; being in the form of a spire; as  a spired steeple.

Spiricle: S p i r i c l e "n. One of certain minute coiled threads in the coating of some seeds. When moistened these threads protrude in great numbers.

Spirifer: S p i r i f e r "n. Any one of numerous species of fossil brachipods of the genus Spirifer  or Delthyris and allied genera in which the long calcareous supports of the arms form a large spiral or helix on each side.

Spirillum: S p i r i l l u m "n. A genus of common motile microorganisms (Spirobacteria) having the form of spiral-shaped filaments. One species is said to be the cause of relapsing fever.

Spiring: S p i r i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Spire

Spiring: S p i r i n g "a. Shooting up in a spire or spires.

Spirit: S p i r i t "n. Air set in motion by breathing; breath; hence  sometimes life itself.

Spirit: S p i r i t "n. A rough breathing; an aspirate  as the letter h; also a mark to denote aspiration; a breathing.

Spirit: S p i r i t "n. Life  or living substance considered independently of corporeal existence; an intelligence conceived of apart from any physical organization or embodiment; vital essence force or energy as distinct from matter.

Spirit: S p i r i t "n. The intelligent  immaterial and immortal part of man; the soul in distinction from the body in which it resides; the agent or subject of vital and spiritual functions whether spiritual or material.

Spirit: S p i r i t "n. Specifically  a disembodied soul; the human soul after it has left the body.

Spirit: S p i r i t "n. Any supernatural being  good or bad; an apparition; a specter; a ghost; also sometimes a sprite ; a fairy; an elf.

Spirit: S p i r i t "n. Energy  vivacity ardor enthusiasm courage etc.

Spirit: S p i r i t "n. One who is vivacious or lively; one who evinces great activity or peculiar characteristics of mind or temper; as  a ruling spirit; a schismatic spirit.

Spirit: S p i r i t "n. Temper or disposition of mind; mental condition or disposition; intellectual or moral state; -- often in the plural; as  to be cheerful or in good spirits; to be downhearted or in bad spirits.

Spirit: S p i r i t "n. Intent; real meaning; -- opposed to the letter  or to formal statement; also characteristic quality especially such as is derived from the individual genius or the personal character; as the spirit of an enterprise of a document or the like.

Spirit: S p i r i t "n. Tenuous  volatile airy or vapory substance possessed of active qualities.

Spirit: S p i r i t "n. Any liquid produced by distillation; especially  alcohol the spirits or spirit of wine (it having been first distilled from wine): -- often in the plural.

Spirit: S p i r i t "n. Rum  whisky brandy gin and other distilled liquors having much alcohol in distinction from wine and malt liquors.

Spirit: S p i r i t "n. A solution in alcohol of a volatile principle. Cf. Tincture.

Spirit: S p i r i t "n. Any one of the four substances  sulphur sal ammoniac quicksilver or arsenic (or according to some orpiment).

Spirit: S p i r i t "n. Stannic chloride. See under Stannic.

Spirit: S p i r i t "v. t. To animate with vigor; to excite; to encourage; to inspirit; as  civil dissensions often spirit the ambition of private men; -- sometimes followed by up.

Spirit: S p i r i t "v. t. To convey rapidly and secretly  or mysteriously as if by the agency of a spirit; to kidnap; -- often with away or off.

Spiritally: S p i r i t a l l y "adv. By means of the breath.

Spirited: S p i r i t e d "imp. & p. p. of Spirit

Spirited: S p i r i t e d "a. Animated or possessed by a spirit.

Spirited: S p i r i t e d "a. Animated; full of life or vigor; lively; full of spirit or fire; as  a spirited oration; a spirited answer.

Spiritful: S p i r i t f u l "a. Full of spirit; spirited.

Spiritielle: S p i r i t i e l l e "a. Of the nature  or having the appearance of a spirit; pure; refined; ethereal.

Spiriting: S p i r i t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Spirit

Spiritism: S p i r i t i s m "n. Spiritualsm.

Spiritist: S p i r i t i s t "n. A spiritualist.

Spiritless: S p i r i t l e s s "a. Destitute of spirit; wanting animation; wanting cheerfulness; dejected; depressed.

Spiritless: S p i r i t l e s s "a. Destitute of vigor; wanting life  courage or fire.

Spiritless: S p i r i t l e s s "a. Having no breath; extinct; dead.

Spiritoso: S p i r i t o s o "a. & adv. Spirited; spiritedly; -- a direction to perform a passage in an animated  lively manner.

Spiritous: S p i r i t o u s "a. Like spirit; refined; defecated; pure.

Spiritous: S p i r i t o u s "a. Ardent; active.

Spiritousness: S p i r i t o u s n e s s "n. Quality of being spiritous.

Spiritual: S p i r i t u a l "a. Consisting of spirit; not material; incorporeal; as  a spiritual substance or being.

Spiritual: S p i r i t u a l "a. Of or pertaining to the intellectual and higher endowments of the mind; mental; intellectual.

Spiritual: S p i r i t u a l "a. Of or pertaining to the moral feelings or states of the soul  as distinguished from the external actions; reaching and affecting the spirits.

Spiritual: S p i r i t u a l "a. Of or pertaining to the soul or its affections as influenced by the Spirit; controlled and inspired by the divine Spirit; proceeding from the Holy Spirit; pure; holy; divine; heavenly-minded; -- opposed to carnal.

Spiritual: S p i r i t u a l "a. Not lay or temporal; relating to sacred things; ecclesiastical; as  the spiritual functions of the clergy; lords spiritual and temporal; a spiritual corporation.

Spiritual: S p i r i t u a l "n. A spiritual function  office or affair. See Spirituality 2.

Spiritual-minded: S p i r i t u a l - m i n d e d "a. Having the mind set on spiritual things  or filled with holy desires and affections.

Spiritualism: S p i r i t u a l i s m "n. The quality or state of being spiritual.

Spiritualism: S p i r i t u a l i s m "n. The doctrine  in opposition to the materialists that all which exists is spirit or soul -- that what is called the external world is either a succession of notions impressed on the mind by the Deity as maintained by Berkeley or else the mere educt of the mind itself as taught by Fichte.

Spiritualism: S p i r i t u a l i s m "n. A belief that departed spirits hold intercourse with mortals by means of physical phenomena  as by rappng or during abnormal mental states as in trances or the like commonly manifested through a person of special susceptibility called a medium; spiritism; the doctrines and practices of spiritualists.

Spiritualist: S p i r i t u a l i s t "n. One who professes a regard for spiritual things only; one whose employment is of a spiritual character; an ecclesiastic.

Spiritualist: S p i r i t u a l i s t "n. One who maintains the doctrine of spiritualism.

Spiritualist: S p i r i t u a l i s t "n. One who believes in direct intercourse with departed spirits  through the agency of persons commonly called mediums by means of physical phenomena; one who attempts to maintain such intercourse; a spiritist.

Spiritualist: S p i r i t u a l i s t "a. Spiritualistic.

Spiritualistic: S p i r i t u a l i s t i c "a. Relating to  or connected with spiritualism.

Spiritualities: S p i r i t u a l i t i e s "pl. "of Spirituality

Spirituality: S p i r i t u a l i t y "n. The quality or state of being spiritual; incorporeality; heavenly-mindedness.

Spirituality: S p i r i t u a l i t y "n. That which belongs to the church  or to a person as an ecclesiastic or to religion as distinct from temporalities.

Spirituality: S p i r i t u a l i t y "n. An ecclesiastical body; the whole body of the clergy  as distinct from or opposed to the temporality.

Spiritualization: S p i r i t u a l i z a t i o n "n. The act of spiritualizing  or the state of being spiritualized.

Spiritualize: S p i r i t u a l i z e "v. t. To refine intellectiually or morally; to purify from the corrupting influence of the world; to give a spiritual character or tendency to; as  to spiritualize soul.

Spiritualize: S p i r i t u a l i z e "v. t. To give a spiritual meaning to; to take in a spiritual sense; -- opposed to literalize.

Spiritualize: S p i r i t u a l i z e "v. t. To extract spirit from; also  to convert into or impregnate with spirit.

Spiritualized: S p i r i t u a l i z e d "imp. & p. p. of Spiritualize

Spiritualizer: S p i r i t u a l i z e r "n. One who spiritualizes.

Spiritually: S p i r i t u a l l y "adv. In a spiritual manner; with purity of spirit; like a spirit.

Spiritualness: S p i r i t u a l n e s s "n. The quality or state of being spiritual or spiritual-minded; spirituality.

Spiritualty: S p i r i t u a l t y "n. An ecclesiastical body; a spirituality.

Spirituosity: S p i r i t u o s i t y "n. The quality or state of being spirituous; spirituousness.

Spirituous: S p i r i t u o u s "a. Having the quality of spirit; tenuous in substance  and having active powers or properties; ethereal; immaterial; spiritual; pure.

Spirituous: S p i r i t u o u s "a. Containing  or of the nature of alcoholic (esp. distilled) spirit; consisting of refined spirit; alcoholic; ardent; as spirituous liquors.

Spirituous: S p i r i t u o u s "a. Lively; gay; vivid; airy.

Spirituousness: S p i r i t u o u s n e s s "n. The quality or state of being spirituous.

Spirketing: S p i r k e t i n g "n. The planking from the waterways up to the port sills.

Spirling: S p i r l i n g "n. Sparling.

Spirobacteria: S p i r o b a c t e r i a "n. pl. See the Note under Microbacteria.

Spirochaeta: S p i r o c h a e t a "n. Alt. of Spirochaete

Spirochaete: S p i r o c h a e t e "n. A genus of Spirobacteria similar to Spirillum  but distinguished by its motility. One species the Spirochaete Obermeyeri is supposed to be the cause of relapsing fever.

Spirograph: S p i r o g r a p h "n. An instrument for recording the respiratory movements  as the sphygmograph does those of the pulse.

Spirometer: S p i r o m e t e r "n. An instrument for measuring the vital capacity of the lungs  or the volume of air which can be expelled from the chest after the deepest possible inspiration. Cf. Pneumatometer.

Spirometry: S p i r o m e t r y "n. The act or process of measuring the chest capacity by means of a spirometer.

Spiroscope: S p i r o s c o p e "n. A wet meter used to determine the breathing capacity of the lungs.

Spiroylic: S p i r o y l i c "a. Alt. of Spiroylous

Spiroylous: S p i r o y l o u s "a. Pertaining to  or designating a substance now called salicylal.

Spirt: S p i r t "v. & n. Same as Spurt.

Spirtle: S p i r t l e "v. t. To spirt in a scattering manner.

Spirula: S p i r u l a "n. A genus of cephalopods having a multilocular  internal siphunculated shell in the form of a flat spiral the coils of which are not in contact.

Spirulate: S p i r u l a t e "n. Having the color spots  or structural parts arranged spirally.

Spiry: S p i r y "a. Of a spiral form; wreathed; curled; serpentine.

Spiry: S p i r y "a. Of or pertaining to a spire; like a spire  tall slender and tapering; abounding in spires; as spiry turrets.

Spissated: S p i s s a t e d "a. Rendered dense or compact  as by evaporation; inspissated; thickened.

Spissitude: S p i s s i t u d e "n. The quality or state of being spissated; as  the spissitude of coagulated blood or of any coagulum.

Spit: S p i t "n. A long  slender pointed rod usually of iron for holding meat while roasting.

Spit: S p i t "n. A small point of land running into the sea  or a long narrow shoal extending from the shore into the sea; as a spit of sand.

Spit: S p i t "n. The depth to which a spade goes in digging; a spade; a spadeful.

Spit: S p i t "n. To thrust a spit through; to fix upon a spit; hence  to thrust through or impale; as to spit a loin of veal.

Spit: S p i t "n. To spade; to dig.

Spitz dog: S p i t z   d o g " A breed of dogs having erect ears and long silky hair  usually white; -- called also Pomeranian dog and louploup.

Spitzenburgh: S p i t z e n b u r g h "n. A kind of red and yellow apple  of medium size and spicy flavor. It originated at Newtown on Long Island.

Splanchnapophyses: S p l a n c h n a p o p h y s e s "pl. "of Splanchnapophysis

Splanchnapophysis: S p l a n c h n a p o p h y s i s "n. Any element of the skeleton in relation with the alimentary canal  as the jaws and hyoidean apparatus.

Splanchnic: S p l a n c h n i c "a. Of or pertaining to the viscera; visceral.

Splanchno-skeleton: S p l a n c h n o - s k e l e t o n "n. That part of the skeleton connected with the sense organs and the viscera.

Splanchnography: S p l a n c h n o g r a p h y "n. Splanchnology.

Splanchnopleure: S p l a n c h n o p l e u r e "n. The inner  or visceral one of the two lamellae into which the vertebrate blastoderm divides on either side of the notochord and from which the walls of the enteric canal and the umbilical vesicle are developed. See Somatopleure.

Splash: S p l a s h "n. Water  or water and dirt thrown upon anything or thrown from a puddle or the like; also a spot or daub as of matter which wets or disfigures.

Splash: S p l a s h "n. A noise made by striking upon or in a liquid.

Splashboard: S p l a s h b o a r d "n. A guard in the front part of vehicle  to prevent splashing by a mud or water from the horse's heels; -- in the United States commonly called dashboard.

Splay: S p l a y "a. A slope or bevel  especially of the sides of a door or window by which the opening is made larged at one face of the wall than at the other or larger at each of the faces than it is between them.

Spleen: S p l e e n "n. A peculiar glandlike but ductless organ found near the stomach or intestine of most vertebrates and connected with the vascular system; the milt. Its exact function in not known.

Spleenless: S p l e e n l e s s "a. Having no spleen; hence  kind; gentle; mild.

Spleenwort: S p l e e n w o r t "n. Any fern of the genus Asplenium  some species of which were anciently used as remedies for disorders of the spleen.

Splenium: S p l e n i u m "n. The thickened posterior border of the corpus callosum; -- so called in allusion to its shape.

Splenius: S p l e n i u s "n. A flat muscle of the back of the neck.

Splenization: S p l e n i z a t i o n "n. A morbid state of the lung produced by inflammation  in which its tissue resembles that of the spleen.

Splenocele: S p l e n o c e l e "n. Hernia formed by the spleen.

Split: S p l i t "imp. & p. p. of Split

Split: S p l i t "v. t. To divide lengthwise; to separate from end to end  esp. by force; to divide in the direction of the grain layers; to rive; to cleave; as to split a piece of timber or a board; to split a gem; to split a sheepskin.

Split: S p l i t "v. t. To burst; to rupture; to rend; to tear asunder.

Split: S p l i t "v. t. To divide or break up into parts or divisions  as by discord; to separate into parts or parties as a political party; to disunite.

Split: S p l i t "v. t. To divide or separate into components; -- often used with up; as  to split up sugar into alcohol and carbonic acid.

Split: S p l i t "v. i. To part asunder; to be rent; to burst; as  vessels split by the freezing of water in them.

Split: S p l i t "v. i. To be broken; to be dashed to pieces.

Split: S p l i t "v. i. To separate into parties or factions.

Split: S p l i t "v. i. To burst with laughter.

Split: S p l i t "v. i. To divulge a secret; to betray confidence; to peach.

Split: S p l i t "v. i. to divide one hand of blackjack into two hands  allowed when the first two cards dealt to a player have the same value.

Split: S p l i t "n. A crack  or longitudinal fissure.

Split: S p l i t "n. A breach or separation  as in a political party; a division.

Split: S p l i t "n. A piece that is split off  or made thin by splitting; a splinter; a fragment.

Split: S p l i t "n. Specif (Leather Manuf.)  one of the sections of a skin made by dividing it into two or more thicknesses.

Split: S p l i t "n. A division of a stake happening when two cards of the kind on which the stake is laid are dealt in the same turn.

Split: S p l i t "n. the substitution of more than one share of a corporation's stock for one share. The market price of the stock usually drops in proportion to the increase in outstanding shares of stock. The split may be in any ratio  as a two-for-one split; a three-for-two split.

Split: S p l i t "n. the division by a player of one hand of blackjack into two hands  allowed when the first two cards dealt to a player have the same value; the player is usually obliged to increase the amount wagered by placing a sum equal to the original bet on the new hand thus created.

Split: S p l i t "a. Divided; cleft.

Split: S p l i t "a. Divided deeply; cleft.

Spodumene: S p o d u m e n e "n. A mineral of a white to yellowish  purplish or emerald-green color occuring in prismatic crystals often of great size. It is a silicate of aluminia and lithia. See Hiddenite.

Spoffish: S p o f f i s h "a. Earnest and active in matters of no moment; bustling.

Spoil: S p o i l "v. t. To plunder; to strip by violence; to pillage; to rob; -- with of before the name of the thing taken; as  to spoil one of his goods or possession.

Spoil: S p o i l "v. t. To seize by violence;; to take by force; to plunder.

Spoil: S p o i l "v. t. To cause to decay and perish; to corrput; to vitiate; to mar.

Spoil: S p o i l "v. t. To render useless by injury; to injure fatally; to ruin; to destroy; as  to spoil paper; to have the crops spoiled by insects; to spoil the eyes by reading.

Spoil: S p o i l "v. i. To practice plunder or robbery.

Spoil: S p o i l "v. i. To lose the valuable qualities; to be corrupted; to decay; as  fruit will soon spoil in warm weather.

Spoil: S p o i l "n. That which is taken from another by violence; especially  the plunder taken from an enemy; pillage; booty.

Spoil: S p o i l "n. Public offices and their emoluments regarded as the peculiar property of a successful party or faction  to be bestowed for its own advantage; -- commonly in the plural; as to the victor belong the spoils.

Spoil: S p o i l "n. That which is gained by strength or effort.

Spoil: S p o i l "n. The act or practice of plundering; robbery; aste.

Spoil: S p o i l "n. Corruption; cause of corruption.

Spoil: S p o i l "n. The slough  or cast skin of a serpent or other animal.

Spoilable: S p o i l a b l e "a. Capable of being spoiled.

Spoiled: S p o i l e d "imp. & p. p. of Spoil

Spoiler: S p o i l e r "n. One who spoils; a plunderer; a pillager; a robber; a despoiler.

Spoiler: S p o i l e r "n. One who corrupts  mars or renders useless.

Spoilfive: S p o i l f i v e "n. A certain game at cards in which  if no player wins three of the five tricks possible on any deal the game is said to be spoiled.

Spoilful: S p o i l f u l "a. Wasteful; rapacious.

Spoiling: S p o i l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Spoil

Spoilsman: S p o i l s m a n "n. One who serves a cause or a party for a share of the spoils; in United States politics  one who makes or recognizes a demand for public office on the ground of partisan service; also one who sanctions such a policy in appointments to the public service.

Spoilsmen: S p o i l s m e n "pl. "of Spoilsman

Spoilsmonger: S p o i l s m o n g e r "n. One who promises or distributes public offices and their emoluments as the price of services to a party or its leaders.

Spoliation: S p o l i a t i o n "v. t. Robbery or plunder in war; especially  the authorized act or practice of plundering neutrals at sea.

Spoliation: S p o l i a t i o n "v. t. The act of an incumbent in taking the fruits of his benefice without right  but under a pretended title.

Spoliation: S p o l i a t i o n "v. t. A process for possession of a church in a spiritual court.

Spoliation: S p o l i a t i o n "v. t. Injury done to a document.

Spoliative: S p o l i a t i v e "a. Serving to take away  diminish or rob; esp. (Med.) serving to diminish sensibily the amount of blood in the body; as spoliative bloodletting.

Spoliator: S p o l i a t o r "n. One who spoliates; a spoiler.

Spoliatory: S p o l i a t o r y "a. Tending to spoil; destructive; spoliative.

Spondaic: S p o n d a i c "a. Alt. of Spondaical

Spondaical: S p o n d a i c a l "a. Or of pertaining to a spondee; consisting of spondees.

Spondaical: S p o n d a i c a l "a. Containing spondees in excess; marked by spondees; as  a spondaic hexameter i. e. one which has a spondee instead of a dactyl in the fifth foot.

Spondee: S p o n d e e "n. A poetic foot of two long syllables  as in the Latin word leges.

Spondulics: S p o n d u l i c s "n. Money.

Spondyl: S p o n d y l "n. Alt. of Spondyle

Spondyle: S p o n d y l e "n. A joint of the backbone; a vertebra.

Spong: S p o n g "n. An irregular  narrow projecting part of a field.

Sponge: S p o n g e "n. Any one of numerous species of Spongiae  or Porifera. See Illust. and Note under Spongiae.

Sponge: S p o n g e "n. The elastic fibrous skeleton of many species of horny Spongiae (keratosa)  used for many purposes especially the varieties of the genus Spongia. The most valuable sponges are found in the Mediterranean and the Red Sea and on the coasts of Florida and the West Indies.

Sponge: S p o n g e "n. One who lives upon others; a pertinaceous and indolent dependent; a parasite; a sponger.

Sponge: S p o n g e "n. Any spongelike substance.

Sponge: S p o n g e "n. Dough before it is kneaded and formed into loaves  and after it is converted into a light spongy mass by the agency of the yeast or leaven.

Sponge: S p o n g e "n. Iron from the puddling furnace  in a pasty condition.

Sponge: S p o n g e "n. Iron ore  in masses reduced but not melted or worked.

Sponge: S p o n g e "n. A mop for cleaning the bore of a cannon after a discharge. It consists of a cylinder of wood  covered with sheepskin with the wool on or cloth with a heavy looped nap and having a handle or staff.

Sponge: S p o n g e "n. The extremity  or point of a horseshoe answering to the heel.

Sponge: S p o n g e "v. t. To cleanse or wipe with a sponge; as  to sponge a slate or a cannon; to wet with a sponge; as to sponge cloth.

Sponge: S p o n g e "v. t. To wipe out with a sponge  as letters or writing; to efface; to destroy all trace of.

Sponge: S p o n g e "v. t. Fig.: To deprive of something by imposition.

Sponge: S p o n g e "v. t. Fig.: To get by imposition or mean arts without cost; as  to sponge a breakfast.

Sponge: S p o n g e "v. i. To suck in  or imbile as a sponge.

Sponge: S p o n g e "v. i. Fig.: To gain by mean arts  by intrusion or hanging on; as an idler sponges on his neighbor.

Sponge: S p o n g e "v. i. To be converted  as dough into a light spongy mass by the agency of yeast or leaven.

Sponged: S p o n g e d "imp. & p. p. of Sponge

Spongelet: S p o n g e l e t "n. See Spongiole.

Spongeous: S p o n g e o u s "a. Resembling sponge; having the nature or qualities of sponge.

Sponger: S p o n g e r "n. One who sponges  or uses a sponge.

Sponger: S p o n g e r "n. One employed in gathering sponges.

Sponger: S p o n g e r "n. Fig.: A parasitical dependent; a hanger-on.

Spongiae: S p o n g i a e "n. pl. The grand division of the animal kingdom which includes the sponges; -- called also Spongida  Spongiaria Spongiozoa and Porifera.

Spongida: S p o n g i d a "n. pl. Spongiae.

Spongiform: S p o n g i f o r m "a. Resembling a sponge; soft and porous; porous.

Spongilla: S p o n g i l l a "n. A genus of siliceous spongea found in fresh water.

Spongin: S p o n g i n "n. The chemical basis of sponge tissue  a nitrogenous hornlike substance which on decomposition with sulphuric acid yields leucin and glycocoll.

Sponginess: S p o n g i n e s s "n. The quality or state of being spongy.

Sponging: S p o n g i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Sponge

Sponging: S p o n g i n g " a. & n. from Sponge  v.

Spongiole: S p o n g i o l e "n. A supposed spongelike expansion of the tip of a rootlet for absorbing water; -- called also spongelet.

Spongiolite: S p o n g i o l i t e "n. One of the microsporic siliceous spicules which occur abundantly in the texture of sponges  and are sometimes found fossil as in flints.

Spongiopilin: S p o n g i o p i l i n "n. A kind of cloth interwoven with small pieces of sponge and rendered waterproof on one side by a covering of rubber. When moistend with hot water it is used as a poultice.

Spongiose: S p o n g i o s e "a. Alt. of Spongious

Spongious: S p o n g i o u s "a. Somewhat spongy; spongelike; full of small cavities like sponge; as  spongious bones.

Spongiozoa: S p o n g i o z o a "n. pl. See Sponglae.

Spongoblast: S p o n g o b l a s t "n. One of the cells which  in sponges secrete the spongin or the material of the horny fibers.

Spongoid: S p o n g o i d "a. Resembling sponge; like sponge.

Spongy: S p o n g y "a. Soft  and full of cavities; of an open loose pliable texture; as a spongy excrescence; spongy earth; spongy cake; spongy bones.

Spongy: S p o n g y "a. Wet; drenched; soaked and soft  like sponge; rainy.

Spongy: S p o n g y "a. Having the quality of imbibing fluids  like a sponge.

Sponk: S p o n k "n. See Spunk.

Sponsal: S p o n s a l "a. Relating to marriage  or to a spouse; spousal.

Sponsible: S p o n s i b l e "a. responsible; worthy of credit.

Sponsion: S p o n s i o n "n. The act of becoming surety for another.

Sponsion: S p o n s i o n "n. An act or engagement on behalf of a state  by an agent not specially authorized for the purpose or by one who exceeds the limits of authority.

Sponsional: S p o n s i o n a l "a. Of or pertaining to a pledge or agreement; responsible.

Sponson: S p o n s o n "n. One of the triangular platforms in front of  and abaft the paddle boxes of a steamboat.

Sponson: S p o n s o n "n. One of the slanting supports under the guards of a steamboat.

Sponson: S p o n s o n "n. One of the armored projections fitted with gun ports  used on modern war vessels.

Sponsor: S p o n s o r "n. One who binds himself to answer for another  and is responsible for his default; a surety.

Spontaneities: S p o n t a n e i t i e s "pl. "of Spontaneity

Spontaneity: S p o n t a n e i t y "n. The quality or state of being spontaneous  or acting from native feeling proneness or temperament without constraint or external force.

Spontaneity: S p o n t a n e i t y "n. The tendency to undergo change  characteristic of both animal and vegetable organisms and not restrained or cheked by the environment.

Spontaneity: S p o n t a n e i t y "n. The tendency to activity of muscular tissue  including the voluntary muscles when in a state of healthful vigor and refreshment.

Spontaneous: S p o n t a n e o u s "a. Proceding from natural feeling  temperament or disposition or from a native internal proneness readiness or tendency without constraint; as a spontaneous gift or proportion.

Spontaneous: S p o n t a n e o u s "a. Proceeding from  or acting by internal impulse energy or natural law without external force; as spontaneous motion; spontaneous growth.

Spontaneous: S p o n t a n e o u s "a. Produced without being planted  or without human labor; as a spontaneous growth of wood.

Spontoon: S p o n t o o n "n. A kind of half-pike  or halberd formerly borne by inferior officers of the British infantry and used in giving signals to the soldiers.

Spook: S p o o k "n. The chimaera.

Spoonbill: S p o o n b i l l "n. Any one of several species of wading birds of the genera Ajaja and Platalea  and allied genera in which the long bill is broadly expanded and flattened at the tip.

Spoor: S p o o r "n. The track or trail of any wild animal; as  the spoor of an elephant; -- used originally by travelers in South Africa.

Spoor: S p o o r "v. i. To follow a spoor or trail.

Sporades: S p o r a d e s "n. pl. Stars not included in any constellation; -- called also informed  or unformed stars.

Sporadial: S p o r a d i a l "a. Sporadic.

Sporadic: S p o r a d i c "a. Occuring singly  or apart from other things of the same kind or in scattered instances; separate; single; as a sporadic fireball; a sporadic case of disease; a sporadic example of a flower.

Sporangia: S p o r a n g i a "pl. "of Sporangium

Sporangiophore: S p o r a n g i o p h o r e "n. The axis or receptacle in certain ferns (as Trichomanes)  which bears the sporangia.

Sporangium: S p o r a n g i u m "n. A spore case in the cryptogamous plants  as in ferns etc.

Spore: S p o r e "n. One of the minute grains in flowerless plants  which are analogous to seeds as serving to reproduce the species.

Spore: S p o r e "n. An embryo sac or embryonal vesicle in the ovules of flowering plants.

Spore: S p o r e "n. A minute grain or germ; a small  round or ovoid body formed in certain organisms and by germination giving rise to a new organism; as the reproductive spores of bacteria etc.

Spore: S p o r e "n. One of the parts formed by fission in certain Protozoa. See Spore formation  belw.

Sporid: S p o r i d "n. A sporidium.

Sporidia: S p o r i d i a "pl. "of Sporidium

Sporidiferous: S p o r i d i f e r o u s "a. Bearing sporidia.

Sporidium: S p o r i d i u m "n. A secondary spore  or a filament produced from a spore in certain kinds of minute fungi.

Sporidium: S p o r i d i u m "n. A spore.

Sporiferous: S p o r i f e r o u s "a. Bearing or producing spores.

Sporification: S p o r i f i c a t i o n "n. Spore formation. See Spore formation (b)  under Spore.

Sporocarp: S p o r o c a r p "n. A closed body or conceptacle containing one or more masses of spores or sporangia.

Sporocarp: S p o r o c a r p "n. A sporangium.

Sporocyst: S p o r o c y s t "n. An asexual zooid  usually forming one of a series of larval forms in the agamic reproduction of various trematodes and other parasitic worms. The sporocyst generally develops from an egg but in its turn produces other larvae by internal budding or by the subdivision of a part or all of its contents into a number of minute germs. See Redia.

Sporocyst: S p o r o c y s t "n. Any protozoan when it becomes encysted produces germs by sporulation.

Sporogenesis: S p o r o g e n e s i s "n. reproduction by spores.

Sporogony: S p o r o g o n y "n. The growth or development of an animal or a zooid from a nonsexual germ.

Sporophore: S p o r o p h o r e "n. A placenta.

Sporophore: S p o r o p h o r e "n. That alternately produced form of certain cryptogamous plants  as ferns mosses and the like which is nonsexual but produces spores in countless numbers. In ferns it is the leafy plant in mosses the capsule. Cf. Oophore.

Sporophoric: S p o r o p h o r i c "a. Having the nature of a sporophore.

Sporosac: S p o r o s a c "n. A hydrozoan reproductive zooid or gonophore which does not become medusoid in form or structure. See Illust. under Athecata.

Sporosac: S p o r o s a c "n. An early or simple larval stage of trematode worms and some other invertebrates  which is capable or reproducing other germs by asexual generation; a nurse; a redia.

Sporozoa: S p o r o z o a "n. pl. An extensive division of parasitic Protozoa  which increase by sporulation. It includes the Gregarinida.

Sporozoid: S p o r o z o i d "n. Same as Zoospore.

Sporran: S p o r r a n "n. A large purse or pouch made of skin with the hair or fur on  worn in front of the kilt by Highlanders when in full dress.

Sport: S p o r t "n. That which diverts  and makes mirth; pastime; amusement.

Sport: S p o r t "n. Mock; mockery; contemptuous mirth; derision.

Sport: S p o r t "n. That with which one plays  or which is driven about in play; a toy; a plaything; an object of mockery.

Sport: S p o r t "n. Play; idle jingle.

Sport: S p o r t "n. Diversion of the field  as fowling hunting fishing racing games and the like esp. when money is staked.

Sport: S p o r t "n. A plant or an animal  or part of a plant or animal which has some peculiarity not usually seen in the species; an abnormal variety or growth. See Sporting plant under Sporting.

Sport: S p o r t "n. A sportsman; a gambler.

Sport: S p o r t "v. t. To divert; to amuse; to make merry; -- used with the reciprocal pronoun.

Sport: S p o r t "v. t. To represent by any knd of play.

Sport: S p o r t "v. t. To exhibit  or bring out in public; to use or wear; as to sport a new equipage.

Sport: S p o r t "v. t. To give utterance to in a sportive manner; to throw out in an easy and copious manner; -- with off; as  to sport off epigrams.

Sportability: S p o r t a b i l i t y "n. Sportiveness.

Sportless: S p o r t l e s s "a. Without sport or mirth; joyless.

Sportling: S p o r t l i n g "n. A little person or creature engaged in sports or in play.

Sportsman: S p o r t s m a n "n. One who pursues the sports of the field; one who hunts  fishes etc.

Sportula: S p o r t u l a "n. A gift; a present; a prize; hence  an alms; a largess.
