Spot: S p o t "n. A mark on a substance or body made by foreign matter; a blot; a place discolored.

Spot: S p o t "n. A stain on character or reputation; something that soils purity; disgrace; reproach; fault; blemish.

Spot: S p o t "n. A small part of a different color from the main part  or from the ground upon which it is; as the spots of a leopard; the spots on a playing card.

Spot: S p o t "n. A small extent of space; a place; any particular place.

Spot: S p o t "n. A variety of the common domestic pigeon  so called from a spot on its head just above its beak.

Spot: S p o t "n. A sciaenoid food fish (Liostomus xanthurus) of the Atlantic coast of the United States. It has a black spot behind the shoulders and fifteen oblique dark bars on the sides. Called also goody  Lafayette masooka and old wife.

Spot: S p o t "n. The southern redfish  or red horse which has a spot on each side at the base of the tail. See Redfish.

Spot: S p o t "n. Commodities  as merchandise and cotton sold for immediate delivery.

Spot: S p o t "v. t. To make visible marks upon with some foreign matter; to discolor in or with spots; to stain; to cover with spots or figures; as  to spot a garnment; to spot paper.

Spot: S p o t "v. t. To mark or note so as to insure recognition; to recognize; to detect; as  to spot a criminal.

Spot: S p o t "v. t. To stain; to blemish; to taint; to disgrace; to tarnish  as reputation; to asperse.

Spot: S p o t "v. i. To become stained with spots.

Spotless: S p o t l e s s "a. Without a spot; especially  free from reproach or impurity; pure; untainted; innocent; as a spotless mind; spotless behavior.

Spousage: S p o u s a g e "v. t. Espousal.

Spousal: S p o u s a l "a. Of or pertaining to a spouse or marriage; nuptial; matrimonial; conjugal; bridal; as  spousal rites; spousal ornaments.

Spousal: S p o u s a l "n. Marriage; nuptials; espousal; -- generally used in the plural; as  the spousals of Hippolita.

Spouse: S p o u s e "n. A man or woman engaged or joined in wedlock; a married person  husband or wife.

Spouse: S p o u s e "n. A married man  in distinct from a spousess or married woman; a bridegroom or husband.

Spouse: S p o u s e "n. To wed; to espouse.

Spout: S p o u t "v. t. To throw out forcibly and abudantly  as liquids through an office or a pipe; to eject in a jet; as an elephant spouts water from his trunk.

Spout: S p o u t "v. t. To utter magniloquently; to recite in an oratorical or pompous manner.

Spout: S p o u t "v. t. To pawn; to pledge; as  spout a watch.

Spout: S p o u t "v. i. To issue with with violence  or in a jet as a liquid through a narrow orifice or from a spout; as water spouts from a hole; blood spouts from an artery.

Spout: S p o u t "v. i. To eject water or liquid in a jet.

Spout: S p o u t "v. i. To utter a speech  especially in a pompous manner.

Spout: S p o u t "v. t. That through which anything spouts; a discharging lip  pipe or orifice; a tube pipe or conductor of any kind through which a liquid is poured or by which it is conveyed in a stream from one place to another; as the spout of a teapot; a spout for conducting water from the roof of a building.

Spout: S p o u t "v. t. A trough for conducting grain  flour etc. into a receptacle.

Spout: S p o u t "v. t. A discharge or jet of water or other liquid  esp. when rising in a column; also a waterspout.

Spouted: S p o u t e d "imp. & p. p. of Spout

Spouter: S p o u t e r "n. One who  or that which spouts.

Spoutfish: S p o u t f i s h "n. A marine animal that spouts water; -- applied especially to certain bivalve mollusks  like the long clams (Mya) which spout or squirt out water when retiring into their holes.

Spouting: S p o u t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Spout

Sprang: S p r a n g "imp. of Spring

Sprat: S p r a t "n. A small European herring (Clupea sprattus) closely allied to the common herring and the pilchard; -- called also garvie. The name is also applied to small herring of different kinds.

Sprat: S p r a t "n. A California surf-fish (Rhacochilus toxotes); -- called also alfione  and perch.

Sprawl: S p r a w l "v. i. To spread and stretch the body or limbs carelessly in a horizontal position; to lie with the limbs stretched out ungracefully.

Sprawl: S p r a w l "v. i. To spread irregularly  as vines plants or tress; to spread ungracefully as chirography.

Spray: S p r a y "n. A small shoot or branch; a twig.

Spray: S p r a y "n. A collective body of small branches; as  the tree has a beautiful spray.

Spray: S p r a y "n. A side channel or branch of the runner of a flask  made to distribute the metal in all parts of the mold.

Spray: S p r a y "n. A group of castings made in the same mold and connected by sprues formed in the runner and its branches.

Spray: S p r a y "v. t. Water flying in small drops or particles  as by the force of wind or the dashing of waves or from a waterfall and the like.

Spray: S p r a y "v. t. A jet of fine medicated vapor  used either as an application to a diseased part or to charge the air of a room with a disinfectant or a deodorizer.

Spray: S p r a y "v. t. An instrument for applying such a spray; an atomizer.

Spray: S p r a y "v. t. To let fall in the form of spray.

Spray: S p r a y "v. t. To throw spray upon; to treat with a liquid in the form of spray; as  to spray a wound or a surgical instrument with carbolic acid.

Spread: S p r e a d "v. t. To extend in length and breadth  or in breadth only; to stretch or expand to a broad or broader surface or extent; to open; to unfurl; as to spread a carpet; to spread a tent or a sail.

Spread: S p r e a d "v. t. To extend so as to cover something; to extend to a great or grater extent in every direction; to cause to fill or cover a wide or wider space.

Spread: S p r e a d "v. t. To divulge; to publish  as news or fame; to cause to be more extensively known; to disseminate; to make known fully; as to spread a report; -- often acompanied by abroad.

Spread: S p r e a d "v. t. To propagate; to cause to affect great numbers; as  to spread a disease.

Spread: S p r e a d "v. t. To diffuse  as emanations or effluvia; to emit; as odoriferous plants spread their fragrance.

Spread: S p r e a d "v. t. To strew; to scatter over a surface; as  to spread manure; to spread lime on the ground.

Spread: S p r e a d "v. t. To prepare; to set and furnish with provisions; as  to spread a table.

Spread: S p r e a d "v. i. To be extended by drawing or beating; as  some metals spread with difficulty.

Spread: S p r e a d "v. i. To be made known more extensively  as news.

Spread: S p r e a d "v. i. To be propagated from one to another; as  the disease spread into all parts of the city.

Spread: S p r e a d "n. A privilege which one person buys of another  of demanding certain shares of stock at a certain price or of delivering the same shares of stock at another price within a time agreed upon.

Spring: S p r i n g "v. i. To leap; to bound; to jump.

Spring: S p r i n g "v. i. To issue with speed and violence; to move with activity; to dart; to shoot.

Spring: S p r i n g "v. i. To start or rise suddenly  as from a covert.

Spring: S p r i n g "v. i. To fly back; as  a bow when bent springs back by its elastic power.

Spring: S p r i n g "v. i. To bend from a straight direction or plane surface; to become warped; as  a piece of timber or a plank sometimes springs in seasoning.

Spring: S p r i n g "v. i. To shoot up  out or forth; to come to the light; to begin to appear; to emerge; as a plant from its seed as streams from their source and the like; -often followed by up forth or out.

Spring: S p r i n g "v. i. To issue or proceed  as from a parent or ancestor; to result as from a cause motive reason or principle.

Spring: S p r i n g "v. i. To grow; to prosper.

Spring: S p r i n g "v. t. To cause to spring up; to start or rouse  as game; to cause to rise from the earth or from a covert; as to spring a pheasant.

Spring: S p r i n g "v. t. To produce or disclose suddenly or unexpectedly.

Spring: S p r i n g "v. t. To cause to explode; as  to spring a mine.

Spring: S p r i n g "v. t. To crack or split; to bend or strain so as to weaken; as  to spring a mast or a yard.

Spring: S p r i n g "v. t. To cause to close suddenly  as the parts of a trap operated by a spring; as to spring a trap.

Spring: S p r i n g "v. t. To bend by force  as something stiff or strong; to force or put by bending as a beam into its sockets and allowing it to straighten when in place; -- often with in out etc.; as to spring in a slat or a bar.

Spring: S p r i n g "v. t. To pass over by leaping; as  to spring a fence.

Spring: S p r i n g "v. i. A leap; a bound; a jump.

Spring: S p r i n g "v. i. A flying back; the resilience of a body recovering its former state by elasticity; as  the spring of a bow.

Spring: S p r i n g "v. i. Elastic power or force.

Spring: S p r i n g "v. i. An elastic body of any kind  as steel India rubber tough wood or compressed air used for various mechanical purposes as receiving and imparting power diminishing concussion regulating motion measuring weight or other force.

Spring: S p r i n g "v. i. Any source of supply; especially  the source from which a stream proceeds; as issue of water from the earth; a natural fountain.

Spring: S p r i n g "v. i. Any active power; that by which action  or motion is produced or propagated; cause; origin; motive.

Spring: S p r i n g "v. i. That which springs  or is originated from a source;

Spring: S p r i n g "v. i. A race; lineage.

Spring: S p r i n g "v. i. A youth; a springal.

Spring: S p r i n g "v. i. A shoot; a plant; a young tree; also  a grove of trees; woodland.

Spring: S p r i n g "v. i. That which causes one to spring; specifically  a lively tune.

Spring: S p r i n g "v. i. The season of the year when plants begin to vegetate and grow; the vernal season  usually comprehending the months of March April and May in the middle latitudes north of the equator.

Spring: S p r i n g "v. i. The time of growth and progress; early portion; first stage.

Spring: S p r i n g "v. i. A crack or fissure in a mast or yard  running obliquely or transversely.

Spring: S p r i n g "v. i. A line led from a vessel's quarter to her cable so that by tightening or slacking it she can be made to lie in any desired position; a line led diagonally from the bow or stern of a vessel to some point upon the wharf to which she is moored.

Springboard: S p r i n g b o a r d "n. An elastic board  secured at the ends or at one end often by elastic supports used in performing feats of agility or in exercising.

Springbok: S p r i n g b o k "n. Alt. of Springbuck

Springbuck: S p r i n g b u c k "n. A South African gazelle (Gazella euchore) noted for its graceful form and swiftness  and for its peculiar habit of springing lighty and suddenly into the air. It has a white dorsal stripe expanding into a broad patch of white on the rump and tail. Called also springer.

Springer: S p r i n g e r "n. The bottom stone of an arch  which lies on the impost. The skew back is one form of springer.

Springer: S p r i n g e r "n. The rib of a groined vault  as being the solid abutment for each section of vaulting.

Springer: S p r i n g e r "n. The grampus.

Springle: S p r i n g l e "n. A springe.

Springlet: S p r i n g l e t "n. A little spring.

Springtail: S p r i n g t a i l "n. Any one of numerous species of small apterous insects belonging to the order Thysanura. They have two elastic caudal stylets which can be bent under the abdomen and then suddenly extended like a spring  thus enabling them to leap to a considerable distance. See Collembola and Podura.

Springtime: S p r i n g t i m e "n. The season of spring; springtide.

Springy: S p r i n g y "superl. Abounding with springs or fountains; wet; spongy; as  springy land.

Spumy: S p u m y "a. Consisting of  containing or covered with froth scum or foam; frothy; foamy.

Spun: S p u n "imp. & p. p. of Spin

Spun: S p u n " imp. & p. p. of Spin.

Spunge: S p u n g e "n. A sponge.

Spunk: S p u n k "n. Wood that readily takes fire; touchwood; also  a kind of tinder made from a species of fungus; punk; amadou.

Spunk: S p u n k "n. An inflammable temper; spirit; mettle; pluck; as  a man of spunk.

Spunky: S p u n k y "superl. Full of spunk; quick; spirited.

Spur: S p u r "n. A sparrow.

Spur: S p u r "n. A tern.

Spur: S p u r "n. An implement secured to the heel  or above the heel of a horseman to urge the horse by its pressure. Modern spurs have a small wheel or rowel with short points. Spurs were the badge of knighthood.

Spur: S p u r "n. That which goads to action; an incitement.

Spur: S p u r "n. Something that projects; a snag.

Spur: S p u r "n. One of the large or principal roots of a tree.

Spur: S p u r "n. Any stiff  sharp spine as on the wings and legs of certain burds on the legs of insects etc.; especially the spine on a cock's leg.

Spur: S p u r "n. A mountain that shoots from any other mountain  or range of mountains and extends to some distance in a lateral direction or at right angles.

Spur: S p u r "n. A spiked iron worn by seamen upon the bottom of the boot  to enable them to stand upon the carcass of a whale to strip off the blubber.

Spur: S p u r "n. A brace strengthening a post and some connected part  as a rafter or crossbeam; a strut.

Spur: S p u r "n. The short wooden buttress of a post.

Spur: S p u r "n. A projection from the round base of a column  occupying the angle of a square plinth upon which the base rests or bringing the bottom bed of the base to a nearly square form. It is generally carved in leafage.

Spur: S p u r "n. Any projecting appendage of a flower looking like a spur.

Spur: S p u r "n. Ergotized rye or other grain.

Spur: S p u r "n. A wall that crosses a part of a rampart and joins to an inner wall.

Spur: S p u r "n. A piece of timber fixed on the bilge ways before launching  having the upper ends bolted to the vessel's side.

Spur: S p u r "n. A curved piece of timber serving as a half to support the deck where a whole beam can not be placed.

Spur: S p u r "v. t. To prick with spurs; to incite to a more hasty pace; to urge or goad; as  to spur a horse.

Spur: S p u r "v. t. To urge or encourage to action  or to a more vigorous pursuit of an object; to incite; to stimulate; to instigate; to impel; to drive.

Spur: S p u r "v. t. To put spurs on; as  a spurred boot.

Spur: S p u r "v. i. To spur on one' horse; to travel with great expedition; to hasten; hence  to press forward in any pursuit.

Spur-royal: S p u r - r o y a l "n. A gold coin  first made in the reign of Edward IV. having a star on the reverse resembling the rowel of a spur. In the reigns of Elizabeth and of James I. its value was fifteen shillings.

Spur-shell: S p u r - s h e l l "n. Any one of several species of handsome gastropod shells of the genus Trochus  or Imperator. The shell is conical with the margin toothed somewhat like the rowel of a spur.

Spur-winged: S p u r - w i n g e d "a. Having one or more spurs on the bend of the wings.

Spurgall: S p u r g a l l "n. A place galled or excoriated by much using of the spur.

Spurgall: S p u r g a l l "v. t. To gall or wound with a spur.

Spurge: S p u r g e "v. t. To emit foam; to froth; -- said of the emission of yeast from beer in course of fermentation.

Spurge: S p u r g e "n. Any plant of the genus Euphorbia. See Euphorbia.

Spurgewort: S p u r g e w o r t "n. Any euphorbiaceous plant.

Spurging: S p u r g i n g "n. A purging.

Spurious: S p u r i o u s "a. Not proceeding from the true source  or from the source pretended; not genuine; false; adulterate.

Spurious: S p u r i o u s "a. Not legitimate; bastard; as  spurious issue.

Spurless: S p u r l e s s "a. Having no spurs.

Spurling: S p u r l i n g "n. A tern.

Spurling-line: S p u r l i n g - l i n e "n. The line which forms the communication between the steering wheel and the telltale.

Spurn: S p u r n "v. t. To drive back or away  as with the foot; to kick.

Spurn: S p u r n "v. t. To reject with disdain; to scorn to receive or accept; to treat with contempt.

Spurn: S p u r n "v. i. To kick or toss up the heels.

Spurn: S p u r n "v. i. To manifest disdain in rejecting anything; to make contemptuous opposition or resistance.

Spurn: S p u r n "n. A kick; a blow with the foot.

Spurn: S p u r n "n. Disdainful rejection; contemptuous tratment.

Spurn: S p u r n "n. A body of coal left to sustain an overhanding mass.

Spurn-water: S p u r n - w a t e r "n. A channel at the end of a deck to restrain the water.

Spurner: S p u r n e r "n. One who spurns.

Spurred: S p u r r e d "a. Wearing spurs; furnished with a spur or spurs; having shoots like spurs.

Spurred: S p u r r e d "a. Affected with spur  or ergot; as spurred rye.

Spurrer: S p u r r e r "n. One who spurs.

Spurrey: S p u r r e y "n. See Spurry.

Spurrier: S p u r r i e r "n. One whose occupation is to make spurs.

Spurry: S p u r r y "n. An annual herb (Spergula arvensis) with whorled filiform leaves  sometimes grown in Europe for fodder.

Spurt: S p u r t "v. i. To gush or issue suddenly or violently out in a stream  as liquor from a cask; to rush from a confined place in a small stream or jet; to spirt.

Spurt: S p u r t "v. t. To throw out  as a liquid in a stream or jet; to drive or force out with violence as a liquid from a pipe or small orifice; as to spurt water from the mouth.

Spurt: S p u r t "n. A sudden and energetic effort  as in an emergency; an increased exertion for a brief space.

Spurt: S p u r t "v. i. To make a sudden and violent exertion  as in an emergency.

Sputation: S p u t a t i o n "n. The act of spitting; expectoration.

Sputative: S p u t a t i v e "a. Inclined to spit; spitting much.

Spute: S p u t e "v. t. To dispute; to discuss.

Sputter: S p u t t e r "v. i. To spit  or to emit saliva from the mouth in small scattered portions as in rapid speaking.

Sputter: S p u t t e r "v. i. To utter words hastily and indistinctly; to speak so rapidly as to emit saliva.

Sputter: S p u t t e r "v. i. To throw out anything  as little jets of steam with a noise like that made by one sputtering.

Sputter: S p u t t e r "v. t. To spit out hastily by quick  successive efforts with a spluttering sound; to utter hastily and confusedly without control over the organs of speech.

Sputter: S p u t t e r "n. Moist matter thrown out in small detached particles; also  confused and hasty speech.

Sputum: S p u t u m "n. That which is expectorated; a salival discharge; spittle; saliva.

Spy: S p y "v. t. To gain sight of; to discover at a distance  or in a state of concealment; to espy; to see.

Spy: S p y "v. t. To discover by close search or examination.

Spy: S p y "v. t. To explore; to view; inspect; and examine secretly  as a country; -- usually with out.

Spy: S p y "v. i. To search narrowly; to scrutinize.

Spy: S p y "n. One who keeps a constant watch of the conduct of others.

Spy: S p y "n. A person sent secretly into an enemy's camp  territory or fortifications to inspect his works ascertain his strength movements or designs and to communicate such intelligence to the proper officer.

Spyboat: S p y b o a t "n. A boat sent to make discoveries and bring intelligence.

Spyglass: S p y g l a s s "n. A small telescope for viewing distant terrestrial objects.

Squab: S q u a b "a. Unfledged; unfeathered; as  a squab pigeon.

Squab: S q u a b "n. A neatling of a pigeon or other similar bird  esp. when very fat and not fully fledged.

Squab: S q u a b "n. A person of a short  fat figure.

Squab: S q u a b "n. A thickly stuffed cushion; especially  one used for the seat of a sofa couch or chair; also a sofa.

Squab: S q u a b "adv. With a heavy fall; plump.

Squab: S q u a b "v. i. To fall plump; to strike at one dash  or with a heavy stroke.

Squad: S q u a d "n. Sloppy mud.

Squadron: S q u a d r o n "n. A body of cavarly comparising two companies or troops  and averging from one hundred and twenty to two hundred men.

Squadron: S q u a d r o n "n. A detachment of vessels employed on any particular service or station  under the command of the senior officer; as the North Atlantic Squadron.

Squadroned: S q u a d r o n e d "a. Formed into squadrons  or squares.

Squali: S q u a l i "n. pl. The suborder of elasmobranch fishes which comprises the sharks.

Squalid: S q u a l i d "a. Dirty through neglect; foul; filthy; extremely dirty.

Squall: S q u a l l "n. A sudden violent gust of wind often attended with rain or snow.

Squall: S q u a l l "v. i. To cry out; to scream or cry violently  as a woman frightened or a child in anger or distress; as the infant squalled.

Squally: S q u a l l y "a. Interrupted by unproductive spots; -- said of a flied of turnips or grain.

Squally: S q u a l l y "a. Not equally good throughout; not uniform; uneven; faulty; -- said of cloth.

Squalodon: S q u a l o d o n "n. A genus of fossil whales belonging to the Phocodontia; -- so called because their are serrated  like a shark's.

Squalodont: S q u a l o d o n t "a. Pertaining to Squalodon.

Squaloid: S q u a l o i d "a. Like or pertaining to a shark or sharks.

Squamae: S q u a m a e "pl. "of Squama

Squamata: S q u a m a t a "n. pl. A division of edentates having the body covered with large  imbricated horny scales. It includes the pangolins.

Squamate: S q u a m a t e "a. Alt. of Squamated

Squamated: S q u a m a t e d "a. Same as Squamose.

Squamduck: S q u a m d u c k " The American eider duck.

Squame: S q u a m e "n. A scale.

Squame: S q u a m e "n. The scale  or exopodite of an antenna of a crustacean.

Squamella: S q u a m e l l a "n. A diminutive scale or bractlet  such as those found on the receptacle in many composite plants; a palea.

Squamellae: S q u a m e l l a e "pl. "of Squamella

Squamellate: S q u a m e l l a t e "a. Furnished or covered with little scales; squamulose.

Squamiform: S q u a m i f o r m "a. Having the shape of a scale.

Squamigerous: S q u a m i g e r o u s "a. Bearing scales.

Squamipen: S q u a m i p e n "n. Any one of a group of fishes having the dorsal and anal fins partially covered with scales.

Squamipennes: S q u a m i p e n n e s "pl. "of Squamipen

Squamoid: S q u a m o i d "a. Resembling a scale; also  covered with scales; scaly.

Squamosal: S q u a m o s a l "a. Scalelike; squamous; as  the squamosal bone.

Squamosal: S q u a m o s a l "a. Of or pertaining to the squamosal bone.

Squamosal: S q u a m o s a l "n. The squamous part of the temporal bone  or a bone correspondending to it under Temporal.

Squamose: S q u a m o s e " Alt. of Squamous

Squamous: S q u a m o u s " Covered with  or consisting of scales; resembling a scale; scaly; as the squamose cones of the pine; squamous epithelial cells; the squamous portion of the temporal bone which is so called from a fancied resemblance to a scale.

Squamous: S q u a m o u s " Of or pertaining to the squamosal bone; squamosal.

Squamozygomatic: S q u a m o z y g o m a t i c "a. Of or pertaining to both the squamosal and zygomatic bones; -- applied to a bone  or a center of ossification in some fetal skulls.

Squamozygomatic: S q u a m o z y g o m a t i c "n. A squamozygomatic bone.

Squamula: S q u a m u l a "n. One of the little hypogynous scales found in the flowers of grasses; a lodicule.

Squamulae: S q u a m u l a e "pl. "of Squamula

Squamule: S q u a m u l e "n. Same as Squamula.

Squamulose: S q u a m u l o s e "a. Having little scales; squamellate; squamulate.

Square: S q u a r e "n. The corner  or angle of a figure.

Square: S q u a r e "n. A parallelogram having four equal sides and four right angles.

Square: S q u a r e "n. Hence  anything which is square or nearly so

Square: S q u a r e "n. A square piece or fragment.

Square: S q u a r e "n. A pane of glass.

Square: S q u a r e "n. A certain number of lines  forming a portion of a column nearly square; -- used chiefly in reckoning the prices of advertisements in newspapers.

Square: S q u a r e "n. One hundred superficial feet.

Square: S q u a r e "n. An area of four sides  generally with houses on each side; sometimes a solid block of houses; also an open place or area for public use as at the meeting or intersection of two or more streets.

Square: S q u a r e "n. An instrument having at least one right angle and two or more straight edges  used to lay out or test square work. It is of several forms as the T square the carpenter's square the try-square. etc.

Square: S q u a r e "n. Hence  a pattern or rule.

Square: S q u a r e "n. The product of a number or quantity multiplied by itself; thus  64 is the square of 8 for 8 / 8 = 64; the square of a + b is a2 + 2ab + b2.

Square: S q u a r e "n. Exact proportion; justness of workmanship and conduct; regularity; rule.

Square: S q u a r e "n. A body of troops formed in a square  esp. one formed to resist a charge of cavalry; a squadron.

Square: S q u a r e "n. Fig.: The relation of harmony  or exact agreement; equality; level.

Square: S q u a r e "n. The position of planets distant ninety degrees from each other; a quadrate.

Square: S q u a r e "n. The act of squaring  or quarreling; a quarrel.

Square: S q u a r e "n. The front of a woman's dress over the bosom  usually worked or embroidered.

Square: S q u a r e "a. Having four equal sides and four right angles; as  a square figure.

Square: S q u a r e "a. Forming a right angle; as  a square corner.

Square: S q u a r e "a. Having a shape broad for the height  with rectilineal and angular rather than curving outlines; as a man of a square frame.

Square: S q u a r e "a. Exactly suitable or correspondent; true; just.

Square: S q u a r e "a. Rendering equal justice; exact; fair; honest  as square dealing.

Square: S q u a r e "a. Even; leaving no balance; as  to make or leave the accounts square.

Square: S q u a r e "a. Leaving nothing; hearty; vigorous.

Square: S q u a r e "a. At right angles with the mast or the keel  and parallel to the horizon; -- said of the yards of a square-rigged vessel when they are so braced.

Square: S q u a r e "n. To form with four sides and four right angles.

Square: S q u a r e "n. To form with right angles and straight lines  or flat surfaces; as to square mason's work.

Square: S q u a r e "n. To compare with  or reduce to any given measure or standard.

Square: S q u a r e "n. To adjust; to regulate; to mold; to shape; to fit; as  to square our actions by the opinions of others.

Square: S q u a r e "n. To make even  so as leave no remainder of difference; to balance; as to square accounts.

Square: S q u a r e "n. To multiply by itself; as  to square a number or a quantity.

Square: S q u a r e "n. To hold a quartile position respecting.

Square: S q u a r e "n. To place at right angles with the keel; as  to square the yards.

Square: S q u a r e "v. i. To accord or agree exactly; to be consistent with; to conform or agree; to suit; to fit.

Square: S q u a r e "v. i. To go to opposite sides; to take an attitude of offense or defense  or of defiance; to quarrel.

Square: S q u a r e "v. i. To take a boxing attitude; -- often with up  sometimes with off.

Square-rigged: S q u a r e - r i g g e d "a. Having the sails extended upon yards suspended horizontally by the middle  as distinguished from fore-and-aft sails; thus a ship and a brig are square-rigged vessels.

Square-toed: S q u a r e - t o e d "n. Having the toe square.

Square-toes: S q u a r e - t o e s "n. A precise person; -- used contemptuously or jocularly.

Squared: S q u a r e d "imp. & p. p. of Square

Squarely: S q u a r e l y "adv. In a square form or manner.

Squareness: S q u a r e n e s s "n. The quality of being square; as  an instrument to try the squareness of work.

Squarer: S q u a r e r "n. One who  or that which squares.

Squarer: S q u a r e r "n. One who squares  or quarrels; a hot-headed contentious fellow.

Squaring: S q u a r i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Square

Squarish: S q u a r i s h "a. Nearly square.

Squarrose: S q u a r r o s e "a. Ragged or full of lose scales or projecting parts; rough; jagged

Squarrose: S q u a r r o s e "a. Consisting of scales widely divaricating; having scales  small leaves or other bodies spreading widely from the axis on which they are crowded; -- said of a calyx or stem.

Squarrose: S q u a r r o s e "a. Divided into shreds or jags  raised above the plane of the leaf and not parallel to it; said of a leaf.

Squarrose: S q u a r r o s e "a. Having scales spreading every way  or standing upright or at right angles to the surface; -- said of a shell.

Squarroso-dentate: S q u a r r o s o - d e n t a t e "a. Having the teeth bent out of the plane of the lamina; -- said of a leaf.

Squarrous: S q u a r r o u s "a. Squarrose.

Squarrulose: S q u a r r u l o s e "a. Somewhat squarrose; slightly squarrose.

Squash: S q u a s h "n. An American animal allied to the weasel.

Squash: S q u a s h "n. A plant and its fruit of the genus Cucurbita  or gourd kind.

Squash: S q u a s h "v. i. To beat or press into pulp or a flat mass; to crush.

Squash: S q u a s h "n. Something soft and easily crushed; especially  an unripe pod of pease.

Squash: S q u a s h "n. Hence  something unripe or soft; -- used in contempt.

Squash: S q u a s h "n. A sudden fall of a heavy  soft body; also a shock of soft bodies.

Squashed: S q u a s h e d "imp. & p. p. of Squash

Squasher: S q u a s h e r "n. One who  or that which squashes.

Squashy: S q u a s h y "a. Easily squashed; soft.

Squat: S q u a t "n. The angel fish (Squatina angelus).

Squat: S q u a t "v. t. To sit down upon the hams or heels; as  the savages squatted near the fire.

Squat: S q u a t "v. t. To sit close to the ground; to cower; to stoop  or lie close to escape observation as a partridge or rabbit.

Squat: S q u a t "v. t. To settle on another's land without title; also  to settle on common or public lands.

Squat: S q u a t "v. t. To bruise or make flat by a fall.

Squat: S q u a t "a. Sitting on the hams or heels; sitting close to the ground; cowering; crouching.

Squat: S q u a t "a. Short and thick  like the figure of an animal squatting.

Squat: S q u a t "n. The posture of one that sits on his heels or hams  or close to the ground.

Squat: S q u a t "n. A sudden or crushing fall.

Squat: S q u a t "n. A small vein of ore.

Squat: S q u a t "n. A mineral consisting of tin ore and spar.

Squaterole: S q u a t e r o l e "n. The black-bellied plover.

Squatted: S q u a t t e d "imp. & p. p. of Squat

Squatter: S q u a t t e r "n. One who squats; specifically  one who settles unlawfully upon land without a title. In the United States and Australia the term is sometimes applied also to a person who settles lawfully upon government land under permission and restrictions before acquiring title.

Squatter: S q u a t t e r "n. See Squat snipe  under Squat.

Squatting: S q u a t t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Squat

Squatty: S q u a t t y "a. Squat; dumpy.

Squaw: S q u a w "n. A female; a woman; -- in the language of Indian tribes of the Algonquin family  correlative of sannup.

Squawberry: S q u a w b e r r y "n. A local name for the partridge berry; also  for the deerberry.

Squawk: S q u a w k "v. i. To utter a shrill  abrupt scream; to squeak harshly.

Squawroot: S q u a w r o o t "n. A scaly parasitic plant (Conopholis Americana) found in oak woods in the United States; -- called also cancer root.

Squawweed: S q u a w w e e d "n. The golden ragwort. See under Ragwort.

Squeak: S q u e a k "v. i. To utter a sharp  shrill cry usually of short duration; to cry with an acute tone as an animal; or to make a sharp disagreeable noise as a pipe or quill a wagon wheel a door; to creak.

Squeak: S q u e a k "v. i. To break silence or secrecy for fear of pain or punishment; to speak; to confess.

Squeak: S q u e a k "n. A sharp  shrill disagreeable sound suddenly utered either of the human voice or of any animal or instrument such as is made by carriage wheels when dry by the soles of leather shoes or by a pipe or reed.

Squeaker: S q u e a k e r "n. One who  or that which squeaks.

Squeaker: S q u e a k e r "n. The Australian gray crow shrile (Strepera anaphonesis); -- so called from its note.

Squeaking: S q u e a k i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Squeak

Squeakingly: S q u e a k i n g l y "adv. In a squeaking manner.

Squeal: S q u e a l "v. i. To cry with a sharp  shrill prolonged sound as certain animals do indicating want displeasure or pain.

Squeal: S q u e a l "v. i. To turn informer; to betray a secret.

Squeal: S q u e a l "n. A shrill  somewhat prolonged cry.

Squeamish: S q u e a m i s h "a. Having a stomach that is easily or nauseated; hence  nice to excess in taste; fastidious; easily disgusted; apt to be offended at trifling improprieties.

Squeamous: S q u e a m o u s "a. Squeamish.

Squeasiness: S q u e a s i n e s s "n. Queasiness.

Squeegee: S q u e e g e e "n. Same as Squilgee.

Squeeze: S q u e e z e "v. t. To press between two bodies; to press together closely; to compress; often  to compress so as to expel juice moisture etc.; as to squeeze an orange with the fingers; to squeeze the hand in friendship.

Squeeze: S q u e e z e "v. t. Fig.: To oppress with hardships  burdens or taxes; to harass; to crush.

Squeeze: S q u e e z e "v. t. To force  or cause to pass by compression; often with out through etc.; as to squeeze water through felt.

Squeeze: S q u e e z e "v. i. To press; to urge one's way  or to pass by pressing; to crowd; -- often with through into etc.; as to squeeze hard to get through a crowd.

Squeeze: S q u e e z e "n. The act of one who squeezes; compression between bodies; pressure.

Squeeze: S q u e e z e "n. A facsimile impression taken in some soft substance  as pulp from an inscription on stone.

Squeezed: S q u e e z e d "imp. & p. p. of Squeeze

Squeezer: S q u e e z e r "n. One who  or that which squeezes; as a lemon squeezer.

Squeezer: S q u e e z e r "n. A machine like a large pair of pliers  for shingling or squeezing the balls of metal when puddled; -- used only in the plural.

Squeezer: S q u e e z e r "n. A machine of several forms for the same purpose; -- used in the singular.

Squeezing: S q u e e z i n g "n. Same as Squeeze  n. 2.

Squesy: S q u e s y "a. Queasy; nice; squeamish; fastidious; scrupulous.

Squeteague: S q u e t e a g u e "n. An American sciaenoid fish (Cynoscion regalis)  abundant on the Atlantic coast of the United States and much valued as a food fish. It is of a bright silvery color with iridescent reflections. Called also weakfish squitee chickwit and sea trout. The spotted squeteague (C. nebulosus) of the Southern United States is a similar fish but the back and upper fins are spotted with black. It is called also spotted weakfish and locally sea trout and sea salmon.

Squib: S q u i b "a. A little pipe  or hollow cylinder of paper filled with powder or combustible matter to be thrown into the air while burning so as to burst there with a crack.

Squib: S q u i b "a. A kind of slow match or safety fuse.

Squib: S q u i b "a. A sarcastic speech or publication; a petty lampoon; a brief  witty essay.

Squib: S q u i b "a. A writer of lampoons.

Squib: S q u i b "a. A paltry fellow.

Squib: S q u i b "v. i. To throw squibs; to utter sarcatic or severe reflections; to contend in petty dispute; as  to squib a little debate.

Squibbed: S q u i b b e d "imp. & p. p. of Squib

Squibbing: S q u i b b i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Squib

Squid: S q u i d "n. Any one of numerous species of ten-armed cephalopods having a long  tapered body and a caudal fin on each side; especially any species of Loligo Ommastrephes and related genera. See Calamary Decacerata Dibranchiata.

Squid: S q u i d "n. A fishhook with a piece of bright lead  bone or other substance fastened on its shank to imitate a squid.

Squier: S q u i e r "n. A square. See 1st Squire.

Squierie: S q u i e r i e "n. Alt. of Squiery

Squiery: S q u i e r y "n. A company of squires; the whole body of squires.

Squiggle: S q u i g g l e "v. i. To shake and wash a fluid about in the mouth with the lips closed.

Squiggle: S q u i g g l e "v. i. To move about like an eel; to squirm.

Squilgee: S q u i l g e e "n. Formerly  a small swab for drying a vessel's deck; now a kind of scraper having a blade or edge of rubber or of leather -- used for removing superfluous water or other liquids as from a vessel's deck after washing from window panes photographer's plates etc.

Squill: S q u i l l "n. A European bulbous liliaceous plant (Urginea  formerly Scilla maritima) of acrid expectorant diuretic and emetic properties used in medicine. Called also sea onion.

Squill: S q u i l l "n. Any bulbous plant of the genus Scilla; as  the bluebell squill (S. mutans).

Squill: S q u i l l "n. A squilla.

Squill: S q u i l l "n. A mantis.

Squilla: S q u i l l a "n. Any one of numerous stomapod crustaceans of the genus Squilla and allied genera. They make burrows in mud or beneath stones on the seashore. Called also mantis shrimp. See Illust. under Stomapoda.

Squillae: S q u i l l a e "pl. "of Squilla

Squillas: S q u i l l a s "pl. "of Squilla

Squillitic: S q u i l l i t i c "a. Of or pertaining to squills.

Squinance: S q u i n a n c e "n. Alt. of Squinancy

Squinancy: S q u i n a n c y "n. The quinsy. See Quinsy.

Squinancy: S q u i n a n c y "n. A European perennial herb (Asperula cynanchica) with narrowly linear whorled leaves; -- formerly thought to cure the quinsy. Also called quincewort.

Squinch: S q u i n c h "n. A small arch thrown across the corner of a square room to support a superimposed mass  as where an octagonal spire or drum rests upon a square tower; -- called also sconce and sconcheon.

Squinsy: S q u i n s y "n. See Quinsy.

Squint: S q u i n t "a. Looking obliquely. Specifically (Med.)  not having the optic axes coincident; -- said of the eyes. See Squint n. 2.

Squint: S q u i n t "n. Fig.: Looking askance.

Squint: S q u i n t "v. i. To see or look obliquely  asquint or awry or with a furtive glance.

Squint: S q u i n t "v. i. To have the axes of the eyes not coincident; -- to be cross-eyed.

Squint: S q u i n t "v. i. To deviate from a true line; to run obliquely.

Squint: S q u i n t "v. t. To turn to an oblique position; to direct obliquely; as  to squint an eye.

Squint: S q u i n t "v. t. To cause to look with noncoincident optic axes.

Squint: S q u i n t "n. The act or habit of squinting.

Squint: S q u i n t "n. A want of coincidence of the axes of the eyes; strabismus.

Squint: S q u i n t "n. Same as Hagioscope.

Squint-eye: S q u i n t - e y e "n. An eye that squints.

Squint-eyed: S q u i n t - e y e d "a. Having eyes that quint; having eyes with axes not coincident; cross-eyed.

Squint-eyed: S q u i n t - e y e d "a. Looking obliquely  or asquint; malignant; as squint-eyed praise; squint-eyed jealousy.

Squinted: S q u i n t e d "imp. & p. p. of Squint

squireling: s q u i r e l i n g "n. A petty squire.

Squirrel: S q u i r r e l "v. i. Any one of numerous species of small rodents belonging to the genus Sciurus and several allied genera of the family Sciuridae. Squirrels generally have a bushy tail  large erect ears and strong hind legs. They are commonly arboreal in their habits but many species live in burrows.

Squirrel: S q u i r r e l "v. i. One of the small rollers of a carding machine which work with the large cylinder.

Squirt: S q u i r t "v. t. To drive or eject in a stream out of a narrow pipe or orifice; as  to squirt water.

Squirt: S q u i r t "v. i. Hence  to throw out or utter words rapidly; to prate.

Squirt: S q u i r t "n. An instrument out of which a liquid is ejected in a small stream with force.

Squirt: S q u i r t "n. A small  quick stream; a jet.

Stab: S t a b "v. t. To pierce with a pointed weapon; to wound or kill by the thrust of a pointed instrument; as  to stab a man with a dagger; also to thrust; as to stab a dagger into a person.

Stabat Mater: S t a b a t   M a t e r " A celebrated Latin hymn  beginning with these words commemorating the sorrows of the mother of our Lord at the foot of the cross. It is read in the Mass of the Sorrows of the Virgin Mary and is sung by Catholics when making the way of the cross (Via Crucis). See Station 7 (c).

Stabiliment: S t a b i l i m e n t "a. The act of making firm; firm support; establishment.

Stabilitate: S t a b i l i t a t e "v. t. To make stable; to establish.

Stability: S t a b i l i t y "a. The state or quality of being stable  or firm; steadiness; firmness; strength to stand without being moved or overthrown; as the stability of a structure; the stability of a throne or a constitution.

Stability: S t a b i l i t y "a. Steadiness or firmness of character  firmness of resolution or purpose; the quality opposite to fickleness irresolution or inconstancy; constancy; steadfastness; as a man of little stability or of unusual stability.

Stability: S t a b i l i t y "a. Fixedness; -- as opposed to fluidity.

Stable: S t a b l e "v. i. Firmly established; not easily moved  shaken or overthrown; fixed; as a stable government.

Stable: S t a b l e "v. i. Steady in purpose; constant; firm in resolution; not easily diverted from a purpose; not fickle or wavering; as  a man of stable character.

Stable: S t a b l e "v. i. Durable; not subject to overthrow or change; firm; as  a stable foundation; a stable position.

Stable: S t a b l e "v. t. To fix; to establish.

Stable: S t a b l e "v. i. A house  shed or building for beasts to lodge and feed in; esp. a building or apartment with stalls for horses; as a horse stable; a cow stable.

Stable stand: S t a b l e   s t a n d " The position of a man who is found at his standing in the forest  with a crossbow or a longbow bent ready to shoot at a deer or close by a tree with greyhounds in a leash ready to slip; -- one of the four presumptions that a man intends stealing the king's deer.

Staccato: S t a c c a t o "a. Disconnected; separated; distinct; -- a direction to perform the notes of a passage in a short  distinct and pointed manner. It is opposed to legato and often indicated by heavy accents written over or under the notes or by dots when the performance is to be less distinct and emphatic.

Staccato: S t a c c a t o "a. Expressed in a brief  pointed manner.

Stack: S t a c k "a. A large pile of hay  grain straw or the like usually of a nearly conical form but sometimes rectangular or oblong contracted at the top to a point or ridge and sometimes covered with thatch.

Stack: S t a c k "a. A pile of poles or wood  indefinite in quantity.

Stack: S t a c k "a. A pile of wood containing 108 cubic feet.

Stack: S t a c k "a. A number of flues embodied in one structure  rising above the roof. Hence:

Stack: S t a c k "a. Any single insulated and prominent structure  or upright pipe which affords a conduit for smoke; as the brick smokestack of a factory; the smokestack of a steam vessel.

Stack: S t a c k "a. A section of memory in a computer used for temporary storage of data  in which the last datum stored is the first retrieved.

Stack: S t a c k "a. A data structure within random-access memory used to simulate a hardware stack; as  a push-down stack.

Stack: S t a c k "n. To lay in a conical or other pile; to make into a large pile; as  to stack hay cornstalks or grain; to stack or place wood.

Stack-guard: S t a c k - g u a r d "n. A covering or protection  as a canvas for a stack.

Stackstand: S t a c k s t a n d "n. A staging for supporting a stack of hay or grain; a rickstand.

Stackyard: S t a c k y a r d "n. A yard or inclosure for stacks of hay or grain.

Stacte: S t a c t e "n. One of the sweet spices used by the ancient Jews in the preparation of incense. It was perhaps an oil or other form of myrrh or cinnamon  or a kind of storax.

Staddle: S t a d d l e "v. i. Anything which serves for support; a staff; a prop; a crutch; a cane.

Staddle: S t a d d l e "v. i. The frame of a stack of hay or grain.

Staddle: S t a d d l e "v. i. A row of dried or drying hay  etc.

Staddle: S t a d d l e "v. i. A small tree of any kind  especially a forest tree.

Stade: S t a d e "n. A stadium.

Stade: S t a d e "n. A landing place or wharf.

Stadia: S t a d i a "pl. "of Stadium

Stadimeter: S t a d i m e t e r "n. A horizontal graduated bar mounted on a staff  used as a stadium or telemeter for measuring distances.

Stadium: S t a d i u m "n. A Greek measure of length  being the chief one used for itinerary distances also adopted by the Romans for nautical and astronomical measurements. It was equal to 600 Greek or 625 Roman feet or 125 Roman paces or to 606 feet 9 inches English. This was also called the Olympic stadium as being the exact length of the foot-race course at Olympia.

Stadium: S t a d i u m "n. Hence  a race course; especially the Olympic course for foot races.

Stadium: S t a d i u m "n. A kind of telemeter for measuring the distance of an object of known dimensions  by observing the angle it subtends; especially (Surveying) a graduated rod used to measure the distance of the place where it stands from an instrument having a telescope by observing the number of the graduations of the rod that are seen between certain parallel wires (stadia wires) in the field of view of the telescope; -- also called stadia and stadia rod.

Stadtholder: S t a d t h o l d e r "n. Formerly  the chief magistrate of the United Provinces of Holland; also the governor or lieutenant governor of a province.

Stadtholderate: S t a d t h o l d e r a t e "n. Alt. of Stadtholdership

Stadtholdership: S t a d t h o l d e r s h i p "n. The office or position of a stadtholder.

Stafette: S t a f e t t e "n. An estafet.

Staff: S t a f f "n. A long piece of wood; a stick; the long handle of an instrument or weapon; a pole or srick  used for many purposes; as a surveyor's staff; the staff of a spear or pike.

Staff: S t a f f "n. A stick carried in the hand for support or defense by a person walking; hence  a support; that which props or upholds.

Staff: S t a f f "n. A pole  stick or wand borne as an ensign of authority; a badge of office; as a constable's staff.

Staff: S t a f f "n. A pole upon which a flag is supported and displayed.

Staff: S t a f f "n. The round of a ladder.

Staff: S t a f f "n. A series of verses so disposed that  when it is concluded the same order begins again; a stanza; a stave.

Staff: S t a f f "n. The five lines and the spaces on which music is written; -- formerly called stave.

Staff: S t a f f "n. An arbor  as of a wheel or a pinion of a watch.

Staff: S t a f f "n. The grooved director for the gorget  or knife used in cutting for stone in the bladder.

Staff: S t a f f "n. An establishment of officers in various departments attached to an army  to a section of an army or to the commander of an army. The general's staff consists of those officers about his person who are employed in carrying his commands into execution. See Etat Major.

Staff: S t a f f "n. Hence: A body of assistants serving to carry into effect the plans of a superintendant or manager; as  the staff of a newspaper.

Staffier: S t a f f i e r "n. An attendant bearing a staff.

Stag: S t a g "n. The adult male of the red deer (Cervus elaphus)  a large European species closely related to the American elk or wapiti.

Stag: S t a g "n. The male of certain other species of large deer.

Stag: S t a g "n. A colt  or filly; also a romping girl.

Stag: S t a g "n. A castrated bull; -- called also bull stag  and bull seg. See the Note under Ox.

Stag: S t a g "n. An outside irregular dealer in stocks  who is not a member of the exchange.

Stag: S t a g "n. One who applies for the allotment of shares in new projects  with a view to sell immediately at a premium and not to hold the stock.

Stag: S t a g "n. The European wren.

Stag: S t a g "v. i. To act as a stag  or irregular dealer in stocks.

Stag: S t a g "v. t. To watch; to dog  or keep track of.

Stag-evil: S t a g - e v i l "n. A kind of palsy affecting the jaw of a horse.

Stag-horned: S t a g - h o r n e d "a. Having the mandibles large and palmate  or branched somewhat like the antlers of a stag; -- said of certain beetles.

Stage: S t a g e "n. A floor or story of a house.

Stage: S t a g e "n. An elevated platform on which an orator may speak  a play be performed an exhibition be presented or the like.

Stage: S t a g e "n. A floor elevated for the convenience of mechanical work  or the like; a scaffold; a staging.

Stage: S t a g e "n. A platform  often floating serving as a kind of wharf.

Stage: S t a g e "n. The floor for scenic performances; hence  the theater; the playhouse; hence also the profession of representing dramatic compositions; the drama as acted or exhibited.

Stage: S t a g e "n. A place where anything is publicly exhibited; the scene of any noted action or carrer; the spot where any remarkable affair occurs.

Stage: S t a g e "n. The platform of a microscope  upon which an object is placed to be viewed. See Illust. of Microscope.

Stage: S t a g e "n. A place of rest on a regularly traveled road; a stage house; a station; a place appointed for a relay of horses.

Stage: S t a g e "n. A degree of advancement in a journey; one of several portions into which a road or course is marked off; the distance between two places of rest on a road; as  a stage of ten miles.

Stage: S t a g e "n. A degree of advancement in any pursuit  or of progress toward an end or result.

Stage: S t a g e "n. A large vehicle running from station to station for the accomodation of the public; a stagecoach; an omnibus.

Stage: S t a g e "n. One of several marked phases or periods in the development and growth of many animals and plants; as  the larval stage; pupa stage; zoea stage.

Stage: S t a g e "v. t. To exhibit upon a stage  or as upon a stage; to display publicly.

Stage-struck: S t a g e - s t r u c k "a. Fascinated by the stage; seized by a passionate desire to become an actor.

Stagecoach: S t a g e c o a c h "n. A coach that runs regularly from one stage  station or place to another for the conveyance of passengers.

Stagehouse: S t a g e h o u s e "n. A house where a stage regularly stops for passengers or a relay of horses.

Stagely: S t a g e l y "a. Pertaining to a stage; becoming the theater; theatrical.

Stageplay: S t a g e p l a y "n. A dramatic or theatrical entertainment.

Stageplayer: S t a g e p l a y e r "n. An actor on the stage; one whose occupation is to represent characters on the stage; as  Garrick was a celebrated stageplayer.

Stager: S t a g e r "n. A player.

Stager: S t a g e r "n. One who has long acted on the stage of life; a practitioner; a person of experience  or of skill derived from long experience.

Stager: S t a g e r "n. A horse used in drawing a stage.

Stagery: S t a g e r y "n. Exhibition on the stage.

Staggard: S t a g g a r d "n. The male red deer when four years old.

Stagger: S t a g g e r "n. To move to one side and the other  as if about to fall in standing or walking; not to stand or walk with steadiness; to sway; to reel or totter.

Stagger: S t a g g e r "n. To cease to stand firm; to begin to give way; to fail.

Stagger: S t a g g e r "n. To begin to doubt and waver in purposes; to become less confident or determined; to hesitate.

Stagger: S t a g g e r "v. t. To cause to reel or totter.

Stagger: S t a g g e r "v. t. To cause to doubt and waver; to make to hesitate; to make less steady or confident; to shock.

Stagger: S t a g g e r "v. t. To arrange (a series of parts) on each side of a median line alternately  as the spokes of a wheel or the rivets of a boiler seam.

Stagger: S t a g g e r "n. An unsteady movement of the body in walking or standing  as if one were about to fall; a reeling motion; vertigo; -- often in the plural; as the stagger of a drunken man.

Stagger: S t a g g e r "n. A disease of horses and other animals  attended by reeling unsteady gait or sudden falling; as parasitic staggers; appopletic or sleepy staggers.

Stagger: S t a g g e r "n. Bewilderment; perplexity.

Staggerbush: S t a g g e r b u s h "n. An American shrub (Andromeda Mariana) having clusters of nodding white flowers. It grows in low  sandy places and is said to poison lambs and calves.

Staggered: S t a g g e r e d "imp. & p. p. of Stagger

Staggerwort: S t a g g e r w o r t "n. A kind of ragwort (Senecio Jacobaea).

Staghound: S t a g h o u n d "n. A large and powerful hound formerly used in hunting the stag  the wolf and other large animals. The breed is nearly extinct.

Staging: S t a g i n g "n. A structure of posts and boards for supporting workmen  etc. as in building.

Staging: S t a g i n g "n. The business of running stagecoaches; also  the act of journeying in stagecoaches.

Stagirite: S t a g i r i t e "n. A native of  or resident in Stagira in ancient Macedonia; especially Aristotle.

Stagnancy: S t a g n a n c y "n. State of being stagnant.

Stagnant: S t a g n a n t "a. That stagnates; not flowing; not running in a current or steam; motionless; hence  impure or foul from want of motion; as a stagnant lake or pond; stagnant blood in the veins.

Stagnant: S t a g n a n t "a. Not active or brisk; dull; as  business in stagnant.

Stagnantly: S t a g n a n t l y "adv. In a stagnant manner.

Stagnate: S t a g n a t e "v. t. To cease to flow; to be motionless; as  blood stagnates in the veins of an animal; hence to become impure or foul by want of motion; as air stagnates in a close room.

Stagnate: S t a g n a t e "v. t. To cease to be brisk or active; to become dull or inactive; as  commerce stagnates; business stagnates.

Stagnate: S t a g n a t e "a. Stagnant.

Stagnated: S t a g n a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Stagnate

Stagnation: S t a g n a t i o n "n. The cessation of action  or of brisk action; the state of being dull; as the stagnation of business.

Stagworm: S t a g w o r m "n. The larve of any species of botfly which is parasitic upon the stag  as /strus or Hypoderma actaeon which burrows beneath the skin and Cephalomyia auribarbis which lives in the nostrils.

Stake: S t a k e "v. t. A piece of wood  usually long and slender pointed at one end so as to be easily driven into the ground as a support or stay; as a stake to support vines fences hedges etc.

Stake: S t a k e "v. t. A stick inserted upright in a lop  eye or mortise at the side or end of a cart a flat car or the like to prevent goods from falling off.

Stake: S t a k e "v. t. The piece of timber to which a martyr was affixed to be burned; hence  martyrdom by fire.

Stake: S t a k e "v. t. To pierce or wound with a stake.

Stake-driver: S t a k e - d r i v e r "n. The common American bittern (Botaurus lentiginosus); -- so called because one of its notes resembles the sound made in driving a stake into the mud. Called also meadow hen  and Indian hen.

Staktometer: S t a k t o m e t e r "n. A drop measurer; a glass tube tapering to a small orifice at the point  and having a bulb in the middle used for finding the number of drops in equal quantities of different liquids. See Pipette.

Stalactic: S t a l a c t i c "a. Alt. of Stalactical

Stalactite: S t a l a c t i t e "n. A pendent cone or cylinder of calcium carbonate resembling an icicle in form and mode of attachment. Stalactites are found depending from the roof or sides of caverns  and are produced by deposition from waters which have percolated through and partially dissolved the overlying limestone rocks.

Stalactite: S t a l a c t i t e "n. In an extended sense  any mineral or rock of similar form and origin; as a stalactite of lava.

Stalactites: S t a l a c t i t e s "pl. "of Stalactite

Stalactites: S t a l a c t i t e s "n. A stalactite.

Stalactitic: S t a l a c t i t i c "a. Alt. of Stalactitical

Stalactitical: S t a l a c t i t i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to a stalactite; having the form or characters of a stalactite; stalactic.

Stalactitiform: S t a l a c t i t i f o r m "a. Having the form of a stalactite; stalactiform.

Stalactoform: S t a l a c t o f o r m "a. Like a stalactite; resembling a stalactite.

Stalagmite: S t a l a g m i t e "n. A deposit more or less resembling an inverted stalactite  formed by calcareous water dropping on the floors of caverns; hence a similar deposit of other material.

Stalk: S t a l k "n. An iron bar with projections inserted in a core to strengthen it; a core arbor.

Stalk: S t a l k "v. i. To walk slowly and cautiously; to walk in a stealthy  noiseless manner; -- sometimes used with a reflexive pronoun.

Stalk: S t a l k "v. i. To walk behind something as a screen  for the purpose of approaching game; to proceed under clover.

Stalk: S t a l k "v. i. To walk with high and proud steps; usually implying the affectation of dignity  and indicating dislike. The word is used however especially by the poets to express dignity of step.

Stalk: S t a l k "v. t. To approach under cover of a screen  or by stealth for the purpose of killing as game.

Stall: S t a l l "v. i. A bench or table on which small articles of merchandise are exposed for sale.

Stall: S t a l l "v. i. A seat in the choir of a church  for one of the officiating clergy. It is inclosed either wholly or partially at the back and sides. The stalls are frequently very rich with canopies and elaborate carving.

Stall: S t a l l "v. i. In the theater  a seat with arms or otherwise partly inclosed as distinguished from the benches sofas etc.

Stamen: S t a m e n "n. A thread; especially  a warp thread.

Stamen: S t a m e n "n. The male organ of flowers for secreting and furnishing the pollen or fecundating dust. It consists of the anther and filament.

Stamin: S t a m i n "n. A kind of woolen cloth.

Stamina: S t a m i n a "pl. "of Stamen

Stamina: S t a m i n a "n. pl. See Stamen.

Stamina: S t a m i n a "n. pl. The fixed  firm part of a body which supports it or gives it strength and solidity; as the bones are the stamina of animal bodies; the ligneous parts of trees are the stamina which constitute their strength.

Stamina: S t a m i n a "n. pl. Whatever constitutes the principal strength or support of anything; power of endurance; backbone; vigor; as  the stamina of a constitution or of life; the stamina of a State.

Staminal: S t a m i n a l "a. Of or pertaining to stamens or stamina; consisting in stamens.

Staminate: S t a m i n a t e "a. Furnished with stamens; producing stamens.

Staminate: S t a m i n a t e "a. Having stamens  but lacking pistils.

Stammel: S t a m m e l "n. A large  clumsy horse.

Stammel: S t a m m e l "n. A kind of woolen cloth formerly in use. It seems to have been often of a red color.

Stammel: S t a m m e l "a. Of the color of stammel; having a red color  thought inferior to scarlet.

Stammer: S t a m m e r "v. i. To make involuntary stops in uttering syllables or words; to hesitate or falter in speaking; to speak with stops and diffivulty; to stutter.

Stammer: S t a m m e r "v. t. To utter or pronounce with hesitation or imperfectly; -- sometimes with out.

Stammer: S t a m m e r "n. Defective utterance  or involuntary interruption of utterance; a stutter.

Stammered: S t a m m e r e d "imp. & p. p. of Stammer

Stammerer: S t a m m e r e r "n. One who stammers.

Stammering: S t a m m e r i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Stammer

Stammering: S t a m m e r i n g "a. Apt to stammer; hesitating in speech; stuttering.

Stammering: S t a m m e r i n g "n. A disturbance in the formation of sounds. It is due essentially to long-continued spasmodic contraction of the diaphragm  by which expiration is preented and hence it may be considered as a spasmodic inspiration.

Stamp: S t a m p "v. i. To strike beat  or press forcibly with the bottom of the foot or by thrusting the foot downward.

Stamp: S t a m p "v. i. To bring down (the foot) forcibly on the ground or floor; as  he stamped his foot with rage.

Stamp: S t a m p "v. i. To crush; to pulverize; specifically (Metal.)  to crush by the blow of a heavy stamp as ore in a mill.

Stamp: S t a m p "v. i. To impress with some mark or figure; as  to stamp a plate with arms or initials.

Stamp: S t a m p "v. i. Fig.: To impress; to imprint; to fix deeply; as  to stamp virtuous principles on the heart.

Stamp: S t a m p "v. i. To cut out  bend or indent as paper sheet metal etc. into various forms by a blow or suddenly applied pressure with a stamp or die etc.; to mint; to coin.

Stamp: S t a m p "v. i. To put a stamp on  as for postage; as to stamp a letter; to stamp a legal document.

Stamp: S t a m p "v. i. To strike; to beat; to crush.

Stamp: S t a m p "v. i. To strike the foot forcibly downward.

Stamp: S t a m p "n. The act of stamping  as with the foot.

Stamp: S t a m p "n. The which stamps; any instrument for making impressions on other bodies  as a die.

Stamp: S t a m p "n. The mark made by stamping; a mark imprinted; an impression.

Stamp: S t a m p "n. that which is marked; a thing stamped.

Stamp: S t a m p "v. t. A picture cut in wood or metal  or made by impression; a cut; a plate.

Stamp: S t a m p "v. t. An offical mark set upon things chargeable with a duty or tax to government  as evidence that the duty or tax is paid; as the stamp on a bill of exchange.

Stamp: S t a m p "v. t. Hence  a stamped or printed device issued by the government at a fixed price and required by law to be affixed to or stamped on certain papers as evidence that the government dues are paid; as a postage stamp; a receipt stamp etc.

Stamp: S t a m p "v. t. An instrument for cutting out  or shaping materials as paper leather etc. by a downward pressure.

Stamp: S t a m p "v. t. A character or reputation  good or bad fixed on anything as if by an imprinted mark; current value; authority; as these persons have the stamp of dishonesty; the Scriptures bear the stamp of a divine origin.

Stamp: S t a m p "v. t. Make; cast; form; character; as  a man of the same stamp or of a different stamp.

Stamp: S t a m p "v. t. A kind of heavy hammer  or pestle raised by water or steam power for beating ores to powder; anything like a pestle used for pounding or bathing.

Stamp: S t a m p "v. t. A half-penny.

Stamp: S t a m p "v. t. Money  esp. paper money.

Stamped: S t a m p e d "imp. & p. p. of Stamp

Stampede: S t a m p e d e "v. t. A wild  headlong scamper or running away of a number of animals; usually caused by fright; hence any sudden flight or dispersion as of a crowd or an army in consequence of a panic.

Stampede: S t a m p e d e "v. i. To run away in a panic; -- said droves of cattle  horses etc. also of armies.

Stampede: S t a m p e d e "v. t. To disperse by causing sudden fright  as a herd or drove of animals.

Stamper: S t a m p e r "n. One who stamps.

Stamper: S t a m p e r "n. An instrument for pounding or stamping.

Stanch: S t a n c h "v. i. To cease  as the flowing of blood.

Stanch: S t a n c h "n. That which stanches or checks.

Stanch: S t a n c h "n. A flood gate by which water is accumulated  for floating a boat over a shallow part of a stream by its release.

Stanch: S t a n c h "v. t. Strong and tight; sound; firm; as  a stanch ship.

Stanch: S t a n c h "v. t. Firm in principle; constant and zealous; loyal; hearty; steady; steadfast; as  a stanch churchman; a stanch friend or adherent.

Stanchion: S t a n c h i o n "n. A vertical bar for confining cattle in a stall.

Stand: S t a n d "n. To be at rest in an erect position; to be fixed in an upright or firm position

Stand: S t a n d "n. To be supported on the feet  in an erect or nearly erect position; -- opposed to lie sit kneel etc.

Stand: S t a n d "n. To continue upright in a certain locality  as a tree fixed by the roots or a building resting on its foundation.

Stand: S t a n d "n. To occupy or hold a place; to have a situation; to be situated or located; as  Paris stands on the Seine.

Stand: S t a n d "n. To cease from progress; not to proceed; to stop; to pause; to halt; to remain stationary.

Stand: S t a n d "n. To remain without ruin or injury; to hold good against tendencies to impair or injure; to be permanent; to endure; to last; hence  to find endurance strength or resources.

Stand: S t a n d "n. To maintain one's ground; to be acquitted; not to fail or yield; to be safe.

Stand: S t a n d "n. To maintain an invincible or permanent attitude; to be fixed  steady or firm; to take a position in resistance or opposition.

Stand: S t a n d "n. To adhere to fixed principles; to maintain moral rectitude; to keep from falling into error or vice.

Stand: S t a n d "n. To have or maintain a position  order or rank; to be in a particular relation; as Christian charity or love stands first in the rank of gifts.

Stand: S t a n d "n. To be in some particular state; to have essence or being; to be; to consist.

Stand: S t a n d "n. To be consistent; to agree; to accord.

Stand: S t a n d "n. To hold a course at sea; as  to stand from the shore; to stand for the harbor.

Stand: S t a n d "n. To offer one's self  or to be offered as a candidate.

Stand: S t a n d "n. To stagnate; not to flow; to be motionless.

Stand: S t a n d "n. To measure when erect on the feet.

Stand: S t a n d "n. To be or remain as it is; to continue in force; to have efficacy or validity; to abide.

Stand: S t a n d "n. To appear in court.

Stand: S t a n d "v. t. To endure; to sustain; to bear; as  I can not stand the cold or the heat.

Stand: S t a n d "v. t. To resist  without yielding or receding; to withstand.

Stand: S t a n d "v. t. To abide by; to submit to; to suffer.

Stand: S t a n d "v. t. To set upright; to cause to stand; as  to stand a book on the shelf; to stand a man on his feet.

Stand: S t a n d "v. t. To be at the expense of; to pay for; as  to stand a treat.

Stand: S t a n d "v. i. The act of standing.

Stand: S t a n d "v. i. A halt or stop for the purpose of defense  resistance or opposition; as to come to or to make a stand.

Stand: S t a n d "v. i. A place or post where one stands; a place where one may stand while observing or waiting for something.

Stand: S t a n d "v. i. A station in a city or town where carriages or wagons stand for hire; as  a cab stand.

Stand: S t a n d "v. i. A raised platform or station where a race or other outdoor spectacle may be viewed; as  the judge's or the grand stand at a race course.

Stand: S t a n d "v. i. A small table; also  something on or in which anything may be laid hung or placed upright; as a hat stand; an umbrella stand; a music stand.

Stand: S t a n d "v. i. A place where a witness stands to testify in court.

Stand: S t a n d "v. i. The situation of a shop  store hotel etc.; as a good bad or convenient stand for business.

Stand: S t a n d "v. i. Rank; post; station; standing.

Stand: S t a n d "v. i. A state of perplexity or embarrassment; as  to be at a stand what to do.

Stand: S t a n d "v. i. A young tree  usually reserved when other trees are cut; also a tree growing or standing upon its own root in distinction from one produced from a scion set in a stock either of the same or another kind of tree.

Stand: S t a n d "v. i. A weight of from two hundred and fifty to three hundred pounds  -- used in weighing pitch.

Stand-by: S t a n d - b y "n. One who  or that which stands by one in need; something upon which one relies for constant use or in an emergency.

Standage: S t a n d a g e "n. A reservior in which water accumulates at the bottom of a mine.

Standard: S t a n d a r d "n. A flag; colors; a banner; especially  a national or other ensign.

Standard: S t a n d a r d "n. That which is established by authority as a rule for the measure of quantity  extent value or quality; esp. the original specimen weight or measure sanctioned by government as the standard pound gallon or yard.

Standard: S t a n d a r d "n. That which is established as a rule or model by authority  custom or general consent; criterion; test.

Standard: S t a n d a r d "n. The proportion of weights of fine metal and alloy established by authority.

Standard: S t a n d a r d "n. A tree of natural size supported by its own stem  and not dwarfed by grafting on the stock of a smaller species nor trained upon a wall or trellis.

Standard: S t a n d a r d "n. The upper petal or banner of a papilionaceous corolla.

Standard: S t a n d a r d "n. An upright support  as one of the poles of a scaffold; any upright in framing.

Standard: S t a n d a r d "n. An inverted knee timber placed upon the deck instead of beneath it  with its vertical branch turned upward from that which lies horizontally.

Standard: S t a n d a r d "n. The sheth of a plow.

Standard: S t a n d a r d "n. A large drinking cup.

Standard: S t a n d a r d "a. Being  affording or according with a standard for comparison and judgment; as standard time; standard weights and measures; a standard authority as to nautical terms; standard gold or silver.

Standard: S t a n d a r d "a. Hence: Having a recognized and permanent value; as  standard works in history; standard authors.

Standard: S t a n d a r d "a. Not supported by  or fastened to a wall; as standard fruit trees.

Standard: S t a n d a r d "a. Not of the dwarf kind; as  a standard pear tree.

Standard-bred: S t a n d a r d - b r e d "a. Bred in conformity to a standard. Specif.  applied to a registered trotting horse which comes up to the standard adopted by the National Association of Trotting-horse Breeders.

Standard-wing: S t a n d a r d - w i n g "n. A curious paradise bird (Semioptera Wallacii) which has two long special feathers standing erect on each wing.

Standardize: S t a n d a r d i z e "v. t. To reduce to a normal standard; to calculate or adjust the strength of  by means of and for uses in analysis.

Standing: S t a n d i n g "a. Remaining erect; not cut down; as  standing corn.

Standing: S t a n d i n g "a. Not flowing; stagnant; as  standing water.

Standing: S t a n d i n g "a. Not transitory; not liable to fade or vanish; lasting; as  a standing color.

Standing: S t a n d i n g "a. Established by law  custom or the like; settled; continually existing; permanent; not temporary; as a standing army; legislative bodies have standing rules of proceeding and standing committees.

Standing: S t a n d i n g "a. Not movable; fixed; as  a standing bed (distinguished from a trundle-bed).

Standing: S t a n d i n g "n. Condition in society; relative position; reputation; rank; as  a man of good standing or of high standing.

Standpipe: S t a n d p i p e "n. A vertical pipe  open at the top between a hydrant and a reservoir to equalize the flow of water; also a large vertical pipe near a pumping engine into which water is forced up so as to give it sufficient head to rise to the required level at a distance.

Standpipe: S t a n d p i p e "n. A supply pipe of sufficient elevation to enable the water to flow into the boiler  notwithstanding the pressure of the steam.

Stannic: S t a n n i c "a. Of or pertaining to tin; derived from or containing tin; specifically  designating those compounds in which the element has a higher valence as contrasted with stannous compounds.

Stanniferous: S t a n n i f e r o u s "a. Containing or affording tin.

Stannine: S t a n n i n e "n. Alt. of Stannite

Stannite: S t a n n i t e "n. A mineral of a steel-gray or iron-black color; tin pyrites. It is a sulphide of tin  copper and iron.

Stanno-: S t a n n o - " A combining form (also used adjectively) denoting relation to  or connection with tin or including tin as an ingredient.

Stannofluoride: S t a n n o f l u o r i d e "n. Any one of a series of double fluorides of tin (stannum) and some other element.

Stannoso-: S t a n n o s o - "a. A combining form (also used adjectively) denoting relation to  or connection with certain stannnous compounds.

Stannotype: S t a n n o t y p e "n. A photograph taken upon a tin plate; a tintype.

Stannous: S t a n n o u s "a. Pertaining to  or containing tin; specifically designating those compounds in which the element has a lower valence as contrasted with stannic compounds.

Stannum: S t a n n u m "n. The technical name of tin. See Tin.

Stanza: S t a n z a "n. A number of lines or verses forming a division of a song or poem  and agreeing in meter rhyme number of lines etc. with other divisions; a part of a poem ordinarily containing every variation of measure in that poem; a combination or arrangement of lines usually recurring; whether like or unlike in measure.

Stanza: S t a n z a "n. An apartment or division in a building; a room or chamber.

Stanzas: S t a n z a s "pl. "of Stanza

Stapedial: S t a p e d i a l "a. Of or pertaining to stapes.

Stapelia: S t a p e l i a "n. An extensive and curious genus of African plants of the natural order Asclepiadaceae (Milkweed family). They are succulent plants without leaves  frequently covered with dark tubercles giving them a very grotesque appearance. The odor of the blossoms is like that of carrion.

Stapes: S t a p e s "n. The innermost of the ossicles of the ear; the stirrup  or stirrup bone; -- so called from its form. See Illust. of Ear.

Staphyline: S t a p h y l i n e "a. Of or pertaining to the uvula or the palate.

Staphylinid: S t a p h y l i n i d "n. Any rove beetle.

Staphyloma: S t a p h y l o m a "n. A protrusion of any part of the globe of the eye; as  a staphyloma of the cornea.

Staphylomatous: S t a p h y l o m a t o u s "a. Of or pertaining to staphyloma; affected with staphyloma.

Staphyloplasty: S t a p h y l o p l a s t y "n. The operation for restoring or replacing the soft palate when it has been lost.

Staphyloraphy: S t a p h y l o r a p h y "n. Alt. of Staphylorrhaphy

Staphylorrhaphy: S t a p h y l o r r h a p h y "n. The operation of uniting a cleft palate  consisting in paring and bringing together the edges of the cleft.

Staphylotomy: S t a p h y l o t o m y "n. The operation of removing a staphyloma by cutting.

Staple: S t a p l e "n. A settled mart; an emporium; a city or town to which merchants brought commodities for sale or exportation in bulk; a place for wholesale traffic.

Staple: S t a p l e "n. Hence: Place of supply; source; fountain head.

Staple: S t a p l e "n. The principal commodity of traffic in a market; a principal commodity or production of a country or district; as  wheat maize and cotton are great staples of the United States.

Staple: S t a p l e "n. The principal constituent in anything; chief item.

Staple: S t a p l e "n. Unmanufactured material; raw material.

Staple: S t a p l e "n. The fiber of wool  cotton flax or the like; as a coarse staple; a fine staple; a long or short staple.

Star: S t a r "n. One of the innumerable luminous bodies seen in the heavens; any heavenly body other than the sun  moon comets and nebulae.

Star: S t a r "n. The polestar; the north star.

Star: S t a r "n. A planet supposed to influence one's destiny; (usually pl.) a configuration of the planets  supposed to influence fortune.

Star: S t a r "n. That which resembles the figure of a star  as an ornament worn on the breast to indicate rank or honor.

Star: S t a r "n. Specifically  a radiated mark in writing or printing; an asterisk [thus *]; -- used as a reference to a note or to fill a blank where something is omitted etc.

Star: S t a r "n. A composition of combustible matter used in the heading of rockets  in mines etc. which exploding in the air presents a starlike appearance.

Star: S t a r "n. A person of brilliant and attractive qualities  especially on public occasions as a distinguished orator a leading theatrical performer etc.

Star: S t a r "v. t. To set or adorn with stars  or bright radiating bodies; to bespangle; as a robe starred with gems.

Star: S t a r "v. i. To be bright  or attract attention as a star; to shine like a star; to be brilliant or prominent; to play a part as a theatrical star.

Star-blind: S t a r - b l i n d "a. Half blind.

Star-chamber: S t a r - c h a m b e r "n. An ancient high court exercising jurisdiction in certain cases  mainly criminal which sat without the intervention of a jury. It consisted of the king's council or of the privy council only with the addition of certain judges. It could proceed on mere rumor or examine witnesses; it could apply torture. It was abolished by the Long Parliament in 1641.

Star-crossed: S t a r - c r o s s e d "a. Not favored by the stars; ill-fated.

Star-read: S t a r - r e a d "n. Doctrine or knowledge of the stars; star lore; astrology; astronomy.

Star-spangled: S t a r - s p a n g l e d "a. Spangled or studded with stars.

Starblowlines: S t a r b l o w l i n e s "n. pl. The men in the starboard watch.

Starboard: S t a r b o a r d "v. t. That side of a vessel which is on the right hand of a person who stands on board facing the bow; -- opposed to larboard  or port.

Starboard: S t a r b o a r d "a. Pertaining to the right-hand side of a ship; being or lying on the right side; as  the starboard quarter; starboard tack.

Starboard: S t a r b o a r d "v. t. To put to the right  or starboard side of a vessel; as to starboard the helm.

Starch: S t a r c h "a. Stiff; precise; rigid.

Starch: S t a r c h "n. A widely diffused vegetable substance found especially in seeds  bulbs and tubers and extracted (as from potatoes corn rice etc.) as a white glistening granular or powdery substance without taste or smell and giving a very peculiar creaking sound when rubbed between the fingers. It is used as a food in the production of commercial grape sugar

Starch: S t a r c h "n. Fig.: A stiff  formal manner; formality.

Starch: S t a r c h "v. t. To stiffen with starch.

Starched: S t a r c h e d "imp. & p. p. of Starch

Starched: S t a r c h e d "a. Stiffened with starch.

Starched: S t a r c h e d "a. Stiff; precise; formal.

Starcher: S t a r c h e r "n. One who starches.

Starching: S t a r c h i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Starch
