Steg: S t e g "n. A gander.

Steganographist: S t e g a n o g r a p h i s t "n. One skilled in steganography; a cryptographer.

Steganography: S t e g a n o g r a p h y "n. The art of writing in cipher  or in characters which are not intelligible except to persons who have the key; cryptography.

Steganophthalmata: S t e g a n o p h t h a l m a t a "n. pl. The Discophora  or Phanerocarpae. Called also Steganophthalmia.

Steganopod: S t e g a n o p o d "n. One of the Steganopodes.

Steganopodes: S t e g a n o p o d e s "n. pl. A division of swimming birds in which all four toes are united by a broad web. It includes the pelicans  cormorants gannets and others.

Steganopodous: S t e g a n o p o d o u s "a. Having all four toes webbed together.

Stegnosis: S t e g n o s i s "n. Constipation; also  constriction of the vessels or ducts.

Stegnotic: S t e g n o t i c "a. Tending to render costive  or to diminish excretions or discharges generally.

Stegnotic: S t e g n o t i c "n. A stegnotic medicine; an astringent.

Stegocephala: S t e g o c e p h a l a "n. pl. An extinct order of amphibians found fossil in the Mesozoic rocks; called also Stegocephali  and Labyrinthodonta.

Stegosauria: S t e g o s a u r i a "n. pl. An extinct order of herbivorous dinosaurs  including the genera Stegosaurus Omosaurus and their allies.

Stegosaurus: S t e g o s a u r u s "n. A genus of large Jurassic dinosaurs remarkable for a powerful dermal armature of plates and spines.

Steik: S t e i k "v. t. To pierce with a sharp instrument; hence  to stitch; to sew; also to fix; to fasten.

Steik: S t e i k "v. t. See Steek.

Stein: S t e i n "n. & v. See Steen.

Steinbock: S t e i n b o c k "n. The European ibex.

Steinbock: S t e i n b o c k "n. A small South African antelope (Nanotragus tragulus) which frequents dry  rocky districts; -- called also steenbok.

Steingale: S t e i n g a l e "n. The stannel.

Steining: S t e i n i n g "n. See Steening.

Steinkirk: S t e i n k i r k "n. A kind of neckcloth worn in a loose and disorderly fashion.

Steinkirk: S t e i n k i r k "n. Same as Steenkirk.

Steinkle: S t e i n k l e "n. The wheater.

Stela: S t e l a "n. A small column or pillar  used as a monument milestone etc.

Stelae: S t e l a e "pl. "of Stela

Stele: S t e l e "n. Same as Stela.

Stele: S t e l e "n. A stale  or handle; a stalk.

Stelene: S t e l e n e "a. Resembling  or used as a stela; columnar.

Stell: S t e l l "v. t. To place or fix firmly or permanently.

Stell: S t e l l "v. t. A prop; a support  as for the feet in standing or cilmbing.

Stell: S t e l l "v. t. A partial inclosure made by a wall or trees  to serve as a shelter for sheep or cattle.

Stellar: S t e l l a r "a. Alt. of Stellary

Stellary: S t e l l a r y "a. Of or pertaining to stars; astral; as  a stellar figure; stellary orbs.

Stellary: S t e l l a r y "a. Full of stars; starry; as  stellar regions.

Stellate: S t e l l a t e "a. Alt. of Stellated

Stellated: S t e l l a t e d "a. Resembling a star; pointed or radiated  like the emblem of a star.

Stellated: S t e l l a t e d "a. Starlike; having similar parts radiating from a common center; as  stellate flowers.

Stellation: S t e l l a t i o n "n. Radiation of light.

Stelled: S t e l l e d "a. Firmly placed or fixed.

Steller: S t e l l e r "n. The rytina; -- called also stellerine.

Stellerid: S t e l l e r i d "n. A starfish.

Stellerida: S t e l l e r i d a "n. pl. An extensive group of echinoderms  comprising the starfishes and ophiurans.

Stelleridan: S t e l l e r i d a n "n. Alt. of Stelleridean

Stelleridean: S t e l l e r i d e a n "n. A starfish  or brittle star.

Stelliferous: S t e l l i f e r o u s "a. Having  or abounding with stars.

Stelliform: S t e l l i f o r m "a. Like a star; star-shaped; radiated.

Stellify: S t e l l i f y "v. t. To turn into a star; to cause to appear like a star; to place among the stars  or in heaven.

Stellion: S t e l l i o n "n. A lizard (Stellio vulgaris)  common about the Eastern Mediterranean among ruins. In color it is olive-green shaded with black with small stellate spots. Called also hardim and star lizard.

Stellionate: S t e l l i o n a t e "n. Any fraud not distinguished by a more special name; -- chiefly applied to sales of the same property to two different persons  or selling that for one's own which belongs to another etc.

Stellular: S t e l l u l a r "a. Having the shape or appearance of little stars; radiated.

Stellular: S t e l l u l a r "a. Marked with starlike spots of color.

Stellulate: S t e l l u l a t e "a. Minutely stellate.

Stelmatopoda: S t e l m a t o p o d a "n. pl. Same as Gymnolaemata.

Stelography: S t e l o g r a p h y "n. The art of writing or inscribing characters on pillars.

Stem: S t e m "v. i. Alt. of Steem

Stem: S t e m "n. Alt. of Steem

Stem: S t e m "n. The principal body of a tree  shrub or plant of any kind; the main stock; the part which supports the branches or the head or top.

Stem: S t e m "n. A little branch which connects a fruit  flower or leaf with a main branch; a peduncle pedicel or petiole; as the stem of an apple or a cherry.

Stem: S t e m "n. The stock of a family; a race or generation of progenitors.

Stem: S t e m "n. A branch of a family.

Stem: S t e m "n. A curved piece of timber to which the two sides of a ship are united at the fore end. The lower end of it is scarfed to the keel  and the bowsprit rests upon its upper end. Hence the forward part of a vessel; the bow.

Stem: S t e m "n. Fig.: An advanced or leading position; the lookout.

Stem: S t e m "n. Anything resembling a stem or stalk; as  the stem of a tobacco pipe; the stem of a watch case or that part to which the ring by which it is suspended is attached.

Stem: S t e m "n. That part of a plant which bears leaves  or rudiments of leaves whether rising above ground or wholly subterranean.

Stem: S t e m "n. The entire central axis of a feather.

Stem: S t e m "n. The basal portion of the body of one of the Pennatulacea  or of a gorgonian.

Stem: S t e m "n. The short perpendicular line added to the body of a note; the tail of a crotchet  quaver semiquaver etc.

Stem: S t e m "n. The part of an inflected word which remains unchanged (except by euphonic variations) throughout a given inflection; theme; base.

Stem: S t e m "v. t. To remove the stem or stems from; as  to stem cherries; to remove the stem and its appendages (ribs and veins) from; as to stem tobacco leaves.

Stem: S t e m "v. t. To ram  as clay into a blasting hole.

Stem: S t e m "v. t. To oppose or cut with  or as with the stem of a vessel; to resist or make progress against; to stop or check the flow of as a current.

Stem: S t e m "v. i. To move forward against an obstacle  as a vessel against a current.

Stem-clasping: S t e m - c l a s p i n g "a. Embracing the stem with its base; amplexicaul; as a leaf or petiole.

Stem-winder: S t e m - w i n d e r "n. A stem-winding watch.

Stem-winding: S t e m - w i n d i n g "a. Wound by mechanism connected with the stem; as  a stem-winding watch.

Stemless: S t e m l e s s "a. Having no stem; (Bot.) acaulescent.

Stemlet: S t e m l e t "n. A small or young stem.

Stemma: S t e m m a "n. One of the ocelli of an insect. See Ocellus.

Stemma: S t e m m a "n. One of the facets of a compound eye of any arthropod.

Stemmata: S t e m m a t a "pl. "of Stemma

Stemmed: S t e m m e d "imp. & p. p. of Stem

Stemmer: S t e m m e r "n. One who  or that which stems (in any of the senses of the verbs).

Stemmery: S t e m m e r y "n. A large building in which tobacco is stemmed.

Stemming: S t e m m i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Stem

Stemmy: S t e m m y "a. Abounding in stems  or mixed with stems; -- said of tea dried currants etc.

Stemple: S t e m p l e "n. A crossbar of wood in a shaft  serving as a step.

Stemson: S t e m s o n "n. A piece of curved timber bolted to the stem  keelson and apron in a ship's frame near the bow.

Stench: S t e n c h "v. t. To stanch.

Stench: S t e n c h "v. i. A smell; an odor.

Stench: S t e n c h "v. i. An ill smell; an offensive odor; a stink.

Stench: S t e n c h "n. To cause to emit a disagreeable odor; to cause to stink.

Stenchy: S t e n c h y "a. Having a stench.

Stencil: S t e n c i l "n. A thin plate of metal  leather or other material used in painting marking etc. The pattern is cut out of the plate which is then laid flat on the surface to be marked and the color brushed over it. Called also stencil plate.

Stencil: S t e n c i l "v. t. To mark  paint or color in figures with stencils; to form or print by means of a stencil.

Stenciled: S t e n c i l e d "imp. & p. p. of Stencil

Stenciler: S t e n c i l e r "n. One who paints or colors in figures by means of stencil.

Stenciling: S t e n c i l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Stencil

Stencilled: S t e n c i l l e d " of Stencil

Stencilling: S t e n c i l l i n g " of Stencil

Stenoderm: S t e n o d e r m "n. Any species of bat belonging to the genus Stenoderma  native of the West Indies and South America. These bats have a short or rudimentary tail and a peculiarly shaped nose membrane.

Stenodermine: S t e n o d e r m i n e "a. Of or pertaining to the genus Stenoderma  which includes several West Indian and South American nose-leaf bats.

Stenograph: S t e n o g r a p h "v. t. To write or report in stenographic characters.

Stenograph: S t e n o g r a p h "n. A production of stenography; anything written in shorthand.

Stenographed: S t e n o g r a p h e d "imp. & p. p. of Stenograph

Stenographer: S t e n o g r a p h e r "n. One who is skilled in stenography; a writer of shorthand.

Stenographic: S t e n o g r a p h i c "a. Alt. of Stenographical

Stenographical: S t e n o g r a p h i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to stenography.

Stenographing: S t e n o g r a p h i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Stenograph

Stenographist: S t e n o g r a p h i s t "n. A stenographer.

Stenography: S t e n o g r a p h y "n. The art of writing in shorthand  by using abbreviations or characters for whole words; shorthand.

Stenophyllous: S t e n o p h y l l o u s "a. Having narrow leaves.

Stenosis: S t e n o s i s "n. A narrowing of the opening or hollow of any passage  tube or orifice; as stenosis of the pylorus. It differs from stricture in being applied especially to diffused rather than localized contractions and in always indicating an origin organic and not spasmodic.

Stenostome: S t e n o s t o m e "a. Having a small or narrow mouth; -- said of certain small ground snakes (Opoterodonta)  which are unable to dilate their jaws.

Stent: S t e n t "obs. p. p. of Stent

Stent: S t e n t "v. t. To keep within limits; to restrain; to cause to stop  or cease; to stint.

Stent: S t e n t "v. i. To stint; to stop; to cease.

Stent: S t e n t "n. An allotted portion; a stint.

Stente: S t e n t e "Obs. imp. of Stent

Stenting: S t e n t i n g "n. An opening in a wall in a coal mine.

Stentor: S t e n t o r "n. A herald  in the Iliad who had a very loud voice; hence any person having a powerful voice.

Stentor: S t e n t o r "n. Any species of ciliated Infusoria belonging to the genus Stentor and allied genera  common in fresh water. The stentors have a bell-shaped or cornucopia-like body with a circle of cilia around the spiral terminal disk. See Illust. under Heterotricha.

Stentor: S t e n t o r "n. A howling monkey  or howler.

Stentorian: S t e n t o r i a n "a. Of or pertaining to a stentor; extremely loud; powerful; as  a stentorian voice; stentorian lungs.

Stentorin: S t e n t o r i n "n. A blue coloring matter found in some stentors. See Stentor  2.

Stentorious: S t e n t o r i o u s "a. Stentorian.

Stentoronic: S t e n t o r o n i c "a. Stentorian.

Stentorophonic: S t e n t o r o p h o n i c "a. Speaking or sounding very loud; stentorian.

Step: S t e p "a. To move the foot in walking; to advance or recede by raising and moving one of the feet to another resting place  or by moving both feet in succession.

Step: S t e p "a. To walk; to go on foot; esp.  to walk a little distance; as to step to one of the neighbors.

Step: S t e p "a. To walk slowly  gravely or resolutely.

Step: S t e p "a. Fig.: To move mentally; to go in imagination.

Step: S t e p "v. t. To set  as the foot.

Step: S t e p "v. t. To fix the foot of (a mast) in its step; to erect.

Step: S t e p "v. i. An advance or movement made by one removal of the foot; a pace.

Step: S t e p "v. i. A rest  or one of a set of rests for the foot in ascending or descending as a stair or a round of a ladder.

Step: S t e p "v. i. The space passed over by one movement of the foot in walking or running; as  one step is generally about three feet but may be more or less. Used also figuratively of any kind of progress; as he improved step by step or by steps.

Step: S t e p "v. i. A small space or distance; as  it is but a step.

Step: S t e p "v. i. A print of the foot; a footstep; a footprint; track.

Step: S t e p "v. i. Gait; manner of walking; as  the approach of a man is often known by his step.

Step: S t e p "v. i. Proceeding; measure; action; an act.

Step: S t e p "v. i. Walk; passage.

Step: S t e p "v. i. A portable framework of stairs  much used indoors in reaching to a high position.

Step: S t e p "v. i. In general  a framing in wood or iron which is intended to receive an upright shaft; specif. a block of wood or a solid platform upon the keelson supporting the heel of the mast.

Step: S t e p "v. i. One of a series of offsets  or parts resembling the steps of stairs as one of the series of parts of a cone pulley on which the belt runs.

Step: S t e p "v. i. A bearing in which the lower extremity of a spindle or a vertical shaft revolves.

Step: S t e p "v. i. The intervak between two contiguous degrees of the csale.

Step: S t e p "v. i. A change of position effected by a motion of translation.

Step-: S t e p - " A prefix used before father  mother brother sister son daughter child etc. to indicate that the person thus spoken of is not a blood relative but is a relative by the marriage of a parent; as a stepmother to X is the wife of the father of X married by him after the death of the mother of X. See Stepchild

Stepbrother: S t e p b r o t h e r "n. A brother by the marriage of one's father with the mother of another  or of one's mother with the father of another.

Stepchild: S t e p c h i l d "n. A bereaved child; one who has lost father or mother.

Stepchild: S t e p c h i l d "n. A son or daughter of one's wife or husband by a former marriage.

Stepdame: S t e p d a m e "n. A stepmother.

Stepdaughter: S t e p d a u g h t e r "n. A daughter of one's wife or husband by a former marriage.

Stepfather: S t e p f a t h e r "n. The husband of one's mother by a subsequent marriage.

Stephanion: S t e p h a n i o n "n. The point on the side of the skull where the temporal line  or upper edge of the temporal fossa crosses the coronal suture.

Stephanite: S t e p h a n i t e "n. A sulphide of antimony and silver of an iron-black color and metallic luster; called also black silver  and brittle silver ore.

Stephanotis: S t e p h a n o t i s "n. A genus of climbing asclepiadaceous shrubs  of Madagascar Malaya etc. They have fleshy or coriaceous opposite leaves and large white waxy flowers in cymes.

Stephanotis: S t e p h a n o t i s "n. A perfume said to be prepared from the flowers of Stephanotis floribunda.

Stepladder: S t e p l a d d e r "n. A portable set of steps.

Stepmother: S t e p m o t h e r "n. The wife of one's father by a subsequent marriage.

Stepparent: S t e p p a r e n t "n. Stepfather or stepmother.

Steppe: S t e p p e "n. One of the vast plains in Southeastern Europe and in Asia  generally elevated and free from wood analogous to many of the prairies in Western North America. See Savanna.

Stepped: S t e p p e d "imp. & p. p. of Step

Stepped: S t e p p e d "a. Provided with a step or steps; having a series of offsets or parts resembling the steps of stairs; as  a stepped key.

Stepper: S t e p p e r "n. One who  or that which steps; as a quick stepper.

Stepping: S t e p p i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Step

Stepping-stone: S t e p p i n g - s t o n e "n. A stone to raise the feet above the surface of water or mud in walking.

Stepping-stone: S t e p p i n g - s t o n e "n. Fig.: A means of progress or advancement.

Stepsister: S t e p s i s t e r "n. A daughter of one's stepfather or stepmother by a former marriage.

Stepson: S t e p s o n "n. A son of one's husband or wife by a former marriage.

Stepstone: S t e p s t o n e "n. A stone laid before a door as a stair to rise on in entering the house.

Stercobilin: S t e r c o b i l i n "n. A coloring matter found in the faeces  a product of the alteration of the bile pigments in the intestinal canal -- identical with hydrobilirubin.

Stercolin: S t e r c o l i n "n. Same as Serolin (b).

Stercoraceous: S t e r c o r a c e o u s "a. Of or pertaining to dung; partaking of the nature of  or containing dung.

Stercoranism: S t e r c o r a n i s m "n. The doctrine or belief of the Stercoranists.

Stercoranist: S t e r c o r a n i s t "n. A nickname formerly given to those who held  or were alleged to hold that the consecrated elements in the eucharist undergo the process of digestion in the body of the recipient.

Stercorarian: S t e r c o r a r i a n "n. A Stercoranist.

Stercorary: S t e r c o r a r y "n. A place  properly secured from the weather for containing dung.

Stercorate: S t e r c o r a t e "n. Excrement; dung.

Stercoration: S t e r c o r a t i o n "n. Manuring with dung.

Stercorianism: S t e r c o r i a n i s m "n. The doctrine or belief of the Stercoranists.

Stercorin: S t e r c o r i n "n. Same as Serolin (b).

Stercory: S t e r c o r y "n. Excrement; dung.

Sterculiaceous: S t e r c u l i a c e o u s "a. Of or pertaining to a natural order (Sterculiaceae) of polypetalous exogenous plants  mostly tropical. The cacao (Theobroma Cacao) is the most useful plant of the order.

Stere: S t e r e "n. A unit of cubic measure in the metric system  being a cubic meter or kiloliter and equal to 35.3 cubic feet or nearly 1/ cubic yards.

Stere: S t e r e "v. t. & i. To stir.

Stere: S t e r e "n. A rudder. See 5th Steer.

Stere: S t e r e "n. Helmsman. See 6th Steer.

Sterelmintha: S t e r e l m i n t h a "n. pl. Same as Platyelminthes.

Stereo-: S t e r e o - " A combining form meaning solid  hard firm as in stereo-chemistry stereography.

Stereo-chemic: S t e r e o - c h e m i c "a. Alt. of Stereo-chemical

Stereo-chemical: S t e r e o - c h e m i c a l "a. Pertaining to  or illustrating the hypothetical space relations of atoms in the molecule; as a stereo-chemic formula.

Stereo-chemistry: S t e r e o - c h e m i s t r y "n. Chemistry considered with reference to the space relations of atoms.

Stereobate: S t e r e o b a t e "n. The lower part or basement of a building or pedestal; -- used loosely for several different forms of basement.

Stereochrome: S t e r e o c h r o m e "n. Stereochromic picture.

Stereochromic: S t e r e o c h r o m i c "a. Pertaining to the art of stereochromy; produced by stereochromy.

Stereochromy: S t e r e o c h r o m y "n. A style of painting on plastered walls or stone  in which the colors are rendered permanent by sprinklings of water in which is mixed a proportion of soluble glass (a silicate of soda).

Stereoelectric: S t e r e o e l e c t r i c "a. Of or pertaining to the generation of electricity by means of solid bodies alone; as  a stereoelectric current is one obtained by means of solids without any liquid.

Stereogram: S t e r e o g r a m "n. A diagram or picture which represents objects in such a way as to give the impression of relief or solidity; also  a stereograph.

Stereograph: S t e r e o g r a p h "n. Any picture  or pair of pictures prepared for exhibition in the stereoscope. Stereographs are now commonly made by means of photography.

Stereographic: S t e r e o g r a p h i c "a. Alt. of Stereographical

Stereographical: S t e r e o g r a p h i c a l "a. Made or done according to the rules of stereography; delineated on a plane; as  a stereographic chart of the earth.

Stereographically: S t e r e o g r a p h i c a l l y "adv. In a stereographical manner; by delineation on a plane.

Stereography: S t e r e o g r a p h y "n. The art of delineating the forms of solid bodies on a plane; a branch of solid geometry which shows the construction of all solids which are regularly defined.

Stereometer: S t e r e o m e t e r "n. An instrument for measuring the solid contents of a body  or the capacity of a vessel; a volumenometer.

Stereometer: S t e r e o m e t e r "n. An instrument for determining the specific gravity of liquid bodies  porous bodies and powders as well as solids.

Stereometric: S t e r e o m e t r i c "a. Alt. of Stereometrical

Stereometrical: S t e r e o m e t r i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to stereometry; performed or obtained by stereometry.

Stereometry: S t e r e o m e t r y "n. The art of measuring and computing the cubical contents of bodies and figures; -- distinguished from planimetry.

Stereomonoscope: S t e r e o m o n o s c o p e "n. An instrument with two lenses  by which an image of a single picture projected upon a screen of ground glass is made to present an appearance of relief and may be viewed by several persons at once.

Stereoplasm: S t e r e o p l a s m "n. The solid or insoluble portion of the cell protoplasm. See Hygroplasm.

Stereopticon: S t e r e o p t i c o n "n. An instrument  consisting essentially of a magic lantern in which photographic pictures are used by which the image of a landscape or any object may be thrown upon a screen in such a manner as to seem to stand out in relief so as to form a striking and accurate representation of the object itself; also a pair of magic lanterns for producing the effect of dissolving views.

Stereoscope: S t e r e o s c o p e "n. An optical instrument for giving to pictures the appearance of solid forms  as seen in nature. It combines in one through a bending of the rays of light two pictures taken for the purpose from points of view a little way apart. It is furnished with two eyeglasses and by refraction or reflection the pictures are superimposed so as to appear as one to the observer.

Stereoscopic: S t e r e o s c o p i c "a. Alt. of Stereoscopical

Stereoscopical: S t e r e o s c o p i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to the stereoscope; characteristic of  or adapted to the stereoscope; as a stereoscopic effect; the stereoscopic function of the eyeglasses; stereoscopic views.

Stereoscopist: S t e r e o s c o p i s t "n. One skilled in the use or construction of stereoscopes.

Stereoscopy: S t e r e o s c o p y "n. The art or science of using the stereoscope  or of constructing the instrument or the views used with it.

Stereostatic: S t e r e o s t a t i c "a. Geostatic.

Stereotomic: S t e r e o t o m i c "a. Alt. of Stereotomical

Stereotomical: S t e r e o t o m i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to stereotomy; performed by stereotomy.

Stereotomy: S t e r e o t o m y "n. The science or art of cutting solids into certain figures or sections  as arches and the like; especially the art of stonecutting.

Stereotype: S t e r e o t y p e "n. A plate forming an exact faximile of a page of type or of an engraving  used in printing books etc.; specifically a plate with type-metal face used for printing.

Stereotype: S t e r e o t y p e "n. The art or process of making such plates  or of executing work by means of them.

Stereotype: S t e r e o t y p e "v. t. To prepare for printing in stereotype; to make the stereotype plates of; as  to stereotype the Bible.

Stereotype: S t e r e o t y p e "v. t. Fig.: To make firm or permanent; to fix.

Stereotyped: S t e r e o t y p e d "imp. & p. p. of Stereotype

Stereotyped: S t e r e o t y p e d "a. Formed into  or printed from stereotype plates.

Stereotyped: S t e r e o t y p e d "a. Fig.: Formed in a fixed  unchangeable manner; as stereotyped opinions.

Stereotyper: S t e r e o t y p e r "n. One who stereotypes; one who makes stereotype plates  or works in a stereotype foundry.

Stereotypery: S t e r e o t y p e r y "n. The art  process or employment of making stereotype plates.

Stereotypery: S t e r e o t y p e r y "n. A place where stereotype plates are made; a stereotype foundry.

Stereotypic: S t e r e o t y p i c "a. Of or pertaining to stereotype  or stereotype plates.

Stereotyping: S t e r e o t y p i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Stereotype

Stereotypist: S t e r e o t y p i s t "n. A stereotyper.

Stereotypographer: S t e r e o t y p o g r a p h e r "n. A stereotype printer.

Stereotypography: S t e r e o t y p o g r a p h y "n. The act or art of printing from stereotype plates.

Stereotypy: S t e r e o t y p y "n. The art or process of making stereotype plates.

Sterhydraulic: S t e r h y d r a u l i c "a. Pertaining to  or designating a kind of hydraulic press; resembling such a press in action or principle.

Sterile: S t e r i l e "a. Producing little or no crop; barren; unfruitful; unproductive; not fertile; as  sterile land; a sterile desert; a sterile year.

Sterile: S t e r i l e "a. Incapable of reproduction; unfitted for reproduction of offspring; not able to germinate or bear fruit; unfruitful; as  a sterile flower which bears only stamens.

Sterile: S t e r i l e "a. Free from reproductive spores or germs; as  a sterile fluid.

Sterile: S t e r i l e "a. Fig.: Barren of ideas; destitute of sentiment; as  a sterile production or author.

Sterility: S t e r i l i t y "n. The quality or condition of being sterile.

Sterility: S t e r i l i t y "n. Quality of being sterile; infecundity; also  the state of being free from germs or spores.

Sterilization: S t e r i l i z a t i o n "n. The act or process of sterilizing  or rendering sterile; also the state of being sterile.

Sterilize: S t e r i l i z e "v. t. To make sterile or unproductive; to impoverish  as land; to exhaust of fertility.

Sterilize: S t e r i l i z e "v. t. To deprive of the power of reproducing; to render incapable of germination or fecundation; to make sterile.

Sterilize: S t e r i l i z e "v. t. To destroy all spores or germs in (an organic fluid or mixture)  as by heat so as to prevent the development of bacterial or other organisms.

Sterilized: S t e r i l i z e d "imp. & p. p. of Sterilize

Sterilizing: S t e r i l i z i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Sterilize

Sterlet: S t e r l e t "n. A small sturgeon (Acipenser ruthenus) found in the Caspian Sea and its rivers  and highly esteemed for its flavor. The finest caviare is made from its roe.

Sterling: S t e r l i n g "n. Same as Starling  3.

Sterling: S t e r l i n g "n. Any English coin of standard value; coined money.

Sterling: S t e r l i n g "n. A certain standard of quality or value for money.

Sterling: S t e r l i n g "a. Belonging to  or relating to the standard British money of account or the British coinage; as a pound sterling; a shilling sterling; a penny sterling; -- now chiefly applied to the lawful money of England; but sterling cost sterling value are used.

Sterling: S t e r l i n g "a. Genuine; pure; of excellent quality; conforming to the highest standard; of full value; as  a work of sterling merit; a man of sterling good sense.

Stern: S t e r n "n. The black tern.

Stern: S t e r n "superl. Having a certain hardness or severity of nature  manner or aspect; hard; severe; rigid; rigorous; austere; fixed; unchanging; unrelenting; hence serious; resolute; harsh; as a sternresolve; a stern necessity; a stern heart; a stern gaze; a stern decree.

Stern: S t e r n "v. t. The helm or tiller of a vessel or boat; also  the rudder.

Stern: S t e r n "v. t. The after or rear end of a ship or other vessel  or of a boat; the part opposite to the stem or prow.

Stern: S t e r n "v. t. Fig.: The post of management or direction.

Stern: S t e r n "v. t. The hinder part of anything.

Stern: S t e r n "v. t. The tail of an animal; -- now used only of the tail of a dog.

Stern: S t e r n "a. Being in the stern  or being astern; as the stern davits.

Stern-wheel: S t e r n - w h e e l "a. Having a paddle wheel at the stern; as  a stern-wheel steamer.

Stern-wheeler: S t e r n - w h e e l e r "n. A steamboat having a stern wheel instead of side wheels.

Sterna: S t e r n a "pl. "of Sternum

Sternage: S t e r n a g e "n. Stern.

Sternal: S t e r n a l "a. Of or pertaining to the sternum; in the region of the sternum.

Sternbergite: S t e r n b e r g i t e "n. A sulphide of silver and iron  occurring in soft flexible laminae varying in color from brown to black.

Sternebra: S t e r n e b r a "n. One of the segments of the sternum.

Sternebrae: S t e r n e b r a e "pl. "of Sternebra

Sterned: S t e r n e d "a. Having a stern of a particular shape; -- used in composition; as  square-sterned.

Sterner: S t e r n e r "n. A director.

Sternforemost: S t e r n f o r e m o s t "adv. With the stern  instead of the bow in advance; hence figuratively in an awkward blundering manner.

Sternite: S t e r n i t e "n. The sternum of an arthropod somite.

Sternly: S t e r n l y "adv. In a stern manner.

Sternmost: S t e r n m o s t "a. Farthest in the rear; farthest astern; as  the sternmost ship in a convoy.

Sternness: S t e r n n e s s "n. The quality or state of being stern.

Sterno-: S t e r n o - " A combining form used in anatomy to indicate connection with  or relation to the sternum; as sternocostal sternoscapular.

Sternocoracoid: S t e r n o c o r a c o i d "a. Of or pertaining to the sternum and the coracoid.

Sternocostal: S t e r n o c o s t a l "a. Of or pertaining to the sternum and the ribs; as  the sternocostal cartilages.

Sternohyoid: S t e r n o h y o i d "a. Of or pertaining to the sternum and the hyoid bone or cartilage.

Sternomastoid: S t e r n o m a s t o i d "a. Of or pertaining to the sternum and the mastoid process.

Sternothyroid: S t e r n o t h y r o i d "a. Of or pertaining to the sternum and the thyroid cartilage.

Sternpost: S t e r n p o s t "n. A straight piece of timber  or an iron bar or beam erected on the extremity of the keel to support the rudder and receive the ends of the planks or plates of the vessel.

Sternsman: S t e r n s m a n "n. A steersman.

Sternson: S t e r n s o n "n. The end of a ship's keelson  to which the sternpost is bolted; -- called also stern knee.

Sternum: S t e r n u m "n. A plate of cartilage  or a series of bony or cartilaginous plates or segments in the median line of the pectoral skeleton of most vertebrates above fishes; the breastbone.

Sternum: S t e r n u m "n. The ventral part of any one of the somites of an arthropod.

Sternums: S t e r n u m s "pl. "of Sternum

Sternutation: S t e r n u t a t i o n "n. The act of sneezing.

Sternutative: S t e r n u t a t i v e "a. Having the quality of provoking to sneeze.

Sternutatory: S t e r n u t a t o r y "a. Sternutative.

Sternutatory: S t e r n u t a t o r y "n. A sternutatory substance or medicine.

Sternway: S t e r n w a y "n. The movement of a ship backward  or with her stern foremost.

Sterquilinous: S t e r q u i l i n o u s "a. Pertaining to a dunghill; hence  mean; dirty; paltry.

Sterre: S t e r r e "n. A star.

Sterrink: S t e r r i n k "n. The crab-eating seal (Lobodon carcinophaga) of the Antarctic Ocean.

Sterrometal: S t e r r o m e t a l "n. Any alloy of copper  zinc tin and iron of which cannon are sometimes made.

Stert: S t e r t "p. p. Started.

Sterte: S t e r t e " p. p. of Start.

Stertorious: S t e r t o r i o u s "a. Stertorous.

Stertorous: S t e r t o r o u s "a. Characterized by a deep snoring  which accompaines inspiration in some diseases especially apoplexy; hence hoarsely breathing; snoring.

Sterve: S t e r v e "v. t. & i. To die  or cause to die; to perish. See Starve.

Stet: S t e t "subj. 3d pers. sing. Let it stand; -- a word used by proof readers to signify that something once erased  or marked for omission is to remain.

Stet: S t e t "v. t. To cause or direct to remain after having been marked for omission; to mark with the word stet  or with a series of dots below or beside the matter; as the proof reader stetted a deled footnote.

Stethal: S t e t h a l "n. One of the higher alcohols of the methane series  homologous with ethal and found in small quantities as an ethereal salt of stearic acid in spermaceti.

Stethograph: S t e t h o g r a p h "n. See Pneumatograph.

Stethometer: S t e t h o m e t e r "n. An apparatus for measuring the external movements of a given point of the chest wall  during respiration; -- also called thoracometer.

Stethoscope: S t e t h o s c o p e "n. An instrument used in auscultation for examining the organs of the chest  as the heart and lungs by conveying to the ear of the examiner the sounds produced in the thorax.

Stethoscope: S t e t h o s c o p e "v. t. To auscultate  or examine with a stethoscope.

Stethoscopic: S t e t h o s c o p i c "a. Alt. of Stethoscopical

Stethoscopical: S t e t h o s c o p i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to a stethoscope; obtained or made by means of a stethoscope.

Stethoscopist: S t e t h o s c o p i s t "n. One skilled in the use of the stethoscope.

Stethoscopy: S t e t h o s c o p y "n. The art or process of examination by the stethoscope.

Stetted: S t e t t e d "imp. & p. p. of Stet

Stetting: S t e t t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Stet

Steve: S t e v e "v. t. To pack or stow  as cargo in a ship's hold. See Steeve.

Stevedore: S t e v e d o r e "n. One whose occupation is to load and unload vessels in port; one who stows a cargo in a hold.

Steven: S t e v e n "n. Voice; speech; language.

Steven: S t e v e n "n. An outcry; a loud call; a clamor.

Stew: S t e w "n. A small pond or pool where fish are kept for the table; a vivarium.

Stew: S t e w "n. An artificial bed of oysters.

Stew: S t e w "v. t. To boil slowly  or with the simmering or moderate heat; to seethe; to cook in a little liquid over a gentle fire without boiling; as to stew meat; to stew oysters; to stew apples.

Stew: S t e w "v. i. To be seethed or cooked in a slow  gentle manner or in heat and moisture.

Stew: S t e w "v. t. A place of stewing or seething; a place where hot bathes are furnished; a hothouse.

Stew: S t e w "v. t. A brothel; -- usually in the plural.

Stew: S t e w "v. t. A prostitute.

Stew: S t e w "v. t. A dish prepared by stewing; as  a stewof pigeons.

Stew: S t e w "v. t. A state of agitating excitement; a state of worry; confusion; as  to be in a stew.

Steward: S t e w a r d "n. A man employed in a large family  or on a large estate to manage the domestic concerns supervise other servants collect the rents or income keep accounts and the like.

Steward: S t e w a r d "n. A person employed in a hotel  or a club or on board a ship to provide for the table superintend the culinary affairs etc. In naval vessels the captain's steward wardroom steward steerage steward warrant officers steward etc. are petty officers who provide for the messes under their charge.

Steward: S t e w a r d "n. A fiscal agent of certain bodies; as  a steward in a Methodist church.

Steward: S t e w a r d "n. In some colleges  an officer who provides food for the students and superintends the kitchen; also an officer who attends to the accounts of the students.

Steward: S t e w a r d "n. In Scotland  a magistrate appointed by the crown to exercise jurisdiction over royal lands.

Steward: S t e w a r d "v. t. To manage as a steward.

Stewardess: S t e w a r d e s s "n. A female steward; specifically  a woman employed in passenger vessels to attend to the wants of female passengers.

Stewardly: S t e w a r d l y "adv. In a manner  or with the care of a steward.

Stewardship: S t e w a r d s h i p "n. The office of a steward.

Stewartry: S t e w a r t r y "n. An overseer or superintendent.

Stewartry: S t e w a r t r y "n. The office of a steward; stewardship.

Stewartry: S t e w a r t r y "n. In Scotland  the jurisdiction of a steward; also the lands under such jurisdiction.

Stewed: S t e w e d "imp. & p. p. of Stew

Stewing: S t e w i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Stew

Stewish: S t e w i s h "a. Suiting a stew  or brothel.

Stewpan: S t e w p a n "n. A pan used for stewing.

Stewpot: S t e w p o t "n. A pot used for stewing.

Stey: S t e y "n. See Stee.

Sthenic: S t h e n i c "a. Strong; active; -- said especially of morbid states attended with excessive action of the heart and blood vessels  and characterized by strength and activity of the muscular and nervous system; as a sthenic fever.

Stiacciato: S t i a c c i a t o "n. The lowest relief  -- often used in Italian sculpture of the 15th and 16th centuries.

Stian: S t i a n "n. A sty on the eye. See Styan.

Stibborn: S t i b b o r n "a. Stubborn.

Stibial: S t i b i a l "a. Like  or having the qualities of antimony; antimonial.

Stibialism: S t i b i a l i s m "n. Antimonial intoxication or poisoning.

Stibiated: S t i b i a t e d "a. Combined or impregnated with antimony (stibium).

Stibic: S t i b i c "a. Antimonic; -- used with reference to certain compounds of antimony.

Stibiconite: S t i b i c o n i t e "n. A native oxide of antimony occurring in masses of a yellow color.

Stibine: S t i b i n e "n. Antimony hydride  or hydrogen antimonide a colorless gas produced by the action of nascent hydrogen on antimony. It has a characteristic odor and burns with a characteristic greenish flame. Formerly called also antimoniureted hydrogen.

Stibious: S t i b i o u s "a. Antimonious.

Stibium: S t i b i u m "n. The technical name of antimony.

Stibium: S t i b i u m "n. Stibnite.

Stibnite: S t i b n i t e "n. A mineral of a lead-gray color and brilliant metallic luster  occurring in prismatic crystals; sulphide of antimony; -- called also antimony glance and gray antimony.

Stibonium: S t i b o n i u m "n. The hypothetical radical SbH4  analogous to ammonium; -- called also antimonium.

Sticcado: S t i c c a d o "n. An instrument consisting of small bars of wood  flat at the bottom and rounded at the top and resting on the edges of a kind of open box. They are unequal in size gradually increasing from the smallest to the largest and are tuned to the diatonic scale. The tones are produced by striking the pieces of wood with hard balls attached to flexible sticks.

Stich: S t i c h "n. A verse  of whatever measure or number of feet.

Stich: S t i c h "n. A line in the Scriptures; specifically (Hebrew Scriptures)  one of the rhythmic lines in the poetical books and passages of the Old Treatment as written in the oldest Hebrew manuscripts and in the Revised Version of the English Bible.

Stich: S t i c h "n. A row  line or rank of trees.

Stichic: S t i c h i c "a. Of or pertaining to stichs  or lines; consisting of stichs or lines.

Stichida: S t i c h i d a "pl. "of Stichidium

Stichidium: S t i c h i d i u m "n. A special podlike or fusiform branch containing tetraspores. It is found in certain red algae.

Stichomancy: S t i c h o m a n c y "n. Divination by lines  or passages of books taken at hazard.

Stichometrical: S t i c h o m e t r i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to stichometry; characterized by stichs  or lines.

Stichometry: S t i c h o m e t r y "n. Measurement of books by the number of lines which they contain.

Stichometry: S t i c h o m e t r y "n. Division of the text of a book into lines; especially  the division of the text of books into lines accommodated to the sense -- a method of writing manuscripts used before punctuation was adopted.

Stichwort: S t i c h w o r t "n. A kind of chickweed (Stellaria Holostea).

Stick: S t i c k "v. t. A small shoot  or branch separated as by a cutting from a tree or shrub; also any stem or branch of a tree of any size cut for fuel or timber.

Stick: S t i c k "v. t. Any long and comparatively slender piece of wood  whether in natural form or shaped with tools; a rod; a wand; a staff; as the stick of a rocket; a walking stick.

Stick: S t i c k "v. t. Anything shaped like a stick; as  a stick of wax.

Stick: S t i c k "v. t. A derogatory expression for a person; one who is inert or stupid; as  an odd stick; a poor stick.

Stick: S t i c k "v. t. A composing stick. See under Composing. It is usually a frame of metal  but for posters handbills etc. one made of wood is used.

Stick: S t i c k "v. t. A thrust with a pointed instrument; a stab.

Stick: S t i c k "n. To penetrate with a pointed instrument; to pierce; to stab; hence  to kill by piercing; as to stick a beast.

Stick: S t i c k "n. To cause to penetrate; to push  thrust or drive so as to pierce; as to stick a needle into one's finger.

Stick: S t i c k "n. To fasten  attach or cause to remain by thrusting in; hence also to adorn or deck with things fastened on as by piercing; as to stick a pin on the sleeve.

Stick: S t i c k "n. To set; to fix in; as  to stick card teeth.

Stick: S t i c k "n. To set with something pointed; as  to stick cards.

Stick: S t i c k "n. To fix on a pointed instrument; to impale; as  to stick an apple on a fork.

Stick: S t i c k "n. To attach by causing to adhere to the surface; as  to stick on a plaster; to stick a stamp on an envelope; also to attach in any manner.

Stick: S t i c k "n. To compose; to set  or arrange in a composing stick; as to stick type.

Stick: S t i c k "n. To run or plane (moldings) in a machine  in contradistinction to working them by hand. Such moldings are said to be stuck.

Stick: S t i c k "n. To cause to stick; to bring to a stand; to pose; to puzzle; as  to stick one with a hard problem.

Stick: S t i c k "n. To impose upon; to compel to pay; sometimes  to cheat.

Stick: S t i c k "v. i. To adhere; as  glue sticks to the fingers; paste sticks to the wall.

Stick: S t i c k "v. i. To remain where placed; to be fixed; to hold fast to any position so as to be moved with difficulty; to cling; to abide; to cleave; to be united closely.

Stick: S t i c k "v. i. To be prevented from going farther; to stop by reason of some obstacle; to be stayed.

Stick: S t i c k "v. i. To be embarrassed or puzzled; to hesitate; to be deterred  as by scruples; to scruple; -- often with at.

Stick: S t i c k "v. i. To cause difficulties  scruples or hesitation.

Stick-lac: S t i c k - l a c "n. See the Note under Lac.

Stick-seed: S t i c k - s e e d "n. A plant (Echinospermum Lappula) of the Borage family  with small blue flowers and prickly nutlets.

Stick-tight: S t i c k - t i g h t "n. Beggar's ticks.

Sticked: S t i c k e d " of Stick

Sticked: S t i c k e d "imp. Stuck.

Sticker: S t i c k e r "n. One who  or that which sticks; as a bill sticker.

Sticker: S t i c k e r "n. That which causes one to stick; that which puzzles or poses.

Sticker: S t i c k e r "n. In the organ  a small wooden rod which connects (in part) a key and a pallet so as to communicate motion by pushing.

Sticker: S t i c k e r "n. Same as Paster  2.

Stickful: S t i c k f u l "n. As much set type as fills a composing stick.

Stickfuls: S t i c k f u l s "pl. "of Stickful

Stickiness: S t i c k i n e s s "n. The quality of being sticky; as  the stickiness of glue or paste.

Sticking: S t i c k i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Stick

Sticking: S t i c k i n g " a. & n. from Stick  v.

Stickit: S t i c k i t "a. Stuck; spoiled in making.

Stickle: S t i c k l e "v. i. To separate combatants by intervening.

Stickle: S t i c k l e "v. i. To contend  contest or altercate esp. in a pertinacious manner on insufficient grounds.

Stickle: S t i c k l e "v. i. To play fast and loose; to pass from one side to the other; to trim.

Stickle: S t i c k l e "v. t. To separate  as combatants; hence to quiet to appease as disputants.

Stickle: S t i c k l e "v. t. To intervene in; to stop  or put an end to by intervening; hence to arbitrate.

Stickle: S t i c k l e "v. t. & i. A shallow rapid in a river; also  the current below a waterfall.

Stickleback: S t i c k l e b a c k "v. t. Any one of numerous species of small fishes of the genus Gasterosteus and allied genera. The back is armed with two or more sharp spines. They inhabit both salt and brackish water  and construct curious nests. Called also sticklebag sharpling and prickleback.

Stickled: S t i c k l e d "imp. & p. p. of Stickle

Stickler: S t i c k l e r "v. t. One who stickles.

Stickler: S t i c k l e r "v. t. One who arbitrates a duel; a sidesman to a fencer; a second; an umpire.

Stickler: S t i c k l e r "v. t. One who pertinaciously contends for some trifling things  as a point of etiquette; an unreasonable obstinate contender; as a stickler for ceremony.

Stickling: S t i c k l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Stickle

Sticktail: S t i c k t a i l "n. The ruddy duck.

Sticky: S t i c k y "superl. Having the quality of sticking to a surface; adhesive; gluey; viscous; viscid; glutinous; tenacious.

Stiddy: S t i d d y "n. An anvil; also  a smith shop. See Stithy.

Stied: S t i e d "imp. & p. p. of Sty

Sties: S t i e s "pl. "of Sty

Stiff: S t i f f "superl. Not easily bent; not flexible or pliant; not limber or flaccid; rigid; firm; as  stiff wood paper joints.

Stiff: S t i f f "superl. Not liquid or fluid; thick and tenacious; inspissated; neither soft nor hard; as  the paste is stiff.

Stiff: S t i f f "superl. Firm; strong; violent; difficult to oppose; as  a stiff gale or breeze.

Stiff: S t i f f "superl. Not easily subdued; unyielding; stubborn; obstinate; pertinacious; as  a stiff adversary.

Stiff: S t i f f "superl. Not natural and easy; formal; constrained; affected; starched; as  stiff behavior; a stiff style.

Stiff: S t i f f "superl. Harsh; disagreeable; severe; hard to bear.

Stiff: S t i f f "superl. Bearing a press of canvas without careening much; as  a stiff vessel; -- opposed to crank.

Stiff: S t i f f "superl. Very large  strong or costly; powerful; as a stiff charge; a stiff price.

Stiff-backed: S t i f f - b a c k e d "a. Obstinate.

Stiff-hearted: S t i f f - h e a r t e d "a. Obstinate; stubborn; contumacious.

Stiff-necked: S t i f f - n e c k e d "a. Stubborn; inflexibly obstinate; contumacious; as  stiff-necked pride; a stiff-necked people.

Stiff-neckedness: S t i f f - n e c k e d n e s s "n. The quality or state of being stiff-necked; stubbornness.

Stiff-tailed: S t i f f - t a i l e d "a. Having the quill feathers of the tail somewhat rigid.

Stiffen: S t i f f e n "v. t. To make stiff; to make less pliant or flexible; as  to stiffen cloth with starch.

Stiffen: S t i f f e n "v. t. To inspissate; to make more thick or viscous; as  to stiffen paste.

Stiffen: S t i f f e n "v. t. To make torpid; to benumb.

Stiffen: S t i f f e n "v. i. To become stiff or stiffer  in any sense of the adjective.

Stiffened: S t i f f e n e d "imp. & p. p. of Stiffen

Stiffener: S t i f f e n e r "n. One who  or that which stiffens anything as a piece of stiff cloth in a cravat.

Stiffening: S t i f f e n i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Stiffen

Stiffening: S t i f f e n i n g "n. Act or process of making stiff.

Stiffening: S t i f f e n i n g "n. Something used to make anything stiff.

Stiffish: S t i f f i s h "a. Somewhat stiff.

Stiffly: S t i f f l y "adv. In a stiff manner.

Stiffness: S t i f f n e s s "n. The quality or state of being stiff; as  the stiffness of cloth or of paste; stiffness of manner; stiffness of character.

Stifftail: S t i f f t a i l "n. The ruddy duck.

Stifle: S t i f l e "n. The joint next above the hock  and near the flank in the hind leg of the horse and allied animals; the joint corresponding to the knee in man; -- called also stifle joint. See Illust. under Horse.

Stifle: S t i f l e "v. t. To stop the breath of by crowding something into the windpipe  or introducing an irrespirable substance into the lungs; to choke; to suffocate; to cause the death of by such means; as to stifle one with smoke or dust.

Stifle: S t i f l e "v. t. To stop; to extinguish; to deaden; to quench; as  to stifle the breath; to stifle a fire or flame.

Stifle: S t i f l e "v. t. To suppress the manifestation or report of; to smother; to conceal from public knowledge; as  to stifle a story; to stifle passion.

Stifle: S t i f l e "v. i. To die by reason of obstruction of the breath  or because some noxious substance prevents respiration.

Stifled: S t i f l e d "imp. & p. p. of Stifle

Stifled: S t i f l e d "a. Stifling.

Stifler: S t i f l e r "n. One who  or that which stifles.

Stifler: S t i f l e r "n. See Camouflet.

Stifling: S t i f l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Stifle

Stigma: S t i g m a "v. t. A mark made with a burning iron; a brand.

Stigma: S t i g m a "v. t. Any mark of infamy or disgrace; sign of moral blemish; stain or reproach caused by dishonorable conduct; reproachful characterization.

Stigma: S t i g m a "v. t. That part of a pistil which has no epidermis  and is fitted to receive the pollen. It is usually the terminal portion and is commonly somewhat glutinous or viscid. See Illust. of Stamen and of Flower.

Stigma: S t i g m a "v. t. A small spot  mark scar or a minute hole; -- applied especially to a spot on the outer surface of a Graafian follicle and to spots of intercellular substance in scaly epithelium or to minute holes in such spots.

Stigma: S t i g m a "v. t. A red speck upon the skin  produced either by the extravasation of blood as in the bloody sweat characteristic of certain varieties of religious ecstasy or by capillary congestion as in the case of drunkards.

Stigma: S t i g m a "v. t. One of the external openings of the tracheae of insects  myriapods and other arthropods; a spiracle.

Stigma: S t i g m a "v. t. One of the apertures of the pulmonary sacs of arachnids. See Illust. of Scorpion.

Stigma: S t i g m a "v. t. One of the apertures of the gill of an ascidian  and of Amphioxus.

Stigma: S t i g m a "v. t. A point so connected by any law whatever with another point  called an index that as the index moves in any manner in a plane the first point or stigma moves in a determinate way in the same plane.

Stigma: S t i g m a "v. t. Marks believed to have been supernaturally impressed upon the bodies of certain persons in imitation of the wounds on the crucified body of Christ. See def. 5  above.

Stigmaria: S t i g m a r i a "n. The fossil root stem of a coal plant of the genus Sigillaria.

Stigmas: S t i g m a s "pl. "of Stigma

Stigmata: S t i g m a t a "pl. "of Stigma

Stigmata: S t i g m a t a "n. pl. of Stigma.

Stigmatic: S t i g m a t i c "n. A notorious profligate or criminal who has been branded; one who bears the marks of infamy or punishment.

Stigmatic: S t i g m a t i c "n. A person who is marked or deformed by nature.

Stigmatic: S t i g m a t i c "n. A person bearing the wounds on the hands and feet resembling those of Jesus Christ caused by His crucifixion; -- for true stigmantics the wounds are supposed to have been caused miraculously  as a sign of great holiness.

Stigmatic: S t i g m a t i c "a. Alt. of Stigmatical

Stigmatical: S t i g m a t i c a l "a. Marked with a stigma  or with something reproachful to character.

Stigmatical: S t i g m a t i c a l "a. Impressing with infamy or reproach.

Stigmatical: S t i g m a t i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to a stigma or stigmata.

Stigmatically: S t i g m a t i c a l l y "adv. With a stigma  or mark of infamy or deformity.

Stigmatist: S t i g m a t i s t "n. One believed to be supernaturally impressed with the marks of Christ's wounds. See Stigma  8.

Stigmatization: S t i g m a t i z a t i o n "n. The act of stigmatizing.

Stigmatization: S t i g m a t i z a t i o n "n. The production of stigmata upon the body. See Stigma  8.

Stigmatize: S t i g m a t i z e "v. t. To mark with a stigma  or brand; as the ancients stigmatized their slaves and soldiers.

Stigmatize: S t i g m a t i z e "v. t. To set a mark of disgrace on; to brand with some mark of reproach or infamy.

Stigmatized: S t i g m a t i z e d "imp. & p. p. of Stigmatize

Stigmatizing: S t i g m a t i z i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Stigmatize

Stigmatose: S t i g m a t o s e "a. Same as Stigmatic.

Stigonomancy: S t i g o n o m a n c y "n. Divination by writing on the bark of a tree.

Stike: S t i k e "n. Stanza.

Stilar: S t i l a r "a. Of or pertaining to the style of a dial.

Stilbene: S t i l b e n e "n. A hydrocarbon  C14H12 produced artificially in large fine crystals; -- called also diphenyl ethylene toluylene etc.

Stilbite: S t i l b i t e "n. A common mineral of the zeolite family  a hydrous silicate of alumina and lime usually occurring in sheaflike aggregations of crystals also in radiated masses. It is of a white or yellowish color with pearly luster on the cleavage surface. Called also desmine.

Stile: S t i l e "n. A pin set on the face of a dial  to cast a shadow; a style. See Style.

Stile: S t i l e "n. Mode of composition. See Style.

Stile: S t i l e "v. i. A step  or set of steps for ascending and descending in passing a fence or wall.

Stile: S t i l e "v. i. One of the upright pieces in a frame; one of the primary members of a frame  into which the secondary members are mortised.

Stilet: S t i l e t "n. A stiletto.

Stilet: S t i l e t "n. See Stylet  2.

Stiletto: S t i l e t t o "n. A kind of dagger with a slender  rounded and pointed blade.

Stiletto: S t i l e t t o "n. A pointed instrument for making eyelet holes in embroidery.

Stiletto: S t i l e t t o "n. A beard trimmed into a pointed form.

Stiletto: S t i l e t t o "v. t. To stab or kill with a stiletto.

Stilettoed: S t i l e t t o e d "imp. & p. p. of Stiletto

Stilettoing: S t i l e t t o i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Stiletto

Stilettos: S t i l e t t o s "pl. "of Stiletto

Still: S t i l l "adv. Motionless; at rest; quiet; as  to stand still; to lie or sit still.

Still: S t i l l "adv. Uttering no sound; silent; as  the audience is still; the animals are still.

Still: S t i l l "adv. Not disturbed by noise or agitation; quiet; calm; as  a still evening; a still atmosphere.

Still: S t i l l "adv. Comparatively quiet or silent; soft; gentle; low.

Still: S t i l l "adv. Constant; continual.

Still: S t i l l "adv. Not effervescing; not sparkling; as  still wines.

Still: S t i l l "n. Freedom from noise; calm; silence; as  the still of midnight.

Still: S t i l l "n. A steep hill or ascent.

Still: S t i l l "a. To this time; until and during the time now present; now no less than before; yet.

Still: S t i l l "a. In the future as now and before.

Still: S t i l l "a. In continuation by successive or repeated acts; always; ever; constantly; uniformly.

Still: S t i l l "a. In an increasing or additional degree; even more; -- much used with comparatives.

Still: S t i l l "a. Notwithstanding what has been said or done; in spite of what has occured; nevertheless; -- sometimes used as a conjunction. See Synonym of But.

Still: S t i l l "a. After that; after what is stated.

Still: S t i l l "a. To stop  as motion or agitation; to cause to become quiet or comparatively quiet; to check the agitation of; as to still the raging sea.

Still: S t i l l "a. To stop  as noise; to silence.

Still: S t i l l "a. To appease; to calm; to quiet  as tumult agitation or excitement; as to still the passions.

Still: S t i l l "v. A vessel  boiler or copper used in the distillation of liquids; specifically one used for the distillation of alcoholic liquors; a retort. The name is sometimes applied to the whole apparatus used in in vaporization and condensation.

Still: S t i l l "v. A house where liquors are distilled; a distillery.

Still: S t i l l "v. t. To cause to fall by drops.

Still: S t i l l "v. t. To expel spirit from by heat  or to evaporate and condense in a refrigeratory; to distill.

Still: S t i l l "v. i. To drop  or flow in drops; to distill.

Still-burn: S t i l l - b u r n "p. pr. & vb. n. To burn in the process of distillation; as  to still-burn brandy.

Still-closing: S t i l l - c l o s i n g "a. Ever closing.

Still-hunt: S t i l l - h u n t "n. A hunting for game in a quiet and cautious manner  or under cover; stalking; hence colloquially the pursuit of any object quietly and cautiously.

Stillage: S t i l l a g e "n. A low stool to keep the goods from touching the floor.

Stillatitious: S t i l l a t i t i o u s "a. Falling in drops; drawn by a still.

Stillatory: S t i l l a t o r y "a. An alembic; a vessel for distillation.

Stillatory: S t i l l a t o r y "a. A laboratory; a place or room in which distillation is performed.

Stillbirth: S t i l l b i r t h "n. The birth of a dead fetus.

Stillborn: S t i l l b o r n "a. Dead at the birth; as  a stillborn child.

Stillborn: S t i l l b o r n "a. Fig.: Abortive; as  a stillborn poem.

Stilled: S t i l l e d "imp. & p. p. of Still

Stiller: S t i l l e r "n. One who stills  or quiets.

Stillhouse: S t i l l h o u s e "n. A house in which distillation is carried on; a distillery.

Stillicide: S t i l l i c i d e "n. A continual falling or succession of drops; rain water falling from the eaves.

Stillicidious: S t i l l i c i d i o u s "a. Falling in drops.

Stilliform: S t i l l i f o r m "a. Having the form of a drop.

Stilling: S t i l l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Still

Stilling: S t i l l i n g "n. A stillion.

Stillion: S t i l l i o n "n. A stand  as for casks or vats in a brewery or for pottery while drying.

Stillness: S t i l l n e s s "n. The quality or state of being still; quietness; silence; calmness; inactivity.

Stillness: S t i l l n e s s "n. Habitual silence or quiet; taciturnity.

Stillroom: S t i l l r o o m "n. A room for distilling.

Stillroom: S t i l l r o o m "n. An apartment in a house where liquors  preserves and the like are kept.

Stillstand: S t i l l s t a n d "n. A standstill.

Stilly: S t i l l y "a. Still; quiet; calm.

Stilly: S t i l l y "adv. In a still manner; quietly; silently; softly.

Stilpnomelane: S t i l p n o m e l a n e "n. A black or greenish black mineral occurring in foliated flates  also in velvety bronze-colored incrustations. It is a hydrous silicate of iron and alumina.

Stilt: S t i l t "n. A pole  or piece of wood constructed with a step or loop to raise the foot above the ground in walking. It is sometimes lashed to the leg and sometimes prolonged upward so as to be steadied by the hand or arm.

Stilt: S t i l t "n. A crutch; also  the handle of a plow.

Stilt: S t i l t "n. Any species of limicoline birds belonging to Himantopus and allied genera  in which the legs are remarkably long and slender. Called also longshanks stiltbird stilt plover and lawyer.

Stilt: S t i l t "v. t. To raise on stilts  or as if on stilts.

Stiltbird: S t i l t b i r d "n. See Stilt  n. 3.

Stilted: S t i l t e d "imp. & p. p. of Stilt

Stilted: S t i l t e d "a. Elevated as if on stilts; hence  pompous; bombastic; as a stilted style; stilted declamation.

Stiltify: S t i l t i f y "v. t. To raise upon stilts  or as upon stilts; to stilt.

Stilting: S t i l t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Stilt

Stilty: S t i l t y "a. Unreasonably elevated; pompous; stilted; as  a stilty style.

Stime: S t i m e "n. A slight gleam or glimmer; a glimpse.

Stimulant: S t i m u l a n t "a. Serving to stimulate.

Stimulant: S t i m u l a n t "a. Produced increased vital action in the organism  or in any of its parts.

Stimulant: S t i m u l a n t "n. That which stimulates  provokes or excites.

Stimulant: S t i m u l a n t "n. An agent which produces a temporary increase of vital activity in the organism  or in any of its parts; -- sometimes used without qualification to signify an alcoholic beverage used as a stimulant.

Stimulate: S t i m u l a t e "v. t. To excite as if with a goad; to excite  rouse or animate to action or more vigorous exertion by some pungent motive or by persuasion; as to stimulate one by the hope of reward or by the prospect of glory.

Stimulate: S t i m u l a t e "v. t. To excite; to irritate; especially  to excite the activity of (a nerve or an irritable muscle) as by electricity.

Stimulated: S t i m u l a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Stimulate

Stimulating: S t i m u l a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Stimulate

Stimulation: S t i m u l a t i o n "n. The act of stimulating  or the state of being stimulated.

Stimulation: S t i m u l a t i o n "n. The irritating action of various agents (stimuli) on muscles  nerves or a sensory end organ by which activity is evoked; especially the nervous impulse produced by various agents on nerves or a sensory end organ by which the part connected with the nerve is thrown into a state of activity; irritation.

Stimulative: S t i m u l a t i v e "a. Having the quality of stimulating.

Stimulative: S t i m u l a t i v e "n. That which stimulates.

Stimulator: S t i m u l a t o r "n. One who stimulates.

Stimulatress: S t i m u l a t r e s s "n. A woman who stimulates.

Stimuli: S t i m u l i "pl. "of Stimulus

Stimulism: S t i m u l i s m "n. The theory of medical practice which regarded life as dependent upon stimulation  or excitation and disease as caused by excess or deficiency in the amount of stimulation.

Stimulism: S t i m u l i s m "n. The practice of treating disease by alcoholic stimulants.

Stimulus: S t i m u l u s "v. t. A goad; hence  something that rouses the mind or spirits; an incentive; as the hope of gain is a powerful stimulus to labor and action.

Stimulus: S t i m u l u s "v. t. That which excites or produces a temporary increase of vital action  either in the whole organism or in any of its parts; especially (Physiol.) any substance or agent capable of evoking the activity of a nerve or irritable muscle or capable of producing an impression upon a sensory organ or more particularly upon its specific end organ.

Sting: S t i n g "v. t. Any sharp organ of offense and defense  especially when connected with a poison gland and adapted to inflict a wound by piercing; as the caudal sting of a scorpion. The sting of a bee or wasp is a modified ovipositor. The caudal sting or spine of a sting ray is a modified dorsal fin ray. The term is sometimes applied to the fang of a serpent. See Illust. of Scorpion.

Sting: S t i n g "v. t. A sharp-pointed hollow hair seated on a gland which secrets an acrid fluid  as in nettles. The points of these hairs usually break off in the wound and the acrid fluid is pressed into it.

Sting: S t i n g "v. t. Anything that gives acute pain  bodily or mental; as the stings of remorse; the stings of reproach.

Sting: S t i n g "v. t. The thrust of a sting into the flesh; the act of stinging; a wound inflicted by stinging.

Sting: S t i n g "v. t. A goad; incitement.

Sting: S t i n g "v. t. The point of an epigram or other sarcastic saying.

Sting: S t i n g "v. t. To pierce or wound with a sting; as  bees will sting an animal that irritates them; the nettles stung his hands.

Sting: S t i n g "v. t. To pain acutely; as  the conscience is stung with remorse; to bite.

Sting: S t i n g "v. t. To goad; to incite  as by taunts or reproaches.

Stingaree: S t i n g a r e e "n. Any sting ray. See under 6th Ray.

Stingbull: S t i n g b u l l "n. The European greater weever fish (Trachinus draco)  which is capable of inflicting severe wounds with the spinous rays of its dorsal fin. See Weever.

Stinger: S t i n g e r "n. One who  or that which stings.

Stingfish: S t i n g f i s h "n. The weever.

Stingily: S t i n g i l y "adv. In a stingy manner.

Stinginess: S t i n g i n e s s "n. The quality or state of being stingy.

Stinging: S t i n g i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Sting

Stinging: S t i n g i n g "a. Piercing  or capable of piercing with a sting; inflicting acute pain as if with a sting goad or pointed weapon; pungent; biting; as stinging cold; a stinging rebuke.

Stingless: S t i n g l e s s "a. Having no sting.

Stingo: S t i n g o "n. Old beer; sharp or strong liquor.

Stingtail: S t i n g t a i l "n. A sting ray.

Stingy: S t i n g y "a. Stinging; able to sting.

Stingy: S t i n g y "superl. Extremely close and covetous; meanly avaricious; niggardly; miserly; penurious; as  a stingy churl.

Stink: S t i n k "v. i. To emit a strong  offensive smell; to send out a disgusting odor.

Stink: S t i n k "v. t. To cause to stink; to affect by a stink.

Stink: S t i n k "n. A strong  offensive smell; a disgusting odor; a stench.

Stinkard: S t i n k a r d "n. A mean  stinking paltry fellow.

Stinkard: S t i n k a r d "n. The teledu of the East Indies. It emits a disagreeable odor.

Stinkball: S t i n k b a l l "n. A composition of substances which in combustion emit a suffocating odor; -- used formerly in naval warfare.

Stinker: S t i n k e r "n. One who  or that which stinks.

Stinker: S t i n k e r "n. Any one of the several species of large antarctic petrels which feed on blubber and carrion and have an offensive odor  as the giant fulmar.

Stinkhorn: S t i n k h o r n "n. A kind of fungus of the genus Phallus  which emits a fetid odor.

Stinking: S t i n k i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Stink

Stinking: S t i n k i n g " a. & n. from Stink  v.

Stinkingly: S t i n k i n g l y "adv. In a stinking manner; with an offensive smell.

Stinkpot: S t i n k p o t "n. An earthen jar charged with powder  grenades and other materials of an offensive and suffocating smell -- sometimes used in boarding an enemy's vessel.

Stinkpot: S t i n k p o t "n. A vessel in which disinfectants are burned.

Stinkpot: S t i n k p o t "n. The musk turtle  or musk tortoise. See under Musk.

Stinkstone: S t i n k s t o n e "n. One of the varieties of calcite  barite and feldspar which emit a fetid odor on being struck; -- called also swinestone.

Stinkweed: S t i n k w e e d "n. Stramonium. See Jamestown weed  and Datura.

Stinkwood: S t i n k w o o d "n. A name given to several kinds of wood with an unpleasant smell  as that of the Foetidia Mauritiana of the Mauritius and that of the South African Ocotea bullata.

Stint: S t i n t "n. Any one of several species of small sandpipers  as the sanderling of Europe and America the dunlin the little stint of India (Tringa minuta) etc. Called also pume.

Stint: S t i n t "n. A phalarope.

Stint: S t i n t "v. t. To restrain within certain limits; to bound; to confine; to restrain; to restrict to a scant allowance.

Stint: S t i n t "v. t. To put an end to; to stop.

Stint: S t i n t "v. t. To assign a certain (i. e.  limited) task to (a person) upon the performance of which one is excused from further labor for the day or for a certain time; to stent.

Stint: S t i n t "v. t. To serve successfully; to get with foal; -- said of mares.

Stint: S t i n t "v. i. To stop; to cease.

Stint: S t i n t "v. t. Limit; bound; restraint; extent.

Stipes: S t i p e s "n. An eyestalk.

Stipitate: S t i p i t a t e "a. Supported by a stipe; elevated on a stipe  as the fronds of most ferns or the pod of certain cruciferous plants.

Stipites: S t i p i t e s "pl. "of Stipes

Stipitiform: S t i p i t i f o r m "a. Having the shape of a stalk; stalklike.

Stipple: S t i p p l e "v. t. To engrave by means of dots  in distinction from engraving in lines.

Stipple: S t i p p l e "v. t. To paint  as in water colors by small short touches which together produce an even or softly graded surface.

Stippling: S t i p p l i n g "n. A mode of execution in which a flat or even tint is produced by many small touches.

Stiptic: S t i p t i c "a. & n. See Styptic.

Stipula: S t i p u l a "n. A stipule.

Stipulaceous: S t i p u l a c e o u s "a. Alt. of Stipular

Stipulae: S t i p u l a e "pl. "of Stipula

Stipular: S t i p u l a r "a. Of or pertaining to stipules; resembling stipules; furnished with stipules; growing on stipules  or close to them; occupying the position of stipules; as stipular glands and stipular tendrils.

Stipulary: S t i p u l a r y "a. Of or pertaining to stipules; stipular.

Stipulas: S t i p u l a s "pl. "of Stipula

Stipulate: S t i p u l a t e "a. Furnished with stipules; as  a stipulate leaf.

Stipulate: S t i p u l a t e "v. i. To make an agreement or covenant with any person or company to do or forbear anything; to bargain; to contract; to settle terms; as  certain princes stipulated to assist each other in resisting the armies of France.

Stipulated: S t i p u l a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Stipulate

Stipulating: S t i p u l a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Stipulate

Stipulation: S t i p u l a t i o n "n. The act of stipulating; a contracting or bargaining; an agreement.

Stipulation: S t i p u l a t i o n "n. That which is stipulated  or agreed upon; that which is definitely arranged or contracted; an agreement; a covenant; a contract or bargain; also any particular article item or condition in a mutual agreement; as the stipulations of the allied powers to furnish each his contingent of troops.

Stipulation: S t i p u l a t i o n "n. A material article of an agreement; an undertaking in the nature of bail taken in the admiralty courts; a bargain.

Stipulation: S t i p u l a t i o n "n. The situation  arrangement and structure of the stipules.

Stipulator: S t i p u l a t o r "n. One who stipulates  contracts or covenants.

Stipule: S t i p u l e "n. An appendage at the base of petioles or leaves  usually somewhat resembling a small leaf in texture and appearance.

Stipuled: S t i p u l e d "a. Furnished with stipules  or leafy appendages.

Stir: S t i r "v. t. To change the place of in any manner; to move.

Stir: S t i r "v. i. To become the object of notice; to be on foot.

Stir: S t i r "v. i. To rise  or be up in the morning.

Stir: S t i r "n. The act or result of stirring; agitation; tumult; bustle; noise or various movements.

Stir: S t i r "n. Public disturbance or commotion; tumultuous disorder; seditious uproar.

Stir: S t i r "n. Agitation of thoughts; conflicting passions.

Stirabout: S t i r a b o u t "n. A dish formed of oatmeal boiled in water to a certain consistency and frequently stirred  or of oatmeal and dripping mixed together and stirred about in a pan; a hasty pudding.

Stiriated: S t i r i a t e d "a. Adorned with pendants like icicles.

Stirious: S t i r i o u s "a. Resembling icicles.

Stirk: S t i r k "n. A young bullock or heifer.

Stirless: S t i r l e s s "a. Without stirring; very quiet; motionless.

Stirp: S t i r p "n. Stock; race; family.
