Stirpiculture: S t i r p i c u l t u r e "n. The breeding of special stocks or races.

Stirps: S t i r p s "n. Stock; race; family.

Stirps: S t i r p s "n. A race  or a fixed and permanent variety.

Stirrage: S t i r r a g e "n. The act of stirring; stir; commotion.

Stirred: S t i r r e d "imp. & p. p. of Stir

Stirrer: S t i r r e r "n. One who  or that which stirs something; also one who moves about especially after sleep; as an early stirrer.

Stirring: S t i r r i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Stir

Stirring: S t i r r i n g "a. Putting in motion  or being in motion; active; active in business; habitually employed in some kind of business; accustomed to a busy life.

Stirrup: S t i r r u p "v. i. A kind of ring  or bent piece of metal wood leather or the like horizontal in one part for receiving the foot of a rider and attached by a strap to the saddle -- used to assist a person in mounting a horse and to enable him to sit steadily in riding as well as to relieve him by supporting a part of the weight of the body.

Stirrup: S t i r r u p "v. i. Any piece resembling in shape the stirrup of a saddle  and used as a support clamp etc. See Bridle iron.

Stirrup: S t i r r u p "v. i. A rope secured to a yard  with a thimble in its lower end for supporting a footrope.

Stirt: S t i r t "v. i. Started; leaped.

Stirte: S t i r t e " imp. of Start  v. i. & t.

Stitch: S t i t c h "v. i. A single pass of a needle in sewing; the loop or turn of the thread thus made.

Stitch: S t i t c h "v. i. A single turn of the thread round a needle in knitting; a link  or loop of yarn; as to let down or drop a stitch; to take up a stitch.

Stitch: S t i t c h "v. i. A space of work taken up  or gone over in a single pass of the needle; hence by extension any space passed over; distance.

Stitch: S t i t c h "v. i. A local sharp pain; an acute pain  like the piercing of a needle; as a stitch in the side.

Stitch: S t i t c h "v. i. A contortion  or twist.

Stitch: S t i t c h "v. i. Any least part of a fabric or dress; as  to wet every stitch of clothes.

Stitch: S t i t c h "v. i. A furrow.

Stitch: S t i t c h "v. t. To form stitches in; especially  to sew in such a manner as to show on the surface a continuous line of stitches; as to stitch a shirt bosom.

Stitch: S t i t c h "v. t. To sew  or unite together by stitches; as to stitch printed sheets in making a book or a pamphlet.

Stitch: S t i t c h "v. t. To form land into ridges.

Stitch: S t i t c h "v. i. To practice stitching  or needlework.

Stitched: S t i t c h e d "imp. & p. p. of Stitch

Stitchel: S t i t c h e l "n. A kind of hairy wool.

Stitcher: S t i t c h e r "n. One who stitches; a seamstress.

Stitchery: S t i t c h e r y "n. Needlework; -- in contempt.

Stitching: S t i t c h i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Stitch

Stitching: S t i t c h i n g "n. The act of one who stitches.

Stitching: S t i t c h i n g "n. Work done by sewing  esp. when a continuous line of stitches is shown on the surface; stitches collectively.

Stitchwort: S t i t c h w o r t "n. See Stichwort.

Stith: S t i t h "a. Strong; stiff; rigid.

Stith: S t i t h "n. An anvil; a stithy.

Stithy: S t i t h y "n. An anvil.

Stithy: S t i t h y "n. A smith's shop; a smithy; a smithery; a forge.

Stithy: S t i t h y "v. t. To forge on an anvil.

Stive: S t i v e "v. t. To stuff; to crowd; to fill full; hence  to make hot and close; to render stifling.

Stive: S t i v e "v. i. To be stifled or suffocated.

Stive: S t i v e "n. The floating dust in flour mills caused by the operation or grinding.

Stived: S t i v e d "imp. & p. p. of Stive

Stiver: S t i v e r "n. A Dutch coin  and money of account of the value of two cents or about one penny sterling; hence figuratively anything of little worth.

Stives: S t i v e s "n. pl. Stews; a brothel.

Stiving: S t i v i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Stive

Stoak: S t o a k "v. t. To stop; to choke.

Stoat: S t o a t "n. The ermine in its summer pelage  when it is reddish brown but with a black tip to the tail. The name is sometimes applied also to other brown weasels.

Stocah: S t o c a h "n. A menial attendant.

Stoccade: S t o c c a d e "n. & v. See Stockade.

Stoccado: S t o c c a d o "n. A stab; a thrust with a rapier.

Stochastic: S t o c h a s t i c "a. Conjectural; able to conjecture.

Stock: S t o c k "n. The stem  or main body of a tree or plant; the fixed strong firm part; the trunk.

Stock: S t o c k "n. The stem or branch in which a graft is inserted.

Stock: S t o c k "n. A block of wood; something fixed and solid; a pillar; a firm support; a post.

Stock: S t o c k "n. Hence  a person who is as dull and lifeless as a stock or post; one who has little sense.

Stock: S t o c k "n. The principal supporting part; the part in which others are inserted  or to which they are attached.

Stock: S t o c k "n. The wood to which the barrel  lock etc. of a musket or like firearm are secured; also a long rectangular piece of wood which is an important part of several forms of gun carriage.

Stock: S t o c k "n. The handle or contrivance by which bits are held in boring; a bitstock; a brace.

Stock: S t o c k "n. The block of wood or metal frame which constitutes the body of a plane  and in which the plane iron is fitted; a plane stock.

Stock: S t o c k "n. The wooden or iron crosspiece to which the shank of an anchor is attached. See Illust. of Anchor.

Stock: S t o c k "n. The support of the block in which an anvil is fixed  or of the anvil itself.

Stock: S t o c k "n. A handle or wrench forming a holder for the dies for cutting screws; a diestock.

Stock: S t o c k "n. The part of a tally formerly struck in the exchequer  which was delivered to the person who had lent the king money on account as the evidence of indebtedness. See Counterfoil.

Stock: S t o c k "n. The original progenitor; also  the race or line of a family; the progenitor of a family and his direct descendants; lineage; family.

Stock: S t o c k "n. Money or capital which an individual or a firm employs in business; fund; in the United States  the capital of a bank or other company in the form of transferable shares each of a certain amount; money funded in government securities called also the public funds; in the plural property consisting of shares in joint-stock companies or in the obligations of a government for its funded debt; -- so in the United States but in England the latter only are called stocks and the former shares.

Stock: S t o c k "n. Same as Stock account  below.

Stock: S t o c k "n. Supply provided; store; accumulation; especially  a merchant's or manufacturer's store of goods; as to lay in a stock of provisions.

Stock: S t o c k "n. Domestic animals or beasts collectively  used or raised on a farm; as a stock of cattle or of sheep etc.; -- called also live stock.

Stock: S t o c k "n. That portion of a pack of cards not distributed to the players at the beginning of certain games  as gleek etc. but which might be drawn from afterward as occasion required; a bank.

Stock: S t o c k "n. A thrust with a rapier; a stoccado.

Stock: S t o c k "n. A covering for the leg  or leg and foot; as upper stocks (breeches); nether stocks (stockings).

Stock: S t o c k "n. A kind of stiff  wide band or cravat for the neck; as a silk stock.

Stock: S t o c k "n. A frame of timber  with holes in which the feet or the feet and hands of criminals were formerly confined by way of punishment.

Stock: S t o c k "n. The frame or timbers on which a ship rests while building.

Stock: S t o c k "n. Red and gray bricks  used for the exterior of walls and the front of buildings.

Stock: S t o c k "n. Any cruciferous plant of the genus Matthiola; as  common stock (Matthiola incana) (see Gilly-flower); ten-weeks stock (M. annua).

Stock: S t o c k "n. An irregular metalliferous mass filling a large cavity in a rock formation  as a stock of lead ore deposited in limestone.

Stock: S t o c k "n. A race or variety in a species.

Stock: S t o c k "n. In tectology  an aggregate or colony of persons (see Person) as trees chains of salpae etc.

Stock: S t o c k "n. The beater of a fulling mill.

Stock: S t o c k "n. A liquid or jelly containing the juices and soluble parts of meat  and certain vegetables etc. extracted by cooking; -- used in making soup gravy etc.

Stock: S t o c k "v. t. To lay up; to put aside for future use; to store  as merchandise and the like.

Stock: S t o c k "v. t. To provide with material requisites; to store; to fill; to supply; as  to stock a warehouse that is to fill it with goods; to stock a farm that is to supply it with cattle and tools; to stock land that is to occupy it with a permanent growth especially of grass.

Stock: S t o c k "v. t. To suffer to retain milk for twenty-four hours or more previous to sale  as cows.

Stock: S t o c k "v. t. To put in the stocks.

Stock: S t o c k "a. Used or employed for constant service or application  as if constituting a portion of a stock or supply; standard; permanent; standing; as a stock actor; a stock play; a stock sermon.

Stock-blind: S t o c k - b l i n d "a. Blind as a stock; wholly blind.

Stock-still: S t o c k - s t i l l "a. Still as a stock  or fixed post; perfectly still.

Stockade: S t o c k a d e "v. t. A line of stout posts or timbers set firmly in the earth in contact with each other (and usually with loopholes) to form a barrier  or defensive fortification.

Stockade: S t o c k a d e "v. t. An inclosure  or pen made with posts and stakes.

Stockade: S t o c k a d e "v. t. To surround  fortify or protect with a stockade.

Stockaded: S t o c k a d e d "imp. & p. p. of Stockade

Stockading: S t o c k a d i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Stockade

Stockbroker: S t o c k b r o k e r "n. A broker who deals in stocks.

Stockdove: S t o c k d o v e "n. A common European wild pigeon (Columba aenas)  so called because at one time believed to be the stock of the domestic pigeon or according to some from its breeding in the stocks or trunks of trees.

Stocked: S t o c k e d "imp. & p. p. of Stock

Stocker: S t o c k e r "n. One who makes or fits stocks  as of guns or gun carriages etc.

Stockfish: S t o c k f i s h "n. Salted and dried fish  especially codfish hake ling and torsk; also codfish dried without being salted.

Stockfish: S t o c k f i s h "n. Young fresh cod.

Stockholder: S t o c k h o l d e r "n. One who is a holder or proprietor of stock in the public funds  or in the funds of a bank or other stock company.

Stockinet: S t o c k i n e t "n. An elastic textile fabric imitating knitting  of which stockings under-garments etc. are made.

Stocking: S t o c k i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Stock

Stocking: S t o c k i n g "n. A close-fitting covering for the foot and leg  usually knit or woven.

Stocking: S t o c k i n g "v. t. To dress in GBs.

Stockinger: S t o c k i n g e r "n. A stocking weaver.

Stockish: S t o c k i s h "a. Like a stock; stupid; blockish.

Stockjobber: S t o c k j o b b e r "n. One who speculates in stocks for gain; one whose occupation is to buy and sell stocks. In England a jobber acts as an intermediary between brokers.

Stockjobbing: S t o c k j o b b i n g "n. The act or art of dealing in stocks; the business of a stockjobber.

Stockman: S t o c k m a n "n. A herdsman; a ranchman; one owning  or having charge of herds of live stock.

Stockmen: S t o c k m e n "pl. "of Stockman

Stockwork: S t o c k w o r k "n. A system of working in ore  etc. when it lies not in strata or veins but in solid masses so as to be worked in chambers or stories.

Stockwork: S t o c k w o r k "n. A metalliferous deposit characterized by the impregnation of the mass of rock with many small veins or nests irregularly grouped. This kind of deposit is especially common with tin ore. Such deposits are worked in floors or stories.

Stocky: S t o c k y "a. Short and thick; thick rather than tall or corpulent.

Stocky: S t o c k y "a. Headstrong.

Stodgy: S t o d g y "a. Wet.

Stoechiology: S t o e c h i o l o g y "n. Alt. of Stoechiometry

Stoechiometry: S t o e c h i o m e t r y "n. See Stoichiology  Stoichiometry etc.

Stoic: S t o i c "n. A disciple of the philosopher Zeno; one of a Greek sect which held that men should be free from passion  unmoved by joy or grief and should submit without complaint to unavoidable necessity by which all things are governed.

Stoic: S t o i c "n. Hence  a person not easily excited; an apathetic person; one who is apparently or professedly indifferent to pleasure or pain.

Stoic: S t o i c "n. Alt. of Stoical

Stoical: S t o i c a l "n. Of or pertaining to the Stoics; resembling the Stoics or their doctrines.

Stoical: S t o i c a l "n. Not affected by passion; manifesting indifference to pleasure or pain.

Stoichiological: S t o i c h i o l o g i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to stoichiology.

Stoichiology: S t o i c h i o l o g y "n. That part of the science of physiology which treats of the elements  or principles composing animal tissues.

Stoichiology: S t o i c h i o l o g y "n. The doctrine of the elementary requisites of mere thought.

Stoichiology: S t o i c h i o l o g y "n. The statement or discussion of the first principles of any science or art.

Stoichiometric: S t o i c h i o m e t r i c "a. Alt. of Stoichiometrical

Stoichiometrical: S t o i c h i o m e t r i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to stoichiometry; employed in  or obtained by stoichiometry.

Stoichiometry: S t o i c h i o m e t r y "n. The art or process of calculating the atomic proportions  combining weights and other numerical relations of chemical elements and their compounds.

Stoicism: S t o i c i s m "n. The opinions and maxims of the Stoics.

Stoicism: S t o i c i s m "n. A real or pretended indifference to pleasure or pain; insensibility; impassiveness.

Stoicity: S t o i c i t y "n. Stoicism.

Stoke: S t o k e "v. t. To stick; to thrust; to stab.

Stoke: S t o k e "v. t. To poke or stir up  as a fire; hence to tend as the fire of a furnace boiler etc.

Stoke: S t o k e "v. i. To poke or stir up a fire; hence  to tend the fires of furnaces steamers etc.

Stokehole: S t o k e h o l e "n. The mouth to the grate of a furnace; also  the space in front of the furnace where the stokers stand.

Stoker: S t o k e r "v. t. One who is employed to tend a furnace and supply it with fuel  especially the furnace of a locomotive or of a marine steam boiler; also a machine for feeding fuel to a fire.

Stoker: S t o k e r "v. t. A fire poker.

Stokey: S t o k e y "a. Close; sultry.

Stola: S t o l a "n. A long garment  descending to the ankles worn by Roman women.

Stolae: S t o l a e "pl. "of Stola

Stole: S t o l e "imp. of Steal

Stole: S t o l e " imp. of Steal.

Stole: S t o l e "n. A stolon.

Stole: S t o l e "n. A long  loose garment reaching to the feet.

Stole: S t o l e "n. A narrow band of silk or stuff  sometimes enriched with embroidery and jewels worn on the left shoulder of deacons and across both shoulders of bishops and priests pendent on each side nearly to the ground. At Mass it is worn crossed on the breast by priests. It is used in various sacred functions.

Stoled: S t o l e d "a. Having or wearing a stole.

Stolen: S t o l e n "p. p. of Steal

Stolen: S t o l e n " p. p. of Steal.

Stolid: S t o l i d "a. Hopelessly insensible or stupid; not easily aroused or excited; dull; impassive; foolish.

Stolidity: S t o l i d i t y "n. The state or quality of being stolid; dullness of intellect; obtuseness; stupidity.

Stolidness: S t o l i d n e s s "n. Same as Stolidity.

Stolon: S t o l o n "n. A trailing branch which is disposed to take root at the end or at the joints; a stole.

Stolon: S t o l o n "n. An extension of the integument of the body  or of the body wall from which buds are developed giving rise to new zooids and thus forming a compound animal in which the zooids usually remain united by the stolons. Such stolons are often present in Anthozoa Hydroidea Bryozoa and social ascidians. See Illust. under Scyphistoma.

Stoloniferous: S t o l o n i f e r o u s "a. Producing stolons; putting forth suckers.

Stoma: S t o m a "n. One of the minute apertures between the cells in many serous membranes.

Stoma: S t o m a "n. The minute breathing pores of leaves or other organs opening into the intercellular spaces  and usually bordered by two contractile cells.

Stoma: S t o m a "n. The line of dehiscence of the sporangium of a fern. It is usually marked by two transversely elongated cells. See Illust. of Sporangium.

Stoma: S t o m a "n. A stigma. See Stigma  n. 6 (a) & (b).

Stomach: S t o m a c h "n. An enlargement  or series of enlargements in the anterior part of the alimentary canal in which food is digested; any cavity in which digestion takes place in an animal; a digestive cavity. See Digestion and Gastric juice under Gastric.

Stomach: S t o m a c h "n. The desire for food caused by hunger; appetite; as  a good stomach for roast beef.

Stomach: S t o m a c h "n. Hence appetite in general; inclination; desire.

Stomach: S t o m a c h "n. Violence of temper; anger; sullenness; resentment; willful obstinacy; stubbornness.

Stomach: S t o m a c h "n. Pride; haughtiness; arrogance.

Stomach: S t o m a c h "v. t. To resent; to remember with anger; to dislike.

Stomach: S t o m a c h "v. t. To bear without repugnance; to brook.

Stomach: S t o m a c h "v. i. To be angry.

Stomachal: S t o m a c h a l "a. Of or pertaining to the stomach; gastric.

Stomachal: S t o m a c h a l "a. Helping the stomach; stomachic; cordial.

Stomachal: S t o m a c h a l "n. A stomachic.

Stomached: S t o m a c h e d "imp. & p. p. of Stomach

Stomacher: S t o m a c h e r "n. One who stomachs.

Stomacher: S t o m a c h e r "n. An ornamental covering for the breast  worn originally both by men and women. Those worn by women were often richly decorated.

Stomachful: S t o m a c h f u l "a. Willfully obstinate; stubborn; perverse.

Stomachic: S t o m a c h i c "a. Alt. of Stomachical

Stomachic: S t o m a c h i c "n. A medicine that strengthens the stomach and excites its action.

Stomachical: S t o m a c h i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to the stomach; as  stomachic vessels.

Stomachical: S t o m a c h i c a l "a. Strengthening to the stomach; exciting the action of the stomach; stomachal; cordial.

Stomaching: S t o m a c h i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Stomach

Stomaching: S t o m a c h i n g "n. Resentment.

Stomachless: S t o m a c h l e s s "a. Being without a stomach.

Stomachless: S t o m a c h l e s s "a. Having no appetite.

Stomachous: S t o m a c h o u s "a. Stout; sullen; obstinate.

Stomachy: S t o m a c h y "a. Obstinate; sullen; haughty.

Stomapod: S t o m a p o d "n. One of the Stomapoda.

Stomapoda: S t o m a p o d a "n. pl. An order of Crustacea including the squillas. The maxillipeds are leglike in form  and the large claws are comblike. They have a large and elongated abdomen which contains a part of the stomach and heart; the abdominal appendages are large and bear the gills. Called also Gastrula Stomatopoda and Squilloidea.

Stomata: S t o m a t a "pl. "of Stoma

Stomate: S t o m a t e "n. A stoma.

Stomatic: S t o m a t i c "a. Of or pertaining to a stoma; of the nature of a stoma.

Stomatic: S t o m a t i c "n. A medicine for diseases of the mouth.

Stomatiferous: S t o m a t i f e r o u s "a. Having or producing stomata.

Stomatitis: S t o m a t i t i s "n. Inflammation of the mouth.

Stomatoda: S t o m a t o d a "n. pl. A division of Protozoa in which a mouthlike opening exists.

Stomatodaeum: S t o m a t o d a e u m "n. Same as Stomodaeum.

Stomatode: S t o m a t o d e "a. Having a mouth; -- applied to certain Protozoa.

Stomatode: S t o m a t o d e "n. One of the Stomatoda.

Stomatogastric: S t o m a t o g a s t r i c "a. Of or pertaining to the mouth and the stomach; as  the stomatogastric ganglion of certain Mollusca.

Stomatoplastic: S t o m a t o p l a s t i c "a. Of or pertaining to the operation of forming a mouth where the aperture has been contracted  or in any way deformed.

Stomatopod: S t o m a t o p o d "n. One of the Stomatopoda.

Stomatopoda: S t o m a t o p o d a "n. pl. Same as Stomapoda.

Stomatopodous: S t o m a t o p o d o u s "a. Of or pertaining to the Stomatopoda.

Stomatoscope: S t o m a t o s c o p e "n. An apparatus for examining the interior of the mouth.

Stomatous: S t o m a t o u s "a. Having a stoma.

Stomodaeum: S t o m o d a e u m "n. A part of the alimentary canal. See under Mesenteron.

Stomodaeum: S t o m o d a e u m "n. The primitive mouth and esophagus of the embryo of annelids and arthropods.

Stomp: S t o m p "v. i. To stamp with the foot.

Stond: S t o n d "n. Stop; halt; hindrance.

Stond: S t o n d "n. A stand; a post; a station.

Stond: S t o n d "v. i. To stand.

Stone: S t o n e "n. Concreted earthy or mineral matter; also  any particular mass of such matter; as a house built of stone; the boy threw a stone; pebbles are rounded stones.

Stone: S t o n e "n. A precious stone; a gem.

Stone: S t o n e "n. Something made of stone. Specifically: -

Stone: S t o n e "n. The glass of a mirror; a mirror.

Stone: S t o n e "n. A monument to the dead; a gravestone.

Stone: S t o n e "n. A calculous concretion  especially one in the kidneys or bladder; the disease arising from a calculus.

Stone: S t o n e "n. One of the testes; a testicle.

Stone: S t o n e "n. The hard endocarp of drupes; as  the stone of a cherry or peach. See Illust. of Endocarp.

Stone: S t o n e "n. A weight which legally is fourteen pounds  but in practice varies with the article weighed.

Stone: S t o n e "n. Fig.: Symbol of hardness and insensibility; torpidness; insensibility; as  a heart of stone.

Stone: S t o n e "n. A stand or table with a smooth  flat top of stone commonly marble on which to arrange the pages of a book newspaper etc. before printing; -- called also imposing stone.

Stone: S t o n e "n. To pelt  beat or kill with stones.

Stone: S t o n e "n. To make like stone; to harden.

Stone: S t o n e "n. To free from stones; also  to remove the seeds of; as to stone a field; to stone cherries; to stone raisins.

Stone: S t o n e "n. To wall or face with stones; to line or fortify with stones; as  to stone a well; to stone a cellar.

Stone: S t o n e "n. To rub  scour or sharpen with a stone.

Stone-blind: S t o n e - b l i n d "a. As blind as a stone; completely blind.

Stone-cold: S t o n e - c o l d "a. Cold as a stone.

Stone-dead: S t o n e - d e a d "a. As dead as a stone.

Stone-deaf: S t o n e - d e a f "a. As deaf as a stone; completely deaf.

Stone-hearted: S t o n e - h e a r t e d "a. Hard-hearted; cruel; pitiless; unfeeling.

Stone-horse: S t o n e - h o r s e "n. Stallion.

Stone-still: S t o n e - s t i l l "a. As still as a stone.

Stonebird: S t o n e b i r d "n. The yellowlegs; -- called also stone snipe. See Tattler  2.

Stonebow: S t o n e b o w "n. A kind of crossbow formerly used for shooting stones.

Stonebrash: S t o n e b r a s h "n. A subsoil made up of small stones or finely-broken rock; brash.

Stonebrearer: S t o n e b r e a r e r "n. A machine for crushing or hammering stone.

Stonebuck: S t o n e b u c k "n. See Steinbock.

Stonechat: S t o n e c h a t "n. A small  active and very common European singing bird (Pratincola rubicola); -- called also chickstone stonechacker stonechatter stoneclink stonesmith.

Stonechat: S t o n e c h a t "n. The wheatear.

Stonechat: S t o n e c h a t "n. The blue titmouse.

Stonecray: S t o n e c r a y "n. A distemper in hawks.

Stonecrop: S t o n e c r o p "n. A sort of tree.

Stonecrop: S t o n e c r o p "n. Any low succulent plant of the genus Sedum  esp. Sedum acre which is common on bare rocks in Europe and is spreading in parts of America. See Orpine.

Stonecutter: S t o n e c u t t e r "n. One whose occupation is to cut stone; also  a machine for dressing stone.

Stonecutting: S t o n e c u t t i n g "n. Hewing or dressing stone.

Stoned: S t o n e d "imp. & p. p. of Stone

Stonegall: S t o n e g a l l "n. See Stannel.

Stonehatch: S t o n e h a t c h "n. The ring plover  or dotterel.

Stonehenge: S t o n e h e n g e "n. An assemblage of upright stones with others placed horizontally on their tops  on Salisbury Plain England -- generally supposed to be the remains of an ancient Druidical temple.

Stoner: S t o n e r "n. One who stones; one who makes an assault with stones.

Stoner: S t o n e r "n. One who walls with stones.

Stoneroot: S t o n e r o o t "n. A North American plant (Collinsonia Canadensis) having a very hard root; horse balm. See Horse balm  under Horse.

Stonerunner: S t o n e r u n n e r "n. The ring plover  or the ringed dotterel.

Stonerunner: S t o n e r u n n e r "n. The dotterel.

Stonesmickle: S t o n e s m i c k l e "n. The stonechat; -- called also stonesmitch.

Stoneware: S t o n e w a r e "n. A species of coarse potter's ware  glazed and baked.

Stoneweed: S t o n e w e e d "n. Any plant of the genus Lithospermum  herbs having a fruit composed of four stony nutlets.

Stonework: S t o n e w o r k "n. Work or wall consisting of stone; mason's work of stone.

Stonewort: S t o n e w o r t "n. Any plant of the genus Chara; -- so called because they are often incrusted with carbonate of lime. See Chara.

Stony: S t o n y "superl. Of or pertaining to stone  consisting of or abounding in stone or stones; resembling stone; hard; as a stony tower; a stony cave; stony ground; a stony crust.

Stony: S t o n y "superl. Converting into stone; petrifying; petrific.

Stony: S t o n y "superl. Inflexible; cruel; unrelenting; pitiless; obdurate; perverse; cold; morally hard; appearing as if petrified; as  a stony heart; a stony gaze.

Stool: S t o o l "n. Material  such as oyster shells spread on the sea bottom for oyster spat to adhere to.

Stoolball: S t o o l b a l l "n. A kind of game with balls  formerly common in England esp. with young women.

Stoop: S t o o p "n. Originally  a covered porch with seats at a house door; the Dutch stoep as introduced by the Dutch into New York. Afterward an out-of-door flight of stairs of from seven to fourteen steps with platform and parapets leading to an entrance door some distance above the street; the French perron. Hence any porch platform entrance stairway or small veranda at a house door.

Stoop: S t o o p "n. A vessel of liquor; a flagon.

Stoop: S t o o p "n. A post fixed in the earth.

Stoop: S t o o p "v. i. To bend the upper part of the body downward and forward; to bend or lean forward; to incline forward in standing or walking; to assume habitually a bent position.

Stoop: S t o o p "v. i. To yield; to submit; to bend  as by compulsion; to assume a position of humility or subjection.

Stoop: S t o o p "v. i. To descend from rank or dignity; to condescend.

Stoop: S t o o p "v. i. To come down as a hawk does on its prey; to pounce; to souse; to swoop.

Stoop: S t o o p "v. i. To sink when on the wing; to alight.

Stoop: S t o o p "v. t. To bend forward and downward; to bow down; as  to stoop the body.

Stoop: S t o o p "v. t. To cause to incline downward; to slant; as  to stoop a cask of liquor.

Stoop: S t o o p "v. t. To cause to submit; to prostrate.

Stoop: S t o o p "v. t. To degrade.

Stoop: S t o o p "n. The act of stooping  or bending the body forward; inclination forward; also an habitual bend of the back and shoulders.

Stoop: S t o o p "n. Descent  as from dignity or superiority; condescension; an act or position of humiliation.

Stoop: S t o o p "n. The fall of a bird on its prey; a swoop.

Stop: S t o p "v. t. To close  as an aperture by filling or by obstructing; as to stop the ears; hence to stanch as a wound.

Stop: S t o p "v. t. To obstruct; to render impassable; as  to stop a way road or passage.

Stop: S t o p "v. t. To arrest the progress of; to hinder; to impede; to shut in; as  to stop a traveler; to stop the course of a stream or a flow of blood.

Stop: S t o p "v. t. To hinder from acting or moving; to prevent the effect or efficiency of; to cause to cease; to repress; to restrain; to suppress; to interrupt; to suspend; as  to stop the execution of a decree the progress of vice the approaches of old age or infirmity.

Stop: S t o p "v. t. To regulate the sounds of  as musical strings by pressing them against the finger board with the finger or by shortening in any way the vibrating part.

Stop: S t o p "v. t. To point  as a composition; to punctuate.

Stop: S t o p "v. t. To make fast; to stopper.

Stop: S t o p "v. i. To cease to go on; to halt  or stand still; to come to a stop.

Stop: S t o p "v. i. To cease from any motion  or course of action.

Stop: S t o p "v. i. To spend a short time; to reside temporarily; to stay; to tarry; as  to stop with a friend.

Stop: S t o p "n. The act of stopping  or the state of being stopped; hindrance of progress or of action; cessation; repression; interruption; check; obstruction.

Stop: S t o p "n. That which stops  impedes or obstructs; as obstacle; an impediment; an obstruction.

Stop: S t o p "n. A device  or piece as a pin block pawl etc. for arresting or limiting motion or for determining the position to which another part shall be brought.

Stop: S t o p "n. The closing of an aperture in the air passage  or pressure of the finger upon the string of an instrument of music so as to modify the tone; hence any contrivance by which the sounds of a musical instrument are regulated.

Stop: S t o p "n. In the organ  one of the knobs or handles at each side of the organist by which he can draw on or shut off any register or row of pipes; the register itself; as the vox humana stop.

Stop: S t o p "n. A member  plain or molded formed of a separate piece and fixed to a jamb against which a door or window shuts. This takes the place or answers the purpose of a rebate. Also a pin or block to prevent a drawer from sliding too far.

Stop: S t o p "n. A point or mark in writing or printing intended to distinguish the sentences  parts of a sentence or clauses; a mark of punctuation. See Punctuation.

Stop: S t o p "n. The diaphragm used in optical instruments to cut off the marginal portions of a beam of light passing through lenses.

Stop: S t o p "n. The depression in the face of a dog between the skull and the nasal bones. It is conspicuous in the bulldog  pug and some other breeds.

Stop: S t o p "n. Some part of the articulating organs  as the lips or the tongue and palate closed (a) so as to cut off the passage of breath or voice through the mouth and the nose (distinguished as a lip-stop or a front-stop etc. as in p t d etc.) or (b) so as to obstruct but not entirely cut off

Stop-gap: S t o p - g a p "n. That which closes or fills up an opening or gap; hence  a temporary expedient.

Stop-over: S t o p - o v e r "a. Permitting one to stop over; as  a stop-over check or ticket. See To stop over under Stop v. i.

Stopcock: S t o p c o c k "n. A bib  faucet or short pipe fitted with a turning stopper or plug for permitting or restraining the flow of a liquid or gas; a cock or valve for checking or regulating the flow of water gas etc. through or from a pipe etc.

Stopcock: S t o p c o c k "n. The turning plug  stopper or spigot of a faucet.

Stopping: S t o p p i n g "n. A pad or poultice of dung or other material applied to a horse's hoof to keep it moist.

Stopping-out: S t o p p i n g - o u t "n. A method adopted in etching  to keep the acid from those parts which are already sufficiently corroded by applying varnish or other covering matter with a brush but allowing the acid to act on the other parts.

Stopple: S t o p p l e "v. t. That which stops or closes the mouth of a vessel; a stopper; as  a glass stopple; a cork stopple.

Storage: S t o r a g e "n. The act of depositing in a store or warehouse for safe keeping; also  the safe keeping of goods in a warehouse.

Storage: S t o r a g e "n. Space for the safe keeping of goods.

Storage: S t o r a g e "n. The price changed for keeping goods in a store.

Storax: S t o r a x "n. Any one of a number of similar complex resins obtained from the bark of several trees and shrubs of the Styrax family. The most common of these is liquid storax  a brown or gray semifluid substance of an agreeable aromatic odor and balsamic taste sometimes used in perfumery and in medicine as an expectorant.

Store: S t o r e "v. t. That which is accumulated  or massed together; a source from which supplies may be drawn; hence an abundance; a great quantity or a great number.

Store: S t o r e "v. t. A place of deposit for goods  esp. for large quantities; a storehouse; a warehouse; a magazine.

Store: S t o r e "v. t. Any place where goods are sold  whether by wholesale or retail; a shop.

Store: S t o r e "v. t. Articles  especially of food accumulated for some specific object; supplies as of provisions arms ammunition and the like; as the stores of an army of a ship of a family.

Stork: S t o r k "n. Any one of several species of large wading birds of the family Ciconidae  having long legs and a long pointed bill. They are found both in the Old World and in America and belong to Ciconia and several allied genera. The European white stork (Ciconia alba) is the best known. It commonly makes its nests on the top of a building a chimney a church spire or a pillar. The black stork (C. nigra) is native of Asia Africa and Europe.

Stork-billed: S t o r k - b i l l e d "a. Having a bill like that of the stork.

Storm: S t o r m "n. A violent disturbance of the atmosphere  attended by wind rain snow hail or thunder and lightning; hence often a heavy fall of rain snow or hail whether accompanied with wind or not.

Storm: S t o r m "n. A violent agitation of human society; a civil  political or domestic commotion; sedition insurrection or war; violent outbreak; clamor; tumult.

Storm: S t o r m "n. A heavy shower or fall  any adverse outburst of tumultuous force; violence.

Storm: S t o r m "n. A violent assault on a fortified place; a furious attempt of troops to enter and take a fortified place by scaling the walls  forcing the gates or the like.

Storm: S t o r m "v. t. To assault; to attack  and attempt to take by scaling walls forcing gates breaches or the like; as to storm a fortified town.

Storm: S t o r m "v. i. To raise a tempest.

Storm: S t o r m "v. i. To blow with violence; also  to rain hail snow or the like usually in a violent manner or with high wind; -- used impersonally; as it storms.

Storm: S t o r m "v. i. To rage; to be in a violent passion; to fume.

Storm-beat: S t o r m - b e a t "a. Beaten  injured or impaired by storms.

Stormful: S t o r m f u l "a. Abounding with storms.

Stormglass: S t o r m g l a s s "n. A glass vessel  usually cylindrical filled with a solution which is sensitive to atmospheric changes indicating by a clouded appearance rain snow etc. and by clearness fair weather.

Stormily: S t o r m i l y "adv. In a stormy manner.

Stormy: S t o r m y "superl. Proceeding from violent agitation or fury; as  a stormy sound; stormy shocks.

Stormy: S t o r m y "superl. Violent; passionate; rough; as  stormy passions.

Story: S t o r y "v. t. A set of rooms on the same floor or level; a floor  or the space between two floors. Also a horizontal division of a building's exterior considered architecturally which need not correspond exactly with the stories within.

Story: S t o r y "n. A narration or recital of that which has occurred; a description of past events; a history; a statement; a record.

Story: S t o r y "n. The relation of an incident or minor event; a short narrative; a tale; especially  a fictitious narrative less elaborate than a novel; a short romance.

Story: S t o r y "n. A euphemism or child's word for a lie; a fib; as  to tell a story.

Stove: S t o v e "n. A house or room artificially warmed or heated; a forcing house  or hothouse; a drying room; -- formerly designating an artificially warmed dwelling or room a parlor or a bathroom but now restricted in this sense to heated houses or rooms used for horticultural purposes or in the processes of the arts.

Strabism: S t r a b i s m "n. Strabismus.

Strabismometer: S t r a b i s m o m e t e r "n. An instrument for measuring the amount of strabismus.

Strabismus: S t r a b i s m u s "n. An affection of one or both eyes  in which the optic axes can not be directed to the same object -- a defect due either to undue contraction or to undue relaxation of one or more of the muscles which move the eyeball; squinting; cross-eye.

Strabotomy: S t r a b o t o m y "n. The operation for the removal of squinting by the division of such muscles as distort the eyeball.

Straddle: S t r a d d l e "v. i. To part the legs wide; to stand or to walk with the legs far apart.

Straddle: S t r a d d l e "v. i. To stand with the ends staggered; -- said of the spokes of a wagon wheel where they join the hub.

Straddle: S t r a d d l e "v. t. To place one leg on one side and the other on the other side of; to stand or sit astride of; as  to straddle a fence or a horse.

Straddle: S t r a d d l e "n. The act of standing  sitting or walking with the feet far apart.

Straddle: S t r a d d l e "n. The position  or the distance between the feet of one who straddles; as a wide straddle.

Straddle: S t r a d d l e "n. A stock option giving the holder the double privilege of a put and a call  i. e. securing to the buyer of the option the right either to demand of the seller at a certain price within a certain time certain securities or to require him to take at the same price and within the same time the same securities.

Straddled: S t r a d d l e d "imp. & p. p. of Straddle

Straddling: S t r a d d l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Straddle

Straddling: S t r a d d l i n g "a. Applied to spokes when they are arranged alternately in two circles in the hub. See Straddle  v. i. and Straddle v. t. 3.

Stradometrical: S t r a d o m e t r i c a l "a. Of  or relating to the measuring of streets or roads.

Straggle: S t r a g g l e "v. t. To wander from the direct course or way; to rove; to stray; to wander from the line of march or desert the line of battle; as  when troops are on the march the men should not straggle.

Straggle: S t r a g g l e "v. t. To wander at large; to roam idly about; to ramble.

Straggle: S t r a g g l e "v. t. To escape or stretch beyond proper limits  as the branches of a plant; to spread widely apart; to shoot too far or widely in growth.

Straggle: S t r a g g l e "v. t. To be dispersed or separated; to occur at intervals.

Straggle: S t r a g g l e "n. The act of straggling.

Straggler: S t r a g g l e r "n. A roving vagabond.

Straggler: S t r a g g l e r "n. Something that shoots  or spreads out beyond the rest or too far; an exuberant growth.

Straggler: S t r a g g l e r "n. Something that stands alone or by itself.

Straight: S t r a i g h t "a. A variant of Strait  a.

Straight: S t r a i g h t "superl. Right  in a mathematical sense; passing from one point to another by the nearest course; direct; not deviating or crooked; as a straight line or course; a straight piece of timber.

Straight: S t r a i g h t "superl. Approximately straight; not much curved; as  straight ribs are such as pass from the base of a leaf to the apex with a small curve.

Straight: S t r a i g h t "superl. Composed of cards which constitute a regular sequence  as the ace king queen jack and ten-spot; as a straight hand; a straight flush.

Straight: S t r a i g h t "superl. Conforming to justice and rectitude; not deviating from truth or fairness; upright; as  straight dealing.

Straight: S t r a i g h t "superl. Unmixed; undiluted; as  to take liquor straight.

Straight: S t r a i g h t "superl. Making no exceptions or deviations in one's support of the organization and candidates of a political party; as  a straight Republican; a straight Democrat; also containing the names of all the regularly nominated candidates of a party and no others; as a straight ballot.

Straight: S t r a i g h t "adv. In a straight manner; directly; rightly; forthwith; immediately; as  the arrow went straight to the mark.

Straight: S t r a i g h t "n. A hand of five cards in consecutive order as to value; a sequence. When they are of one suit  it is calles straight flush.

Straight: S t r a i g h t "v. t. To straighten.

Straight-joint: S t r a i g h t - j o i n t "a. Having straight joints.

Straight-joint: S t r a i g h t - j o i n t "a. Applied to a floor the boards of which are so laid that the joints form a continued line transverse to the length of the boards themselves.

Straight-joint: S t r a i g h t - j o i n t "a. In the United States  applied to planking or flooring put together without the tongue and groove the pieces being laid edge to edge.

Straight-lined: S t r a i g h t - l i n e d "a. Having straight lines.

Straight-out: S t r a i g h t - o u t "a. Acting without concealment  obliquity or compromise; hence unqualified; thoroughgoing.

Straight-pight: S t r a i g h t - p i g h t "a. Straight in form or upright in position; erect.

Straight-spoken: S t r a i g h t - s p o k e n "a. Speaking with directness; plain-spoken.

Straighted: S t r a i g h t e d "imp. & p. p. of Straighten

Straightedge: S t r a i g h t e d g e "n. A board  or piece of wood or metal having one edge perfectly straight -- used to ascertain whether a line is straight or a surface even and for drawing straight lines.

Straighten: S t r a i g h t e n "v. t. To make straight; to reduce from a crooked to a straight form.

Straighten: S t r a i g h t e n "v. t. To make right or correct; to reduce to order; as  to straighten one's affairs; to straighten an account.

Straighten: S t r a i g h t e n "v. t. A variant of Straiten.

Straightener: S t r a i g h t e n e r "n. One who  or that which straightens.

Straightforth: S t r a i g h t f o r t h "adv. Straightway.

Straightforward: S t r a i g h t f o r w a r d "adv. In a straightforward manner.

Straighthorn: S t r a i g h t h o r n "n. An orthoceras.

Straighting: S t r a i g h t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Straighten

Straightly: S t r a i g h t l y "adv. In a right line; not crookedly.

Straightly: S t r a i g h t l y "adv. A variant of Straitly. See 1st Straight.

Strain: S t r a i n "n. Race; stock; generation; descent; family.

Strain: S t r a i n "n. Hereditary character  quality or disposition.

Strain: S t r a i n "n. Rank; a sort.

Strain: S t r a i n "a. To draw with force; to extend with great effort; to stretch; as  to strain a rope; to strain the shrouds of a ship; to strain the cords of a musical instrument.

Strain: S t r a i n "a. To act upon  in any way so as to cause change of form or volume as forces on a beam to bend it.

Strain: S t r a i n "a. To exert to the utmost; to ply vigorously.

Strain: S t r a i n "a. To stretch beyond its proper limit; to do violence to  in the matter of intent or meaning; as to strain the law in order to convict an accused person.

Strain: S t r a i n "a. To injure by drawing  stretching or the exertion of force; as the gale strained the timbers of the ship.

Strain: S t r a i n "a. To injure in the muscles or joints by causing to make too strong an effort; to harm by overexertion; to sprain; as  to strain a horse by overloading; to strain the wrist; to strain a muscle.

Strain: S t r a i n "a. To squeeze; to press closely.

Strain: S t r a i n "a. To make uneasy or unnatural; to produce with apparent effort; to force; to constrain.

Strain: S t r a i n "a. To urge with importunity; to press; as  to strain a petition or invitation.

Strain: S t r a i n "a. To press  or cause to pass through a strainer as through a screen a cloth or some porous substance; to purify or separate from extraneous or solid matter by filtration; to filter; as to strain milk through cloth.

Strain: S t r a i n "v. i. To make violent efforts.

Strain: S t r a i n "v. i. To percolate; to be filtered; as  water straining through a sandy soil.

Strain: S t r a i n "n. The act of straining  or the state of being strained.

Strain: S t r a i n "n. A violent effort; an excessive and hurtful exertion or tension  as of the muscles; as he lifted the weight with a strain; the strain upon a ship's rigging in a gale; also the hurt or injury resulting; a sprain.

Strain: S t r a i n "n. A change of form or dimensions of a solid or liquid mass  produced by a stress.

Strain: S t r a i n "n. A portion of music divided off by a double bar; a complete musical period or sentence; a movement  or any rounded subdivision of a movement.

Strain: S t r a i n "n. Any sustained note or movement; a song; a distinct portion of an ode or other poem; also  the pervading note or burden of a song poem oration book etc.; theme; motive; manner; style; also a course of action or conduct; as he spoke in a noble strain; there was a strain of woe in his story; a strain of trickery appears in his career.

Strain: S t r a i n "n. Turn; tendency; inborn disposition. Cf. 1st Strain.

Strainable: S t r a i n a b l e "a. Capable of being strained.

Strainable: S t r a i n a b l e "a. Violent in action.

Strainably: S t r a i n a b l y "adv. Violently.

Strained: S t r a i n e d "imp. & p. p. of Strain

Strained: S t r a i n e d "a. Subjected to great or excessive tension; wrenched; weakened; as  strained relations between old friends.

Strained: S t r a i n e d "a. Done or produced with straining or excessive effort; as  his wit was strained.

Strainer: S t r a i n e r "n. One who strains.

Strainer: S t r a i n e r "n. That through which any liquid is passed for purification or to separate it from solid matter; anything  as a screen or a cloth used to strain a liquid; a device of the character of a sieve or of a filter; specifically an openwork or perforated screen as for the end of the suction pipe of a pump to prevent large solid bodies from entering with a liquid.

Straining: S t r a i n i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Strain

Straining: S t r a i n i n g " a. & n. from Strain.

Straint: S t r a i n t "n. Overexertion; excessive tension; strain.

Strait: S t r a i t "a. A narrow pass or passage.

Strait: S t r a i t "a. A (comparatively) narrow passageway connecting two large bodies of water; -- often in the plural; as  the strait or straits of Gibraltar; the straits of Magellan; the strait or straits of Mackinaw.

Strait-handed: S t r a i t - h a n d e d "a. Parsimonious; sparing; niggardly.

Strait-jacket: S t r a i t - j a c k e t "n. A dress of strong materials for restraining maniacs or those who are violently delirious. It has long sleeves  which are closed at the ends confining the hands and may be tied behind the back.

Stranger: S t r a n g e r "n. One who comes from a foreign land; a foreigner.

Stranger: S t r a n g e r "n. One who is unknown or unacquainted; as  the gentleman is a stranger to me; hence one not admitted to communication fellowship or acquaintance.

Stranger: S t r a n g e r "n. One not belonging to the family or household; a guest; a visitor.

Stranger: S t r a n g e r "n. One not privy or party an act  contract or title; a mere intruder or intermeddler; one who interferes without right; as actual possession of land gives a good title against a stranger having no title; as to strangers a mortgage is considered merely as a pledge; a mere stranger to the levy.

Stranger: S t r a n g e r "v. t. To estrange; to alienate.

Strangulated: S t r a n g u l a t e d "a. Contracted at irregular intervals  if tied with a ligature; constricted.

Strangulation: S t r a n g u l a t i o n "n. The act of strangling  or the state of being strangled.

Strangulation: S t r a n g u l a t i o n "n. Inordinate compression or constriction of a tube or part  as of the throat; especially such as causes a suspension of breathing of the passage of contents or of the circulation as in cases of hernia.

Strangurious: S t r a n g u r i o u s "a. Of or pertaining to strangury.

Strangury: S t r a n g u r y "n. A painful discharge of urine  drop by drop produced by spasmodic muscular contraction.

Strangury: S t r a n g u r y "n. A swelling or other disease in a plant  occasioned by a ligature fastened tightly about it.

Strap: S t r a p "n. A narrow strip of anything  as of iron or brass.

Strap: S t r a p "n. A piece of rope or metal passing around a block and used for fastening it to anything.

Strappado: S t r a p p a d o "n. A military punishment formerly practiced  which consisted in drawing an offender to the top of a beam and letting him fall to the length of the rope by which means a limb was often dislocated.

Strappado: S t r a p p a d o "v. t. To punish or torture by the strappado.

Strapwork: S t r a p w o r k "n. A kind of ornament consisting of a narrow fillet or band folded  crossed and interlaced.

Stratagem: S t r a t a g e m "n. An artifice or trick in war for deceiving the enemy; hence  in general artifice; deceptive device; secret plot; evil machination.

Stratagemical: S t r a t a g e m i c a l "a. Containing stratagem; as  a stratagemical epistle.

Stratarithmetry: S t r a t a r i t h m e t r y "n. The art of drawing up an army  or any given number of men in any geometrical figure or of estimating or expressing the number of men in such a figure.

Strategical: S t r a t e g i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to strategy; effected by artifice.

Strategist: S t r a t e g i s t "n. One skilled in strategy  or the science of directing great military movements.

Strategus: S t r a t e g u s "n. The leader or commander of an army; a general.

Strategy: S t r a t e g y "n. The science of military command  or the science of projecting campaigns and directing great military movements; generalship.

Strategy: S t r a t e g y "n. The use of stratagem or artifice.

Strath: S t r a t h "n. A valley of considerable size  through which a river runs; a valley bottom; -- often used in composition with the name of the river; as Strath Spey Strathdon Strathmore.

Strathspey: S t r a t h s p e y "n. A lively Scottish dance  resembling the reel but slower; also the tune.

Straticulate: S t r a t i c u l a t e "a. Characterized by the presence of thin parallel strata  or layers as in an agate.

Stratification: S t r a t i f i c a t i o n "n. The act or process of laying in strata  or the state of being laid in the form of strata or layers.

Stratification: S t r a t i f i c a t i o n "n. The deposition of material in successive layers in the growth of a cell wall  thus giving rise to a stratified appearance.

Stratified: S t r a t i f i e d "a. Having its substance arranged in strata  or layers; as stratified rock.

Stratified: S t r a t i f i e d "imp. & p. p. of Stratify

Stratiform: S t r a t i f o r m "a. Having the form of strata.

Stratify: S t r a t i f y "v. t. To form or deposit in strata  or layers as substances in the earth; to arrange in strata.

Stratifying: S t r a t i f y i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Stratify

Stratigraphic: S t r a t i g r a p h i c "a. Alt. of Stratigraphical

Stratigraphic: S t r a t i g r a p h i c "a. Alt. of -ical

Stratigraphical: S t r a t i g r a p h i c a l "a. Pertaining to  or depended upon the order or arrangement of strata; as stratigraphical evidence.

Stratigraphy: S t r a t i g r a p h y "n. That branch of geology which treats of the arrangement and succession of strata.

Stratocracy: S t r a t o c r a c y "n. A military government; government by military chiefs and an army.

Stratographic: S t r a t o g r a p h i c "a. Alt. of Stratographical

Stratographical: S t r a t o g r a p h i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to stratography.

Stratography: S t r a t o g r a p h y "n. A description of an army  or of what belongs to an army.

Stratonic: S t r a t o n i c "a. Of or pertaining to an army.

Stratotic: S t r a t o t i c "a. Warlike; military.

Stratum: S t r a t u m "n. A bed of earth or rock of one kind  formed by natural causes and consisting usually of a series of layers which form a rock as it lies between beds of other kinds. Also used figuratively.

Stratum: S t r a t u m "n. A bed or layer artificially made; a course.

Stratums: S t r a t u m s "pl. "of Stratum

Stratus: S t r a t u s "n. A form of clouds in which they are arranged in a horizontal band or layer. See Cloud.

Straught: S t r a u g h t " imp. & p. p. of Stretch.

Straught: S t r a u g h t "v. t. To stretch; to make straight.

Straw: S t r a w "v. t. To spread or scatter. See Strew  and Strow.

Straw: S t r a w "n. A stalk or stem of certain species of grain  pulse etc. especially of wheat rye oats barley more rarely of buckwheat beans and pease.

Straw: S t r a w "n. The gathered and thrashed stalks of certain species of grain  etc.; as a bundle or a load of rye straw.

Straw: S t r a w "n. Anything proverbially worthless; the least possible thing; a mere trifle.

Straw-colored: S t r a w - c o l o r e d "a. Being of a straw color. See Straw color  under Straw n.

Straw-cutter: S t r a w - c u t t e r "n. An instrument to cut straw for fodder.

Strawberry: S t r a w b e r r y "n. A fragrant edible berry  of a delicious taste and commonly of a red color the fruit of a plant of the genus Fragaria of which there are many varieties. Also the plant bearing the fruit. The common American strawberry is Fragaria virginiana; the European F. vesca. There are also other less common species.

Strawboard: S t r a w b o a r d "n. Pasteboard made of pulp of straw.

Strawed: S t r a w e d " imp. & p. p. of Straw.

Strawworm: S t r a w w o r m "n. A caddice worm.

Strawy: S t r a w y "a. Of or pertaining to straw; made of  or resembling straw.

Stray: S t r a y "a. To wander  as from a direct course; to deviate or go out of the way.

Stray: S t r a y "a. To wander from company  or from the proper limits; to rove at large; to roam; to go astray.

Stray: S t r a y "a. Figuratively  to wander from the path of duty or rectitude; to err.

Stray: S t r a y "v. t. To cause to stray.

Stray: S t r a y "v. i. Having gone astray; strayed; wandering; as  a strayhorse or sheep.

Stray: S t r a y "n. Any domestic animal that has an inclosure  or its proper place and company and wanders at large or is lost; an estray. Used also figuratively.

Stray: S t r a y "n. The act of wandering or going astray.

Strayed: S t r a y e d "imp. & p. p. of Stray

Strayer: S t r a y e r "n. One who strays; a wanderer.

Straying: S t r a y i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Stray

Stre: S t r e "n. Straw.

Streak: S t r e a k "v. t. To stretch; to extend; hence  to lay out as a dead body.

Streak: S t r e a k "n. A line or long mark of a different color from the ground; a stripe; a vein.

Streak: S t r e a k "n. A strake.

Streak: S t r e a k "n. The fine powder or mark yielded by a mineral when scratched or rubbed against a harder surface  the color of which is sometimes a distinguishing character.

Streak: S t r e a k "n. The rung or round of a ladder.

Streak: S t r e a k "v. t. To form streaks or stripes in or on; to stripe; to variegate with lines of a different color  or of different colors.

Streak: S t r e a k "v. t. With it as an object: To run swiftly.

Streaked: S t r e a k e d "imp. & p. p. of Streak

Streaked: S t r e a k e d "a. Marked or variegated with stripes.

Streaked: S t r e a k e d "a. Uncomfortable; out of sorts.

Streaking: S t r e a k i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Streak

Streaky: S t r e a k y "a. Same as Streaked  1.

Stream: S t r e a m "n. A current of water or other fluid; a liquid flowing continuously in a line or course  either on the earth as a river brook etc. or from a vessel reservoir or fountain; specifically any course of running water; as many streams are blended in the Mississippi; gas and steam came from the earth in streams; a stream of molten lead from a furnace; a stream of lava from a volcano.

Stream: S t r e a m "n. A beam or ray of light.

Stream: S t r e a m "n. Anything issuing or moving with continued succession of parts; as  a stream of words; a stream of sand.

Stream: S t r e a m "n. A continued current or course; as  a stream of weather.

Stream: S t r e a m "n. Current; drift; tendency; series of tending or moving causes; as  the stream of opinions or manners.

Stream: S t r e a m "v. i. To issue or flow in a stream; to flow freely or in a current  as a fluid or whatever is likened to fluids; as tears streamed from her eyes.

Stream: S t r e a m "v. i. To pour out  or emit a stream or streams.

Stream: S t r e a m "v. i. To issue in a stream of light; to radiate.

Stream: S t r e a m "v. i. To extend; to stretch out with a wavy motion; to float in the wind; as  a flag streams in the wind.

Stream: S t r e a m "v. t. To send forth in a current or stream; to cause to flow; to pour; as  his eyes streamed tears.

Stream: S t r e a m "v. t. To mark with colors or embroidery in long tracts.

Stream: S t r e a m "v. t. To unfurl.

Streamed: S t r e a m e d "imp. & p. p. of Stream

Streamer: S t r e a m e r "n. An ensign  flag or pennant which floats in the wind; specifically a long narrow ribbonlike flag.

Streamer: S t r e a m e r "n. A stream or column of light shooting upward from the horizon  constituting one of the forms of the aurora borealis.

Streamer: S t r e a m e r "n. A searcher for stream tin.

Streamful: S t r e a m f u l "a. Abounding in streams  or in water.

Streaminess: S t r e a m i n e s s "n. The state of being streamy; a trailing.

Streaming: S t r e a m i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Stream

Streaming: S t r e a m i n g "a. Sending forth streams.

Streaming: S t r e a m i n g "n. The act or operation of that which streams; the act of that which sends forth  or which runs in streams.

Streaming: S t r e a m i n g "n. The reduction of stream tin; also  the search for stream tin.

Streamless: S t r e a m l e s s "a. Destitute of streams  or of a stream as a region of country or a dry channel.

Streamlet: S t r e a m l e t "n. A small stream; a rivulet; a rill.

Streamy: S t r e a m y "a. Abounding with streams  or with running water; streamful.

Streamy: S t r e a m y "a. Resembling a stream; issuing in a stream.

Stree: S t r e e "n. Straw.

Streek: S t r e e k "v. t. To stretch; also  to lay out as a dead body. See Streak.

Streel: S t r e e l "v. i. To trail along; to saunter or be drawn along  carelessly swaying in a kind of zigzag motion.

Streen: S t r e e n "n. See Strene.

Street: S t r e e t "a. Originally  a paved way or road; a public highway; now commonly a thoroughfare in a city or village bordered by dwellings or business houses.

Streetwalker: S t r e e t w a l k e r "n. A common prostitute who walks the streets to find customers.

Streetward: S t r e e t w a r d "n. An officer  or ward having the care of the streets.

Streetward: S t r e e t w a r d "a. Facing toward the street.

Streight: S t r e i g h t "a. n.  & adv. See 2nd Strait.

Streighten: S t r e i g h t e n "v. t. See Straiten.

Strein: S t r e i n "v. t. To strain.

Streit: S t r e i t "a. Drawn.

Streit: S t r e i t "a. Close; narrow; strict.

Streite: S t r e i t e "adv. Narrowly; strictly; straitly.

Strelitz: S t r e l i t z "n. sing. & pl. A soldier of the ancient Muscovite guard or Russian standing army; also  the guard itself.

Strelitzia: S t r e l i t z i a "n. A genus of plants related to the banana  found at the Cape of Good Hope. They have rigid glaucous distichous leaves and peculiar richly colored flowers.

Strene: S t r e n e "n. Race; offspring; stock; breed; strain.

Strenger: S t r e n g e r " Alt. of Strengest

Strengest: S t r e n g e s t " the original compar. & superl. of Strong.

Strength: S t r e n g t h "n. The quality or state of being strong; ability to do or to bear; capacity for exertion or endurance  whether physical intellectual or moral; force; vigor; power; as strength of body or of the arm; strength of mind of memory or of judgment.

Strength: S t r e n g t h "n. Power to resist force; solidity or toughness; the quality of bodies by which they endure the application of force without breaking or yielding; -- in this sense opposed to frangibility; as  the strength of a bone of a beam of a wall a rope and the like.

Strength: S t r e n g t h "n. Power of resisting attacks; impregnability.

Strength: S t r e n g t h "n. That quality which tends to secure results; effective power in an institution or enactment; security; validity; legal or moral force; logical conclusiveness; as  the strength of social or legal obligations; the strength of law; the strength of public opinion; strength of evidence; strength of argument.

Strength: S t r e n g t h "n. One who  or that which is regarded as embodying or affording force strength or firmness; that on which confidence or reliance is based; support; security.

Strength: S t r e n g t h "n. Force as measured; amount  numbers or power of any body as of an army a navy and the like; as what is the strength of the enemy by land or by sea?

Strength: S t r e n g t h "n. Vigor or style; force of expression; nervous diction; -- said of literary work.

Strength: S t r e n g t h "n. Intensity; -- said of light or color.

Strength: S t r e n g t h "n. Intensity or degree of the distinguishing and essential element; spirit; virtue; excellence; -- said of liquors  solutions etc.; as the strength of wine or of acids.

Strength: S t r e n g t h "n. A strong place; a stronghold.

Strength: S t r e n g t h "v. t. To strengthen.

Strengthen: S t r e n g t h e n "v. t. To make strong or stronger; to add strength to; as  to strengthen a limb a bridge an army; to strengthen an obligation; to strengthen authority.

Strengthen: S t r e n g t h e n "v. t. To animate; to encourage; to fix in resolution.

Strengthen: S t r e n g t h e n "v. i. To grow strong or stronger.

Strengthened: S t r e n g t h e n e d "imp. & p. p. of Strengthen

Strengthener: S t r e n g t h e n e r "n. One who  or that which gives or adds strength.

Strengthening: S t r e n g t h e n i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Strengthen

Strengthening: S t r e n g t h e n i n g "a. That strengthens; giving or increasing strength.

Strengthful: S t r e n g t h f u l "a. Abounding in strength; full of strength; strong.

Strengthing: S t r e n g t h i n g "n. A stronghold.

Strengthless: S t r e n g t h l e s s "a. Destitute of strength.

Strengthner: S t r e n g t h n e r "n. See Strengthener.

Strengthy: S t r e n g t h y "a. Having strength; strong.

Strenuity: S t r e n u i t y "n. Strenuousness; activity.

Strenuous: S t r e n u o u s "a. Eagerly pressing or urgent; zealous; ardent; earnest; bold; valiant; intrepid; as  a strenuous advocate for national rights; a strenuous reformer; a strenuous defender of his country.

Strepent: S t r e p e n t "a. Noisy; loud.

Streperous: S t r e p e r o u s "a. Loud; boisterous.

Strepitores: S t r e p i t o r e s "n. pl. A division of birds  including the clamatorial and picarian birds which do not have well developed singing organs.

Strepsipter: S t r e p s i p t e r "n. Alt. of Strepsipteran

Strepsiptera: S t r e p s i p t e r a "n. pl. A group of small insects having the anterior wings rudimentary  and in the form of short and slender twisted appendages while the posterior ones are large and membranous. They are parasitic in the larval state on bees wasps and the like; -- called also Rhipiptera. See Illust. under Rhipipter.

Strepsipteran: S t r e p s i p t e r a n "n. One of the Strepsiptera.

Strepsipterous: S t r e p s i p t e r o u s "a. Of or pertaining to Strepsiptera.

Strepsorhina: S t r e p s o r h i n a "n. pl. Same as Lemuroidea.

Strepsorhine: S t r e p s o r h i n e "a. Having twisted nostrils; -- said of the lemurs.

Strepsorhine: S t r e p s o r h i n e "n. One of the Strepsorhina; a lemur. See Illust. under Monkey.

Streptobacteria: S t r e p t o b a c t e r i a "n. pl. A so-called variety of bacterium  consisting in reality of several bacteria linked together in the form of a chain.

Streptococci: S t r e p t o c o c c i "pl. "of Streptococcus

Streptococcus: S t r e p t o c o c c u s "n. A long or short chain of micrococci  more or less curved.

Streptoneura: S t r e p t o n e u r a "n. pl. An extensive division of gastropod Mollusca in which the loop or visceral nerves is twisted  and the sexes separate. It is nearly to equivalent to Prosobranchiata.

Streptothrix: S t r e p t o t h r i x "n. A genus of bacilli occurring of the form of long  smooth and apparently branched threads either straight or twisted.

Stress: S t r e s s "n. Distress.

Stress: S t r e s s "n. Pressure  strain; -- used chiefly of immaterial things; except in mechanics; hence urgency; importance; weight; significance.

Stress: S t r e s s "n. The force  or combination of forces which produces a strain; force exerted in any direction or manner between contiguous bodies or parts of bodies and taking specific names according to its direction or mode of action as thrust or pressure pull or tension shear or tangential stress.

Stress: S t r e s s "n. Force of utterance expended upon words or syllables. Stress is in English the chief element in accent and is one of the most important in emphasis. See Guide to pronunciation  // 31-35.

Stress: S t r e s s "n. Distress; the act of distraining; also  the thing distrained.

Stress: S t r e s s "v. t. To press; to urge; to distress; to put to difficulties.

Stress: S t r e s s "v. t. To subject to stress  pressure or strain.

Stressful: S t r e s s f u l "a. Having much stress.

Stretch: S t r e t c h "v. t. To reach out; to extend; to put forth.

Stretch: S t r e t c h "v. t. To draw out to the full length; to cause to extend in a straight line; as  to stretch a cord or rope.

Stretch: S t r e t c h "v. t. To cause to extend in breadth; to spread; to expand; as  to stretch cloth; to stretch the wings.

Stretch: S t r e t c h "v. t. To make tense; to tighten; to distend forcibly.

Stretch: S t r e t c h "v. t. To draw or pull out to greater length; to strain; as  to stretch a tendon or muscle.

Stretch: S t r e t c h "v. t. To exaggerate; to extend too far; as  to stretch the truth; to stretch one's credit.

Stretch: S t r e t c h "v. i. To be extended; to be drawn out in length or in breadth  or both; to spread; to reach; as the iron road stretches across the continent; the lake stretches over fifty square miles.

Stretch: S t r e t c h "v. i. To extend or spread one's self  or one's limbs; as the lazy man yawns and stretches.

Stretch: S t r e t c h "v. i. To be extended  or to bear extension without breaking as elastic or ductile substances.

Stretch: S t r e t c h "v. i. To strain the truth; to exaggerate; as  a man apt to stretch in his report of facts.

Stretch: S t r e t c h "v. i. To sail by the wind under press of canvas; as  the ship stretched to the eastward.

Stretch: S t r e t c h "n. Act of stretching  or state of being stretched; reach; effort; struggle; strain; as a stretch of the limbs; a stretch of the imagination.

Stretch: S t r e t c h "n. A continuous line or surface; a continuous space of time; as  grassy stretches of land.

Stretch: S t r e t c h "n. The extent to which anything may be stretched.

Stretch: S t r e t c h "n. The reach or extent of a vessel's progress on one tack; a tack or board.

Stretch: S t r e t c h "n. Course; direction; as  the stretch of seams of coal.

Stretched: S t r e t c h e d "imp. & p. p. of Stretch

Stretcher: S t r e t c h e r "n. One who  or that which stretches.

Stretcher: S t r e t c h e r "n. A brick or stone laid with its longer dimension in the line of direction of the wall.

Stretcher: S t r e t c h e r "n. A piece of timber used in building.

Stretcher: S t r e t c h e r "n. A narrow crosspiece of the bottom of a boat against which a rower braces his feet.

Stretcher: S t r e t c h e r "n. A crosspiece placed between the sides of a boat to keep them apart when hoisted up and griped.

Stretcher: S t r e t c h e r "n. A litter  or frame for carrying disabled wounded or dead persons.

Stretcher: S t r e t c h e r "n. An overstretching of the truth; a lie.

Stretcher: S t r e t c h e r "n. One of the rods in an umbrella  attached at one end to one of the ribs and at the other to the tube sliding upon the handle.

Stretcher: S t r e t c h e r "n. An instrument for stretching boots or gloves.

Stretcher: S t r e t c h e r "n. The frame upon which canvas is stretched for a painting.

Stretto: S t r e t t o "n. The crowding of answer upon subject near the end of a fugue.

Stretto: S t r e t t o "n. In an opera or oratorio  a coda or winding up in an accelerated time.

Strew: S t r e w "v. t. To scatter; to spread by scattering; to cast or to throw loosely apart; -- used of solids  separated or separable into parts or particles; as to strew seed in beds; to strew sand on or over a floor; to strew flowers over a grave.

Strew: S t r e w "v. t. To cover more or less thickly by scattering something over or upon; to cover  or lie upon by having been scattered; as they strewed the ground with leaves; leaves strewed the ground.

Strew: S t r e w "v. t. To spread abroad; to disseminate.

Strewed: S t r e w e d "imp. & p. p. of Strew

Strewing: S t r e w i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Strew

Strewing: S t r e w i n g "n. The act of scattering or spreading.

Strewing: S t r e w i n g "n. Anything that is  or may be strewed; -- used chiefly in the plural.

Strewment: S t r e w m e n t "n. Anything scattered  as flowers for decoration.

strewn: s t r e w n "p. p. of Strew

Stria: S t r i a "n. A minute groove  or channel; a threadlike line as of color; a narrow structural band or line; a striation; as the striae or groovings produced on a rock by a glacier passing over it; the striae on the surface of a shell; a stria of nervous matter in the brain.

Stria: S t r i a "n. A fillet between the flutes of columns  pilasters or the like.

Striae: S t r i a e "pl. "of Stria

Striated: S t r i a t e d "a. Marked with striaae  or fine grooves or lines of color; showing narrow structural bands or lines; as a striated crystal; striated muscular fiber.

Striatum: S t r i a t u m "n. The corpus striatum.

Strich: S t r i c h "n. An owl.

Strick: S t r i c k "n. A bunch of hackled flax prepared for drawing into slivers.

Stricken: S t r i c k e n "p. p. & a. Struck; smitten; wounded; as  the stricken deer.

Stricken: S t r i c k e n "n. Worn out; far gone; advanced. See Strike  v. t. 21.

Stricken: S t r i c k e n "v. t. Whole; entire; -- said of the hour as marked by the striking of a clock.

Stricken: S t r i c k e n " of Strike

Strict: S t r i c t "a. Strained; drawn close; tight; as  a strict embrace; a strict ligature.

Strict: S t r i c t "a. Tense; not relaxed; as  a strict fiber.

Strict: S t r i c t "a. Exact; accurate; precise; rigorously nice; as  to keep strict watch; to pay strict attention.

Strict: S t r i c t "a. Governed or governing by exact rules; observing exact rules; severe; rigorous; as  very strict in observing the Sabbath.

Strict: S t r i c t "a. Rigidly; interpreted; exactly limited; confined; restricted; as  to understand words in a strict sense.

Strict: S t r i c t "a. Upright  or straight and narrow; -- said of the shape of the plants or their flower clusters.

Striction: S t r i c t i o n "n. The act of constricting  or the state of being constricted.

Strictly: S t r i c t l y "adv. In a strict manner; closely; precisely.

Strictness: S t r i c t n e s s "n. Quality or state of being strict.

Stricture: S t r i c t u r e "n. Strictness.

Stricture: S t r i c t u r e "n. A stroke; a glance; a touch.

Stricture: S t r i c t u r e "n. A touch of adverse criticism; censure.

Stricture: S t r i c t u r e "n. A localized morbid contraction of any passage of the body. Cf. Organic stricture  and Spasmodic stricture under Organic and Spasmodic.

Strictured: S t r i c t u r e d "a. Affected with a stricture; as  a strictured duct.

Strid: S t r i d "n. A narrow passage between precipitous rocks or banks  which looks as if it might be crossed at a stride.

Strid: S t r i d " of Stride

Strid: S t r i d " of Stride

Stride: S t r i d e "v. t. To stand with the legs wide apart; to straddle.

Strident: S t r i d e n t "a. Characterized by harshness; grating; shrill.

Stridor: S t r i d o r "n. A harsh  shrill or creaking noise.

Stridulate: S t r i d u l a t e "v. t. To make a shrill  creaking noise

Stridulate: S t r i d u l a t e "v. t. to make a shrill or musical sound  such as is made by the males of many insects.

Stridulation: S t r i d u l a t i o n "n. The act of stridulating.

Stridulation: S t r i d u l a t i o n "n. The act of making shrill sounds or musical notes by rubbing together certain hard parts  as is done by the males of many insects especially by Orthoptera such as crickets grasshoppers and locusts.

Stridulation: S t r i d u l a t i o n "n. The noise itself.

Stridulator: S t r i d u l a t o r "n. That which stridulates.

Stridulatory: S t r i d u l a t o r y "a. Stridulous; able to stridulate; used in stridulating; adapted for stridulation.

Stridulous: S t r i d u l o u s "a. Making a shrill  creaking sound.

Strife: S t r i f e "n. The act of striving; earnest endeavor.

Strife: S t r i f e "n. Exertion or contention for superiority; contest of emulation  either by intellectual or physical efforts.

Strife: S t r i f e "n. Altercation; violent contention; fight; battle.

Strife: S t r i f e "n. That which is contended against; occasion of contest.

Strifeful: S t r i f e f u l "a. Contentious; discordant.

Strigate: S t r i g a t e "a. Having transverse bands of color.

Striges: S t r i g e s "n. pl. The tribe of birds which comprises the owls.

Strigil: S t r i g i l "n. An instrument of metal  ivory etc. used for scraping the skin at the bath.

Strigillose: S t r i g i l l o s e "a. Set with stiff  slender bristles.

Strigine: S t r i g i n e "a. Of or pertaining to owls; owl-like.

Strigment: S t r i g m e n t "n. Scraping; that which is scraped off.

Strigose: S t r i g o s e "a. Set with stiff  straight bristles; hispid; as a strigose leaf.

Strigous: S t r i g o u s "a. Strigose.

Strike: S t r i k e "v. t. To touch or hit with some force  either with the hand or with an instrument; to smite; to give a blow to either with the hand or with any instrument or missile.

Strike: S t r i k e "v. t. To come in collision with; to strike against; as  a bullet struck him; the wave struck the boat amidships; the ship struck a reef.

Strike: S t r i k e "v. t. To give  as a blow; to impel as with a blow; to give a force to; to dash; to cast.

Strike: S t r i k e "v. t. To stamp or impress with a stroke; to coin; as  to strike coin from metal: to strike dollars at the mint.

Strike: S t r i k e "v. t. To thrust in; to cause to enter or penetrate; to set in the earth; as  a tree strikes its roots deep.

Strike: S t r i k e "v. t. To punish; to afflict; to smite.

Strike: S t r i k e "v. t. To cause to sound by one or more beats; to indicate or notify by audible strokes; as  the clock strikes twelve; the drums strike up a march.

Strike: S t r i k e "v. t. To lower; to let or take down; to remove; as  to strike sail; to strike a flag or an ensign as in token of surrender; to strike a yard or a topmast in a gale; to strike a tent; to strike the centering of an arch.

Strike: S t r i k e "v. t. To make a sudden impression upon  as by a blow; to affect sensibly with some strong emotion; as to strike the mind with surprise; to strike one with wonder alarm dread or horror.

Strike: S t r i k e "v. t. To affect in some particular manner by a sudden impression or impulse; as  the plan proposed strikes me favorably; to strike one dead or blind.

Strike: S t r i k e "v. t. To cause or produce by a stroke  or suddenly as by a stroke; as to strike a light.

Strike: S t r i k e "v. t. To cause to ignite; as  to strike a match.

Strike: S t r i k e "v. t. To make and ratify; as  to strike a bargain.

Strike: S t r i k e "v. t. To take forcibly or fraudulently; as  to strike money.

Strike: S t r i k e "v. t. To level  as a measure of grain salt or the like by scraping off with a straight instrument what is above the level of the top.

Strike: S t r i k e "v. t. To cut off  as a mortar joint even with the face of the wall or inward at a slight angle.

Strike: S t r i k e "v. t. To hit upon  or light upon suddenly; as my eye struck a strange word; they soon struck the trail.

Strike: S t r i k e "v. t. To borrow money of; to make a demand upon; as  he struck a friend for five dollars.

Strike: S t r i k e "v. t. To lade into a cooler  as a liquor.

Strike: S t r i k e "v. t. To stroke or pass lightly; to wave.

Strike: S t r i k e "v. t. To advance; to cause to go forward; -- used only in past participle.

Strike: S t r i k e "v. i. To move; to advance; to proceed; to take a course; as  to strike into the fields.

Strike: S t r i k e "v. i. To deliver a quick blow or thrust; to give blows.

Strike: S t r i k e "v. i. To hit; to collide; to dush; to clash; as  a hammer strikes against the bell of a clock.

Strike: S t r i k e "v. i. To sound by percussion  with blows or as with blows; to be struck; as the clock strikes.

Strike: S t r i k e "v. i. To make an attack; to aim a blow.

Strike: S t r i k e "v. i. To touch; to act by appulse.

Strike: S t r i k e "v. i. To run upon a rock or bank; to be stranded; as  the ship struck in the night.

Strike: S t r i k e "v. i. To pass with a quick or strong effect; to dart; to penetrate.

Strike: S t r i k e "v. i. To break forth; to commence suddenly; -- with into; as  to strike into reputation; to strike into a run.

Strike: S t r i k e "v. i. To lower a flag  or colors in token of respect or to signify a surrender of a ship to an enemy.

Strike: S t r i k e "v. i. To quit work in order to compel an increase  or prevent a reduction of wages.

Strike: S t r i k e "v. i. To become attached to something; -- said of the spat of oysters.

Strike: S t r i k e "v. i. To steal money.

Strike: S t r i k e "n. The act of quitting work; specifically  such an act by a body of workmen done as a means of enforcing compliance with demands made on their employer.

Strike: S t r i k e "n. The horizontal direction of the outcropping edges of tilted rocks; or  the direction of a horizontal line supposed to be drawn on the surface of a tilted stratum. It is at right angles to the dip.

Strike: S t r i k e "n. The extortion of money  or the attempt to extort money by threat of injury; blackmailing.
