Subsellium: S u b s e l l i u m "n. One of the stalls of the lower range where there are two ranges. See Illust. of Stall.

Subsemitone: S u b s e m i t o n e "n. The sensible or leading note  or sharp seventh of any key; subtonic.

Subsensible: S u b s e n s i b l e "a. Deeper than the reach of the senses.

Subseptuple: S u b s e p t u p l e "a. Having the ratio of one to seven.

Subsequence: S u b s e q u e n c e "n. Alt. of Subsequency

Subsequency: S u b s e q u e n c y "n. The act or state of following; -- opposed to precedence.

Subsequent: S u b s e q u e n t "a. Following in time; coming or being after something else at any time  indefinitely; as subsequent events; subsequent ages or years; a period long subsequent to the foundation of Rome.

Subsequent: S u b s e q u e n t "a. Following in order of place; succeeding; as  a subsequent clause in a treaty.

Subsequently: S u b s e q u e n t l y "adv. At a later time; afterwards.

Subserous: S u b s e r o u s "a. Situated under a serous membrane.

Subserve: S u b s e r v e "v. t. To serve in subordination or instrumentally; to be subservient to; to help forward; to promote.

Subserve: S u b s e r v e "v. i. To be subservient or subordinate; to serve in an inferior capacity.

Subserved: S u b s e r v e d "imp. & p. p. of Subserve

Subservience: S u b s e r v i e n c e "n. Alt. of Subserviency

Subserviency: S u b s e r v i e n c y "n. The quality or state of being subservient; instrumental fitness or use; hence  willingness to serve another's purposes; in a derogatory sense servility.

Subservient: S u b s e r v i e n t "a. Fitted or disposed to subserve; useful in an inferior capacity; serving to promote some end; subordinate; hence  servile truckling.

Subserviently: S u b s e r v i e n t l y "adv. In a subservient manner.

Subserving: S u b s e r v i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Subserve

Subsesqui-: S u b s e s q u i - " A prefix (also used adjectively) denoting the combination of constituents (especially electro-negative and electro-positive bodies) in the proportion of two to three; as  a subsesqui acetate i. e. a salt having two equivalents of acetic acid to three of the base.

Subsextuple: S u b s e x t u p l e "a. Having the ratio of one to six; as  a subsextuple proportion.

Subside: S u b s i d e "v. i. To sink or fall to the bottom; to settle  as lees.

Subside: S u b s i d e "v. i. To tend downward; to become lower; to descend; to sink.

Subside: S u b s i d e "v. i. To fall into a state of quiet; to cease to rage; to be calmed; to settle down; to become tranquil; to abate; as  the sea subsides; the tumults of war will subside; the fever has subsided.

Subsided: S u b s i d e d "imp. & p. p. of Subside

Subsidency: S u b s i d e n c y "n. The act or process of subsiding.

Subsidiaries: S u b s i d i a r i e s "pl. "of Subsidiary

Subsidiarily: S u b s i d i a r i l y "adv. In a subsidiary manner; so as to assist.

Subsidiary: S u b s i d i a r y "a. Furnishing aid; assisting; auxiliary; helping; tributary; especially  aiding in an inferior position or capacity; as a subsidiary stream.

Subsidiary: S u b s i d i a r y "a. Of or pertaining to a subsidy; constituting a subsidy; being a part of  or of the nature of a subsidy; as subsidiary payments to an ally.

Subsidiary: S u b s i d i a r y "n. One who  or that which contributes aid or additional supplies; an assistant; an auxiliary.

Subsidies: S u b s i d i e s "pl. "of Subsidy

Subsiding: S u b s i d i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Subside

Subsidize: S u b s i d i z e "v. t. To furnish with a subsidy; to purchase the assistance of by the payment of a subsidy; to aid or promote  as a private enterprise with public money; as to subsidize a steamship line.

Subsidized: S u b s i d i z e d "imp. & p. p. of Subsidize

Subsidizing: S u b s i d i z i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Subsidize

Subsidy: S u b s i d y "n. Support; aid; cooperation; esp.  extraordinary aid in money rendered to the sovereign or to a friendly power.

Subsidy: S u b s i d y "n. Specifically: A sum of money paid by one sovereign or nation to another to purchase the cooperation or the neutrality of such sovereign or nation in war.

Subsidy: S u b s i d y "n. A grant from the government  from a municipal corporation or the like to a private person or company to assist the establishment or support of an enterprise deemed advantageous to the public; a subvention; as a subsidy to the owners of a line of ocean steamships.

Subsistence: S u b s i s t e n c e "n. Real being; existence.

Subsizar: S u b s i z a r "n. An under sizar; a student of lower rank than a sizar.

Subsoil: S u b s o i l "n. The bed  or stratum of earth which lies immediately beneath the surface soil.

Subsoil: S u b s o i l "v. t. To turn up the subsoil of.

Subsolary: S u b s o l a r y "a. Being under the sun; hence  terrestrial; earthly; mundane.

Subspecies: S u b s p e c i e s "n. A group somewhat lessdistinct than speciesusually are  but based on characters more important than those which characterize ordinary varieties; often a geographical variety or race.

Subsphenoidal: S u b s p h e n o i d a l "a. Situated under  or on the ventral side of the body of the sphenoid bone.

Subspherical: S u b s p h e r i c a l "a. Nearly spherical; having a figure resembling that of a sphere.

Subspinous: S u b s p i n o u s "a. Subvertebral.

Subspinous: S u b s p i n o u s "a. Situated beneath a spinous process  as that of the scapula; as subspinous dislocation of the humerus.

Substance: S u b s t a n c e "n. That which underlies all outward manifestations; substratum; the permanent subject or cause of phenomena  whether material or spiritual; that in which properties inhere; that which is real in distinction from that which is apparent; the abiding part of any existence in distinction from any accident; that which constitutes anything what it is; real or existing essence.

Substance: S u b s t a n c e "n. The most important element in any existence; the characteristic and essential components of anything; the main part; essential import; purport.

Substance: S u b s t a n c e "n. Body; matter; material of which a thing is made; hence  substantiality; solidity; firmness; as the substance of which a garment is made; some textile fabrics have little substance.

Substance: S u b s t a n c e "n. Material possessions; estate; property; resources.

Substance: S u b s t a n c e "n. Same as Hypostasis  2.

Substance: S u b s t a n c e "v. t. To furnish or endow with substance; to supply property to; to make rich.

Substanceless: S u b s t a n c e l e s s "a. Having no substance; unsubstantial.

Substant: S u b s t a n t "a. Substantial; firm.

Substantial: S u b s t a n t i a l "a. Belonging to substance; actually existing; real; as  substantial life.

Substantial: S u b s t a n t i a l "a. Not seeming or imaginary; not illusive; real; solid; true; veritable.

Substantial: S u b s t a n t i a l "a. Corporeal; material; firm.

Substantial: S u b s t a n t i a l "a. Having good substance; strong; stout; solid; firm; as  substantial cloth; a substantial fence or wall.

Substantial: S u b s t a n t i a l "a. Possessed of goods or an estate; moderately wealthy; responsible; as  a substantial freeholder.

Substantiality: S u b s t a n t i a l i t y "n. The quality or state of being substantial; corporiety; materiality.

Substantialness: S u b s t a n t i a l n e s s "n. The quality or state of being substantial; as  the substantialness of a wall or column.

Substantials: S u b s t a n t i a l s "n. pl. Essential parts.

Substantiate: S u b s t a n t i a t e "v. t. To make to exist; to make real.

Substantival: S u b s t a n t i v a l "a. Of or pertaining to a substantive; of the nature of substantive.

Substantive: S u b s t a n t i v e "a. Betokening or expressing existence; as  the substantive verb that is the verb to be.

Substantive: S u b s t a n t i v e "a. Depending on itself; independent.

Substantive: S u b s t a n t i v e "a. Enduring; solid; firm; substantial.

Substantive: S u b s t a n t i v e "a. Pertaining to  or constituting the essential part or principles; as the law substantive.

Substantive: S u b s t a n t i v e "n. A noun or name; the part of speech which designates something that exists  or some object of thought either material or immaterial; as the words man horse city goodness excellence are substantives.

Substantive: S u b s t a n t i v e "v. t. To substantivize.

Substantively: S u b s t a n t i v e l y "adv. In a substantive manner; in substance; essentially.

Substantively: S u b s t a n t i v e l y "adv. As a substantive  name or noun; as an adjective may be used substantively.

Substile: S u b s t i l e "n. See Substyle.

Substituent: S u b s t i t u e n t "n. Any atom  group or radical substituted for another or entering a molecule in place of some other part which is removed.

Substitute: S u b s t i t u t e "n. One who  or that which is substituted or put in the place of another; one who acts for another; that which stands in lieu of something else

Substitute: S u b s t i t u t e "n. a person who enlists for military service in the place of a conscript or drafted man.

Substitute: S u b s t i t u t e "n. To put in the place of another person or thing; to exchange.

Substituted: S u b s t i t u t e d "imp. & p. p. of Substitute

Substituted: S u b s t i t u t e d "a. Exchanged; put in the place of another.

Substituted: S u b s t i t u t e d "a. Containing substitutions or replacements; having been subjected to the process of substitution  or having some of its parts replaced; as alcohol is a substituted water; methyl amine is a substituted ammonia.

Substituting: S u b s t i t u t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Substitute

Substitution: S u b s t i t u t i o n "n. The act of substituting or putting one person or thing in the place of another; as  the substitution of an agent attorney or representative to act for one in his absense; the substitution of bank notes for gold and silver as a circulating medium.

Substitution: S u b s t i t u t i o n "n. The state of being substituted for another.

Substitution: S u b s t i t u t i o n "n. The office or authority of one acting for another; delegated authority.

Substitution: S u b s t i t u t i o n "n. The designation of a person in a will to take a devise or legacy  either on failure of a former devisee or legatee by incapacity or unwillingness to accept or after him.

Substitution: S u b s t i t u t i o n "n. The doctrine that Christ suffered vicariously  being substituted for the sinner and that his sufferings were expiatory.

Substitution: S u b s t i t u t i o n "n. The act or process of substituting an atom or radical for another atom or radical; metethesis; also  the state of being so substituted. See Metathesis.

Substitutional: S u b s t i t u t i o n a l "a. Of or pertaining to substitution; standing in the place of another; substituted.

Substitutionary: S u b s t i t u t i o n a r y "a. Of or pertaining to substitution; substitutional.

Substitutive: S u b s t i t u t i v e "a. Tending to afford or furnish a substitute; making substitution; capable of being substituted.

Substrate: S u b s t r a t e "a. Having very slight furrows.

Substrate: S u b s t r a t e "v. t. To strew or lay under anything.

Substratum: S u b s t r a t u m "n. That which is laid or spread under; that which underlies something  as a layer of earth lying under another; specifically (Agric.) the subsoil.

Substratum: S u b s t r a t u m "n. The permanent subject of qualities or cause of phenomena; substance.

Substruct: S u b s t r u c t "v. t. To build beneath something; to lay as the foundation.

Substruction: S u b s t r u c t i o n "n. Underbuilding; the foundation  or any preliminary structure intended to raise the lower floor or basement of a building above the natural level of the ground.

Substructure: S u b s t r u c t u r e "n. Same as Substruction.

Substructure: S u b s t r u c t u r e "n. An under structure; a foundation; groundwork.

Substylar: S u b s t y l a r "a. Pertaining to the substyle.

Substyle: S u b s t y l e "n. A right line on which the style  or gnomon of a dial is erected; being the common section of the face of the dial and a plane perpendicular to it passing through the style.

Subsulphate: S u b s u l p h a t e "n. A sulphate with an excess of the base.

Subsulphide: S u b s u l p h i d e "n. A nonacid compound consisting of one equivalent of sulphur and more than one equivalent of some other body  as a metal.

Subsultive: S u b s u l t i v e "a. Subsultory.

Subsultory: S u b s u l t o r y "a. Bounding; leaping; moving by sudden leaps or starts.

Subsultus: S u b s u l t u s "n. A starting  twitching or convulsive motion.

Subsumable: S u b s u m a b l e "a. Capable of being subsumed.

Subsume: S u b s u m e "v. t. To take up into or under  as individual under species species under genus or particular under universal; to place (any one cognition) under another as belonging to it; to include under something else.

Subsumption: S u b s u m p t i o n "n. The act of subsuming  or of including under another.

Subsumption: S u b s u m p t i o n "n. That which is subsumed  as the minor clause or premise of a syllogism.

Subsumptive: S u b s u m p t i v e "a. Relating to  or containing a subsumption.

Subtangent: S u b t a n g e n t "n. The part of the axis contained between the ordinate and tangent drawn to the same point in a curve.

Subtartarean: S u b t a r t a r e a n "a. Being or living under Tartarus; infernal.

Subtectacle: S u b t e c t a c l e "n. A space under a roof; a tabernacle; a dwelling.

Subtegulaneous: S u b t e g u l a n e o u s "a. Under the roof or eaves; within doors.

Subtenant: S u b t e n a n t "n. One who rents a tenement  or land etc. of one who is also a tenant; an undertenant.

Subtend: S u b t e n d "v. t. To extend under  or be opposed to; as the line of a triangle which subtends the right angle; the chord subtends an arc.

Subtended: S u b t e n d e d "imp. & p. p. of Subtend

Subtepid: S u b t e p i d "a. Slightly tepid.

Subterfluous: S u b t e r f l u o u s "a. Running under or beneath.

Subterfuge: S u b t e r f u g e "n. That to which one resorts for escape or concealment; an artifice employed to escape censure or the force of an argument  or to justify opinions or conduct; a shift; an evasion.

Subterrane: S u b t e r r a n e "n. A cave or room under ground.

Subterraneal: S u b t e r r a n e a l "a. Subterranean.

Subterrany: S u b t e r r a n y "a. Subterranean.

Subterrestrial: S u b t e r r e s t r i a l "a. Subterranean.

Subthalamic: S u b t h a l a m i c "a. Situated under the optic thalamus.

Subtile: S u b t i l e "a. Thin; not dense or gross; rare; as  subtile air; subtile vapor; a subtile medium.

Subtile: S u b t i l e "a. Delicately constituted or constructed; nice; fine; delicate; tenuous; finely woven.

Subtile: S u b t i l e "a. Acute; piercing; searching.

Subtile: S u b t i l e "a. Characterized by nicety of discrimination; discerning; delicate; refined; subtle.

Subtile: S u b t i l e "a. Sly; artful; cunning; crafty; subtle; as  a subtile person; a subtile adversary; a subtile scheme.

Subtiliate: S u b t i l i a t e "v. t. To make thin or rare.

Subtilism: S u b t i l i s m "n. The quality or state of being subtile; subtility; subtlety.

Subtility: S u b t i l i t y "n. Subtilty.

Subtilization: S u b t i l i z a t i o n "n. The act of making subtile.

Subtilization: S u b t i l i z a t i o n "n. The operation of making so volatile as to rise in steam or vapor.

Subtilization: S u b t i l i z a t i o n "n. Refinement; subtlety; extreme attenuation.

Subtilize: S u b t i l i z e "v. t. To make thin or fine; to make less gross or coarse.

Subtilize: S u b t i l i z e "v. t. To refine; to spin into niceties; as  to subtilize arguments.

Subtilize: S u b t i l i z e "v. i. To refine in argument; to make very nice distinctions.

Subtilty: S u b t i l t y "n. The quality or state of being subtile; thinness; fineness; as  the subtility of air or light.

Subtilty: S u b t i l t y "n. Refinement; extreme acuteness; subtlety.

Subtilty: S u b t i l t y "n. Cunning; skill; craft.

Subtilty: S u b t i l t y "n. Slyness in design; artifice; guile; a cunning design or artifice; a trick; subtlety.

Subtle: S u b t l e "superl. Sly in design; artful; cunning; insinuating; subtile; -- applied to persons; as  a subtle foe.

Subtle: S u b t l e "superl. Cunningly devised; crafty; treacherous; as  a subtle stratagem.

Subtle: S u b t l e "superl. Characterized by refinement and niceness in drawing distinctions; nicely discriminating; -- said of persons; as  a subtle logician; refined; tenuous; sinuous; insinuating; hence penetrative or pervasive; -- said of the mind; its faculties or its operations; as a subtle intellect; a subtle imagination; a subtle process of thought; also difficult of apprehension; elusive.

Subtle: S u b t l e "superl. Smooth and deceptive.

Subtleness: S u b t l e n e s s "n. The quality or state of being subtle; subtlety.

Subtleties: S u b t l e t i e s "pl. "of Subtlety

Subtlety: S u b t l e t y "n. The quality or state of being subtle  or sly; cunning; craftiness; artfulness.

Subtlety: S u b t l e t y "n. Nice discernment with delicacy of mental action; nicety of discrimination.

Subtlety: S u b t l e t y "n. Something that is sly  crafty or delusive.

Subtly: S u b t l y "adv. In a subtle manner; slyly; artfully; cunningly.

Subtly: S u b t l y "adv. Nicely; delicately.

Subtly: S u b t l y "adv. Deceitfully; delusively.

Subtonic: S u b t o n i c "a. Applied to  or distinguishing a speech element consisting of tone or proper vocal sound not pure as in the vowels but dimmed and otherwise modified by some kind of obstruction in the oral or the nasal passage and in some cases with a mixture of breath sound; -- a term introduced by Dr. James Rush in 1833. See Guide to Pronunciation //155 199-202.

Subtonic: S u b t o n i c "n. A subtonic sound or element; a vocal consonant  as b d g n etc.; a subvocal.

Subtonic: S u b t o n i c "n. The seventh tone of the scale  or that immediately below the tonic; -- called also subsemitone.

Subtorrid: S u b t o r r i d "a. Nearly torrid.

Subtract: S u b t r a c t "v. t. To withdraw  or take away as a part from the whole; to deduct; as subtract 5 from 9 and the remainder is 4.

Subtracted: S u b t r a c t e d "imp. & p. p. of Subtract

Subtracter: S u b t r a c t e r "n. One who subtracts.

Subtracter: S u b t r a c t e r "n. The subtrahend.

Subtracting: S u b t r a c t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Subtract

Subtraction: S u b t r a c t i o n "n. The act or operation of subtracting or taking away a part.

Subtraction: S u b t r a c t i o n "n. The taking of a lesser number or quantity from a greater of the same kind or denomination; an operation for finding the difference between two numbers or quantities.

Subtraction: S u b t r a c t i o n "n. The withdrawing or withholding from a person of some right to which he is entitled by law.

Subtractive: S u b t r a c t i v e "a. Tending  or having power to subtract.

Subtractive: S u b t r a c t i v e "a. Having the negative sign  or sign minus.

Subtrahend: S u b t r a h e n d "n. The sum or number to be subtracted  or taken from another.

Subtranslucent: S u b t r a n s l u c e n t "a. Not perfectly translucent.

Subtransparent: S u b t r a n s p a r e n t "a. Not perfectly transparent.

Subtreasurer: S u b t r e a s u r e r "n. The public officer who has charge of a subtreasury.

Subtreasuries: S u b t r e a s u r i e s "pl. "of Subtreasury

Subtreasury: S u b t r e a s u r y "n. A subordinate treasury  or place of deposit; as the United States subtreasury at New York.

Subtriangular: S u b t r i a n g u l a r "a. Nearly  but not perfectly triangular.

Subtribe: S u b t r i b e "n. A division of a tribe; a group of genera of a little lower rank than a tribe.

Subtrihedral: S u b t r i h e d r a l "a. Approaching the form of a three-sided pyramid; as  the subtrihedral crown of a tooth.

Subtriple: S u b t r i p l e "a. Containing a third  or one part to three.

Subtriplicate: S u b t r i p l i c a t e "a. Expressed by the cube root; -- said especially of ratios.

Subtropical: S u b t r o p i c a l "a. Nearly tropical.

Subtrude: S u b t r u d e "v. t. To place under; to insert.

Subtruded: S u b t r u d e d "imp. & p. p. of Subtrude

Subturriculate: S u b t u r r i c u l a t e "a. Somewhat turriculate.

Subtutor: S u b t u t o r "n. An under tutor.

Subtypical: S u b t y p i c a l "a. Deviating somewhat from the type of a species  genus or other group; slightly aberrant.

Subulate: S u b u l a t e "a. Alt. of Subulated

Subulated: S u b u l a t e d "a. Very narrow  and tapering gradually to a fine point from a broadish base; awl-shaped; linear.

Subulicornes: S u b u l i c o r n e s "n. pl. A division of insects having slender or subulate antennae. The dragon flies and May flies are examples.

Subuliform: S u b u l i f o r m "a. Subulate.

Subulipalp: S u b u l i p a l p "n. One of a group of carabid beetles having slender palpi.

Subumbonal: S u b u m b o n a l "a. Beneath or forward of the umbos of a bivalve shell.

Subumbrella: S u b u m b r e l l a "n. The integument of the under surface of the bell  or disk-shaped body of a jellyfish.

Subundation: S u b u n d a t i o n "n. A flood; a deluge.

Subungual: S u b u n g u a l "a. Under the nail or hoof.

Suburb: S u b u r b "n. An outlying part of a city or town; a smaller place immediately adjacent to a city; in the plural  the region which is on the confines of any city or large town; as a house stands in the suburbs; a garden situated in the suburbs of Paris.

Suburb: S u b u r b "n. Hence  the confines; the outer part; the environment.

Suburban: S u b u r b a n "a. Of or pertaining to suburbs; inhabiting  or being in the suburbs of a city.

Suburban: S u b u r b a n "n. One who dwells in the suburbs.

Suburbed: S u b u r b e d "a. Having a suburb or suburbs on its outer part.

Suburbial: S u b u r b i a l "a. Alt. of Suburbian

Suburbian: S u b u r b i a n "a. Suburban.

Suburbicarian: S u b u r b i c a r i a n "a. Alt. of Suburbicary

Suburbicary: S u b u r b i c a r y "a. Being in the suburbs; -- applied to the six dioceses in the suburbs of Rome subject to the pope as bishop of Rome.

Suburethral: S u b u r e t h r a l "a. Situated under the urethra  or under its orifice.

Subvaginal: S u b v a g i n a l "a. Situated under or inside a sheath or vaginal membrane; as  the subvaginal or subdural spaces about the optic nerve.

Subvariety: S u b v a r i e t y "n. A subordinate variety  or a division of a variety.

Subvene: S u b v e n e "v. i. To come under  as a support or stay; to happen.

Subvened: S u b v e n e d "imp. & p. p. of Subvene

Subvening: S u b v e n i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Subvene

Subventaneous: S u b v e n t a n e o u s "a. Produced by the wind.

Subvention: S u b v e n t i o n "n. The act of coming under.

Subvention: S u b v e n t i o n "n. The act of relieving  as of a burden; support; aid; assistance; help.

Subvention: S u b v e n t i o n "n. A government aid or bounty.

Subvention: S u b v e n t i o n "v. t. To subventionize.

Subventionize: S u b v e n t i o n i z e "v. t. To come to the aid of; to subsidize; to support.

Subventitious: S u b v e n t i t i o u s "a. Helping; aiding; supporting.

Subverant: S u b v e r a n t "a. Reserved.

Subverse: S u b v e r s e "v. t. To subvert.

Subversion: S u b v e r s i o n "n. The act of overturning  or the state of being overturned; entire overthrow; an overthrow from the foundation; utter ruin; destruction; as the subversion of a government; the subversion of despotic power; the subversion of the constitution.

Subversionary: S u b v e r s i o n a r y "a. Promoting destruction.

Subversive: S u b v e r s i v e "a. Tending to subvert; having a tendency to overthrow and ruin.

Subvert: S u b v e r t "v. t. To overturn from the foundation; to overthrow; to ruin utterly.

Subvert: S u b v e r t "v. t. To pervert  as the mind and turn it from the truth; to corrupt; to confound.

Subvert: S u b v e r t "v. i. To overthrow anything from the foundation; to be subversive.

Subvertebral: S u b v e r t e b r a l "a. Situated beneath  or on the ventral side of the vertebral column; situated beneath or inside of the endoskeleton; hypaxial; hyposkeletal.

Subverted: S u b v e r t e d "imp. & p. p. of Subvert

Subverter: S u b v e r t e r "n. One who  or that which subverts; an overthrower.

Subvertible: S u b v e r t i b l e "a. That may be subverted.

Subverting: S u b v e r t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Subvert

Subvitalized: S u b v i t a l i z e d "a. Imperfectly vitalized; having naturally but little vital power or energy.

Subvocal: S u b v o c a l "a. & n. Same as Subtonic.

Subway: S u b w a y "n. An underground way or gallery; especially  a passage under a street in which water mains gas mains telegraph wires etc. are conducted.

Subworker: S u b w o r k e r "n. A subordinate worker or helper.

Subzigomatic: S u b z i g o m a t i c "a. Situated under the zygoma or zygomatic process.

Subzonal: S u b z o n a l "a. Situated under a zone  or zona; -- applied to a membrane between the zona radiata and the umbilical vesicle in the mammal embryo.

Succade: S u c c a d e "n. A sweetmeat.

Succade: S u c c a d e "n. Sweetmeats  or preserves in sugar whether fruit vegetables or confections.

Succedane: S u c c e d a n e "n. A succedaneum.

Succedanea: S u c c e d a n e a "pl. "of Succedaneum

Succedaneous: S u c c e d a n e o u s "a. Pertaining to  or acting as a succedaneum; supplying the place of something else; being or employed as a substitute for another.

Succedaneum: S u c c e d a n e u m "n. One who  or that which succeeds to the place of another; that which is used for something else; a substitute

Succedaneum: S u c c e d a n e u m "n. a remedy used as a substitute for another.

Succeed: S u c c e e d "v. t. To follow in order; to come next after; hence  to take the place of; as the king's eldest son succeeds his father on the throne; autumn succeeds summer.

Succeed: S u c c e e d "v. t. To fall heir to; to inherit.

Succeed: S u c c e e d "v. t. To come after; to be subsequent or consequent to; to follow; to pursue.

Succeed: S u c c e e d "v. t. To support; to prosper; to promote.

Succeed: S u c c e e d "v. i. To come in the place of another person  thing or event; to come next in the usual natural or prescribed course of things; to follow; hence to come next in the possession of anything; -- often with to.

Succeed: S u c c e e d "v. i. Specifically: To ascend the throne after the removal the death of the occupant.

Succeed: S u c c e e d "v. i. To descend  as an estate or an heirloom in the same family; to devolve.

Succeed: S u c c e e d "v. i. To obtain the object desired; to accomplish what is attempted or intended; to have a prosperous issue or termination; to be successful; as  he succeeded in his plans; his plans succeeded.

Succeed: S u c c e e d "v. i. To go under cover.

Succeedant: S u c c e e d a n t "a. Succeeding one another; following.

Succeeded: S u c c e e d e d "imp. & p. p. of Succeed

Succeeder: S u c c e e d e r "n. A successor.

Succeeding: S u c c e e d i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Succeed

Succeeding: S u c c e e d i n g "n. The act of one who  or that which succeeds; also that which succeeds or follows after; consequence.

Succentor: S u c c e n t o r "n. A subchanter.

Success: S u c c e s s "n. Act of succeeding; succession.

Success: S u c c e s s "n. That which comes after; hence  consequence issue or result of an endeavor or undertaking whether good or bad; the outcome of effort.

Success: S u c c e s s "n. The favorable or prosperous termination of anything attempted; the attainment of a proposed object; prosperous issue.

Success: S u c c e s s "n. That which meets with  or one who accomplishes favorable results as a play or a player.

Successary: S u c c e s s a r y "n. Succession.

Successful: S u c c e s s f u l "a. Resulting in success; assuring  or promotive of success; accomplishing what was proposed; having the desired effect; hence prosperous; fortunate; happy; as a successful use of medicine; a successful experiment; a successful enterprise.

Succession: S u c c e s s i o n "n. The act of succeeding  or following after; a following of things in order of time or place or a series of things so following; sequence; as a succession of good crops; a succession of disasters.

Succession: S u c c e s s i o n "n. A series of persons or things according to some established rule of precedence; as  a succession of kings or of bishops; a succession of events in chronology.

Succession: S u c c e s s i o n "n. An order or series of descendants; lineage; race; descent.

Succession: S u c c e s s i o n "n. The power or right of succeeding to the station or title of a father or other predecessor; the right to enter upon the office  rank position etc. held ny another; also the entrance into the office station or rank of a predecessor; specifically the succeeding or right of succeeding to a throne.

Succession: S u c c e s s i o n "n. The right to enter upon the possession of the property of an ancestor  or one near of kin or one preceding in an established order.

Succession: S u c c e s s i o n "n. The person succeeding to rank or office; a successor or heir.

Successional: S u c c e s s i o n a l "a. Of or pertaining to a succession; existing in a regular order; consecutive.

Successionist: S u c c e s s i o n i s t "n. A person who insists on the importance of a regular succession of events  offices etc.; especially (Eccl.) one who insists that apostolic succession alone is valid.

Successive: S u c c e s s i v e "a. Following in order or in uninterrupted course; coming after without interruption or interval; following one after another in a line or series; consecutive; as  the successive revolution of years; the successive kings of Egypt; successive strokes of a hammer.

Successive: S u c c e s s i v e "a. Having or giving the right of succeeding to an inheritance; inherited by succession; hereditary; as  a successive title; a successive empire.

Successively: S u c c e s s i v e l y "adv. In a successive manner.

Successiveness: S u c c e s s i v e n e s s "n. The quality or state of being successive.

Successless: S u c c e s s l e s s "a. Having no success.

Successor: S u c c e s s o r "n. One who succeeds or follows; one who takes the place which another has left  and sustains the like part or character; -- correlative to predecessor; as the successor of a deceased king.

Succi: S u c c i "pl. "of Succus

Succiduous: S u c c i d u o u s "a. Ready to fall; falling.

Succiferous: S u c c i f e r o u s "a. Producing or conveying sap.

Succinamate: S u c c i n a m a t e "n. A salt of succinamic acid.

Succinamic: S u c c i n a m i c "a. Of  pertaining to or designating an acid amide derivative of succinic acid obtained as a white crystalline substance and forming a series of salts.

Succinate: S u c c i n a t e "n. A salt of succinic acid.

Succinct: S u c c i n c t "a. Girded or tucked up; bound; drawn tightly together.

Succinct: S u c c i n c t "a. Compressed into a narrow compass; brief; concise.

Succinic: S u c c i n i c "a. Pertaining to  or derived from amber; specif. designating a dibasic acid C/H/.(CO/H)/ first obtained by the dry distillation of amber. It is found in a number of plants as in lettuce and wormwood and is also produced artificially as a white crystalline substance having a slightly acid taste.

Succinimide: S u c c i n i m i d e "n. A white crystalline nitrogenous substance  C2H4.(CO)2.NH obtained by treating succinic anhydride with ammonia gas. It is a typical imido acid and forms a series of salts. See Imido acid under Imido.

Succinite: S u c c i n i t e "n. Amber.

Succinite: S u c c i n i t e "n. A garnet of an amber color.

Succinous: S u c c i n o u s "a. Succinic.

Succinurate: S u c c i n u r a t e "n. A salt of succinuric acid.

Succinuric: S u c c i n u r i c "a. Pertaining to  or designating an acid amide analogous to succinamic acid which is obtained as a white crystalline substance by heating urea with succinic anhydride. It is known also in its salts.

Succinyl: S u c c i n y l "n. A hypothetical radical characteristic of succinic acid and certain of its derivatives.

Succise: S u c c i s e "a. Appearing as if a part were cut off at the extremity.

Succision: S u c c i s i o n "n. The act of cutting down  as of trees; the act of cutting off.

Succor: S u c c o r "v. t. To run to  or run to support; hence to help or relieve when in difficulty want or distress; to assist and deliver from suffering; to relieve; as to succor a besieged city.

Succor: S u c c o r "v. t. Aid; help; assistance; esp.  assistance that relieves and delivers from difficulty want or distress.

Succor: S u c c o r "v. t. The person or thing that brings relief.

Succorable: S u c c o r a b l e "a. Capable of being succored or assisted; admitting of relief.

Succored: S u c c o r e d "imp. & p. p. of Succor

Succorer: S u c c o r e r "n. One who affords succor; a helper.

Succoring: S u c c o r i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Succor

Succorless: S u c c o r l e s s "a. Destitute of succor.

Succory: S u c c o r y "n. A plant of the genus Cichorium. See Chicory.

Succotash: S u c c o t a s h "n. Green maize and beans boiled together. The dish is borrowed from the native Indians.

Succoteague: S u c c o t e a g u e "n. The squeteague.

Succuba: S u c c u b a "n. A female demon or fiend. See Succubus.

Succubae: S u c c u b a e "pl. "of Succuba

Succubi: S u c c u b i "pl. "of Succubus

Succubine: S u c c u b i n e "a. Of or pertaining to succuba.

Succubous: S u c c u b o u s "a. Having the leaves so placed that the upper part of each one is covered by the base of the next higher leaf  as in hepatic mosses of the genus Plagiochila.

Succubus: S u c c u b u s "n. A demon or fiend; especially  a lascivious spirit supposed to have sexual intercourse with the men by night; a succuba. Cf. Incubus.

Succubus: S u c c u b u s "n. The nightmare. See Nightmare  2.

Succula: S u c c u l a "n. A bare axis or cylinder with staves or levers in it to turn it round  but without any drum.

Succulence: S u c c u l e n c e "n. Alt. of Succulency

Succulency: S u c c u l e n c y "n. The quality or condition of being succulent; juiciness; as  the succulence of a peach.

Succulent: S u c c u l e n t "a. Full of juice; juicy.

Succulently: S u c c u l e n t l y "adv. In a succulent manner.

Succulous: S u c c u l o u s "a. Succulent; juicy.

Succumb: S u c c u m b "v. t. To yield; to submit; to give up unresistingly; as  to succumb under calamities; to succumb to disease.

Succumbed: S u c c u m b e d "imp. & p. p. of Succumb

Succumbent: S u c c u m b e n t "a. Submissive; yielding.

Succumbing: S u c c u m b i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Succumb

Succursal: S u c c u r s a l "v. t. Serving to aid or help; serving as a chapel of ease; tributary.

Succus: S u c c u s "n. The expressed juice of a plant  for medicinal use.

Succussation: S u c c u s s a t i o n "n. A trot or trotting.

Succussation: S u c c u s s a t i o n "n. A shaking; succussion.

Succussion: S u c c u s s i o n "n. The act of shaking; a shake; esp. (Med.)  a shaking of the body to ascertain if there be a liquid in the thorax.

Succussive: S u c c u s s i v e "a. Characterized by a shaking motion  especially an up and down movement and not merely tremulous oscillation; as the succussive motion in earthquakes.

Such: S u c h "a. Of that kind; of the like kind; like; resembling; similar; as  we never saw such a day; -- followed by that or as introducing the word or proposition which defines the similarity or the standard of comparison; as the books are not such that I can recommend them or not such as I can recommend; these apples are not such as those we saw yesterday; give your children such precepts as tend to make them better.

Such: S u c h "a. Having the particular quality or character specified.

Such: S u c h "a. The same that; -- with as; as  this was the state of the kingdom at such time as the enemy landed.

Such: S u c h "a. Certain; -- representing the object as already particularized in terms which are not mentioned.

Suchospondylous: S u c h o s p o n d y l o u s "a. Having dorsal vertebrae with long and divided transverse processes; -- applied to certain reptiles.

Suchwise: S u c h w i s e "adv. In a such a manner; so.

Suck: S u c k "v. t. To draw  as a liquid by the action of the mouth and tongue which tends to produce a vacuum and causes the liquid to rush in by atmospheric pressure; to draw or apply force to by exhausting the air.

Suck: S u c k "v. t. To draw liquid from by the action of the mouth; as  to suck an orange; specifically to draw milk from (the mother the breast etc.) with the mouth; as the young of an animal sucks the mother or dam; an infant sucks the breast.

Suck: S u c k "v. t. To draw in  or imbibe by any process resembles sucking; to inhale; to absorb; as to suck in air; the roots of plants suck water from the ground.

Suck: S u c k "v. t. To draw or drain.

Suck: S u c k "v. t. To draw in  as a whirlpool; to swallow up.

Suck: S u c k "v. i. To draw  or attempt to draw something by suction as with the mouth or through a tube.

Suck: S u c k "v. i. To draw milk from the breast or udder; as  a child or the young of an animal is first nourished by sucking.

Suck: S u c k "v. i. To draw in; to imbibe; to partake.

Suck: S u c k "n. The act of drawing with the mouth.

Suck: S u c k "n. That which is drawn into the mouth by sucking; specifically  mikl drawn from the breast.

Suck: S u c k "n. A small draught.

Suck: S u c k "n. Juice; succulence.

Suckanhock: S u c k a n h o c k "n. A kind of seawan. See Note under Seawan.

Suckatash: S u c k a t a s h "n. See Succotash.

Sucked: S u c k e d "imp. & p. p. of Suck

Sucken: S u c k e n "n. The jurisdiction of a mill  or that extent of ground astricted to it the tenants of which are bound to bring their grain thither to be ground.

Sucker: S u c k e r "n. One who  or that which sucks; esp. one of the organs by which certain animals as the octopus and remora adhere to other bodies.

Sucker: S u c k e r "n. A suckling; a sucking animal.

Sucker: S u c k e r "n. The embolus  or bucket of a pump; also the valve of a pump basket.

Sucker: S u c k e r "n. A pipe through which anything is drawn.

Sucker: S u c k e r "n. A small piece of leather  usually round having a string attached to the center which when saturated with water and pressed upon a stone or other body having a smooth surface adheres by reason of the atmospheric pressure with such force as to enable a considerable weight to be thus lifted by the string; -- used by children as a plaything.

Sucker: S u c k e r "n. A shoot from the roots or lower part of the stem of a plant; -- so called  perhaps from diverting nourishment from the body of the plant.

Sucker: S u c k e r "n. Any one of numerous species of North American fresh-water cyprinoid fishes of the family Catostomidae; so called because the lips are protrusile. The flesh is coarse  and they are of little value as food. The most common species of the Eastern United States are the northern sucker (Catostomus Commersoni) the white sucker (C. teres) the hog sucker (C. nigricans) and the chub or sweet sucker (Erimyzon sucetta). Some of the large Western species are called buffalo fish red horse black horse and suckerel.

Sucker: S u c k e r "n. The remora.

Sucker: S u c k e r "n. The lumpfish.

Sucker: S u c k e r "n. The hagfish  or myxine.

Sucker: S u c k e r "n. A California food fish (Menticirrus undulatus) closely allied to the kingfish (a); -- called also bagre.

Sucker: S u c k e r "n. A parasite; a sponger. See def. 6  above.

Sucker: S u c k e r "n. A hard drinker; a soaker.

Sucker: S u c k e r "n. A greenhorn; one easily gulled.

Sucker: S u c k e r "n. A nickname applied to a native of Illinois.

Sucker: S u c k e r "v. t. To strip off the suckers or shoots from; to deprive of suckers; as  to sucker maize.

Sucker: S u c k e r "v. i. To form suckers; as  corn suckers abundantly.

Suckered: S u c k e r e d "imp. & p. p. of Sucker

Suckering: S u c k e r i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Sucker

Sucket: S u c k e t "v. t. A sweetmeat; a dainty morsel.

Suckfish: S u c k f i s h "n. A sucker fish.

Sucking: S u c k i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Suck

Sucking: S u c k i n g "a. Drawing milk from the mother or dam; hence  colloquially young inexperienced as a sucking infant; a sucking calf.

Suckle: S u c k l e "n. A teat.

Suckle: S u c k l e "v. t. To give suck to; to nurse at the breast.

Suckle: S u c k l e "v. i. To nurse; to suck.

Suckled: S u c k l e d "imp. & p. p. of Suckle

Suckler: S u c k l e r "n. An animal that suckles its young; a mammal.

Suckling: S u c k l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Suckle

Suckling: S u c k l i n g "v. t. A young child or animal nursed at the breast.

Suckling: S u c k l i n g "v. t. A small kind of yellow clover (Trifolium filiforme) common in Southern Europe.

Sucrate: S u c r a t e "n. A compound of sucrose (or of some related carbohydrate) with some base  after the analogy of a salt; as sodium sucrate.

Sucre: S u c r e "n. A silver coin of Ecuador  worth 68 cents.

Sucrose: S u c r o s e "n. A common variety of sugar found in the juices of many plants  as the sugar cane sorghum sugar maple beet root etc. It is extracted as a sweet white crystalline substance which is valuable as a food product and being antiputrescent is largely used in the preservation of fruit. Called also saccharose cane sugar etc. By extension

Suction: S u c t i o n "v. t. The act or process of sucking; the act of drawing  as fluids by exhausting the air.

Suctoria: S u c t o r i a "n. pl. An order of Infusoria having the body armed with somewhat stiff  tubular processes which they use as suckers in obtaining their food. They are usually stalked.

Suctoria: S u c t o r i a "n. pl. Same as Rhizocephala.

Suctorial: S u c t o r i a l "a. Adapted for sucking; living by sucking; as  the humming birds are suctorial birds.

Suctorial: S u c t o r i a l "a. Capable of adhering by suction; as  the suctorial fishes.

Suctorian: S u c t o r i a n "n. A cartilaginous fish with a mouth adapted for suction  as the lampery.

Suctorian: S u c t o r i a n "n. One of the Suctoria.

Suctorious: S u c t o r i o u s "a. Suctorial.

Sudamina: S u d a m i n a "n. pl Minute vesicles surrounded by an area of reddened skin  produced by excessive sweating.

Sudarium: S u d a r i u m "n. The handkerchief upon which the Savior is said to have impressed his own portrait miraculously  when wiping his face with it as he passed to the crucifixion.

Sudary: S u d a r y "n. A napkin or handkerchief.

Sug: S u g "n. A kind of worm or larva.

Sugar: S u g a r "n. A sweet white (or brownish yellow) crystalline substance  of a sandy or granular consistency obtained by crystallizing the evaporated juice of certain plants as the sugar cane sorghum beet root sugar maple etc. It is used for seasoning and preserving many kinds of food and drink. Ordinary sugar is essentially sucrose. See the Note below.

Sugar: S u g a r "n. By extension  anything resembling sugar in taste or appearance; as sugar of lead (lead acetate) a poisonous white crystalline substance having a sweet taste.

Sugar: S u g a r "n. Compliment or flattery used to disguise or render acceptable something obnoxious; honeyed or soothing words.

Sugar: S u g a r "v. i. In making maple sugar  to complete the process of boiling down the sirup till it is thick enough to crystallize; to approach or reach the state of granulation; -- with the preposition off.

Sugar: S u g a r "v. t. To impregnate  season cover or sprinkle with sugar; to mix sugar with.

Sugar: S u g a r "v. t. To cover with soft words; to disguise by flattery; to compliment; to sweeten; as  to sugar reproof.

Suite: S u i t e "n. One of the old musical forms  before the time of the more compact sonata consisting of a string or series of pieces all in the same key mostly in various dance rhythms with sometimes an elaborate prelude. Some composers of the present day affect the suite form.

Sullied: S u l l i e d "imp. & p. p. of Sully

Sullies: S u l l i e s "pl. "of Sully

Sully: S u l l y "v. t. To soil; to dirty; to spot; to tarnish; to stain; to darken; -- used literally and figuratively; as  to sully a sword; to sully a person's reputation.

Sully: S u l l y "v. i. To become soiled or tarnished.

Sully: S u l l y "n. Soil; tarnish; stain.

Sullying: S u l l y i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Sully

Sulphacid: S u l p h a c i d "n. An acid in which  to a greater or less extent sulphur plays a part analogous to that of oxygen in an oxyacid; thus thiosulphuric and sulpharsenic acids are sulphacids; -- called also sulphoacid. See the Note under Acid n. 2.

Sulphamate: S u l p h a m a t e "n. A salt of sulphamic acid.

Sulphamic: S u l p h a m i c "a. Of or pertaining to a sulphamide; derived from  or related to a sulphamide; specifically designating an amido acid derivative NH2.SO2.OH of sulphuric acid (analogous to sulphonic acid) which is not known in the free state but is known in its salts.

Sulphamide: S u l p h a m i d e "n. Any one of a series of amido compounds obtained by treating sulphuryl chloride with various amines.

Sulphanilic: S u l p h a n i l i c "a. Of  pertaining to or designating an anilene sulphonic acid which is obtained as a white crystalline substance.

Sulphantimonate: S u l p h a n t i m o n a t e "n. A salt of sulphantimonic acid.

Sulphantimonic: S u l p h a n t i m o n i c "a. Of  pertaining to or designating a hypothetical sulphacid of antimony (called also thioantimonic acid) analogous to sulpharsenic acid.

Sulphantimonious: S u l p h a n t i m o n i o u s "a. Of  pertaining to or designating a hypothetical sulphacid of antimony (called also thioantimonious acid) analogous to sulpharsenious acid.

Sulphantimonite: S u l p h a n t i m o n i t e "n. A salt of sulphantimonious acid.

Sulpharsenate: S u l p h a r s e n a t e "n. A salt of sulpharsenic acid.

Sulpharsenic: S u l p h a r s e n i c "a. Of  pertaining to or designating a hypothetical sulphacid (called also thioarsenic acid) analogous to arsenic acid and known only in its salts.

Sulpharsenious: S u l p h a r s e n i o u s "a. Of  pertaining to or designating a hypothetical sulphacid (called also thioarsenious acid) analogous to arsenious acid and known only in its salts.

Sulpharsenite: S u l p h a r s e n i t e "n. A salt of sulpharsenious acid.

Sulphate: S u l p h a t e "n. A salt of sulphuric acid.

Sulphatic: S u l p h a t i c "a. Of  pertaining to resembling or containing a sulphate or sulphates.

Sulphato-: S u l p h a t o - " A combining form (also used adjectively) denoting a sulphate as an ingredient in certain double salts; as  sulphato-carbonate.

Sulphaurate: S u l p h a u r a t e "n. A salt of sulphauric acid.

Sulphauric: S u l p h a u r i c "a. Of  pertaining to or designating a hypothetical sulphacid of gold (aurum) known only in its salts.

Sulphide: S u l p h i d e "n. A binary compound of sulphur  or one so regarded; -- formerly called sulphuret.

Sulphinate: S u l p h i n a t e "n. A salt of a sulphinic acid.

Sulphindigotic: S u l p h i n d i g o t i c "a. Of  pertaining to or designating a sulphonic acid obtained as a blue solution by dissolving indigo in sulphuric acid; -- formerly called also cerulic sulphuric acid but properly called indigo-disulphonic acid.

Sulphine: S u l p h i n e "n. Any one of a series of basic compounds which consist essentially of sulphur united with hydrocarbon radicals. In general they are oily or crystalline deliquescent substances having a peculiar odor; as  trimethyl sulphine (CH3)3S.OH. Cf. Sulphonium.

Sulphinic: S u l p h i n i c "a. Of  pertaining to or designating any one of a series of acids regarded as acid ethereal salts of hyposulphurous acid; as methyl sulphinic acid CH3.SO.OH a thick unstable liquid.

Sulphinide: S u l p h i n i d e "n. A white or yellowish crystalline substance  C6H4.(SO2.CO).NH produced artificially by the oxidation of a sulphamic derivative of toluene. It is the sweetest substance known having over two hundred times the sweetening power of sugar and is known in commerce under the name of saccharine. It has acid properties and forms salts (which are inaccurately called saccharinates).

Sulphion: S u l p h i o n "n. A hypothetical radical  SO4 regarded as forming the acid or negative constituent of sulphuric acid and the sulphates in electrolytic decomposition; -- so called in accordance with the binary theory of salts.

Sulphionide: S u l p h i o n i d e "n. A binary compound of sulphion  or one so regarded; thus sulphuric acid H/SO/ is a sulphionide.

Sulphite: S u l p h i t e "n. A salt of sulphurous acid.

Sulpho-: S u l p h o - " A prefix (also used adjectively) designating sulphur as an ingredient in certain compounds. Cf. Thio-.

Sulphoarsenic: S u l p h o a r s e n i c "a. Of  pertaining to or containing sulphur and arsenic; -- said of an acid which is the same as arsenic acid with the substitution of sulphur for oxygen.

Sulphocarbonate: S u l p h o c a r b o n a t e "n. A salt of sulphocarbonic acid; a thiocarbonate.

Sulphocarbonic: S u l p h o c a r b o n i c "a. Of  pertaining to or designating a sulphacid H2CSO2 (called also thiocarbonic acid) or an acid H2CS3 analogous to carbonic acid obtained as a yellow oily liquid of a pungent odor and forming salts.

Sulphocyanate: S u l p h o c y a n a t e "n. A salt of sulphocyanic acid; -- also called thiocyanate  and formerly inaccurately sulphocyanide.

Sulphocyanic: S u l p h o c y a n i c "a. Of  pertaining to derived from or designating a sulphacid HSCN analogous to cyanic acid and obtained as a colorless deliquescent crystalline substance having a bitter saline taste and not poisonous.

Sulphocyanide: S u l p h o c y a n i d e "n. See Sulphocyanate.

Sulphocyanogen: S u l p h o c y a n o g e n "n. See Persulphocyanogen.

Sulphonal: S u l p h o n a l "n. A substance employed as a hypnotic  produced by the union of mercaptan and acetone.

Sulphonate: S u l p h o n a t e "n. A salt of sulphonic acid.

Sulphone: S u l p h o n e "n. Any one of a series of compounds analogous to the ketones  and consisting of the sulphuryl group united with two hydrocarbon radicals; as dimethyl sulphone (CH/)/.SO/.

Sulphonic: S u l p h o n i c "a. Pertaining to  or derived from a sulphone; -- used specifically to designate any one of a series of acids (regarded as acid ethereal salts of sulphurous acid) obtained by the oxidation of the mercaptans or by treating sulphuric acid with certain aromatic bases (as benzene); as phenyl sulphonic acid C6H5.SO2.OH a stable colorless crystalline substance.

Sulphonium: S u l p h o n i u m "n. A hypothetical radical  SH3 regarded as the type and nucleus of the sulphines.

Sulphophosphate: S u l p h o p h o s p h a t e "n. A salt of sulphophosphoric acid.

Sulphophosphite: S u l p h o p h o s p h i t e "n. A salt of sulphophosphorous acid.

Sulphophosphoric: S u l p h o p h o s p h o r i c "a. Of  pertaining to or designating a hypothetical sulphacid of phosphorus analogous to phosphoric acid and known in its salts.

Sulphophosphorous: S u l p h o p h o s p h o r o u s "a. Of  pertaining to or designating a hypothetical acid of phosphorus analogous to phosphorous acid and known in its salts.

Sulphosalt: S u l p h o s a l t "n. A salt of a sulphacid.

Sulphostannate: S u l p h o s t a n n a t e "n. A salt of sulphostannic acid.

Sulphostannic: S u l p h o s t a n n i c "a. Of  pertaining to or designating a sulphacid of tin (more exactly called metasulphostannic acid) which is obtained as a dark brown amorphous substance H/SnS/ forming a well-known series of salts.

Sulphotungstate: S u l p h o t u n g s t a t e "n. A salt of sulphotungstic acid.

Sulphotungstic: S u l p h o t u n g s t i c "a. Of  pertaining to or designating hypothetical sulphacid of tungsten (called also sulphowolframic acid) analogous to sulphuric acid and known in its salts.

Sulphovinic: S u l p h o v i n i c "a. Of  pertaining to and formerly designating ethylsulphuric acid.

Sulphur: S u l p h u r "n. A nonmetallic element occurring naturally in large quantities  either combined as in the sulphides (as pyrites) and sulphates (as gypsum) or native in volcanic regions in vast beds mixed with gypsum and various earthy materials from which it is melted out. Symbol S. Atomic weight 32. The specific gravity of ordinary octohedral sulphur is 2.05; of prismatic sulphur 1.96.

Sulphur: S u l p h u r "n. Any one of numerous species of yellow or orange butterflies of the subfamily Pierinae; as  the clouded sulphur (Eurymus / Colias philodice) which is the common yellow butterfly of the Eastern United States.

Sulphur-bottom: S u l p h u r - b o t t o m "n. A very large whalebone whale of the genus Sibbaldius  having a yellowish belly; especially S. sulfureus of the North Pacific and S. borealis of the North Atlantic; -- called also sulphur whale.

Sulphurate: S u l p h u r a t e "a. Sulphureous.

Sulphurate: S u l p h u r a t e "v. t. To sulphurize.

Sulphurated: S u l p h u r a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Sulphurate

Sulphurating: S u l p h u r a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Sulphurate

Sulphuration: S u l p h u r a t i o n "n. The act or process of combining or impregnating with sulphur or its compounds; also  the state of being so combined or impregnated.

Sulphurator: S u l p h u r a t o r "n. An apparatus for impregnating with  or exposing to the action of sulphur; especially an apparatus for fumigating or bleaching by means of the fumes of burning sulphur.

Sulphureity: S u l p h u r e i t y "n. The quality or state of being sulphureous.

Sulphureous: S u l p h u r e o u s "a. Consisting of sulphur; having the qualities of sulphur  or brimstone; impregnated with sulphur.

Sulphuret: S u l p h u r e t "n. A sulphide; as  a sulphuret of potassium.

Sulphureted: S u l p h u r e t e d "a. Combined or impregnated with sulphur; sulphurized.

Sulphuric: S u l p h u r i c "a. Of or pertaining to sulphur; as  a sulphuric smell.

Sulphuric: S u l p h u r i c "a. Derived from  or containing sulphur; specifically designating those compounds in which the element has a higher valence as contrasted with the sulphurous compounds; as sulphuric acid.

Sulphurine: S u l p h u r i n e "a. Sulphureous.

Sulphuring: S u l p h u r i n g "n. Exposure to the fumes of burning sulphur  as in bleaching; the process of bleaching by exposure to the fumes of sulphur.

Sulphurize: S u l p h u r i z e "v. t. To combine or impregnate with sulphur or any of its compounds; as  to sulphurize caoutchouc in vulcanizing.

Sulphurous: S u l p h u r o u s "a. Of or pertaining to sulphur.

Sulphurous: S u l p h u r o u s "a. Derived from  or containing sulphur; specifically designating those compounds in which the element has a lower valence as contrasted with the sulphuric compounds.

Sulphurous: S u l p h u r o u s "a. Having the characteristic odor of sulphur dioxide  or of hydrogen sulphide or of other sulphur compounds.

Sulphurwort: S u l p h u r w o r t "n. The hog's fennel. See under Fennel.

Sulphury: S u l p h u r y "a. Resembling  or partaking of the nature of sulphur; having the qualities of sulphur.

Sulphuryl: S u l p h u r y l "n. The hypothetical radical SO2; -- called also sulphon.

Sulphydrate: S u l p h y d r a t e "n. A compound  analogous to a hydrate regarded as a salt of sulphydric acid or as a derivative of hydrogen sulphide in which one half of the hydrogen is replaced by a base (as potassium sulphydrate KSH) or as a hydrate in which the oxygen has been wholly or partially replaced by sulphur.

Sulphydric: S u l p h y d r i c "a. Of  pertaining to or designating hydrogen sulphide which is regarded as an acid especially when in solution.

Sulpician: S u l p i c i a n "n. One of an order of priests established in France in 1642 to educate men for the ministry. The order was introduced soon afterwards into Canada  and in 1791 into the United States.

Sultan: S u l t a n "n. A ruler  or sovereign of a Mohammedan state; specifically the ruler of the Turks; the Padishah or Grand Seignior; -- officially so called.

Sultan-red: S u l t a n - r e d "a. Having a deep red color.

Sultana: S u l t a n a "n. The wife of a sultan; a sultaness.

Sultana: S u l t a n a "n. A kind of seedless raisin produced near Smyrna in Asiatic Turkey.

Sultanate: S u l t a n a t e "n. The rule or dominion of a sultan; sultanship.

Sultaness: S u l t a n e s s "n. A sultana.

Sultanic: S u l t a n i c "a. Pertaining to a sultan.

Sultanry: S u l t a n r y "n. The dominions of a sultan.

Sultanship: S u l t a n s h i p "n. The office or dignity of a sultan.

Sultany: S u l t a n y "n. Sultanry.

Sultriness: S u l t r i n e s s "n. The quality or state of being sultry.

Sultry: S u l t r y "superl. Very hot  burning and oppressive; as Libya's sultry deserts.

Sultry: S u l t r y "superl. Very hot and moist  or hot close stagnant and oppressive as air.

Sultryly: S u l t r y l y "adv. In a sultry manner.

Sum: S u m "n. The aggregate of two or more numbers  magnitudes quantities or particulars; the amount or whole of any number of individuals or particulars added together; as the sum of 5 and 7 is 12.

Sum: S u m "n. A quantity of money or currency; any amount  indefinitely; as a sum of money; a small sum or a large sum.

Sum: S u m "n. The principal points or thoughts when viewed together; the amount; the substance; compendium; as  this is the sum of all the evidence in the case; this is the sum and substance of his objections.

Sum: S u m "n. Height; completion; utmost degree.

Sum: S u m "n. A problem to be solved  or an example to be wrought out.

Sum: S u m "v. t. To bring together into one whole; to collect into one amount; to cast up  as a column of figures; to ascertain the totality of; -- usually with up.

Sum: S u m "v. t. To bring or collect into a small compass; to comprise in a few words; to condense; -- usually with up.

Sum: S u m "v. t. To have (the feathers) full grown; to furnish with complete  or full-grown plumage.

Sumac: S u m a c "n. Alt. of Sumach

Sumach: S u m a c h "n. Any plant of the genus Rhus  shrubs or small trees with usually compound leaves and clusters of small flowers. Some of the species are used in tanning some in dyeing and some in medicine. One the Japanese Rhus vernicifera yields the celebrated Japan varnish or lacquer.

Sumach: S u m a c h "n. The powdered leaves  peduncles and young branches of certain species of the sumac plant used in tanning and dyeing.

Sumatran: S u m a t r a n "a. Of or pertaining to Sumatra or its inhabitants.

Sumatran: S u m a t r a n "n. A native of Sumatra.

Sumbul: S u m b u l "n. The musky root of an Asiatic umbelliferous plant  Ferula Sumbul. It is used in medicine as a stimulant.

Sumless: S u m l e s s "a. Not to be summed up or computed; so great that the amount can not be ascertained; incalculable; inestimable.

Summaries: S u m m a r i e s "pl. "of Summary

Summarily: S u m m a r i l y "adv. In a summary manner.

Summarist: S u m m a r i s t "n. One who summarized.

Summarize: S u m m a r i z e "v. t. To comprise in  or reduce to a summary; to present briefly.

Summary: S u m m a r y "a. Formed into a sum; summed up; reduced into a narrow compass  or into few words; short; brief; concise; compendious; as a summary statement of facts.

Summary: S u m m a r y "a. Hence  rapidly performed; quickly executed; as a summary process; to take summary vengeance.

Summary: S u m m a r y "a. A general or comprehensive statement; an abridged account; an abstract  abridgment or compendium containing the sum or substance of a fuller account.

Summation: S u m m a t i o n "v. t. The act of summing  or forming a sum or total amount; also an aggregate.

Summed: S u m m e d "imp. & p. p. of Sum

Summer: S u m m e r "v. One who sums; one who casts up an account.

Summer: S u m m e r "n. A large stone or beam placed horizontally on columns  piers posts or the like serving for various uses. Specifically: (a) The lintel of a door or window. (b) The commencement of a cross vault. (c) A central floor timber as a girder or a piece reaching from a wall to a girder. Called also summertree.

Summer: S u m m e r "n. The season of the year in which the sun shines most directly upon any region; the warmest period of the year.

Summer: S u m m e r "v. i. To pass the summer; to spend the warm season; as  to summer in Switzerland.

Summer: S u m m e r "v. t. To keep or carry through the summer; to feed during the summer; as  to summer stock.

Summer-fallow: S u m m e r - f a l l o w "v. t. To plow and work in summer  in order to prepare for wheat or other crop; to plow and let lie fallow.

Summered: S u m m e r e d "imp. & p. p. of Summer

Summerhouse: S u m m e r h o u s e "n. A rustic house or apartment in a garden or park  to be used as a pleasure resort in summer.

Summerhouses: S u m m e r h o u s e s "pl. "of Summerhouse

Summering: S u m m e r i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Summer

Summerliness: S u m m e r l i n e s s "n. The quality or state of being like summer.

Summersault: S u m m e r s a u l t "n. Alt. of Summerset

Summerset: S u m m e r s e t "n. See Somersault  Somerset.

Summerstir: S u m m e r s t i r "v. t. To summer-fallow.

Summertide: S u m m e r t i d e "n. Summer time.

Summertree: S u m m e r t r e e "n. A summer. See 2d Summer.

Summery: S u m m e r y "a. Of or pertaining to summer; like summer; as  a summery day.

Summing: S u m m i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Sum

Summist: S u m m i s t "n. One who sums up; one who forms an abridgment or summary.

Summit: S u m m i t "n. The top; the highest point.

Summit: S u m m i t "n. The highest degree; the utmost elevation; the acme; as  the summit of human fame.

Summit: S u m m i t "n. The most elevated part of a bivalve shell  or the part in which the hinge is situated.

Summitless: S u m m i t l e s s "a. Having no summit.

Summity: S u m m i t y "n. The height or top of anything.

Summity: S u m m i t y "n. The utmost degree; perfection.

Summon: S u m m o n "v. t. To call  bid or cite; to notify to come to appear; -- often with up.

Summon: S u m m o n "v. t. To give notice to  or command to appear as in court; to cite by authority; as to summon witnesses.

Summon: S u m m o n "v. t. To call upon to surrender  as a fort.

Summoned: S u m m o n e d "imp. & p. p. of Summon

Summoner: S u m m o n e r "v. t. One who summons; one who cites by authority; specifically  a petty officer formerly employed to summon persons to appear in court; an apparitor.

Summoning: S u m m o n i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Summon

Summons: S u m m o n s "v. The act of summoning; a call by authority  or by the command of a superior to appear at a place named or to attend to some duty.

Summons: S u m m o n s "v. A warning or citation to appear in court; a written notification signed by the proper officer  to be served on a person warning him to appear in court at a day specified to answer to the plaintiff testify as a witness or the like.

Summons: S u m m o n s "v. A demand to surrender.

Summons: S u m m o n s "v. t. To summon.

Summonses: S u m m o n s e s "pl. "of Summons

Sumner: S u m n e r "n. A summoner.

Sumoom: S u m o o m "n. See Simoom.

Sump: S u m p "n. A round pit of stone  lined with clay for receiving the metal on its first fusion.

Sump: S u m p "n. The cistern or reservoir made at the lowest point of a mine  from which is pumped the water which accumulates there.

Sump: S u m p "n. A pond of water for salt works.

Sump: S u m p "n. A puddle or dirty pool.

Sumph: S u m p h "n. A dunce; a blockhead.

Sumpitan: S u m p i t a n "n. A kind of blowgun for discharging arrows  -- used by the savages of Borneo and adjacent islands.

Sumpter: S u m p t e r "n. The driver of a pack horse.

Sumpter: S u m p t e r "n. A pack; a burden.

Sumpter: S u m p t e r "n. An animal  especially a horse that carries packs or burdens; a baggage horse.

Sumpter: S u m p t e r "a. Carrying pack or burdens on the back; as  a sumpter horse; a sumpter mule.

Sumption: S u m p t i o n "n. A taking.

Sumption: S u m p t i o n "n. The major premise of a syllogism.

Sumptuary: S u m p t u a r y "a. Relating to expense; regulating expense or expenditure.

Sumptuosity: S u m p t u o s i t y "n. Expensiveness; costliness; sumptuousness.

Sumptuous: S u m p t u o u s "a. Involving large outlay or expense; costly; expensive; hence  luxurious; splendid; magnificient; as a sumptuous house or table; sumptuous apparel.

Sun: S u n "n. See Sunn.

Sun: S u n "n. The luminous orb  the light of which constitutes day and its absence night; the central body round which the earth and planets revolve by which they are held in their orbits and from which they receive light and heat. Its mean distance from the earth is about 92 500 000 miles and its diameter about 860 000.

Sun: S u n "n. Any heavenly body which forms the center of a system of orbs.

Sun: S u n "n. The direct light or warmth of the sun; sunshine.

Sun: S u n "n. That which resembles the sun  as in splendor or importance; any source of light warmth or animation.

Sun: S u n "v. t. To expose to the sun's rays; to warm or dry in the sun; as  to sun cloth; to sun grain.

Sun star: S u n   s t a r " See Sun star  under Sun.

Sun-burner: S u n - b u r n e r "n. A circle or cluster of gas-burners for lighting and ventilating public buildings.

Sun-dried: S u n - d r i e d "a. Dried by the heat of the sun.

Sun-struck: S u n - s t r u c k "a. Overcome by  or affected with sunstroke; as sun-struck soldiers.

Sunbeam: S u n b e a m "n. A beam or ray of the sun.

Sunbird: S u n b i r d "n. Any one of numerous species of small brilliantly colored birds of the family Nectariniidae  native of Africa Southern Asia the East Indies and Australia. In external appearance and habits they somewhat resemble humming birds but they are true singing birds (Oscines).

Sunbird: S u n b i r d "n. The sun bittern.

Sunblink: S u n b l i n k "n. A glimpse or flash of the sun.

Sunbonnet: S u n b o n n e t "n. A bonnet  generally made of some thin or light fabric projecting beyond the face and commonly having a cape -- worn by women as a protection against the sun.

Sunbow: S u n b o w "n. A rainbow; an iris.

Sunburn: S u n b u r n "v. t. To burn or discolor by the sun; to tan.

Sunburn: S u n b u r n "n. The burning or discoloration produced on the skin by the heat of the sun; tan.

Sunburned: S u n b u r n e d "imp. & p. p. of Sunburn

Sunburning: S u n b u r n i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Sunburn

Sunburning: S u n b u r n i n g "n. Sunburn; tan.

Sunburnt: S u n b u r n t " of Sunburn

Sunburst: S u n b u r s t "n. A burst of sunlight.

Sundart: S u n d a r t "n. Sunbeam.

Sunday: S u n d a y "n. The first day of the week  -- consecrated among Christians to rest from secular employments and to religious worship; the Christian Sabbath; the Lord's Day.

Sunday: S u n d a y "a. Belonging to the Christian Sabbath.

Sunder: S u n d e r "v. t. To disunite in almost any manner  either by rending cutting or breaking; to part; to put or keep apart; to separate; to divide; to sever; as to sunder a rope; to sunder a limb; to sunder friends.

Sunder: S u n d e r "v. i. To part; to separate.

Sunder: S u n d e r "v. t. A separation into parts; a division or severance.

Sunder: S u n d e r "v. t. To expose to the sun and wind.

Sundered: S u n d e r e d "imp. & p. p. of Sunder

Sundering: S u n d e r i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Sunder

Sundew: S u n d e w "n. Any plant of the genus Drosera  low bog plants whose leaves are beset with pediceled glands which secrete a viscid fluid that glitters like dewdrops and attracts and detains insects. After an insect is caught the glands curve inward like tentacles and the leaf digests it. Called also lustwort.

Sundial: S u n d i a l "n. An instrument to show the time of day by means of the shadow of a gnomon  or style on a plate.

Sundog: S u n d o g "n. A luminous spot occasionally seen a few degrees from the sun  supposed to be formed by the intersection of two or more halos or in a manner similar to that of halos.

Sundown: S u n d o w n "n. The setting of the sun; sunset.

Sundown: S u n d o w n "n. A kind of broad-brimmed sun hat worn by women.

Sundries: S u n d r i e s "n. pl. Many different or small things; sundry things.

Sundrily: S u n d r i l y "adv. In sundry ways; variously.

Sundry: S u n d r y "v. t. Several; divers; more than one or two; various.

Sundry: S u n d r y "v. t. Separate; diverse.

Sundryman: S u n d r y m a n "n. One who deals in sundries  or a variety of articles.

Sundrymen: S u n d r y m e n "pl. "of Sundryman

Sunfish: S u n f i s h "n. A very large oceanic plectognath fish (Mola mola  Mola rotunda or Orthagoriscus mola) having a broad body and a truncated tail.

Sunfish: S u n f i s h "n. Any one of numerous species of perch-like North American fresh-water fishes of the family Centrachidae. They have a broad  compressed body and strong dorsal spines. Among the common species of the Eastern United States are Lepomis gibbosus (called also bream pondfish pumpkin seed and sunny) the blue sunfish or dollardee (L. pallidus) and the long-eared sunfish (L. auritus). Several of the species are called also pondfish.

Sunfish: S u n f i s h "n. The moonfish  or bluntnosed shiner.

Sunfish: S u n f i s h "n. The opah.

Sunfish: S u n f i s h "n. The basking  or liver shark.

Sunfish: S u n f i s h "n. Any large jellyfish.

Sunflower: S u n f l o w e r "n. Any plant of the genus Helianthus; -- so called probably from the form and color of its flower  which is large disk with yellow rays. The commonly cultivated sunflower is Helianthus annuus a native of America.

Sung: S u n g "imp. of Sing

Sung: S u n g "p. p. of Sing

Sung: S u n g " imp. & p. p. of Sing.

Sunglass: S u n g l a s s "n. A convex lens of glass for producing heat by converging the sun's rays into a focus.

Sunglasses: S u n g l a s s e s "pl. "of Sunglass

Sunglow: S u n g l o w "n. A rosy flush in the sky seen after sunset.

Sunk: S u n k "imp. of Sink

Sunk: S u n k "p. p. of Sink

Sunk: S u n k " imp. & p. p. of Sink.

Sunken: S u n k e n " of Sink

Sunken: S u n k e n "a. Lying on the bottom of a river or other water; sunk.

Sunless: S u n l e s s "a. Destitute or deprived of the sun or its rays; shaded; shadowed.

Sunlight: S u n l i g h t "n. The light of the sun.

Sunlike: S u n l i k e "a. Like or resembling the sun.

Sunlit: S u n l i t "a. Lighted by the sun.

Sunn: S u n n "n. An East Indian leguminous plant (Crotalaria juncea) and its fiber  which is also called sunn hemp.

Sunna: S u n n a "n. A collection of traditions received by the orthodox Mohammedans as of equal authority with the Koran.

Sunned: S u n n e d "imp. & p. p. of Sun

Sunniah: S u n n i a h "n. One of the sect of Sunnites.

Sunniness: S u n n i n e s s "n. The quality or state of being sunny.

Sunning: S u n n i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Sun

Sunnite: S u n n i t e "n. One of the orthodox Mohammedans who receive the Sunna as of equal importance with the Koran.

Sunnud: S u n n u d "n. A charter or warrant; also  a deed of gift.

Sunny: S u n n y "superl. Of or pertaining to the sun; proceeding from  or resembling the sun; hence shining; bright; brilliant; radiant.

Sunny: S u n n y "superl. Exposed to the rays of the sun; brightened or warmed by the direct rays of the sun; as  a sunny room; the sunny side of a hill.

Sunny: S u n n y "superl. Cheerful; genial; as  a sunny disposition.

Sunny: S u n n y "n. See Sunfish (b).

Sunproof: S u n p r o o f "a. Impervious to the rays of the sun.

Sunrise: S u n r i s e "n. Alt. of Sunrising

Sunrising: S u n r i s i n g "n. The first appearance of the sun above the horizon in the morning; more generally  the time of such appearance whether in fair or cloudy weather; as to begin work at sunrise.

Sunrising: S u n r i s i n g "n. Hence  the region where the sun rises; the east.

Sunset: S u n s e t "n. Alt. of Sunsetting

Sunsetting: S u n s e t t i n g "n. The descent of the sun below the horizon; also  the time when the sun sets; evening. Also used figuratively.

Sunsetting: S u n s e t t i n g "n. Hence  the region where the sun sets; the west.

Sunshade: S u n s h a d e "n. Anything used as a protection from the sun's rays.

Sunshade: S u n s h a d e "n. A small parasol.

Sunshade: S u n s h a d e "n. An awning.

Sunshine: S u n s h i n e "n. The light of the sun  or the place where it shines; the direct rays of the sun the place where they fall or the warmth and light which they give.

Sunshine: S u n s h i n e "n. Anything which has a warming and cheering influence like that of the rays of the sun; warmth; illumination; brightness.

Sunshine: S u n s h i n e "a. Sunshiny; bright.

Sunshiny: S u n s h i n y "a. Bright with the rays of the sun; clear  warm or pleasant; as a sunshiny day.

Sunshiny: S u n s h i n y "a. Bright like the sun; resplendent.

Sunshiny: S u n s h i n y "a. Beaming with good spirits; cheerful.

Sunsquall: S u n s q u a l l "n. Any large jellyfish.

Sunsted: S u n s t e d "n. Solstice.

Sunstone: S u n s t o n e "n. Aventurine feldspar. See under Aventurine.

Sunstroke: S u n s t r o k e "n. Any affection produced by the action of the sun on some part of the body; especially  a sudden prostration of the physical powers with symptoms resembling those of apoplexy occasioned by exposure to excessive heat and often terminating fatally; coup de soleil.

Sunup: S u n u p "n. Sunrise.

Sunward: S u n w a r d "adv. Toward the sun.

Sunwise: S u n w i s e "adv. In the direction of the sun's apparent motion  or from the east southward and westward and so around the circle; also in the same direction as the movement of the hands of a watch lying face upward.

Sup: S u p "v. t. To take into the mouth with the lips  as a liquid; to take or drink by a little at a time; to sip.

Sup: S u p "n. A small mouthful  as of liquor or broth; a little taken with the lips; a sip.

Sup: S u p "v. i. To eat the evening meal; to take supper.

Sup: S u p "v. t. To treat with supper.

Supawn: S u p a w n "n. Boiled Indian meal; hasty pudding; mush.

Supe: S u p e "n. A super.

Super: S u p e r "n. A contraction of Supernumerary  in sense 2.

Super-: S u p e r - " A prefix signifying above  over beyond and hence often denoting in a superior position in excess over and above in addition exceedingly; as in superimpose supersede supernatural superabundance.

Super-: S u p e r - " A prefix formerly much used to denote that the ingredient to the name of which it was prefixed was present in a large  or unusually large proportion as compared with the other ingredients; as in calcium superphosphate. It has been superseded by per- bi- di- acid etc. (as peroxide bicarbonate disulphide and acid sulphate) which retain the old meanings of super- but with sharper definition. Cf. Acid

Superable: S u p e r a b l e "a. Capable of being overcome or conquered; surmountable.

Superabound: S u p e r a b o u n d "v. i. To be very abundant or exuberant; to be more than sufficient; as  the country superabounds with corn.

Superabundance: S u p e r a b u n d a n c e "n. The quality or state of being superabundant; a superabundant quantity; redundancy; excess.

Superabundant: S u p e r a b u n d a n t "a. Abounding to excess; being more than is sufficient; redundant; as  superabundant zeal.

Superacidulated: S u p e r a c i d u l a t e d "a. Acidulated to excess.

Superadd: S u p e r a d d "v. t. To add over and above; to add to what has been added; to annex  as something extrinsic.

Superadded: S u p e r a d d e d "imp. & p. p. of Superadd

Superadding: S u p e r a d d i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Superadd

Superaddition: S u p e r a d d i t i o n "n. The act of adding something in excess or something extraneous; also  something which is added in excess or extraneously.

Superadvenient: S u p e r a d v e n i e n t "a. Coming upon; coming in addition to  or in assistance of something.

Superalimentation: S u p e r a l i m e n t a t i o n "n. The act of overfeeding  or making one take food in excess of the natural appetite for it.

Superaltar: S u p e r a l t a r "n. A raised shelf or stand on the back of an altar  on which different objects can be placed; a predella or gradino.

Superangelic: S u p e r a n g e l i c "a. Superior to the angels in nature or rank.

Superannuate: S u p e r a n n u a t e "v. t. To impair or disquality on account of age or infirmity.

Superannuate: S u p e r a n n u a t e "v. t. To give a pension to  on account of old age or other infirmity; to cause to retire from service on a pension.

Superannuate: S u p e r a n n u a t e "v. i. To last beyond the year; -- said of annual plants.

Superannuated: S u p e r a n n u a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Superannuate

Superannuating: S u p e r a n n u a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Superannuate

Superannuation: S u p e r a n n u a t i o n "n. The state of being superannuated  or too old for office or business; the state of being disqualified by old age; decrepitude.

Superb: S u p e r b "a. Grand; magnificent; august; stately; as  a superb edifice; a superb colonnade.

Superb: S u p e r b "a. Rich; elegant; as  superb furniture or decorations.

Superb: S u p e r b "a. Showy; excellent; grand; as  a superb exhibition.

Superbiate: S u p e r b i a t e "v. t. To make (a person) haughty.

Supercarbonate: S u p e r c a r b o n a t e "n. A bicarbonate.

Supercarbureted: S u p e r c a r b u r e t e d "a. Bicarbureted.

Supercargo: S u p e r c a r g o "n. An officer or person in a merchant ship  whose duty is to manage the sales and superintend the commercial concerns of the voyage.

Supercarpal: S u p e r c a r p a l "a. Situated above  or in the upper part of the carpus.

Supercelestial: S u p e r c e l e s t i a l "a. Situated above the firmament  or great vault of heaven.

Supercelestial: S u p e r c e l e s t i a l "a. Higher than celestial; superangelic.
