Supercharge: S u p e r c h a r g e "v. t. To charge (a bearing) upon another bearing; as  to supercharge a rose upon a fess.

Supercharge: S u p e r c h a r g e "n. A bearing charged upon another bearing.

Supercharged: S u p e r c h a r g e d "imp. & p. p. of Supercharge

Supercharging: S u p e r c h a r g i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Supercharge

Superchemical: S u p e r c h e m i c a l "a. Above or beyond chemistry; inexplicable by chemical laws.

Superchery: S u p e r c h e r y "n. Deceit; fraud; imposition.

Superciliary: S u p e r c i l i a r y "a. Of or pertaining to the eyebrows; supraorbital.

Superciliary: S u p e r c i l i a r y "a. Having a distinct streak of color above the eyes; as  the superciliary woodpecker.

Supercilious: S u p e r c i l i o u s "a. Lofty with pride; haughty; dictatorial; overbearing; arrogant; as  a supercilious officer; asupercilious air; supercilious behavior.

Supercilium: S u p e r c i l i u m "n. The eyebrow  or the region of the eyebrows.

Supercolumniation: S u p e r c o l u m n i a t i o n "n. The putting of one order above another; also  an architectural work produced by this method; as the putting of the Doric order in the ground story Ionic above it and Corinthian or Composite above this.

Superconception: S u p e r c o n c e p t i o n "n. Superfetation.

Superconsequence: S u p e r c o n s e q u e n c e "n. Remote consequence.

Supercrescence: S u p e r c r e s c e n c e "n. That which grows upon another growing thing; a parasite.

Supercrescent: S u p e r c r e s c e n t "a. Growing on some other growing thing.

Supercretaceous: S u p e r c r e t a c e o u s "a. Same as Supracretaceous.

Supercurious: S u p e r c u r i o u s "a. Excessively curious or inquisitive.

Superdominant: S u p e r d o m i n a n t "n. The sixth tone of the scale; that next above the dominant; -- called also submediant.

Supereminence: S u p e r e m i n e n c e "n. Alt. of Supereminency

Supereminency: S u p e r e m i n e n c y "n. The quality or state of being supereminent; distinguished eminence; as  the supereminence of Cicero as an orator or Lord Chatham as a statesman.

Supereminent: S u p e r e m i n e n t "a. Eminent in a superior degree; surpassing others in excellence; as  a supereminent divine; the supereminent glory of Christ.

Supererogant: S u p e r e r o g a n t "a. Supererogatory.

Supererogate: S u p e r e r o g a t e "v. i. To do more than duty requires; to perform works of supererogation; to atone (for a dificiency in another) by means of a surplus action or quality.

Supererogated: S u p e r e r o g a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Supererogate

Supererogating: S u p e r e r o g a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Supererogate

Supererogation: S u p e r e r o g a t i o n "n. The act of supererogating; performance of more than duty or necessity requires.

Supererogative: S u p e r e r o g a t i v e "a. Supererogatory.

Supererogatory: S u p e r e r o g a t o r y "a. Performed to an extent not enjoined  or not required by duty or necessity; as supererogatory services.

Superessential: S u p e r e s s e n t i a l "a. Essential above others  or above the constitution of a thing.

Superethical: S u p e r e t h i c a l "a. More than ethical; above ethics.

Superexalt: S u p e r e x a l t "v. t. To exalt to a superior degree; to exalt above others.

Superexaltation: S u p e r e x a l t a t i o n "n. Elevation above the common degree.

Superexalted: S u p e r e x a l t e d "imp. & p. p. of Superexalt

Superexalting: S u p e r e x a l t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Superexalt

Superexcellence: S u p e r e x c e l l e n c e "n. Superior excellence; extraordinary excellence.

Superexcellent: S u p e r e x c e l l e n t "a. Excellent in an uncommon degree; very excellent.

Superexcination: S u p e r e x c i n a t i o n "n. Excessive  or more than normal excitation.

Superexcrescence: S u p e r e x c r e s c e n c e "n. Something growing superfluously.

Superfamily: S u p e r f a m i l y "n. A group intermediate between a family and a suborder.

Superfecundation: S u p e r f e c u n d a t i o n "n. Fertilization of two ova  at the same menstruation by two different acts of coition.

Superfecundity: S u p e r f e c u n d i t y "n. Superabundant fecundity or multiplication of the species.

Superfetate: S u p e r f e t a t e "v. i. To conceive after a prior conception  but before the birth of the offspring.

Superfetation: S u p e r f e t a t i o n "n. The formation of a fetus at the result of an impregnation occurring after another impregnation but before the birth of the offspring produced by it. This is possible only when there is a double uterus  or where menstruation persists up to the time of the second impregnation.

Superfete: S u p e r f e t e "v. i. To superfetate.

Superfete: S u p e r f e t e "v. t. To conceive (another fetus) after a former conception.

Superfice: S u p e r f i c e "n. A superficies.

Superficial: S u p e r f i c i a l "a. Of or pertaining to the superficies  or surface; lying on the surface; shallow; not deep; as a superficial color; a superficial covering; superficial measure or contents; superficial tillage.

Superficial: S u p e r f i c i a l "a. Reaching or comprehending only what is obvious or apparent; not deep or profound; shallow; -- said especially in respect to study  learning and the like; as a superficial scholar; superficial knowledge.

Superficialist: S u p e r f i c i a l i s t "n. One who attends to anything superficially; a superficial or shallow person; a sciolist; a smatterer.

Superficiality: S u p e r f i c i a l i t y "n. The quality or state of being superficial; also  that which is superficial.

Superficialize: S u p e r f i c i a l i z e "v. t. To attend to  or to treat superficially or in a shallow or slighting way.

Superficiary: S u p e r f i c i a r y "n. One to whom a right of surface occupation is granted; one who pays quitrent for a house built upon another man's ground.

Superficiary: S u p e r f i c i a r y "a. Of or pertaining to the superficies  or surface; superficial.

Superficiary: S u p e r f i c i a r y "a. Situated or built on another man's land  as a house.

Superficies: S u p e r f i c i e s "n. The surface; the exterior part  superficial area or face of a thing.

Superficies: S u p e r f i c i e s "n. Everything on the surface of a piece of ground  or of a building so closely connected by art or nature as to constitute a part of it as houses or other superstructures fences trees vines etc.

Superficies: S u p e r f i c i e s "n. A real right consisting of a grant by a landed proprietor of a piece of ground  bearing a strong resemblance to the long building leases granted by landholders in England in consideration of a rent and under reservation of the ownership of the soil.

Superfine: S u p e r f i n e "a. Very fine  or most fine; being of surpassing fineness; of extra nice or fine quality; as superfine cloth.

Superfine: S u p e r f i n e "a. Excessively fine; too nice; over particular; as  superfine distinctions; superfine tastes.

Superfineness: S u p e r f i n e n e s s "n. The state of being superfine.

Superfinical: S u p e r f i n i c a l "a. Extremely finical.

Superfluence: S u p e r f l u e n c e "n. Superfluity.

Superfluitant: S u p e r f l u i t a n t "a. Floating above or on the surface.

Superfluities: S u p e r f l u i t i e s "pl. "of Superfluity

Superfluity: S u p e r f l u i t y "n. A greater quantity than is wanted; superabundance; as  a superfluity of water; a superfluity of wealth.

Superfluity: S u p e r f l u i t y "n. The state or quality of being superfluous; excess.

Superfluity: S u p e r f l u i t y "n. Something beyond what is needed; something which serves for show or luxury.

Superfluous: S u p e r f l u o u s "a. More than is wanted or is sufficient; rendered unnecessary by superabundance; unnecessary; useless; excessive; as  a superfluous price.

Superflux: S u p e r f l u x "n. Superabundance; superfluity; an overflowing.

Superfoetation: S u p e r f o e t a t i o n "n. Superfetation.

Superfoliation: S u p e r f o l i a t i o n "n. Excess of foliation.

Superfrontal: S u p e r f r o n t a l "n. A cloth which is placed over the top of an altar  and often hangs down a few inches over the frontal.

Superfuse: S u p e r f u s e "a. To pour (something) over or on something else.

Superheat: S u p e r h e a t "v. t. To heat too much  to overheat; as to superheat an oven.

Superheat: S u p e r h e a t "v. t. To heat  as steam apart from contact with water until it resembles a perfect gas.

Superheat: S u p e r h e a t "n. The increase of temperature communicated to steam by superheating it.

Superheated: S u p e r h e a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Superheat

Superheater: S u p e r h e a t e r "n. An apparatus for superheating steam.

Superheating: S u p e r h e a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Superheat

Superhive: S u p e r h i v e "n. A removable upper part of a hive. The word is sometimes contracted to super.

Superhuman: S u p e r h u m a n "a. Above or beyond what is human; sometimes  divine; as superhuman strength; superhuman wisdom.

Superimpose: S u p e r i m p o s e "v. t. To lay or impose on something else; as  a stratum of earth superimposed on another stratum.

Superimposed: S u p e r i m p o s e d "imp. & p. p. of Superimpose

Superimposing: S u p e r i m p o s i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Superimpose

Superincumbence: S u p e r i n c u m b e n c e "n. Alt. of Superincumbency

Superincumbency: S u p e r i n c u m b e n c y "n. The quality or state of being superincumbent.

Superincumbent: S u p e r i n c u m b e n t "a. Lying or resting on something else.

Superinduce: S u p e r i n d u c e "v. t. To bring in  or upon as an addition to something.

Superinduced: S u p e r i n d u c e d "imp. & p. p. of Superinduce

Superinducement: S u p e r i n d u c e m e n t "n. Superinduction.

Superinducing: S u p e r i n d u c i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Superinduce

Superinduction: S u p e r i n d u c t i o n "n. The act of superinducing  or the state of being superinduced.

Superinfuse: S u p e r i n f u s e "v. t. To infuse over.

Superinjection: S u p e r i n j e c t i o n "n. An injection succeeding another.

Superinpregnation: S u p e r i n p r e g n a t i o n "n. The act of impregnating  or the state of being impregnated in addition to a prior impregnation; superfetation.

Superinspect: S u p e r i n s p e c t "v. t. To over see; to superintend by inspection.

Superinstitution: S u p e r i n s t i t u t i o n "n. One institution upon another  as when A is instituted and admitted to a benefice upon a title and B instituted and admitted upon the presentation of another.

Superintellectual: S u p e r i n t e l l e c t u a l "a. Being above intellect.

Superintend: S u p e r i n t e n d "v. t. To have or exercise the charge and oversight of; to oversee with the power of direction; to take care of with authority; to supervise; as  an officer superintends the building of a ship or the construction of a fort.

Superintended: S u p e r i n t e n d e d "imp. & p. p. of Superintend

Superintendence: S u p e r i n t e n d e n c e "n. The act of superintending; care and oversight for the purpose of direction; supervision.

Superintendency: S u p e r i n t e n d e n c y "n. The act of superintending; superintendence.

Superintendent: S u p e r i n t e n d e n t "a. Overseeing; superintending.

Superintendent: S u p e r i n t e n d e n t "n. One who has the oversight and charge of some place  institution or organization affairs etc. with the power of direction; as the superintendent of an almshouse; the superintendent of public works.

Superintender: S u p e r i n t e n d e r "n. A superintendent.

Superintending: S u p e r i n t e n d i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Superintend

Superinvestiture: S u p e r i n v e s t i t u r e "n. An outer vestment or garment.

Superior: S u p e r i o r "a. More elevated in place or position; higher; upper; as  the superior limb of the sun; the superior part of an image.

Superior: S u p e r i o r "a. Higher in rank or office; more exalted in dignity; as  a superior officer; a superior degree of nobility.

Superior: S u p e r i o r "a. Higher or greater in excellence; surpassing others in the greatness  or value of any quality; greater in quality or degree; as a man of superior merit; or of superior bravery.

Superior: S u p e r i o r "a. Beyond the power or influence of; too great or firm to be subdued or affected by; -- with to.

Superior: S u p e r i o r "a. More comprehensive; as a term in classification; as  a genus is superior to a species.

Superior: S u p e r i o r "a. Above the ovary; -- said of parts of the flower which  although normally below the ovary adhere to it and so appear to originate from its upper part; also of an ovary when the other floral organs are plainly below it in position and free from it.

Superior: S u p e r i o r "a. Belonging to the part of an axillary flower which is toward the main stem; posterior.

Superior: S u p e r i o r "a. Pointing toward the apex of the fruit; ascending; -- said of the radicle.

Superior: S u p e r i o r "n. One who is above  or surpasses another in rank station office age ability or merit; one who surpasses in what is desirable; as Addison has no superior as a writer of pure English.

Superior: S u p e r i o r "n. The head of a monastery  convent abbey or the like.

Superioress: S u p e r i o r e s s "n. A woman who acts as chief in a convent  abbey or nunnery; a lady superior.

Superiority: S u p e r i o r i t y "n. The quality  state or condition of being superior; as superiority of rank; superiority in merit.

Superiorly: S u p e r i o r l y "adv. In a superior position or manner.

Superjacent: S u p e r j a c e n t "a. Situated immediately above; as  superjacent rocks.

Superlation: S u p e r l a t i o n "n. Exaltation of anything beyond truth or propriety.

Superlative: S u p e r l a t i v e "a. Lifted up to the highest degree; most eminent; surpassing all other; supreme; as  superlative wisdom or prudence; a woman of superlative beauty; the superlative glory of the divine character.

Superlative: S u p e r l a t i v e "a. Expressing the highest or lowest degree of the quality  manner etc. denoted by an adjective or an adverb. The superlative degree is formed from the positive by the use of -est most or least; as highest most pleasant least bright.

Superlative: S u p e r l a t i v e "n. That which is highest or most eminent; the utmost degree.

Superlative: S u p e r l a t i v e "n. The superlative degree of adjectives and adverbs; also  a form or word by which the superlative degree is expressed; as strongest wisest most stormy least windy are all superlatives.

Superlucration: S u p e r l u c r a t i o n "n. Excessive or extraordinary gain.

Superlunar: S u p e r l u n a r "a. Alt. of Superlunary

Superlunary: S u p e r l u n a r y "a. Being above the moon; not belonging to this world; -- opposed to sublunary.

Supermaterial: S u p e r m a t e r i a l "a. Being above  or superior to matter.

Supermaxilla: S u p e r m a x i l l a "n. The supermaxilla.

Supermaxillary: S u p e r m a x i l l a r y "a. Supermaxillary.

Supermedial: S u p e r m e d i a l "a. Above the middle.

Supermundane: S u p e r m u n d a n e "a. Being above the world; -- opposed to inframundane.

Supermundial: S u p e r m u n d i a l "a. Supermundane.

Supernacular: S u p e r n a c u l a r "a. Like supernaculum; first-rate; as  a supernacular wine.

Supernaculum: S u p e r n a c u l u m "adv. & n. A kind of mock Latin term intended to mean  upon the nail; -- used formerly by topers.

Supernaculum: S u p e r n a c u l u m "adv. & n. Good liquor  of which not enough is left to wet one's nail.

Supernal: S u p e r n a l "a. Being in a higher place or region; locally higher; as  the supernal orbs; supernal regions.

Supernal: S u p e r n a l "a. Relating or belonging to things above; celestial; heavenly; as  supernal grace.

Supernatant: S u p e r n a t a n t "a. Swimming above; floating on the surface; as  oil supernatant on water.

Supernatant: S u p e r n a t a n t "n. The liquid remaining after solids suspended in the liquid have been sedimented by gravity or by centrifugation. Contrasted with the solid sediment  or (in centrifugation) the pellet.

Supernatation: S u p e r n a t a t i o n "n. The act of floating on the surface of a fluid.

Supernatural: S u p e r n a t u r a l "a. Being beyond  or exceeding the power or laws of nature; miraculous.

Supernaturalism: S u p e r n a t u r a l i s m "n. The quality or state of being supernatural; supernaturalness.

Supernaturalism: S u p e r n a t u r a l i s m "n. The doctrine of a divine and supernatural agency in the production of the miracles and revelations recorded in the Bible  and in the grace which renews and sanctifies men -- in opposition to the doctrine which denies the agency of any other than physical or natural causes in the case.

Supernaturalist: S u p e r n a t u r a l i s t "n. One who holds to the principles of supernaturalism.

Supernaturalistic: S u p e r n a t u r a l i s t i c "a. Of or pertaining to supernaturalism.

Supernaturality: S u p e r n a t u r a l i t y "n. The quality or state of being supernatural.

Supernaturalize: S u p e r n a t u r a l i z e "v. t. To treat or regard as supernatural.

Supernaturally: S u p e r n a t u r a l l y "adv. In a supernatural manner.

Supernaturalness: S u p e r n a t u r a l n e s s "n. The quality or state of being supernatural.

Supernumeraries: S u p e r n u m e r a r i e s "pl. "of Supernumerary

Supernumerary: S u p e r n u m e r a r y "a. Exceeding the number stated or prescribed; as  a supernumerary officer in a regiment.

Supernumerary: S u p e r n u m e r a r y "a. Exceeding a necessary  usual or required number or quality; superfluous; as supernumerary addresses; supernumerary expense.

Supernumerary: S u p e r n u m e r a r y "n. A person or thing beyond the number stated.

Supernumerary: S u p e r n u m e r a r y "n. A person or thing beyond what is necessary or usual; especially  a person employed not for regular service but only to fill the place of another in case of need; specifically in theaters a person who is not a regular actor but is employed to appear in a stage spectacle.

Superoccipital: S u p e r o c c i p i t a l "a. Supraoccipital.

Superorder: S u p e r o r d e r "n. A group intermediate in importance between an order and a subclass.

Superordination: S u p e r o r d i n a t i o n "n. The ordination of a person to fill a station already occupied; especially  the ordination by an ecclesiastical official during his lifetime of his successor.

Superoxide: S u p e r o x i d e "n. See Peroxide.

Superparticular: S u p e r p a r t i c u l a r "a. Of or pertaining to a ratio when the excess of the greater term over the less is a unit  as the ratio of 1 to 2 or of 3 to 4.

Superpartient: S u p e r p a r t i e n t "a. Of or pertaining to a ratio when the excess of the greater term over the less is more than a unit  as that of 3 to 5 or 7 to 10.

Superphosphate: S u p e r p h o s p h a t e "n. An acid phosphate.

Superphysical: S u p e r p h y s i c a l "a. Above or beyond physics; not explainable by physical laws.

Superplant: S u p e r p l a n t "n. A plant growing on another  as the mistletoe; an epiphyte.

Superplease: S u p e r p l e a s e "v. t. To please exceedingly.

Superplus: S u p e r p l u s "n. Surplus.

Superplusage: S u p e r p l u s a g e "n. Surplusage.

Superpolitic: S u p e r p o l i t i c "a. More than politic; above or exceeding policy.

Superponderate: S u p e r p o n d e r a t e "v. t. To wiegh over and above.

Superposable: S u p e r p o s a b l e "a. Capable of being superposed  as one figure upon another.

Superpose: S u p e r p o s e "v. t. To lay upon  as one kind of rock on another.

Superpose: S u p e r p o s e "v. t. To lay (a figure) upon another in such a manner that all the parts of the one coincide with the parts of the other; as  to superpose one plane figure on another.

Superposed: S u p e r p o s e d "imp. & p. p. of Superpose

Superposing: S u p e r p o s i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Superpose

Superposition: S u p e r p o s i t i o n "n. The act of superposing  or the state of being superposed; as the superposition of rocks; the superposition of one plane figure on another in geometry.

Superpraise: S u p e r p r a i s e "v. t. To praise to excess.

Superproportion: S u p e r p r o p o r t i o n "n. Overplus or excess of proportion.

Superpurgation: S u p e r p u r g a t i o n "n. Excessive purgation.

Superreflection: S u p e r r e f l e c t i o n "n. The reflection of a reflected image or sound.

Superregal: S u p e r r e g a l "a. More than regal; worthy of one greater than a king.

Superreward: S u p e r r e w a r d "v. t. To reward to an excessive degree.

Superroyal: S u p e r r o y a l "a. Larger than royal; -- said of a particular size of printing and writing paper. See the Note under Paper  n.

Supersacral: S u p e r s a c r a l "a. Situated over  or on the dorsal side of the sacrum.

Supersaliency: S u p e r s a l i e n c y "n. The act of leaping on anything.

Supersalient: S u p e r s a l i e n t "a. Leaping upon.

Supersalt: S u p e r s a l t "n. An acid salt. See Acid salt (a)  under Salt n.

Supersaturate: S u p e r s a t u r a t e "v. t. To add to beyond saturation; as  to supersaturate a solution.

Supersaturation: S u p e r s a t u r a t i o n "n. The operation of supersaturating  or the state of being supersaturated.

Superscribe: S u p e r s c r i b e "v. t. To write or engrave (a name  address inscription or the like) on the top or surface; to write a name address or the like on the outside or cover of (anything); as to superscribe a letter.

Superscribed: S u p e r s c r i b e d "imp. & p. p. of Superscribe

Superscribing: S u p e r s c r i b i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Superscribe

Superscript: S u p e r s c r i p t "n. Superscription.

Superscription: S u p e r s c r i p t i o n "n. The act of superscribing.

Superscription: S u p e r s c r i p t i o n "n. That which is written or engraved on the surface  outside or above something else; specifically an address on a letter envelope or the like.

Superscription: S u p e r s c r i p t i o n "n. That part of a prescription which contains the Latin word recipe (Take) or the sign /.

Supersecular: S u p e r s e c u l a r "a. Being above the world  or secular things.

Supersede: S u p e r s e d e "v. t. To come  or be placed in the room of; to replace.

Supersede: S u p e r s e d e "v. t. To displace  or set aside and put another in place of; as to supersede an officer.

Supersede: S u p e r s e d e "v. t. To make void  inefficacious or useless by superior power or by coming in the place of; to set aside; to render unnecessary; to suspend; to stay.

Supersede: S u p e r s e d e "v. t. To omit; to forbear.

Supersedeas: S u p e r s e d e a s "n. A writ of command to suspend the powers of an officer in certain cases  or to stay proceedings under another writ.

Superseded: S u p e r s e d e d "imp. & p. p. of Supersede

Superseding: S u p e r s e d i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Supersede

Supersedure: S u p e r s e d u r e "n. The act of superseding  or setting aside; supersession; as the supersedure of trial by jury.

Superseminate: S u p e r s e m i n a t e "v. t. To sow  as seed over something previously sown.

Supersemination: S u p e r s e m i n a t i o n "n. The sowing of seed over seed previously sown.

Supersensible: S u p e r s e n s i b l e "a. Beyond the reach of the senses; above the natural powers of perception.

Supersensitive: S u p e r s e n s i t i v e "a. Excessively sensitive; morbidly sensitive.

Supersensual: S u p e r s e n s u a l "a. Supersensible.

Supersensuous: S u p e r s e n s u o u s "a. Supersensible.

Supersensuous: S u p e r s e n s u o u s "a. Excessively sensuous.

Superserviceable: S u p e r s e r v i c e a b l e "a. Overofficious; doing more than is required or desired.

Supersession: S u p e r s e s s i o n "n. The act of superseding  or the state of being superseded; supersedure.

Supersolar: S u p e r s o l a r "a. Above the sun.

Supersphenoidal: S u p e r s p h e n o i d a l "a. Situated above  or on the dorsal side of the body of the sphenoid bone.

Superspinous: S u p e r s p i n o u s "a. Supraspinuos.

Superstatum: S u p e r s t a t u m "n. A stratum  or layer above another.

Superstition: S u p e r s t i t i o n "n. An excessive reverence for  or fear of that which is unknown or mysterious.

Superstition: S u p e r s t i t i o n "n. An ignorant or irrational worship of the Supreme Deity; excessive exactness or rigor in religious opinions or practice; extreme and unnecessary scruples in the observance of religious rites not commanded  or of points of minor importance; also a rite or practice proceeding from excess of sculptures in religion.

Superstition: S u p e r s t i t i o n "n. The worship of a false god or gods; false religion; religious veneration for objects.

Superstition: S u p e r s t i t i o n "n. Belief in the direct agency of superior powers in certain extraordinary or singular events  or in magic omens prognostics or the like.

Superstition: S u p e r s t i t i o n "n. Excessive nicety; scrupulous exactness.

Superstitionist: S u p e r s t i t i o n i s t "n. One addicted to superstition.

Superstitious: S u p e r s t i t i o u s "a. Of or pertaining to superstition; proceeding from  or manifesting superstition; as superstitious rites; superstitious observances.

Superstitious: S u p e r s t i t i o u s "a. Evincing superstition; overscrupulous and rigid in religious observances; addicted to superstition; full of idle fancies and scruples in regard to religion.

Superstitious: S u p e r s t i t i o u s "a. Overexact; scrupulous beyond need.

Superstrain: S u p e r s t r a i n "v. t. To overstrain.

Superstrata: S u p e r s t r a t a "pl. "of Superstatum

Superstruct: S u p e r s t r u c t "v. t. To build over or upon another structure; to erect upon a foundation.

Superstruction: S u p e r s t r u c t i o n "n. The act of superstructing  or building upon.

Superstruction: S u p e r s t r u c t i o n "n. That which id superstructed  or built upon some foundation; an edifice; a superstructure.

Superstructive: S u p e r s t r u c t i v e "a. Built or erected on something else.

Superstructor: S u p e r s t r u c t o r "n. One who builds a superstructure.

Superstructure: S u p e r s t r u c t u r e "n. Any material structure or edifice built on something else; that which is raised on a foundation or basis

Superstructure: S u p e r s t r u c t u r e "n. all that part of a building above the basement. Also used figuratively.

Superstructure: S u p e r s t r u c t u r e "n. The sleepers  and fastenings in distinction from the roadbed.

Supersubstantial: S u p e r s u b s t a n t i a l "a. More than substantial; spiritual.

Supersubtle: S u p e r s u b t l e "a. To subtle.

Supersulphate: S u p e r s u l p h a t e "n. An acid sulphate.

Supersulphureted: S u p e r s u l p h u r e t e d "a. Supersulphurized.

Supersulphurize: S u p e r s u l p h u r i z e "v. t. To impregnate or combine with an excess of sulphur.

Supertemporal: S u p e r t e m p o r a l "n. That which is more than temporal; that which is eternal.

Superterranean: S u p e r t e r r a n e a n "a. Being above ground.

Superterrene: S u p e r t e r r e n e "a. Being above ground  or above the earth.

Superterrestrial: S u p e r t e r r e s t r i a l "a. Being above the earth  or above what belongs to the earth.

Supertonic: S u p e r t o n i c "n. The note next above the keynote; the second of the scale.

Supertragical: S u p e r t r a g i c a l "a. Tragical to excess.

Supertuberation: S u p e r t u b e r a t i o n "n. The production of young tubers  as potatoes from the old while still growing.

Supervacaneous: S u p e r v a c a n e o u s "a. Serving no purpose; superfluous; needless.

Supervene: S u p e r v e n e "v. i. To come as something additional or extraneous; to occur with reference or relation to something else; to happen upon or after something else; to be added; to take place; to happen.

Supervened: S u p e r v e n e d "imp. & p. p. of Supervene

Supervenient: S u p e r v e n i e n t "a. Coming as something additional or extraneous; coming afterwards.

Supervening: S u p e r v e n i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Supervene

Supervention: S u p e r v e n t i o n "n. The act of supervening.

Supervisal: S u p e r v i s a l "n. Supervision.

Supervise: S u p e r v i s e "v. t. To oversee for direction; to superintend; to inspect with authority; as  to supervise the construction of a steam engine or the printing of a book.

Supervise: S u p e r v i s e "v. t. To look over so as to read; to peruse.

Supervise: S u p e r v i s e "n. Supervision; inspection.

Supervised: S u p e r v i s e d "imp. & p. p. of Supervise

Supervising: S u p e r v i s i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Supervise

Supervision: S u p e r v i s i o n "n. The act of overseeing; inspection; superintendence; oversight.

Supervisive: S u p e r v i s i v e "a. Supervisory.

Supervisor: S u p e r v i s o r "n. One who supervises; an overseer; an inspector; a superintendent; as  a supervisor of schools.

Supervisor: S u p e r v i s o r "n. A spectator; a looker-on.

Supervisory: S u p e r v i s o r y "a. Of or pertaining to supervision; as  supervisory powers.

Supervive: S u p e r v i v e "v. t. To survive; to outlive.

Supervolute: S u p e r v o l u t e "a. Having a plainted and convolute arrangement in the bud  as in the morning-glory.

Supination: S u p i n a t i o n "n. The act of turning the hand palm upward; also  position of the hand with the palm upward.

Supination: S u p i n a t i o n "n. The act or state of lying with the face upward. Opposed to pronation.

Supinator: S u p i n a t o r "n. A muscle which produces the motion of supination.

Supine: S u p i n e "a. Lying on the back  or with the face upward; -- opposed to prone.

Supine: S u p i n e "a. Leaning backward  or inclining with exposure to the sun; sloping; inclined.

Supine: S u p i n e "a. Negligent; heedless; indolent; listless.

Supine: S u p i n e "n. A verbal noun; or (according to C.F.Becker)  a case of the infinitive mood ending in -um and -u that in -um being sometimes called the former supine and that in -u the latter supine.

Supinity: S u p i n i t y "n. Supineness.

Suppage: S u p p a g e "n. What may be supped; pottage.

Suppalpation: S u p p a l p a t i o n "n. The act of enticing by soft words; enticement.

Supparasitation: S u p p a r a s i t a t i o n "n. The act of flattering to gain favor; servile approbation.

Supparasite: S u p p a r a s i t e "v. t. To flatter; to cajole; to act the parasite.

Suppawn: S u p p a w n "n. See Supawn.

Supped: S u p p e d "imp. & p. p. of Sup

Suppedaneous: S u p p e d a n e o u s "a. Being under the feet.

Suppeditate: S u p p e d i t a t e "v. t. To supply; to furnish.

Suppeditation: S u p p e d i t a t i o n "n. Supply; aid afforded.

Supper: S u p p e r "n. A meal taken at the close of the day; the evening meal.

Supper: S u p p e r "v. i. To take supper; to sup.

Supper: S u p p e r "v. t. To supply with supper.

Supperless: S u p p e r l e s s "a. Having no supper; deprived of supper; as  to go supperless to bed.

Supping: S u p p i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Sup

Supping: S u p p i n g "n. The act of one who sups; the act of taking supper.

Supping: S u p p i n g "n. That which is supped; broth.

Supplace: S u p p l a c e "v. t. To replace.

Supplant: S u p p l a n t "n. To trip up.

Supplant: S u p p l a n t "n. To remove or displace by stratagem; to displace and take the place of; to supersede; as  a rival supplants another in the favor of a mistress or a prince.

Supplant: S u p p l a n t "n. To overthrow  undermine or force away in order to get a substitute in place of.

Supplantation: S u p p l a n t a t i o n "n. The act of supplanting or displacing.

Supplanted: S u p p l a n t e d "imp. & p. p. of Supplant

Supplanter: S u p p l a n t e r "n. One who supplants.

Supplanting: S u p p l a n t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Supplant

Supple: S u p p l e "a. Pliant; flexible; easily bent; as  supple joints; supple fingers.

Supple: S u p p l e "a. Yielding compliant; not obstinate; submissive to guidance; as  a supple horse.

Supple: S u p p l e "a. Bending to the humor of others; flattering; fawning; obsequious.

Supple: S u p p l e "v. t. To make soft and pliant; to render flexible; as  to supple leather.

Supple: S u p p l e "v. t. To make compliant  submissive or obedient.

Supple: S u p p l e "v. i. To become soft and pliant.

Supple-chapped: S u p p l e - c h a p p e d "a. Having a limber tongue.

Supple-jack: S u p p l e - j a c k "n. A climbing shrub (Berchemia volubilus) of the Southern United States  having a tough and pliable stem.

Supple-jack: S u p p l e - j a c k "n. A somewhat similar tropical American plant (Paullinia Curassavica); also  a walking stick made from its stem.

Suppled: S u p p l e d "imp. & p. p. of Supple

Supplely: S u p p l e l y "adv. In a supple manner; softly; pliantly; mildly.

Supplement: S u p p l e m e n t "v. t. That which supplies a deficiency  or meets a want; a store; a supply.

Supplement: S u p p l e m e n t "v. t. That which fills up  completes or makes an addition to something already organized arranged or set apart; specifically a part added to or issued as a continuation of a book or paper to make good its deficiencies or correct its errors.

Supplement: S u p p l e m e n t "v. t. The number of degrees which  if added to a specified arc make it 180 ; the quantity by which an arc or an angle falls short of 180 degrees or an arc falls short of a semicircle.

Supplement: S u p p l e m e n t "v. t. To fill up or supply by addition; to add something to.

Supplemental: S u p p l e m e n t a l "a. Alt. of Supplementary

Supplementary: S u p p l e m e n t a r y "a. Added to supply what is wanted; additional; being  or serving as a supplement; as a supplemental law; a supplementary sheet or volume.

Supplementation: S u p p l e m e n t a t i o n "n. The act of supplementing.

Supplemented: S u p p l e m e n t e d "imp. & p. p. of Supplement

Supplementing: S u p p l e m e n t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Supplement

Suppleness: S u p p l e n e s s "n. The quality or state of being supple; flexibility; pliableness; pliancy.

Suppletive: S u p p l e t i v e "a. Alt. of Suppletory

Suppletories: S u p p l e t o r i e s "pl. "of Suppletory

Suppletory: S u p p l e t o r y "a. Supplying deficiencies; supplementary; as  a suppletory oath.

Suppletory: S u p p l e t o r y "n. That which is to supply what is wanted.

Supplial: S u p p l i a l "n. The act of supplying; a supply.

Suppliance: S u p p l i a n c e "n. That which supplies a want; assistance; a gratification; satisfaction.

Suppliance: S u p p l i a n c e "n. Supplication; entreaty.

Suppliant: S u p p l i a n t "a. Asking earnestly and submissively; entreating; beseeching; supplicating.

Suppliant: S u p p l i a n t "a. Manifesting entreaty; expressive of supplication.

Suppliant: S u p p l i a n t "n. One who supplicates; a humble petitioner; one who entreats submissively.

Supplicancy: S u p p l i c a n c y "n. Supplication.

Supplicant: S u p p l i c a n t "a. Entreating; asking submissively.

Supplicant: S u p p l i c a n t "n. One who supplicates; a suppliant.

Supplicat: S u p p l i c a t "n. A petition; esp.  a written one with a certificate that the conditions have been complied with.

Supplicate: S u p p l i c a t e "v. t. To entreat for; to seek by earnest prayer; to ask for earnestly and humbly; as  to supplicate blessings on Christian efforts to spread the gospel.

Supplicate: S u p p l i c a t e "v. t. To address in prayer; to entreat as a supplicant; as  to supplicate the Deity.

Supplicate: S u p p l i c a t e "v. i. To make petition with earnestness and submission; to implore.

Supplicated: S u p p l i c a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Supplicate

Supplicating: S u p p l i c a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Supplicate

Supplicatingly: S u p p l i c a t i n g l y "adv. In a supplicating manner.

Supplication: S u p p l i c a t i o n "n. The act of supplicating; humble and earnest prayer  as in worship.

Supplication: S u p p l i c a t i o n "n. A humble petition; an earnest request; an entreaty.

Supplication: S u p p l i c a t i o n "n. A religious solemnity observed in consequence of some military success  and also in times of distress and danger to avert the anger of the gods.

Supplicator: S u p p l i c a t o r "n. One who supplicates; a supplicant.

Supplicatory: S u p p l i c a t o r y "a. Containing supplication; humble; earnest.

Supplied: S u p p l i e d "imp. & p. p. of Supply

Supplier: S u p p l i e r "n. One who supplies.

Supplies: S u p p l i e s "pl. "of Supply

Suppling: S u p p l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Supple

Supply: S u p p l y "v. t. To fill up  or keep full; to furnish with what is wanted; to afford or furnish with a sufficiency; as rivers are supplied by smaller streams; an aqueduct supplies an artificial lake; -- often followed by with before the thing furnished; as to supply a furnace with fuel; to supply soldiers with ammunition.

Supply: S u p p l y "v. t. To serve instead of; to take the place of.

Supply: S u p p l y "v. t. To fill temporarily; to serve as substitute for another in  as a vacant place or office; to occupy; to have possession of; as to supply a pulpit.

Supply: S u p p l y "v. t. To give; to bring or furnish; to provide; as  to supply money for the war.

Supply: S u p p l y "n. The act of supplying; supplial.

Supply: S u p p l y "n. That which supplies a want; sufficiency of things for use or want.

Supply: S u p p l y "n. Auxiliary troops or reenforcements.

Supply: S u p p l y "n. The food  and the like which meets the daily necessities of an army or other large body of men; store; -- used chiefly in the plural; as the army was discontented for lack of supplies.

Supply: S u p p l y "n. An amount of money provided  as by Parliament or Congress to meet the annual national expenditures; generally in the plural; as to vote supplies.

Supply: S u p p l y "n. A person who fills a place for a time; one who supplies the place of another; a substitute; esp.  a clergyman who supplies a vacant pulpit.

Supply: S u p p l y "a. Serving to contain  deliver or regulate a supply of anything; as a supply tank or valve.

Supplyant: S u p p l y a n t "a. Supplying or aiding; auxiliary; suppletory.

Supplying: S u p p l y i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Supply

Supplyment: S u p p l y m e n t "n. A supplying or furnishing; supply.

Support: S u p p o r t "v. t. To bear by being under; to keep from falling; to uphold; to sustain  in a literal or physical sense; to prop up; to bear the weight of; as a pillar supports a structure; an abutment supports an arch; the trunk of a tree supports the branches.

Support: S u p p o r t "v. t. To endure without being overcome  exhausted or changed in character; to sustain; as to support pain distress or misfortunes.

Support: S u p p o r t "v. t. To keep from failing or sinking; to solace under affictive circumstances; to assist; to encourage; to defend; as  to support the courage or spirits.

Support: S u p p o r t "v. t. To assume and carry successfully  as the part of an actor; to represent or act; to sustain; as to support the character of King Lear.

Support: S u p p o r t "v. t. To furnish with the means of sustenance or livelihood; to maintain; to provide for; as  to support a family; to support the ministers of the gospel.

Support: S u p p o r t "v. t. To carry on; to enable to continue; to maintain; as  to support a war or a contest; to support an argument or a debate.

Support: S u p p o r t "v. t. To verify; to make good; to substantiate; to establish; to sustain; as  the testimony is not sufficient to support the charges; the evidence will not support the statements or allegations.

Support: S u p p o r t "v. t. To vindicate; to maintain; to defend successfully; as  to be able to support one's own cause.

Support: S u p p o r t "v. t. To uphold by aid or countenance; to aid; to help; to back up; as  to support a friend or a party; to support the present administration.

Support: S u p p o r t "v. t. A attend as an honorary assistant; as  a chairman supported by a vice chairman; O'Connell left the prison supported by his two sons.

Support: S u p p o r t "n. The act  state or operation of supporting upholding or sustaining.

Support: S u p p o r t "n. That which upholds  sustains or keeps from falling as a prop a pillar or a foundation of any kind.

Support: S u p p o r t "n. That which maintains or preserves from being overcome  falling yielding sinking giving way or the like; subsistence; maintenance; assistance; reenforcement; as he gave his family a good support the support of national credit; the assaulting column had the support of a battery.

Supportable: S u p p o r t a b l e "a. Capable of being supported  maintained or endured; endurable.

Supportance: S u p p o r t a n c e "n. Support.

Supportation: S u p p o r t a t i o n "n. Maintenance; support.

Supported: S u p p o r t e d "imp. & p. p. of Support

Supporter: S u p p o r t e r "n. One who  or that which supports; as oxygen is a supporter of life.

Supporter: S u p p o r t e r "n. Especially  an adherent; one who sustains advocates and defends; as the supporter of a party faction or candidate.

Supporter: S u p p o r t e r "n. A knee placed under the cathead.

Supporter: S u p p o r t e r "n. A figure  sometimes of a man but commonly of some animal placed on either side of an escutcheon and exterior to it. Usually both supporters of an escutcheon are similar figures.

Supporter: S u p p o r t e r "n. A broad band or truss for supporting the abdomen or some other part or organ.

Supportful: S u p p o r t f u l "a. Abounding with support.

Supporting: S u p p o r t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Support

Supportless: S u p p o r t l e s s "a. Having no support.

Supportment: S u p p o r t m e n t "n. Support.

Supportress: S u p p o r t r e s s "n. A female supporter.

Supposable: S u p p o s a b l e "a. Capable of being supposed  or imagined to exist; as that is not a supposable case.

Supposal: S u p p o s a l "n. The act of supposing; also  that which is supposed; supposition; opinion.

Suppose: S u p p o s e "v. t. To represent to one's self  or state to another not as true or real but as if so and with a view to some consequence or application which the reality would involve or admit of; to imagine or admit to exist for the sake of argument or illustration; to assume to be true; as let us suppose the earth to be the center of the system what would be the result?

Suppose: S u p p o s e "v. t. To imagine; to believe; to receive as true.

Suppose: S u p p o s e "v. t. To require to exist or to be true; to imply by the laws of thought or of nature; as  purpose supposes foresight.

Suppose: S u p p o s e "v. t. To put by fraud in the place of another.

Suppose: S u p p o s e "v. i. To make supposition; to think; to be of opinion.

Suppose: S u p p o s e "n. Supposition.

Supposed: S u p p o s e d "imp. & p. p. of Suppose

Supposeer: S u p p o s e e r "n. One who supposes.

Supposing: S u p p o s i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Suppose

Supposition: S u p p o s i t i o n "n. The act of supposing  laying down imagining or considering as true or existing what is known not to be true or what is not proved.

Supposition: S u p p o s i t i o n "n. That which is supposed; hypothesis; conjecture; surmise; opinion or belief without sufficient evidence.

Suppositional: S u p p o s i t i o n a l "a. Resting on supposition; hypothetical; conjectural; supposed.

Supposititious: S u p p o s i t i t i o u s "a. Fraudulently substituted for something else; not being what is purports to be; not genuine; spurious; counterfeit; as  a supposititious child; a supposititious writing.

Supposititious: S u p p o s i t i t i o u s "a. Suppositional; hypothetical.

Suppositive: S u p p o s i t i v e "a. Including or implying supposition  or hypothesis; supposed.

Suppositive: S u p p o s i t i v e "n. A word denoting or implying supposition  as the words if granting provided etc.

Suppositor: S u p p o s i t o r "n. An apparatus for the introduction of suppositories into the rectum.

Suppositories: S u p p o s i t o r i e s "pl. "of Suppository

Suppository: S u p p o s i t o r y "n. A pill or bolus for introduction into the rectum; esp.  a cylinder or cone of medicated cacao butter.

Supposure: S u p p o s u r e "n. Supposition; hypothesis; conjecture.

Suppress: S u p p r e s s "v. t. To overpower and crush; to subdue; to put down; to quell.

Suppress: S u p p r e s s "v. t. To keep in; to restrain from utterance or vent; as  to suppress the voice; to suppress a smile.

Suppress: S u p p r e s s "v. t. To retain without disclosure; to conceal; not to reveal; to prevent publication of; as  to suppress evidence; to suppress a pamphlet; to suppress the truth.

Suppress: S u p p r e s s "v. t. To stop; to restrain; to arrest the discharges of; as  to suppress a diarrhea or a hemorrhage.

Suppressed: S u p p r e s s e d "imp. & p. p. of Suppress

Suppressible: S u p p r e s s i b l e "a. That may be suppressed.

Suppressing: S u p p r e s s i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Suppress

Suppression: S u p p r e s s i o n "n. The act of suppressing  or the state of being suppressed; repression; as the suppression of a riot insurrection or tumult; the suppression of truth of reports of evidence and the like.

Suppression: S u p p r e s s i o n "n. Complete stoppage of a natural secretion or excretion; as  suppression of urine; -- used in contradiction to retention which signifies that the secretion or excretion is retained without expulsion.

Suppression: S u p p r e s s i o n "n. Omission; as  the suppression of a word.

Suppressive: S u p p r e s s i v e "a. Tending to suppress; subduing; concealing.

Suppressor: S u p p r e s s o r "n. One who suppresses.

Supprise: S u p p r i s e "v. t. To surprise.

Suppurant: S u p p u r a n t "n. A suppurative.

Suppurate: S u p p u r a t e "v. i. To generate pus; as  a boil or abscess suppurates.

Suppurate: S u p p u r a t e "v. t. To cause to generate pus; as  to suppurate a sore.

Suppurated: S u p p u r a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Suppurate

Suppurating: S u p p u r a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Suppurate

Suppuration: S u p p u r a t i o n "n. The act or process of suppurating.

Suppuration: S u p p u r a t i o n "n. The matter produced by suppuration; pus.

Suppurative: S u p p u r a t i v e "a. Tending to suppurate; promoting suppuration.

Suppurative: S u p p u r a t i v e "n. A suppurative medicine.

Supputate: S u p p u t a t e "v. t. To suppute.

Supputation: S u p p u t a t i o n "n. Reckoning; account.

Suppute: S u p p u t e "v. t. To reckon; to compute; to suppose; to impute.

Supra: S u p r a "adv. Over; above; before; also  beyond; besides; -- much used as a prefix.

Supra-acromial: S u p r a - a c r o m i a l "a. Situated above the acromial process of the scapula.

Supra-angular: S u p r a - a n g u l a r "a. See Surangular.

Supra-auricular: S u p r a - a u r i c u l a r "a. Situated above the ear coverts  or auriculars; -- said of certain feathers of birds.

Supra-auricular: S u p r a - a u r i c u l a r "n. A supra-auricular feather.

Supra-axillary: S u p r a - a x i l l a r y "a. Growing above the axil; inserted above the axil  as a peduncle. See Suprafoliaceous.

Supra-esophagal: S u p r a - e s o p h a g a l "a. Alt. of Supra-esophageal

Supra-esophageal: S u p r a - e s o p h a g e a l "a. Situated above  or on the dorsal side of the esophagus; as the supra-esophageal ganglion of Crustacea.

Supra-ethmoid: S u p r a - e t h m o i d "a. Above  or on the dorsal side of the ethmoid bone or cartilage.

Supra-ilium: S u p r a - i l i u m "n. The cartilaginous cap at the sacral end of the ilium of some animals.

Supra-oesophagal: S u p r a - o e s o p h a g a l "a. See Supra-esophagal.

Suprabranchial: S u p r a b r a n c h i a l "a. Situated above the branchiae; -- applied especially to the upper division of the gill cavity of bivalve mollusks.

Suprachoroid: S u p r a c h o r o i d "a. Alt. of Suprachoroidal

Suprachoroidal: S u p r a c h o r o i d a l "a. Situated above the choroid; -- applied to the layer of the choroid coat of the eyeball next to the sclerotic.

Supraciliary: S u p r a c i l i a r y "a. Superciliary.

Supraclavicle: S u p r a c l a v i c l e "n. A bone which usually connects the clavicle with the post-temporal in the pectorial arch of fishes.

Supraclavicular: S u p r a c l a v i c u l a r "a. Situated above the clavicle.

Supraclavicular: S u p r a c l a v i c u l a r "a. Of or pertaining to the supraclavicle.

Supracondylar: S u p r a c o n d y l a r "a. Alt. of Supracondyloid

Supracondyloid: S u p r a c o n d y l o i d "a. Situated above a condyle or condyles.

Supracostal: S u p r a c o s t a l "a. Situated above  or on the outside of the ribs.

Supracranial: S u p r a c r a n i a l "a. Situated above  or in the roof of the cranium.

Supracretaceous: S u p r a c r e t a c e o u s "a. Lying above the chalk; Supercretaceous.

Supradecompound: S u p r a d e c o m p o u n d "a. More than decompound; divided many times.

Suprafoliaceous: S u p r a f o l i a c e o u s "a. Inserted into the stem above the leaf  petiole or axil as a peduncle or flower.

Supraglotic: S u p r a g l o t i c "a. Situated above the glottis; -- applied to that part of the cavity of the larynx above the true vocal cords.

Suprahepatic: S u p r a h e p a t i c "a. Situated over  or on the dorsal side of the liver; -- applied to the branches of the hepatic veins.

Suprahyoid: S u p r a h y o i d "a. Hyomental.

Supralapsarian: S u p r a l a p s a r i a n "n. One of that class of Calvinists who believed that God's decree of election determined that man should fall  in order that the opportunity might be furnished of securing the redemption of a part of the race the decree of salvation being conceived of as formed before or beyond and not after or following the lapse or fall. Cf. Infralapsarian.

Supralapsarian: S u p r a l a p s a r i a n "a. Of or pertaining to the Supralapsarians  or their doctrine.

Supralapsarianism: S u p r a l a p s a r i a n i s m "n. The doctrine  belief or principles of the Supralapsarians.

Supralapsary: S u p r a l a p s a r y "a. Supralapsarian.

Supralapsary: S u p r a l a p s a r y "n. A Supralapsarian.

Supraloral: S u p r a l o r a l "a. Situated above the lores; as  the supraloral feathers of a bird.

Supraloral: S u p r a l o r a l "n. A supraloral feather.

Supralunar: S u p r a l u n a r "a. Alt. of Supralunary

Supralunary: S u p r a l u n a r y "a. Beyond the moon; hence  very lofty.

Supramaxilla: S u p r a m a x i l l a "n. The upper jaw or maxilla.

Supramaxillae: S u p r a m a x i l l a e "pl. "of Supramaxilla

Supramaxillary: S u p r a m a x i l l a r y "a. Situated over the lower jaw; as  the supramaxillary nerve.

Supramaxillary: S u p r a m a x i l l a r y "a. Of or pertaining to the upper jaw.

Supramundane: S u p r a m u n d a n e "a. Being or situated above the world or above our system; celestial.

Supranaturalism: S u p r a n a t u r a l i s m "n. The state of being supernatural; belief in supernatural agency or revelation; supernaturalism.

Supranaturalist: S u p r a n a t u r a l i s t "n. A supernaturalist.

Supranaturalist: S u p r a n a t u r a l i s t "a. Alt. of Supranaturalistic

Supranaturalistic: S u p r a n a t u r a l i s t i c "a. Of or pertaining to supernaturalism; supernaturalistic.

Supraoccipital: S u p r a o c c i p i t a l "a. Situated over  or in the upper part of the occiput; of or pertaining to the supraoccipital bone.

Supraoccipital: S u p r a o c c i p i t a l "n. The supraoccipital bone.

Supraocular: S u p r a o c u l a r "a. Above the eyes; -- said of certain scales of fishes and reptiles.

Supraorbital: S u p r a o r b i t a l "a. Alt. of Supraorbitar

Supraorbitar: S u p r a o r b i t a r "a. Situated above the orbit of the eye.

Suprapedal: S u p r a p e d a l "a. Situated above the foot of a mollusk; as  the suprapedal gland.

Supraprotest: S u p r a p r o t e s t "n. An acceptance of a bill by a third person after protest for nonacceptance by the drawee.

Suprapubian: S u p r a p u b i a n "a. Alt. of Suprapubic

Suprapubic: S u p r a p u b i c "a. Situated above  or anterior to the pubic bone.

Suprarenal: S u p r a r e n a l "a. Situated above  or anterior to the kidneys.

Suprarenal: S u p r a r e n a l "n. A suprarenal capsule.

Suprascalpular: S u p r a s c a l p u l a r "a. Alt. of Suprascalpulary

Suprascalpulary: S u p r a s c a l p u l a r y "a. Situated above  or on the anterior side of the scapula.

Suprasphenoidal: S u p r a s p h e n o i d a l "a. Situated above the sphenoidal bone; as  the suprasphenoidal appendage or pituitary body.

Supraspinal: S u p r a s p i n a l "a. Situated above the vertebral column.

Supraspinal: S u p r a s p i n a l "a. Situated above a spine or spines; supraspinate; supraspinous.

Supraspinate: S u p r a s p i n a t e "a. Alt. of Supraspinous

Supraspinous: S u p r a s p i n o u s "a. Situated above a spine or spines; especially  situated above or on the dorsal side of the neural spines of the vertebral column or above or in front of the spine of the scapula.

Suprastapedial: S u p r a s t a p e d i a l "a. Of  pertaining to or designating that part of the columella of the ear which projects above the connection with the stapes as in many animals.

Suprastapedial: S u p r a s t a p e d i a l "n. The suprastapedial part of the columella.

Suprasternal: S u p r a s t e r n a l "a. Situated above  or anterior to the sternum.

Supratemporal: S u p r a t e m p o r a l "a. Situated above the temporal bone or temporal fossa.

Supratemporal: S u p r a t e m p o r a l "n. A supratemporal bone.

Supratrochlear: S u p r a t r o c h l e a r "a. Situated over or above a trochlea or trochlear surface; -- applied esp. to one of the subdivisions of the trigeminal nerve.

Supravaginal: S u p r a v a g i n a l "a. Situated above or outside a sheath or vaginal membrane.

Supravision: S u p r a v i s i o n "n. Supervision.

Supravisor: S u p r a v i s o r "n. A supervisor.

Supravulgar: S u p r a v u l g a r "a. Being above the vulgar or common people.

Supremacy: S u p r e m a c y "n. The state of being supreme  or in the highest station of power; highest or supreme authority or power; as the supremacy of a king or a parliament.

Supreme: S u p r e m e "a. Highest in authority; holding the highest place in authority  government or power.

Supreme: S u p r e m e "a. Highest; greatest; most excellent or most extreme; utmost; greatist possible (sometimes in a bad sense); as  supreme love; supreme glory; supreme magnanimity; supreme folly.

Supreme: S u p r e m e "a. Situated at the highest part or point.

Supremely: S u p r e m e l y "adv. In a supreme manner.

Supremity: S u p r e m i t y "n. Supremacy.

Sur-: S u r - " A prefix signifying over  above beyond upon.

Sura: S u r a "n. One of the sections or chapters of the Koran  which are one hundred and fourteen in number.

Suradanni: S u r a d a n n i "n. A valuable kind of wood obtained on the shores of the Demerara River in South America  much used for timbers rails naves and fellies of wheels and the like.

Suraddition: S u r a d d i t i o n "n. Something added or appended  as to a name.

Surah: S u r a h "n. A soft twilled silk fabric much used for women's dresses; -- called also surah silk.

Sural: S u r a l "a. Of or pertaining to the calf of the leg; as  the sural arteries.

Surance: S u r a n c e "n. Assurance.

Surangular: S u r a n g u l a r "a. Above the angular bone; supra-angular; -- applied to a bone of the lower jaw in many reptiles and birds.

Surangular: S u r a n g u l a r "n. The surangular bone.

Surbase: S u r b a s e "n. A cornice  or series of moldings on the top of the base of a pedestal podium etc. See Illust. of Column.

Surbase: S u r b a s e "n. A board or group of moldings running round a room on a level with the tops of the chair backs.

Surbased: S u r b a s e d "a. Having a surbase  or molding above the base.

Surbased: S u r b a s e d "a. Having the vertical height from springing line to crown less than the half span; -- said of an arch; as  a segmental arch is surbased.

Surbate: S u r b a t e "v. t. To make sore or bruise  as the feet by travel.

Surbate: S u r b a t e "v. t. To harass; to fatigue.

Surbated: S u r b a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Surbate

Surbating: S u r b a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Surbate

Surbeat: S u r b e a t "v. t. Same as Surbate.

Surbed: S u r b e d "v. t. To set edgewise  as a stone; that is to set it in a position different from that which it had in the quarry.

Surbedded: S u r b e d d e d "imp. & p. p. of Surbed

Surbedding: S u r b e d d i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Surbed

Surbet: S u r b e t "v. t. Same as Surbate.

Surbet: S u r b e t "a. Surbated; bruised.

Surcease: S u r c e a s e "n. Cessation; stop; end.

Surcease: S u r c e a s e "v. t. To cause to cease; to end.

Surcease: S u r c e a s e "v. i. To cease.

Surceaseance: S u r c e a s e a n c e "n. Cessation.

Surcharge: S u r c h a r g e "v. t. To overload; to overburden; to overmatch; to overcharge; as  to surcharge a beast or a ship; to surcharge a cannon.

Surcharge: S u r c h a r g e "v. t. To overstock; especially  to put more cattle into as a common than the person has a right to do or more than the herbage will sustain. Blackstone.

Surcharge: S u r c h a r g e "v. t. To show an omission in (an account) for which credit ought to have been given.

Surcharge: S u r c h a r g e "n. An overcharge; an excessive load or burden; a load greater than can well be borne.

Surcharge: S u r c h a r g e "n. The putting  by a commoner of more beasts on the common than he has a right to.

Surcharge: S u r c h a r g e "n. The showing an omission  as in an account for which credit ought to have been given.

Surcharged: S u r c h a r g e d "imp. & p. p. of Surcharge

Surchargement: S u r c h a r g e m e n t "n. The act of surcharging; also  surcharge surplus.

Surcharger: S u r c h a r g e r "n. One who surcharges.

Surcharging: S u r c h a r g i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Surcharge

Surcingle: S u r c i n g l e "n. A belt  band or girth which passes over a saddle or over anything laid on a horse's back to bind it fast.

Surcingle: S u r c i n g l e "n. The girdle of a cassock  by which it is fastened round the waist.

Surcingled: S u r c i n g l e d "a. Bound with the surcingle.

Surcle: S u r c l e "n. A little shoot; a twig; a sucker.

Surcloy: S u r c l o y "v. t. To surfeit.

Surcloyed: S u r c l o y e d "imp. & p. p. of Surcloy

Surcoat: S u r c o a t "n. A coat worn over the other garments; especially  the long and flowing garment of knights worn over the armor and frequently emblazoned with the arms of the wearer.

Surcoat: S u r c o a t "n. A name given to the outer garment of either sex at different epochs of the Middle Ages.

Surcrew: S u r c r e w "n. Increase; addition; surplus.

Surculate: S u r c u l a t e "v. t. To purne; to trim.

Surculation: S u r c u l a t i o n "n. Act of purning.

Surculose: S u r c u l o s e "a. Producing suckers  or shoots resembling suckers.

Surd: S u r d "a. Net having the sense of hearing; deaf.

Surd: S u r d "a. Unheard.

Surd: S u r d "a. Involving surds; not capable of being expressed in rational numbers; radical; irrational; as  a surd expression or quantity; a surd number.

Surd: S u r d "a. Uttered  as an element of speech without tone or proper vocal sound; voiceless; unintonated; nonvocal; atonic; whispered; aspirated; sharp; hard as f p s etc.; -- opposed to sonant. See Guide to Pronunciation //169 179 180.

Surd: S u r d "n. A quantity which can not be expressed by rational numbers; thus   2 is a surd.

Surd: S u r d "n. A surd element of speech. See Surd  a. 4.

Surdal: S u r d a l "a. Same as Surd  a. 3.

Surdiny: S u r d i n y "n. A sardine.

Surdity: S u r d i t y "n. Deafness.

Sure: S u r e "superl. Certainly knowing and believing; confident beyond doubt; implicity trusting; unquestioning; positive.

Sure: S u r e "superl. Certain to find or retain; as  to be sure of game; to be sure of success; to be sure of life or health.

Sure: S u r e "superl. Fit or worthy to be depended on; certain not to fail or disappoint expectation; unfailing; strong; permanent; enduring.

Sure: S u r e "superl. Betrothed; engaged to marry.

Sure: S u r e "superl. Free from danger; safe; secure.

Sure: S u r e "adv. In a sure manner; safely; certainly.

Sure-footed: S u r e - f o o t e d "a. Not liable to stumble or fall; as  a sure-footed horse.

Surely: S u r e l y "adv. In a sure or certain manner; certainly; infallibly; undoubtedly; assuredly.

Surely: S u r e l y "adv. Without danger; firmly; steadly; securely.

Surement: S u r e m e n t "n. A making sure; surety.

Sureness: S u r e n e s s "n. The state of being sure; certainty.

Suresby: S u r e s b y "n. One to be sure of  or to be relied on.

Sureties: S u r e t i e s "pl. "of Surety

Suretiship: S u r e t i s h i p "n. Suretyship.

Surety: S u r e t y "n. The state of being sure; certainty; security.

Surety: S u r e t y "n. That which makes sure; that which confirms; ground of confidence or security.

Surety: S u r e t y "n. Security against loss or damage; security for payment  or for the performance of some act.

Surety: S u r e t y "n. One who is bound with and for another who is primarily liable  and who is called the principal; one who engages to answer for another's appearance in court or for his payment of a debt or for performance of some act; a bondsman; a bail.

Surety: S u r e t y "n. Hence  a substitute; a hostage.

Surety: S u r e t y "n. Evidence; confirmation; warrant.

Surety: S u r e t y "v. t. To act as surety for.

Suretyship: S u r e t y s h i p "n. The state of being surety; the obligation of a person to answer for the debt  default or miscarriage of another.

Surf: S u r f "n. The swell of the sea which breaks upon the shore  esp. upon a sloping beach.

Surf: S u r f "n. The bottom of a drain.

Surface: S u r f a c e "n. The exterior part of anything that has length and breadth; one of the limits that bound a solid  esp. the upper face; superficies; the outside; as the surface of the earth; the surface of a diamond; the surface of the body.

Surface: S u r f a c e "n. Hence  outward or external appearance.

Surface: S u r f a c e "n. A magnitude that has length and breadth without thickness; superficies; as  a plane surface; a spherical surface.

Surface: S u r f a c e "n. That part of the side which is terminated by the flank prolonged  and the angle of the nearest bastion.

Surface: S u r f a c e "v. t. To give a surface to; especially  to cause to have a smooth or plain surface; to make smooth or plain.

Surface: S u r f a c e "v. t. To work over the surface or soil of  as ground in hunting for gold.

Surfboat: S u r f b o a t "n. A boat intended for use in heavy surf. It is built with a pronounced sheer  and with a view to resist the shock of waves and of contact with the beach.

Surfeit: S u r f e i t "n. Excess in eating and drinking.

Surfeit: S u r f e i t "n. Fullness and oppression of the system  occasioned often by excessive eating and drinking.

Surfeit: S u r f e i t "n. Disgust caused by excess; satiety.

Surfeit: S u r f e i t "v. i. To load the stomach with food  so that sickness or uneasiness ensues; to eat to excess.

Surfeit: S u r f e i t "v. i. To indulge to satiety in any gratification.

Surfeit: S u r f e i t "v. t. To feed so as to oppress the stomach and derange the function of the system; to overfeed  and produce satiety sickness or uneasiness; -- often reflexive; as to surfeit one's self with sweets.

Surfeit: S u r f e i t "v. t. To fill to satiety and disgust; to cloy; as  he surfeits us with compliments.

Surgeon: S u r g e o n "n. One whose profession or occupation is to cure diseases or injuries of the body by manual operation; one whose occupation is to cure local injuries or disorders (such as wounds  dislocations tumors etc.) whether by manual operation or by medication and constitutional treatment.

Surgeon: S u r g e o n "n. Any one of numerous species of chaetodont fishes of the family Teuthidae  or Acanthuridae which have one or two sharp lancelike spines on each side of the base of the tail. Called also surgeon fish doctor fish lancet fish and sea surgeon.

Suspect: S u s p e c t "a. Suspected; distrusted.

Suspect: S u s p e c t "a. Suspicion.

Suspect: S u s p e c t "a. One who  or that which is suspected; an object of suspicion; -- formerly applied to persons and things; now only to persons suspected of crime.

Suspect: S u s p e c t "v. t. To imagine to exist; to have a slight or vague opinion of the existence of  without proof and often upon weak evidence or no evidence; to mistrust; to surmise; -- commonly used regarding something unfavorable hurtful or wrong; as to suspect the presence of disease.

Suspect: S u s p e c t "v. t. To imagine to be guilty  upon slight evidence or without proof; as to suspect one of equivocation.

Suspect: S u s p e c t "v. t. To hold to be uncertain; to doubt; to mistrust; to distruct; as  to suspect the truth of a story.

Suspect: S u s p e c t "v. t. To look up to; to respect.

Suspect: S u s p e c t "v. i. To imagine guilt; to have a suspicion or suspicions; to be suspicious.

Suspectable: S u s p e c t a b l e "a. That may be suspected.

Suspected: S u s p e c t e d "imp. & p. p. of Suspect

Suspected: S u s p e c t e d "a. Distrusted; doubted.

Suspecter: S u s p e c t e r "n. One who suspects.

Suspectful: S u s p e c t f u l "a. Apt to suspect or mistrust; full of suspicion; suspicious; as  to be suspectful of the motives of others.

Suspecting: S u s p e c t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Suspect

Suspection: S u s p e c t i o n "n. Suspicion.

Suspectiousness: S u s p e c t i o u s n e s s "n. Suspiciousness; cause for suspicion.

Suspectless: S u s p e c t l e s s "a. Not suspecting; having no suspicion.

Suspectless: S u s p e c t l e s s "a. Not suspected; not mistrusted.

Suspend: S u s p e n d "n. To attach to something above; to hang; as  to suspend a ball by a thread; to suspend a needle by a loadstone.

Suspend: S u s p e n d "n. To make to depend; as  God hath suspended the promise of eternal life on the condition of obedience and holiness of life.

Suspend: S u s p e n d "n. To cause to cease for a time; to hinder from proceeding; to interrupt; to delay; to stay.

Suspend: S u s p e n d "n. To hold in an undetermined or undecided state; as  to suspend one's judgment or opinion.

Suspend: S u s p e n d "n. To debar  or cause to withdraw temporarily from any privilege from the execution of an office from the enjoyment of income etc.; as to suspend a student from college; to suspend a member of a club.

Suspend: S u s p e n d "n. To cause to cease for a time from operation or effect; as  to suspend the habeas corpus act; to suspend the rules of a legislative body.

Suspend: S u s p e n d "n. To support in a liquid  as an insoluble powder by stirring to facilitate chemical action.

Suspend: S u s p e n d "v. i. To cease from operation or activity; esp.  to stop payment or be unable to meet obligations or engagements (said of a commercial firm or a bank).

Suspended: S u s p e n d e d "imp. & p. p. of Suspend

Suspender: S u s p e n d e r "n. One who  or that which suspends; esp. one of a pair of straps or braces worn over the shoulders for holding up the trousers.

Suspending: S u s p e n d i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Suspend

Suspensation: S u s p e n s a t i o n "n. The act of suspending  or the state of being suspended especially for a short time; temporary suspension.

Suspense: S u s p e n s e "a. Held or lifted up; held or prevented from proceeding.

Suspense: S u s p e n s e "a. Expressing  or proceeding from suspense or doubt.

Suspense: S u s p e n s e "a. The state of being suspended; specifically  a state of uncertainty and expectation with anxiety or apprehension; indetermination; indecision; as the suspense of a person waiting for the verdict of a jury.

Suspense: S u s p e n s e "a. Cessation for a time; stop; pause.

Suspense: S u s p e n s e "a. A temporary cessation of one's right; suspension  as when the rent or other profits of land cease by unity of possession of land and rent.

Suspensely: S u s p e n s e l y "adv. In suspense.

Suspensibility: S u s p e n s i b i l i t y "n. The quality or state of being suspensible.

Suspensible: S u s p e n s i b l e "a. Capable of being suspended; capable of being held from sinking.

Suspension: S u s p e n s i o n "n. The act of suspending  or the state of being suspended; pendency; as suspension from a hook.

Suspension: S u s p e n s i o n "n. Especially  temporary delay interruption or cessation

Suspension: S u s p e n s i o n "n. Of labor  study pain etc.

Suspension: S u s p e n s i o n "n. Of decision  determination judgment etc.; as to ask a suspension of judgment or opinion in view of evidence to be produced.

Suspension: S u s p e n s i o n "n. Of the payment of what is due; as  the suspension of a mercantile firm or of a bank.

Suspension: S u s p e n s i o n "n. Of punishment  or sentence of punishment.

Suspension: S u s p e n s i o n "n. Of a person in respect of the exercise of his office  powers prerogative etc.; as the suspension of a student or of a clergyman.

Suspension: S u s p e n s i o n "n. Of the action or execution of law  etc.; as the suspension of the habeas corpus act.

Suspension: S u s p e n s i o n "n. A conditional withholding  interruption or delay; as the suspension of a payment on the performance of a condition.

Suspension: S u s p e n s i o n "n. The state of a solid when its particles are mixed with  but undissolved in a fluid and are capable of separation by straining; also any substance in this state.

Suspension: S u s p e n s i o n "n. A keeping of the hearer in doubt and in attentive expectation of what is to follow  or of what is to be the inference or conclusion from the arguments or observations employed.

Suspension: S u s p e n s i o n "n. A stay or postponement of execution of a sentence condemnatory by means of letters of suspension granted on application to the lord ordinary.

Suspension: S u s p e n s i o n "n. The prolongation of one or more tones of a chord into the chord which follows  thus producing a momentary discord suspending the concord which the ear expects. Cf. Retardation.

Suspensive: S u s p e n s i v e "a. Tending to suspend  or to keep in suspense; causing interruption or delay; uncertain; doubtful.

Suspensor: S u s p e n s o r "n. A suspensory.

Suspensor: S u s p e n s o r "n. The cord which suspends the embryo; and which is attached to the radicle in the young state; the proembryo.

Suspensoria: S u s p e n s o r i a "pl. "of Suspensorium

Suspensorium: S u s p e n s o r i u m "n. Anything which suspends or holds up a part: especially  the mandibular suspensorium (a series of bones or of cartilages representing them) which connects the base of the lower jaw with the skull in most vertebrates below mammals.

Suspensory: S u s p e n s o r y "a. Suspended; hanging; depending.

Suspensory: S u s p e n s o r y "a. Fitted or serving to suspend; suspending; as  a suspensory muscle.

Suspensory: S u s p e n s o r y "a. Of or pertaining to a suspensorium.

Suspensory: S u s p e n s o r y "n. That which suspends  or holds up as a truss

Suspensory: S u s p e n s o r y "n. a bandage or bag for supporting the scrotum.

Suspicable: S u s p i c a b l e "v. t. Liable to suspicion; suspicious.

Suspiciency: S u s p i c i e n c y "v. t. Suspiciousness; suspicion.

Suspicion: S u s p i c i o n "n. The act of suspecting; the imagination or apprehension of the existence of something (esp. something wrong or hurtful) without proof  or upon very slight evidence or upon no evidence.

Suspicion: S u s p i c i o n "n. Slight degree; suggestion; hint.

Suspicion: S u s p i c i o n "v. t. To view with suspicion; to suspect; to doubt.

Suspicious: S u s p i c i o u s "a. Inclined to suspect; given or prone to suspicion; apt to imagine without proof.

Suspicious: S u s p i c i o u s "a. Indicating suspicion  mistrust or fear.

Suspicious: S u s p i c i o u s "a. Liable to suspicion; adapted to raise suspicion; giving reason to imagine ill; questionable; as  an author of suspicious innovations; suspicious circumstances.

Suspiral: S u s p i r a l "n. A breathing hole; a vent or ventiduct.

Suspiral: S u s p i r a l "n. A spring of water passing under ground toward a cistern or conduit.

Suspiration: S u s p i r a t i o n "n. The act of sighing  or fetching a long and deep breath; a deep respiration; a sigh.

Suspire: S u s p i r e "v. i. To fetch a long  deep breath; to sigh; to breathe.

Suspire: S u s p i r e "n. A long  deep breath; a sigh.

Suspired: S u s p i r e d "a. Ardently desired or longed for; earnestly coveted.

Sustain: S u s t a i n "v. t. To keep from falling; to bear; to uphold; to support; as  a foundation sustains the superstructure; a beast sustains a load; a rope sustains a weight.

Sustain: S u s t a i n "v. t. Hence  to keep from sinking as in despondence or the like; to support.

Sustain: S u s t a i n "v. t. To maintain; to keep alive; to support; to subsist; to nourish; as  provisions to sustain an army.

Sustain: S u s t a i n "v. t. To aid  comfort or relieve; to vindicate.

Sustain: S u s t a i n "v. t. To endure without failing or yielding; to bear up under; as  to sustain defeat and disappointment.

Sustain: S u s t a i n "v. t. To suffer; to bear; to undergo.

Sustain: S u s t a i n "v. t. To allow the prosecution of; to admit as valid; to sanction; to continue; not to dismiss or abate; as  the court sustained the action or suit.

Sustain: S u s t a i n "v. t. To prove; to establish by evidence; to corroborate or confirm; to be conclusive of; as  to sustain a charge an accusation or a proposition.

Sustain: S u s t a i n "n. One who  or that which upholds or sustains; a sustainer.

Sustainable: S u s t a i n a b l e "a. Capable of being sustained or maintained; as  the action is not sustainable.

Sustained: S u s t a i n e d "imp. & p. p. of Sustain

Sustained: S u s t a i n e d "a. Held up to a certain pitch  degree or level; uniform; as sustained pasion; a sustained style of writing; a sustained note in music.

Sustainer: S u s t a i n e r "n. One who  or that which sustains.

Sustaining: S u s t a i n i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Sustain

Sustainment: S u s t a i n m e n t "n. The act of sustaining; maintenance; support.

Sustaltic: S u s t a l t i c "a. Mournful; -- said of a species of music among the ancient Greeks.

Sustenance: S u s t e n a n c e "n. The act of sustaining; support; maintenance; subsistence; as  the sustenance of the body; the sustenance of life.

Sustenance: S u s t e n a n c e "n. That which supports life; food; victuals; provisions; means of living; as  the city has ample sustenance.

Sustentacle: S u s t e n t a c l e "n. Sustenance.

Sustentacular: S u s t e n t a c u l a r "a. Supporting; sustaining; as  a sustentacular tissue.

Sustentate: S u s t e n t a t e "v. t. To sustain.

Sustentation: S u s t e n t a t i o n "n. The act of sustaining  or the state of being sustained; preservation from falling; support; sustenance; maintenance.

Sustentation: S u s t e n t a t i o n "n. The aggregate of the functions by which a living organism is maintained in a normal condition of weight and growth.

Sustentative: S u s t e n t a t i v e "a. Adapted to sustain  strengthen or corroborate; as sustentative citations or quotations.

Sustention: S u s t e n t i o n "n. Sustentation.

Susurrant: S u s u r r a n t "a. Whispering.

Susurration: S u s u r r a t i o n "n. A whispering; a soft murmur.
