Sutile: S u t i l e "a. Done by stitching.

Sutler: S u t l e r "n. A person who follows an army  and sells to the troops provisions liquors and the like.

Sutlership: S u t l e r s h i p "n. The condition or occupation of a sutler.

Sutling: S u t l i n g "a. Belonging to sutlers; engaged in the occupation of a sutler.

Sutor: S u t o r "n. A kind of sirup made by the Indians of Arizona from the fruit of some cactaceous plant (probably the Cereus giganteus).

Sutra: S u t r a "n. A precept; an aphorism; a brief rule.

Sutra: S u t r a "n. A collection of such aphorisms.

Sutra: S u t r a "n. A body of Hindoo literature containing aphorisms on grammar  meter law and philosophy and forming a connecting link between the Vedic and later Sanscrit literature.

Sutras: S u t r a s "pl. "of Sutra

Suttee: S u t t e e "n. A Hindoo widow who immolates herself  or is immolated on the funeral pile of her husband; -- so called because this act of self-immolation is regarded as envincing excellence of wifely character.

Suttee: S u t t e e "n. The act of burning a widow on the funeral pile of her husband.

Sutteeism: S u t t e e i s m "n. The practice of self-immolation of widows in Hindostan.

Suttle: S u t t l e "n. The weight when the tare has been deducted  and tret is yet to be allowed.

Suttle: S u t t l e "v. i. To act as sutler; to supply provisions and other articles to troops.

Sutural: S u t u r a l "a. Of or pertaining to a suture  or seam.

Sutural: S u t u r a l "a. Taking place at a suture; as  a sutural de/iscence.

Suturally: S u t u r a l l y "adv. In a sutural manner.

Suturated: S u t u r a t e d "a. Sewed or knit together; united by a suture; stitched.

Suture: S u t u r e "n. The act of sewing; also  the line along which two things or parts are sewed together or are united so as to form a seam or that which resembles a seam.

Suture: S u t u r e "n. The uniting of the parts of a wound by stitching.

Suture: S u t u r e "n. The stitch by which the parts are united.

Suture: S u t u r e "n. The line of union  or seam in an immovable articulation like those between the bones of the skull; also such an articulation itself; synarthrosis. See Harmonic suture under Harmonic.

Suture: S u t u r e "n. The line  or seam formed by the union of two margins in any part of a plant; as the ventral suture of a legume.

Suture: S u t u r e "n. A line resembling a seam; as  the dorsal suture of a legume which really corresponds to a midrib.

Suture: S u t u r e "n. The line at which the elytra of a beetle meet and are sometimes confluent.

Suture: S u t u r e "n. A seam  or impressed line as between the segments of a crustacean or between the whorls of a univalve shell.

Sutured: S u t u r e d "a. Having a suture or sutures; knit or united together.

Suwarrow: S u w a r r o w "n. The giant cactus (Cereus giganteus); -- so named by the Indians of Arizona. Called also saguaro.

Suzerain: S u z e r a i n "n. A superior lord  to whom fealty is due; a feudal lord; a lord paramount.

Suzerainty: S u z e r a i n t y "n. The dominion or authority of a suzerain; paramount authority.

Swab: S w a b "n. To clean with a mop or swab; to wipe when very wet  as after washing; as to swab the desk of a ship.

Swab: S w a b "n. A kind of mop for cleaning floors  the desks of vessels etc. esp. one made of rope-yarns or threads.

Swab: S w a b "n. A bit of sponge  cloth or the like fastened to a handle for cleansing the mouth of a sick person applying medicaments to deep-seated parts etc.

Swab: S w a b "n. An epaulet.

Swab: S w a b "n. A cod  or pod as of beans or pease.

Swab: S w a b "n. A sponge  or other suitable substance attached to a long rod or handle for cleaning the bore of a firearm.

Swabber: S w a b b e r "n. One who swabs a floor or desk.

Swabber: S w a b b e r "n. Formerly  an interior officer on board of British ships of war whose business it was to see that the ship was kept clean.

Swad: S w a d "n. A thin layer of refuse at the bottom of a seam.

Swaddle: S w a d d l e "n. Anything used to swaddle with  as a cloth or band; a swaddling band.

Swaddle: S w a d d l e "v. t. To bind as with a bandage; to bind or warp tightly with clothes; to swathe; -- used esp. of infants; as  to swaddle a baby.

Swag: S w a g "n. A swaying  irregular motion.

Swag: S w a g "n. A burglar's or thief's booty; boodle.

Swag-bellied: S w a g - b e l l i e d "a. Having a prominent  overhanging belly.

Swagbelly: S w a g b e l l y "n. A prominent  overhanging belly.

Swagbelly: S w a g b e l l y "n. Any large tumor developed in the abdomen  and neither fluctuating nor sonorous.

Swage: S w a g e "v. t. & i. See Assuage.

Swage: S w a g e "n. A tool  variously shaped or grooved on the end or face used by blacksmiths and other workers in metals for shaping their work whether sheet metal or forging by holding the swage upon the work or the work upon the swage and striking with a sledge.

Swage: S w a g e "v. t. To shape by means of a swage; to fashion  as a piece of iron by forcing it into a groove or mold having the required shape.

Swaged: S w a g e d "imp. & p. p. of Swage

Swagger: S w a g g e r "v. i. To boast or brag noisily; to be ostentatiously proud or vainglorious; to bluster; to bully.

Swagger: S w a g g e r "v. t. To bully.

Swagger: S w a g g e r "n. The act or manner of a swaggerer.

Swain: S w a i n "n. A servant.

Swain: S w a i n "n. A young man dwelling in the country; a rustic; esp.  a cuntry gallant or lover; -- chiefly in poetry.

Swainish: S w a i n i s h "a. Pertaining to  or resembling a swain; rustic; ignorant.

Swainling: S w a i n l i n g "n. A little swain.

Swainmote: S w a i n m o t e "n. A court held before the verders of the forest as judges  by the steward of the court thrice every year the swains or freeholders within the forest composing the jury.

Swainship: S w a i n s h i p "n. The condition of a swain.

Swal: S w a l "imp. Swelled.

Swale: S w a l e "n. A valley or low place; a tract of low  and usually wet land; a moor; a fen.

Swale: S w a l e "v. i. & t. To melt and waste away; to singe. See Sweal  v.

Swale: S w a l e "n. A gutter in a candle.

Swallet: S w a l l e t "n. Water breaking in upon the miners at their work; -- so called among tin miners.

Swallow: S w a l l o w "n. Any one of numerous species of passerine birds of the family Hirundinidae  especially one of those species in which the tail is deeply forked. They have long pointed wings and are noted for the swiftness and gracefulness of their flight.

Swallow: S w a l l o w "n. Any one of numerous species of swifts which resemble the true swallows in form and habits  as the common American chimney swallow or swift.

Swallow: S w a l l o w "n. The aperture in a block through which the rope reeves.

Swallow: S w a l l o w "v. t. To take into the stomach; to receive through the gullet  or esophagus into the stomach; as to swallow food or drink.

Swallow: S w a l l o w "v. t. To draw into an abyss or gulf; to ingulf; to absorb -- usually followed by up.

Swallow: S w a l l o w "v. t. To receive or embrace  as opinions or belief without examination or scruple; to receive implicitly.

Swallow: S w a l l o w "v. t. To engross; to appropriate; -- usually with up.

Swallow: S w a l l o w "v. t. To occupy; to take up; to employ.

Swallow: S w a l l o w "v. t. To seize and waste; to exhaust; to consume.

Swallow: S w a l l o w "v. t. To retract; to recant; as  to swallow one's opinions.

Swallow: S w a l l o w "v. t. To put up with; to bear patiently or without retaliation; as  to swallow an affront or insult.

Swallow: S w a l l o w "v. i. To perform the act of swallowing; as  his cold is so severe he is unable to swallow.

Swallow: S w a l l o w "n. The act of swallowing.

Swallow: S w a l l o w "n. The gullet  or esophagus; the throat.

Swallow: S w a l l o w "n. Taste; relish; inclination; liking.

Swallow: S w a l l o w "n. Capacity for swallowing; voracity.

Swallow: S w a l l o w "n. As much as is  or can be swallowed at once; as a swallow of water.

Swallow: S w a l l o w "n. That which ingulfs; a whirlpool.

Swallow-tailed: S w a l l o w - t a i l e d "a. Having a tail like that of a swallow; hence  like a swallow's tail in form; having narrow and tapering or pointed skirts; as a swallow-tailed coat.

Swallow-tailed: S w a l l o w - t a i l e d "a. United by dovetailing; dovetailed.

Swallowed: S w a l l o w e d "imp. & p. p. of Swallow

Swallower: S w a l l o w e r "n. One who swallows; also  a glutton.

Swallowfish: S w a l l o w f i s h "n. The European sapphirine gurnard (Trigla hirundo). It has large pectoral fins.

Swallowing: S w a l l o w i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Swallow

Swallowtail: S w a l l o w t a i l "n. A kind of tenon or tongue used in making joints. See Dovetail.

Swallowtail: S w a l l o w t a i l "n. A species of willow.

Swallowtail: S w a l l o w t a i l "n. An outwork with converging sides  its head or front forming a reentrant angle; -- so called from its form. Called also priestcap.

Swallowtail: S w a l l o w t a i l "n. A swallow-tailed coat.

Swallowtail: S w a l l o w t a i l "n. An arrow.

Swallowtail: S w a l l o w t a i l "n. Any one of numerous species of large and handsome butterflies  belonging to Papilio and allied genera in which the posterior border of each hind wing is prolongated in the form of a long lobe.

Swallowwort: S w a l l o w w o r t "n. See Celandine.

Swallowwort: S w a l l o w w o r t "n. A poisonous plant (Vincetoxicum officinale) of the Milkweed family  at one time used in medicine; -- also called white swallowwort.

Swamp: S w a m p "n. Wet  spongy land; soft low ground saturated with water but not usually covered with it; marshy ground away from the seashore.

Swamp: S w a m p "v. t. To plunge or sink into a swamp.

Swamp: S w a m p "v. t. To cause (a boat) to become filled with water; to capsize or sink by whelming with water.

Swamp: S w a m p "v. t. Fig.: To plunge into difficulties and perils; to overwhelm; to ruin; to wreck.

Swamp: S w a m p "v. i. To sink or stick in a swamp; figuratively  to become involved in insuperable difficulties.

Swamp: S w a m p "v. i. To become filled with water  as a boat; to founder; to capsize or sink; figuratively to be ruined; to be wrecked.

Swamped: S w a m p e d "imp. & p. p. of Swamp

Swamping: S w a m p i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Swamp

Swampy: S w a m p y "a. Consisting of swamp; like a swamp; low  wet and spongy; as swampy land.

Swan: S w a n "n. Any one of numerous species of large aquatic birds belonging to Cygnus  Olor and allied genera of the subfamily Cygninae. They have a large and strong beak and a long neck and are noted for their graceful movements when swimming. Most of the northern species are white. In literature the swan was fabled to sing a melodious song especially at the time of its death.

Swan: S w a n "n. Fig.: An appellation for a sweet singer  or a poet noted for grace and melody; as Shakespeare is called the swan of Avon.

Swan: S w a n "n. The constellation Cygnus.

Swan-hopping: S w a n - h o p p i n g "n. A corruption of Swan-upping.

Swan-upping: S w a n - u p p i n g "n. A yearly expedition on the Thames to take up young swans and mark them  as by Companies of Dyers and Vintners; -- called also swan-hopping.

Swan's-down: S w a n ' s - d o w n "n. Alt. of Swans-down

Swang: S w a n g "n. A swamp.

Swang: S w a n g "Archaic imp. of Swing

Swank: S w a n k "imp. of Swink

Swanky: S w a n k y "n. An active and clever young fellow.

Swanlike: S w a n l i k e "a. Resembling a swan.

Swanmark: S w a n m a r k "n. A mark of ownership cut on the bill or swan.

Swannery: S w a n n e r y "n. A place where swans are bred.

Swanny: S w a n n y "a. Swanlike; as  a swanny glossiness of the neck.

Swanpan: S w a n p a n "n. The Chinese abacus; a schwanpan.

Swans-down: S w a n s - d o w n "n. The down  or fine soft feathers of the swan used on various articles of dress.

Swans-down: S w a n s - d o w n "n. A fine  soft thick cloth of wool mixed with silk or cotton; a sort of twilled fustian like moleskin.

Swanskin: S w a n s k i n "n. The act of a swan with the down or the feathers on.

Swanskin: S w a n s k i n "n. A species of soft flannel  thick and warm.

Swarm: S w a r m "v. i. To climb a tree  pole or the like by embracing it with the arms and legs alternately. See Shin.

Swarm: S w a r m "n. A large number or mass of small animals or insects  especially when in motion.

Swarm: S w a r m "n. Especially  a great number of honeybees which emigrate from a hive at once and seek new lodgings under the direction of a queen; a like body of bees settled permanently in a hive.

Swarm: S w a r m "n. Hence  any great number or multitude as of people in motion or sometimes of inanimate objects; as a swarm of meteorites.

Swarm: S w a r m "v. i. To collect  and depart from a hive by flight in a body; -- said of bees; as bees swarm in warm clear days in summer.

Swarm: S w a r m "v. i. To appear or collect in a crowd; to throng together; to congregate in a multitude.

Swarm: S w a r m "v. i. To be crowded; to be thronged with a multitude of beings in motion.

Swarm: S w a r m "v. i. To abound; to be filled (with).

Swarm: S w a r m "v. i. To breed multitudes.

Swarm: S w a r m "v. t. To crowd or throng.

Swarmed: S w a r m e d "imp. & p. p. of Swarm

Swarmspore: S w a r m s p o r e "n. One of innumerable minute  motile reproductive bodies produced asexually by certain algae and fungi; a zoospore.

Swarmspore: S w a r m s p o r e "n. One of the minute flagellate germs produced by the sporulation of a protozoan; -- called also zoospore.

Swash: S w a s h "v. t. Soft  like fruit too ripe; swashy.

Swash: S w a s h "n. Impulse of water flowing with violence; a dashing or splashing of water.

Swash: S w a s h "n. A narrow sound or channel of water lying within a sand bank  or between a sand bank and the shore or a bar over which the sea washes.

Swash: S w a s h "n. Liquid filth; wash; hog mash.

Sway: S w a y "v. i. To move or wield with the hand; to swing; to wield; as  to sway the scepter.

Sway: S w a y "v. i. To influence or direct by power and authority; by persuasion  or by moral force; to rule; to govern; to guide.

Sway: S w a y "v. i. To cause to incline or swing to one side  or backward and forward; to bias; to turn; to bend; warp; as reeds swayed by wind; judgment swayed by passion.

Sway: S w a y "v. i. To hoist; as  to sway up the yards.

Sway: S w a y "v. i. To be drawn to one side by weight or influence; to lean; to incline.

Sway: S w a y "v. i. To move or swing from side to side; or backward and forward.

Sway: S w a y "v. i. To have weight or influence.

Sway: S w a y "v. i. To bear sway; to rule; to govern.

Sway: S w a y "n. The act of swaying; a swaying motion; the swing or sweep of a weapon.

Sway: S w a y "n. Influence  weight or authority that inclines to one side; as the sway of desires.

Sway: S w a y "n. Preponderance; turn or cast of balance.

Sway: S w a y "n. Rule; dominion; control.

Sway: S w a y "n. A switch or rod used by thatchers to bind their work.

Sway-backed: S w a y - b a c k e d "a. Having the back hollow or sagged  whether naturally or as the result of injury or weakness; -- said of horses and other animals.

Sway-bracing: S w a y - b r a c i n g "n. The horizontal bracing of a bridge  which prevents its swaying.

Swaying: S w a y i n g "n. An injury caused by violent strains or by overloading; -- said of the backs of horses.

Sweal: S w e a l "v. i. To melt and run down  as the tallow of a candle; to waste away without feeding the flame.

Swear: S w e a r "v. i. To affirm or utter a solemn declaration  with an appeal to God for the truth of what is affirmed; to make a promise threat or resolve on oath; also to affirm solemnly by some sacred object or one regarded as sacred as the Bible the Koran etc.

Swear: S w e a r "v. i. To give evidence on oath; as  to swear to the truth of a statement; he swore against the prisoner.

Swear: S w e a r "v. i. To make an appeal to God in an irreverant manner; to use the name of God or sacred things profanely; to call upon God in imprecation; to curse.

Swear: S w e a r "v. t. To utter or affirm with a solemn appeal to God for the truth of the declaration; to make (a promise  threat or resolve) under oath.

Swear: S w e a r "v. t. To put to an oath; to cause to take an oath; to administer an oath to; -- ofetn followed by in or into; as  to swear witnesses; to swear a jury; to swear in an officer; he was sworn into office.

Swear: S w e a r "v. t. To declare or charge upon oath; as  he swore treason against his friend.

Swear: S w e a r "v. t. To appeal to by an oath.

Swearer: S w e a r e r "n. One who swears; one who calls God to witness for the truth of his declaration.

Swearer: S w e a r e r "n. A profane person; one who uses profane language.

Swearing: S w e a r i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Swear

Sweat: S w e a t "imp. & p. p. of Sweat

Sweat: S w e a t "v. i. To excrete sensible moisture from the pores of the skin; to perspire.

Sweat: S w e a t "v. i. Fig.: To perspire in toil; to work hard; to drudge.

Sweat: S w e a t "v. i. To emit moisture  as green plants in a heap.

Sweat: S w e a t "v. t. To cause to excrete moisture from the skin; to cause to perspire; as  his physicians attempted to sweat him by most powerful sudorifics.

Sweat: S w e a t "v. t. To emit or suffer to flow from the pores; to exude.

Sweat: S w e a t "v. t. To unite by heating  after the application of soldier.

Sweat: S w e a t "v. t. To get something advantageous  as money property or labor from (any one) by exaction or oppression; as to sweat a spendthrift; to sweat laborers.

Sweat: S w e a t "v. i. The fluid which is excreted from the skin of an animal; the fluid secreted by the sudoriferous glands; a transparent  colorless acid liquid with a peculiar odor containing some fatty acids and mineral matter; perspiration. See Perspiration.

Sweat: S w e a t "v. i. The act of sweating; or the state of one who sweats; hence  labor; toil; drudgery.

Sweat: S w e a t "v. i. Moisture issuing from any substance; as  the sweat of hay or grain in a mow or stack.

Sweat: S w e a t "v. i. The sweating sickness.

Sweat: S w e a t "v. i. A short run by a race horse in exercise.

Sweated: S w e a t e d " of Sweat

Sweater: S w e a t e r "n. One who sweats.

Sweater: S w e a t e r "n. One who  or that which causes to sweat

Sweater: S w e a t e r "n. A sudorific.

Sweater: S w e a t e r "n. A woolen jacket or jersey worn by athletes.

Sweater: S w e a t e r "n. An employer who oppresses his workmen by paying low wages.

Sweatily: S w e a t i l y "adv. In a sweaty manner.

Sweatiness: S w e a t i n e s s "n. Quality or state of being sweaty.

Sweating: S w e a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Sweat

Sweating: S w e a t i n g " a. & n. from Sweat  v.

Sweaty: S w e a t y "superl. Moist with sweat; as  a sweaty skin; a sweaty garment.

Sweaty: S w e a t y "superl. Consisting of sweat; of the nature of sweat.

Sweaty: S w e a t y "superl. Causing sweat; hence  laborious; toilsome; difficult.

Swede: S w e d e "n. A native or inhabitant of Sweden.

Swede: S w e d e "n. A Swedish turnip. See under Turnip.

Swedenborgian: S w e d e n b o r g i a n "n. One who holds the doctrines of the New Jerusalem church  as taught by Emanuel Swedenborg a Swedish philosopher and religious writer who was born a. d. 1688 and died 1772. Swedenborg claimed to have intercourse with the spiritual world through the opening of his spiritual senses in 1745. He taught that the Lord Jesus Christ as comprehending in himself all the fullness of the Godhead is the one only God and that there is a spiritual sense to the Scriptures which he (Swedenborg) was able to reveal because he saw the correspondence between natural and spiritual things.

Swedenborgian: S w e d e n b o r g i a n "a. Of or pertaining to Swedenborg or his views.

Swedenborgianism: S w e d e n b o r g i a n i s m "n. The doctrines of the Swedenborgians.

Swedish: S w e d i s h "a. Of or pertaining to Sweden or its inhabitants.

Swedish: S w e d i s h "n. The language of Swedes.

Sweeny: S w e e n y "n. An atrophy of the muscles of the shoulder in horses; also  atrophy of any muscle in horses.

Sweep: S w e e p "v. i. To pass a broom across (a surface) so as to remove loose dirt  dust etc.; to brush or rub over with a broom for the purpose of cleaning; as to sweep a floor the street or a chimney. Used also figuratively.

Sweep: S w e e p "v. i. To drive or carry along or off with a broom or a brush  or as if with a broom; to remove by or as if by brushing; as to sweep dirt from a floor; the wind sweeps the snow from the hills; a freshet sweeps away a dam timber or rubbish; a pestilence sweeps off multitudes.

Sweep: S w e e p "v. i. To brush against or over; to rub lightly along.

Sweep: S w e e p "v. i. To carry with a long  swinging or dragging motion; hence to carry in a stately or proud fashion.

Sweep: S w e e p "v. i. To strike with a long stroke.

Sweep: S w e e p "v. i. To draw or drag something over; as  to sweep the bottom of a river with a net.

Sweep: S w e e p "v. i. To pass over  or traverse with the eye or with an instrument of observation; as to sweep the heavens with a telescope.

Sweep: S w e e p "v. i. To clean rooms  yards etc. or to clear away dust dirt litter etc. with a broom brush or the like.

Sweep: S w e e p "v. i. To brush swiftly over the surface of anything; to pass with switness and force  as if brushing the surface of anything; to move in a stately manner; as the wind sweeps across the plain; a woman sweeps through a drawing-room.

Sweep: S w e e p "v. i. To pass over anything comprehensively; to range through with rapidity; as  his eye sweeps through space.

Sweep: S w e e p "n. The act of sweeping.

Sweep: S w e e p "n. The compass or range of a stroke; as  a long sweep.

Sweep: S w e e p "n. The compass of any turning body or of any motion; as  the sweep of a door; the sweep of the eye.

Sweep: S w e e p "n. The compass of anything flowing or brushing; as  the flood carried away everything within its sweep.

Sweep: S w e e p "n. Violent and general destruction; as  the sweep of an epidemic disease.

Sweep: S w e e p "n. Direction and extent of any motion not rectlinear; as  the sweep of a compass.

Sweep: S w e e p "n. Direction or departure of a curve  a road an arch or the like away from a rectlinear line.

Sweep: S w e e p "n. One who sweeps; a sweeper; specifically  a chimney sweeper.

Sweep: S w e e p "n. A movable templet for making molds  in loam molding.

Sweep: S w e e p "n. The mold of a ship when she begins to curve in at the rungheads; any part of a ship shaped in a segment of a circle.

Sweep: S w e e p "n. A large oar used in small vessels  partly to propel them and partly to steer them.

Sweep: S w e e p "n. The almond furnace.

Sweep: S w e e p "n. A long pole  or piece of timber moved on a horizontal fulcrum fixed to a tall post and used to raise and lower a bucket in a well for drawing water.

Sweep: S w e e p "n. In the game of casino  a pairing or combining of all the cards on the board and so removing them all; in whist the winning of all the tricks (thirteen) in a hand; a slam.

Sweep: S w e e p "n. The sweeping of workshops where precious metals are worked  containing filings etc.

Sweep-saw: S w e e p - s a w "n. A bow-saw.

Sweepage: S w e e p a g e "n. The crop of hay got in a meadow.

Sweeper: S w e e p e r "n. One who  or that which sweeps or cleans by sweeping; a sweep; as a carpet sweeper.

Sweeping: S w e e p i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Sweep

Sweeping: S w e e p i n g "a. Cleaning off surfaces  or cleaning away dust dirt or litter as a broom does; moving with swiftness and force; carrying everything before it; including in its scope many persons or things; as a sweeping flood; a sweeping majority; a sweeping accusation.

Sweepings: S w e e p i n g s "n. pl. Things collected by sweeping; rubbish; as  the sweepings of a street.

Sweepstake: S w e e p s t a k e "n. A winning of all the stakes or prizes.

Sweepstake: S w e e p s t a k e "n. A complete removal or carrying away; a clean sweep.

Sweepstakes: S w e e p s t a k e s "n. A winning of all the stakes or prizes; a sweepstake.

Sweepstakes: S w e e p s t a k e s "sing. / pl. The whole money or other things staked at a horse race  a given sum being put up for each horse all of which goes to the winner or is divided among several as may be previously agreed.

Sweepstakes: S w e e p s t a k e s "sing. / pl. A race for all the sums staked or prizes offered.

Sweepwasher: S w e e p w a s h e r "n. One who extracts the residuum of precious metals from the sweepings  potsherds etc. of refineries of gold and silver or places where these metals are used.

Sweepy: S w e e p y "a. Moving with a sweeping motion.

Sweet: S w e e t "superl. Having an agreeable taste or flavor such as that of sugar; saccharine; -- opposed to sour and bitter; as  a sweet beverage; sweet fruits; sweet oranges.

Sweet: S w e e t "superl. Pleasing to the smell; fragrant; redolent; balmy; as  a sweet rose; sweet odor; sweet incense.

Sweet: S w e e t "superl. Pleasing to the ear; soft; melodious; harmonious; as  the sweet notes of a flute or an organ; sweet music; a sweet voice; a sweet singer.

Sweet: S w e e t "superl. Pleasing to the eye; beautiful; mild and attractive; fair; as  a sweet face; a sweet color or complexion.

Sweet: S w e e t "superl. Fresh; not salt or brackish; as  sweet water.

Sweet: S w e e t "superl. Not changed from a sound or wholesome state. Specifically: (a) Not sour; as  sweet milk or bread. (b) Not state; not putrescent or putrid; not rancid; as sweet butter; sweet meat or fish.

Sweet: S w e e t "superl. Plaesing to the mind; mild; gentle; calm; amiable; winning; presuasive; as  sweet manners.

Sweet: S w e e t "n. That which is sweet to the taste; -- used chiefly in the plural.

Sweet: S w e e t "n. Confectionery  sweetmeats preserves etc.

Sweet: S w e e t "n. Home-made wines  cordials metheglin etc.

Sweet: S w e e t "n. That which is sweet or pleasant in odor; a perfume.

Sweet: S w e e t "n. That which is pleasing or grateful to the mind; as  the sweets of domestic life.

Sweet: S w e e t "n. One who is dear to another; a darling; -- a term of endearment.

Sweet: S w e e t "adv. Sweetly.

Sweet: S w e e t "v. t. To sweeten.

Sweet-breasted: S w e e t - b r e a s t e d "a. Having a sweet  musical voice as the nightingale. Cf. Breast n. 6.

Sweet-scented: S w e e t - s c e n t e d "a. Having a sweet scent or smell; fragrant.

Sweet-sop: S w e e t - s o p "n. A kind of custard apple (Anona squamosa). See under Custard.

Sweetbread: S w e e t b r e a d "n. Either the thymus gland or the pancreas  the former being called neck / throat sweetbread the latter belly sweetbread. The sweetbreads of ruminants esp. of the calf are highly esteemed as food. See Pancreas and Thymus.

Sweetbread: S w e e t b r e a d "n. The pancreas.

Sweetbrier: S w e e t b r i e r "n. A kind of rose (Rosa rubiginosa) with minutely glandular and fragrant foliage. The small-flowered sweetbrier is Rosa micrantha.

Sweeten: S w e e t e n "a. To make sweet to the taste; as  to sweeten tea.

Sweeten: S w e e t e n "a. To make pleasing or grateful to the mind or feelings; as  to sweeten life; to sweeten friendship.

Sweeten: S w e e t e n "a. To make mild or kind; to soften; as  to sweeten the temper.

Sweeten: S w e e t e n "a. To make less painful or laborious; to relieve; as  to sweeten the cares of life.

Sweeten: S w e e t e n "a. To soften to the eye; to make delicate.

Sweeten: S w e e t e n "a. To make pure and salubrious by destroying noxious matter; as  to sweeten rooms or apartments that have been infected; to sweeten the air.

Sweeten: S w e e t e n "a. To make warm and fertile; -- opposed to sour; as  to dry and sweeten soils.

Sweeten: S w e e t e n "a. To restore to purity; to free from taint; as  to sweeten water butter or meat.

Sweeten: S w e e t e n "v. i. To become sweet.

Sweetened: S w e e t e n e d "imp. & p. p. of Sweeten

Sweetener: S w e e t e n e r "n. One who  or that which sweetens; one who palliates; that which moderates acrimony.

Sweetening: S w e e t e n i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Sweeten

Sweetening: S w e e t e n i n g "n. The act of making sweet.

Sweetening: S w e e t e n i n g "n. That which sweetens.

Sweeting: S w e e t i n g "n. A sweet apple.

Sweeting: S w e e t i n g "n. A darling; -- a word of endearment.

Sweetish: S w e e t i s h "a. Somewhat sweet.

Sweetly: S w e e t l y "adv. In a sweet manner.

Sweetmeat: S w e e t m e a t "n. Fruit preserved with sugar  as peaches pears melons nuts orange peel etc.; -- usually in the plural; a confect; a confection.

Sweetmeat: S w e e t m e a t "n. The paint used in making patent leather.

Sweetmeat: S w e e t m e a t "n. A boat shell (Crepidula fornicata) of the American coast.

Sweetness: S w e e t n e s s "n. The quality or state of being sweet (in any sense of the adjective); gratefulness to the taste or to the smell; agreeableness.

Sweetroot: S w e e t r o o t "n. Licorice.

Sweetwater: S w e e t w a t e r "n. A variety of white grape  having a sweet watery juice; -- also called white sweetwater and white muscadine.

Sweetweed: S w e e t w e e d "n. A name for two tropical American weeds (Capraria biflora  and Scoparia dulcis) of the Figwort family.

Sweetwood: S w e e t w o o d "n. The true laurel (Laurus nobilis.)

Sweetwood: S w e e t w o o d "n. The timber of the tree Oreodaphne Leucoxylon  growing in Jamaica. The name is also applied to the timber of several other related trees.

Sweetwort: S w e e t w o r t "n. Any plant of a sweet taste.

Sweigh: S w e i g h "n. Sway; movement.

Sweinmote: S w e i n m o t e "n. See Swainmote.

Swell: S w e l l "v. i. To grow larger; to dilate or extend the exterior surface or dimensions  by matter added within or by expansion of the inclosed substance; as the legs swell in dropsy; a bruised part swells; a bladder swells by inflation.

Swell: S w e l l "v. i. To increase in size or extent by any addition; to increase in volume or force; as  a river swells and overflows its banks; sounds swell or diminish.

Swell: S w e l l "v. i. To rise or be driven into waves or billows; to heave; as  in tempest the ocean swells into waves.

Swell: S w e l l "v. i. To be puffed up or bloated; as  to swell with pride.

Swell: S w e l l "v. i. To be inflated; to belly; as  the sails swell.

Swell: S w e l l "v. i. To be turgid  bombastic or extravagant; as swelling words; a swelling style.

Swell: S w e l l "v. i. To protuberate; to bulge out; as  a cask swells in the middle.

Swell: S w e l l "v. i. To be elated; to rise arrogantly.

Swell: S w e l l "v. i. To grow upon the view; to become larger; to expand.

Swell: S w e l l "v. i. To become larger in amount; as  many little debts added swell to a great amount.

Swell: S w e l l "v. i. To act in a pompous  ostentatious or arrogant manner; to strut; to look big.

Swell: S w e l l "v. t. To increase the size  bulk or dimensions of; to cause to rise dilate or increase; as rains and dissolving snow swell the rivers in spring; immigration swells the population.

Swell: S w e l l "v. t. To aggravate; to heighten.

Swell: S w e l l "v. t. To raise to arrogance; to puff up; to inflate; as  to be swelled with pride or haughtiness.

Swell: S w e l l "v. t. To augment gradually in force or loudness  as the sound of a note.

Swell: S w e l l "n. The act of swelling.

Swell: S w e l l "n. Gradual increase.

Swell: S w e l l "n. Increase or augmentation in bulk; protuberance.

Swell: S w e l l "n. Increase in height; elevation; rise.

Swell: S w e l l "n. Increase of force  intensity or volume of sound.

Swell: S w e l l "n. Increase of power in style  or of rhetorical force.

Swell: S w e l l "n. A gradual ascent  or rounded elevation of land; as an extensive plain abounding with little swells.

Swell: S w e l l "n. A wave  or billow; especially a succession of large waves; the roll of the sea after a storm; as a heavy swell sets into the harbor.

Swell: S w e l l "n. A gradual increase and decrease of the volume of sound; the crescendo and diminuendo combined; -- generally indicated by the sign.

Swell: S w e l l "n. A showy  dashing person; a dandy.

Swell: S w e l l "a. Having the characteristics of a person of rank and importance; showy; dandified; distinguished; as  a swell person; a swell neighborhood.

Swelldom: S w e l l d o m "n. People of rank and fashion; the class of swells  collectively.

Swelling: S w e l l i n g "n. A protuberance; a prominence

Swelling: S w e l l i n g "n. an unnatural prominence or protuberance; as  a scrofulous swelling.

Swelter: S w e l t e r "v. t. To exude  like sweat.

Swietenia: S w i e t e n i a "n. A genus of meliaceous trees consisting of one species (Sweitenia Mahogoni)  the mahogany tree.

Swift: S w i f t "v. i. Moving a great distance in a short time; moving with celerity or velocity; fleet; rapid; quick; speedy; prompt.

Swift: S w i f t "v. i. Of short continuance; passing away quickly.

Swift: S w i f t "adv. Swiftly.

Swift: S w i f t "n. The current of a stream.

Swift: S w i f t "n. Any one of numerous species of small  long-winged insectivorous birds of the family Micropodidae. In form and habits the swifts resemble swallows but they are destitute of complex vocal muscles and are not singing birds but belong to a widely different group allied to the humming birds.

Swift: S w i f t "n. Any one of several species of lizards  as the pine lizard.

Swift: S w i f t "n. The ghost moth. See under Ghost.

Swift: S w i f t "n. A reel  or turning instrument for winding yarn thread etc.; -- used chiefly in the plural.

Swift: S w i f t "n. The main card cylinder of a flax-carding machine.

Swifter: S w i f t e r "n. A rope used to retain the bars of the capstan in their sockets while men are turning it.

Swifter: S w i f t e r "n. A rope used to encircle a boat longitudinally  to strengthen and defend her sides.

Swifter: S w i f t e r "n. The forward shroud of a lower mast.

Swifter: S w i f t e r "v. t. To tighten  as slack standing rigging by bringing the opposite shrouds nearer.

Swiftfoot: S w i f t f o o t "a. Nimble; fleet.

Swiftfoot: S w i f t f o o t "n. The courser.

Swiftlet: S w i f t l e t "n. Any one of numerous species of small East Indian and Asiatic swifts of the genus Collocalia. Some of the species are noted for furnishing the edible bird's nest. See Illust. under Edible.

Swiftly: S w i f t l y "adv. In a swift manner; with quick motion or velocity; fleetly.

Swiftness: S w i f t n e s s "n. The quality or state of being swift; speed; quickness; celerity; velocity; rapidity; as  the swiftness of a bird; the swiftness of a stream; swiftness of descent in a falling body; swiftness of thought etc.

Swig: S w i g "v. t. To drink in long draughts; to gulp; as  to swig cider.

Swig: S w i g "v. t. To suck.

Swig: S w i g "n. A long draught.

Swig: S w i g "n. A tackle with ropes which are not parallel.

Swig: S w i g "n. A beverage consisting of warm beer flavored with spices  lemon etc.

Swig: S w i g "v. t. To castrate  as a ram by binding the testicles tightly with a string so that they mortify and slough off.

Swig: S w i g "v. t. To pull upon (a tackle) by throwing the weight of the body upon the fall between the block and a cleat.

Swill: S w i l l "v. t. To wash; to drench.

Swill: S w i l l "n. To drink in great draughts; to swallow greedily.

Swill: S w i l l "n. To inebriate; to fill with drink.

Swill: S w i l l "v. i. To drink greedily or swinishly; to drink to excess.

Swill: S w i l l "n. The wash  or mixture of liquid substances given to swine; hogwash; -- called also swillings.

Swill: S w i l l "n. Large draughts of liquor; drink taken in excessive quantities.

Swim: S w i m "v. i. To be supported by water or other fluid; not to sink; to float; as  any substance will swim whose specific gravity is less than that of the fluid in which it is immersed.

Swim: S w i m "v. i. To move progressively in water by means of strokes with the hands and feet  or the fins or the tail.

Swim: S w i m "v. i. To be overflowed or drenched.

Swim: S w i m "v. i. Fig.: To be as if borne or floating in a fluid.

Swim: S w i m "v. i. To be filled with swimming animals.

Swim: S w i m "v. t. To pass or move over or on by swimming; as  to swim a stream.

Swim: S w i m "v. t. To cause or compel to swim; to make to float; as  to swim a horse across a river.

Swim: S w i m "v. t. To immerse in water that the lighter parts may float; as  to swim wheat in order to select seed.

Swim: S w i m "n. The act of swimming; a gliding motion  like that of one swimming.

Swim: S w i m "n. The sound  or air bladder of a fish.

Swim: S w i m "n. A part of a stream much frequented by fish.

Swim: S w i m "v. i. To be dizzy; to have an unsteady or reeling sensation; as  the head swims.

Swimbel: S w i m b e l "n. A moaning or sighing sound or noise; a sough.

Swimmer: S w i m m e r "n. One who swims.

Swimmer: S w i m m e r "n. A protuberance on the leg of a horse.

Swimmer: S w i m m e r "n. A swimming bird; one of the natatores.

Swimmeret: S w i m m e r e t "n. One of a series of flat  fringed and usually bilobed appendages of which several pairs occur on the abdominal somites of many crustaceans. They are used as fins in swimming.

Swimming: S w i m m i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Swim

Swimming: S w i m m i n g "a. Suffused with moisture; as  swimming eyes.

Swimming: S w i m m i n g "n. The act of one who swims.

Swimming: S w i m m i n g "a. Being in a state of vertigo or dizziness; as  a swimming brain.

Swimming: S w i m m i n g "n. Vertigo; dizziness; as  a swimming in the head.

Swine: S w i n e "n. Any animal of the hog kind  especially one of the domestical species. Swine secrete a large amount of subcutaneous fat which when extracted is known as lard. The male is specifically called boar the female sow and the young pig. See Hog.

Swine-pox: S w i n e - p o x "n. A variety of the chicken pox  with acuminated vesicles containing a watery fluid; the water pox.

Swinebread: S w i n e b r e a d "n. The truffle.

Swinecase: S w i n e c a s e "n. A hogsty.

Swinesty: S w i n e s t y "n. A sty  or pen for swine.

Swing: S w i n g "v. i. To move to and fro  as a body suspended in the air; to wave; to vibrate; to oscillate.

Swing: S w i n g "v. i. To sway or move from one side or direction to another; as  the door swung open.

Swing: S w i n g "v. i. To use a swing; as  a boy swings for exercise or pleasure. See Swing n. 3.

Swing: S w i n g "n. To turn round by action of wind or tide when at anchor; as  a ship swings with the tide.

Swing: S w i n g "n. To be hanged.

Swing: S w i n g "v. t. To cause to swing or vibrate; to cause to move backward and forward  or from one side to the other.

Swing: S w i n g "v. t. To give a circular movement to; to whirl; to brandish; as  to swing a sword; to swing a club; hence colloquially to manage; as to swing a business.

Swing: S w i n g "v. t. To admit or turn (anything) for the purpose of shaping it; -- said of a lathe; as  the lathe can swing a pulley of 12 inches diameter.

Swing: S w i n g "n. The act of swinging; a waving  oscillating or vibratory motion of a hanging or pivoted object; oscillation; as the swing of a pendulum.

Swing: S w i n g "n. Swaying motion from one side or direction to the other; as  some men walk with a swing.

Swing: S w i n g "n. A line  cord or other thing suspended and hanging loose upon which anything may swing; especially an apparatus for recreation by swinging commonly consisting of a rope the two ends of which are attached overhead as to the bough of a tree a seat being placed in the loop at the bottom; also any contrivance by which a similar motion is produced for amusement or exercise.

Swing: S w i n g "n. Influence of power of a body put in swaying motion.

Swing: S w i n g "n. Capacity of a turning lathe  as determined by the diameter of the largest object that can be turned in it.

Swing: S w i n g "n. Free course; unrestrained liberty or license; tendency.

Swoon: S w o o n "n. A fainting fit; syncope.

Swooned: S w o o n e d "imp. & p. p. of Swoon

Swooning: S w o o n i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Swoon

Swooning: S w o o n i n g " a. & n. from Swoon  v.

Swoop: S w o o p "n. To fall on at once and seize; to catch while on the wing; as  a hawk swoops a chicken.

Swoop: S w o o p "n. To seize; to catch up; to take with a sweep.

Swoop: S w o o p "v. i. To descend with closed wings from a height upon prey  as a hawk; to swoop.

Swoop: S w o o p "v. i. To pass with pomp; to sweep.

Swoop: S w o o p "n. A falling on and seizing  as the prey of a rapacious bird; the act of swooping.

Swooped: S w o o p e d "imp. & p. p. of Swoop

Swooping: S w o o p i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Swoop

Swoopstake: S w o o p s t a k e "n. See Sweepstake.

Swoopstake: S w o o p s t a k e "adv. Altogether; indiscriminately.

Swop: S w o p "v. & n. Same as Swap.

Sword: S w o r d "n. An offensive weapon  having a long and usually sharp/pointed blade with a cutting edge or edges. It is the general term including the small sword rapier saber scimiter and many other varieties.

Sword: S w o r d "n. Hence  the emblem of judicial vengeance or punishment or of authority and power.

Sword: S w o r d "n. Destruction by the sword  or in battle; war; dissension.

Sword: S w o r d "n. The military power of a country.

Sword: S w o r d "n. One of the end bars by which the lay of a hand loom is suspended.

Sword-shaped: S w o r d - s h a p e d "a. Shaped like a sword; ensiform  as the long flat leaves of the Iris cattail and the like.

Swordbill: S w o r d b i l l "n. A humming bird (Docimastes ensiferus) having a very long  slender bill exceeding the length of the body of the bird.

Sworded: S w o r d e d "a. Girded with a sword.

Sworder: S w o r d e r "n. One who uses  or fights with a sword; a swordsman; a soldier; a cutthroat.

Swordfish: S w o r d f i s h "n. A very large oceanic fish (Xiphias gladius)  the only representative of the family Xiphiidae. It is highly valued as a food fish. The bones of the upper jaw are consolidated and form a long rigid swordlike beak; the dorsal fin is high and without distinct spines; the ventral fins are absent. The adult is destitute of teeth. It becomes sixteen feet or more long.

Swordfish: S w o r d f i s h "n. The gar pike.

Swordfish: S w o r d f i s h "n. The cutlass fish.

Swordfish: S w o r d f i s h "n. A southern constellation. See Dorado  1.

Swordick: S w o r d i c k "n. The spotted gunnel (Muraenoides gunnellus).

Swording: S w o r d i n g "n. Slashing with a sword.

Swordless: S w o r d l e s s "a. Destitute of a sword.

Swordman: S w o r d m a n "n. A swordsman.

Swordmen: S w o r d m e n "pl. "of Swordman

Swordplay: S w o r d p l a y "n. Fencing; a sword fight.

Swordplayer: S w o r d p l a y e r "n. A fencer; a gladiator; one who exhibits his skill in the use of the sword.

Swordsman: S w o r d s m a n "n. A soldier; a fighting man.

Swordsman: S w o r d s m a n "n. One skilled of a use of the sword; a professor of the science of fencing; a fencer.

Swordsmanship: S w o r d s m a n s h i p "n. The state of being a swordsman; skill in the use of the sword.

Swordsmen: S w o r d s m e n "pl. "of Swordsman

Swordtail: S w o r d t a i l "n. The limulus.

Swordtail: S w o r d t a i l "n. Any hemipterous insect of the genus Uroxiphus  found upon forest trees.

Swore: S w o r e " imp. of Swear.

Swough: S w o u g h "n. A swoon.

Swound: S w o u n d "v. & n. See Swoon  v. & n.

Swown: S w o w n "v. & n. Swoon.
