Sy: S y "imp. Saw.

Syb: S y b "a. See Sib.

Sybarite: S y b a r i t e "n. A person devoted to luxury and pleasure; a voluptuary.

Sybaritic: S y b a r i t i c "a. Alt. of Sybaritical

Sybaritical: S y b a r i t i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to the Sybarites; resembling the Sybarites; luxurious; wanton; effeminate.

Sybaritism: S y b a r i t i s m "n. Luxuriousness; effeminacy; wantonness; voluptuousness.

Sycamine: S y c a m i n e "n. See Sycamore.

Sycamore: S y c a m o r e "n. A large tree (Ficus Sycomorus) allied to the common fig. It is found in Egypt and Syria  and is the sycamore or sycamine of Scripture.

Sycamore: S y c a m o r e "n. The American plane tree  or buttonwood.

Sycamore: S y c a m o r e "n. A large European species of maple (Acer Pseudo-Platanus).

Syce: S y c e "n. A groom.

Sycee: S y c e e "n. Silver  pounded into ingots of the shape of a shoe and used as currency. The most common weight is about one pound troy.

Sychnocarpous: S y c h n o c a r p o u s "a. Having the capacity of bearing several successive crops of fruit without perishing; as  sychnocarpous plants.

Sycite: S y c i t e "n. A nodule of flint  or a pebble which resembles a fig.

Sycoceric: S y c o c e r i c "a. Of  pertaining to or designating an acid obtained by the oxidation of sycoceryl alcohol.

Sycoceryl: S y c o c e r y l "n. A radical  of the aromatic series regarded as an essential ingredient of certain compounds found in the waxy resin of an Australian species of fig.

Sycock: S y c o c k "n. The missel thrush.

Sycones: S y c o n e s "n. pl. A division of calcareous sponges.

Syconium: S y c o n i u m "n. Alt. of Syconus

Syconus: S y c o n u s "n. A collective fleshy fruit  in which the ovaries are hidden within a hollow receptacle as in the fig.

Sycophancy: S y c o p h a n c y "n. The character or characteristic of a sycophant.

Sycophancy: S y c o p h a n c y "n. False accusation; calumniation; talebearing.

Sycophancy: S y c o p h a n c y "n. Obsequious flattery; servility.

Sycophant: S y c o p h a n t "n. An informer; a talebearer.

Sycophant: S y c o p h a n t "n. A base parasite; a mean or servile flatterer; especially  a flatterer of princes and great men.

Sycophant: S y c o p h a n t "v. t. To inform against; hence  to calumniate.

Sycophant: S y c o p h a n t "v. t. To play the sycophant toward; to flatter obsequiously.

Sycophant: S y c o p h a n t "v. i. To play the sycophant.

Sycophantcy: S y c o p h a n t c y "n. Sycophancy.

Sycophantic: S y c o p h a n t i c "a. Alt. of Sycophantical

Sycophantical: S y c o p h a n t i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to a sycophant; characteristic of a sycophant; meanly or obsequiously flattering; courting favor by mean adulation; parasitic.

Sycophantish: S y c o p h a n t i s h "a. Like a sycophant; obsequiously flattering.

Sycophantism: S y c o p h a n t i s m "n. Sycophancy.

Sycophantize: S y c o p h a n t i z e "v. i. To play the sycophant.

Sycophantry: S y c o p h a n t r y "n. Sycophancy.

Sycosis: S y c o s i s "n. A pustular eruption upon the scalp  or the beared part of the face whether due to ringworm acne or impetigo.

Syderolite: S y d e r o l i t e "n. A kind of Bohemian earthenware resembling the Wedgwood ware.

Sye: S y e "imp. Saw.

Syenite: S y e n i t e "n. Orig.  a rock composed of quartz hornblende and feldspar anciently quarried at Syene in Upper Egypt and now called granite.

Syenite: S y e n i t e "n. A granular  crystalline ingeous rock composed of orthoclase and hornblende the latter often replaced or accompanied by pyroxene or mica. Syenite sometimes contains nephelite (elaeolite) or leucite and is then called nephelite (elaeolite) syenite or leucite syenite.

Syenitic: S y e n i t i c "a. Relating to Syene; as  Syenitic inscriptions.

Syenitic: S y e n i t i c "a. Relating to  or like syenite; as syenitic granite.

Syke: S y k e "n. & v. See Sike.

Syker: S y k e r "a. & adv. See Sicker.

Syle: S y l e "n. A young herring (Clupea harengus).

Syllabaria: S y l l a b a r i a "pl. "of Syllabarium

Syllabarium: S y l l a b a r i u m "n. A syllabary.

Syllabary: S y l l a b a r y "n. A table of syllables; more especially  a table of the indivisible syllabic symbols used in certain languages as the Japanese and Cherokee instead of letters.

Syllabe: S y l l a b e "n. Syllable.

Syllabi: S y l l a b i "pl. "of Syllabus

Syllabic: S y l l a b i c "a. Alt. of Syllabical

Syllabical: S y l l a b i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to a syllable or syllables; as  syllabic accent.

Syllabical: S y l l a b i c a l "a. Consisting of a syllable or syllables; as  a syllabic augment.

Syllabically: S y l l a b i c a l l y "adv. In a syllabic manner.

Syllabicate: S y l l a b i c a t e "v. t. To form or divide into syllables; to syllabify.

Syllabicated: S y l l a b i c a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Syllabicate

Syllabicating: S y l l a b i c a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Syllabicate

Syllabication: S y l l a b i c a t i o n "n. The act of forming syllables; the act or method of dividing words into syllables. See Guide to Pron.  /275.

Syllabification: S y l l a b i f i c a t i o n "n. Same as Syllabication.

Syllabified: S y l l a b i f i e d "imp. & p. p. of Syllabify

Syllabify: S y l l a b i f y "v. t. To form or divide into syllables.

Syllabifying: S y l l a b i f y i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Syllabify

Syllabism: S y l l a b i s m "n. The expressing of the sounds of a language by syllables  rather than by an alphabet or by signs for words.

Syllabist: S y l l a b i s t "n. One who forms or divides words into syllables  or is skilled in doing this.

Syllabize: S y l l a b i z e "v. t. To syllabify.

Syllable: S y l l a b l e "n. An elementary sound  or a combination of elementary sounds uttered together or with a single effort or impulse of the voice and constituting a word or a part of a word. In other terms it is a vowel or a diphtong either by itself or flanked by one or more consonants the whole produced by a single impulse or utterance. One of the liquids l m n may fill the place of a vowel in a syllable. Adjoining syllables in a word or phrase need not to be marked off by a pause

Syllable: S y l l a b l e "n. In writing and printing  a part of a word separated from the rest and capable of being pronounced by a single impulse of the voice. It may or may not correspond to a syllable in the spoken language.

Syllable: S y l l a b l e "n. A small part of a sentence or discourse; anything concise or short; a particle.

Syllable: S y l l a b l e "v. t. To pronounce the syllables of; to utter; to articulate.

Syllabub: S y l l a b u b "n. Same as Syllabub.

Syllabus: S y l l a b u s "n. A compendium containing the heads of a discourse  and the like; an abstract.

Syllabuses: S y l l a b u s e s "pl. "of Syllabus

Syllepsis: S y l l e p s i s "n. A figure of speech by which a word is used in a literal and metaphorical sense at the same time.

Syllepsis: S y l l e p s i s "n. The agreement of a verb or adjective with one  rather than another of two nouns with either of which it might agree in gender number etc.; as rex et regina beati.

Sylleptic: S y l l e p t i c "a. Alt. of Sylleptical

Sylleptical: S y l l e p t i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to a syllepsis; containing syllepsis.

Syllidian: S y l l i d i a n "n. Any one of numerous species of marine annelids of the family Syllidae.

Syllogism: S y l l o g i s m "n. The regular logical form of every argument  consisting of three propositions of which the first two are called the premises and the last the conclusion. The conclusion necessarily follows from the premises; so that if these are true the conclusion must be true and the argument amounts to demonstration

Syllogistic: S y l l o g i s t i c "a. Alt. of Syllogistical

Syllogistical: S y l l o g i s t i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to a syllogism; consisting of a syllogism  or of the form of reasoning by syllogisms; as syllogistic arguments or reasoning.

Syllogistically: S y l l o g i s t i c a l l y "adv. In a syllogistic manner.

Syllogization: S y l l o g i z a t i o n "n. A reasoning by syllogisms.

Syllogize: S y l l o g i z e "v. i. To reason by means of syllogisms.

Syllogized: S y l l o g i z e d "imp. & p. p. of Syllogize

Syllogizer: S y l l o g i z e r "n. One who syllogizes.

Syllogizing: S y l l o g i z i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Syllogize

Sylph: S y l p h "n. An imaginary being inhabiting the air; a fairy.

Sylph: S y l p h "n. Fig.: A slender  graceful woman.

Sylph: S y l p h "n. Any one of several species of very brilliant South American humming birds  having a very long and deeply-forked tail; as the blue-tailed sylph (Cynanthus cyanurus).

Sylphid: S y l p h i d "n. A little sylph; a young or diminutive sylph.

Sylphine: S y l p h i n e "a. Like a sylph.

Sylphish: S y l p h i s h "a. Sylphlike.

Sylphlike: S y l p h l i k e "a. Like a sylph; airy; graceful.

Sylva: S y l v a "n. Same as Silva.

Sylvae: S y l v a e "pl. "of Sylva

Sylvan: S y l v a n "a. Of or pertaining to a sylva; forestlike; hence  rural; rustic.

Sylvan: S y l v a n "a. Abounding in forests or in trees; woody.

Sylvan: S y l v a n "a. A fabled deity of the wood; a satyr; a faun; sometimes  a rustic.

Sylvan: S y l v a n "n. A liquid hydrocarbon obtained together with furfuran (tetrol) by the distillation of pine wood; -- called also methyl tetrol  or methyl furfuran.

Sylvanite: S y l v a n i t e "n. A mineral  a telluride of gold and silver of a steel-gray silver-white or brass-yellow color. It often occurs in implanted crystals resembling written characters and hence is called graphic tellurium.

Sylvanium: S y l v a n i u m "n. An old name for tellurium.

Sylvate: S y l v a t e "n. A salt of sylvic acid.

Sylvatic: S y l v a t i c "a. Sylvan.

Sylvestrian: S y l v e s t r i a n "a. Sylvan.

Sylvic: S y l v i c "a. Of  pertaining to or resembling pine or its products; specifically designating an acid called also abeitic acid which is the chief ingredient of common resin (obtained from Pinus sylvestris and other species).

Sylvicoline: S y l v i c o l i n e "a. Of or pertaining to the family of warblers (Sylvicolidae). See Warbler.

Sylviculture: S y l v i c u l t u r e "n. The cultivation of forest trees for timber or other purposes; forestry; arboriculture.

Sylviculturist: S y l v i c u l t u r i s t "n. One who cultivates forest trees  especially as a business.

Sylvine: S y l v i n e "n. Alt. of Sylvite

Sylvite: S y l v i t e "n. Native potassium chloride.

Sym-: S y m - " See Syn-.

Symar: S y m a r "n. Alt. of Symarr

Symarr: S y m a r r "n. See Simar.

Symbal: S y m b a l "n. See Cimbal.

Symbol: S y m b o l "n. A visible sign or representation of an idea; anything which suggests an idea or quality  or another thing as by resemblance or by convention; an emblem; a representation; a type; a figure; as the lion is the symbol of courage; the lamb is the symbol of meekness or patience.

Symbol: S y m b o l "n. Any character used to represent a quantity  an operation a relation or an abbreviation.

Symbol: S y m b o l "n. An abstract or compendium of faith or doctrine; a creed  or a summary of the articles of religion.

Symbol: S y m b o l "n. That which is thrown into a common fund; hence  an appointed or accustomed duty.

Symbol: S y m b o l "n. Share; allotment.

Symbol: S y m b o l "n. An abbreviation standing for the name of an element and consisting of the initial letter of the Latin or New Latin name  or sometimes of the initial letter with a following one; as C for carbon Na for sodium (Natrium) Fe for iron (Ferrum) Sn for tin (Stannum) Sb for antimony (Stibium) etc. See the list of names and symbols under Element.

Symbol: S y m b o l "v. t. To symbolize.

Symbolic: S y m b o l i c "a. See Symbolics.

Symbolic: S y m b o l i c "a. Alt. of Symbolical

Symbolical: S y m b o l i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to a symbol or symbols; of the nature of a symbol; exhibiting or expressing by resemblance or signs; representative; as  the figure of an eye is symbolic of sight and knowledge.

Symbolics: S y m b o l i c s "n. The study of ancient symbols

Symbolics: S y m b o l i c s "n. that branch of historic theology which treats of creeds and confessions of faith; symbolism; -- called also symbolic.

Symbolism: S y m b o l i s m "n. The act of symbolizing  or the state of being symbolized; as symbolism in Christian art is the representation of truth virtues vices etc. by emblematic colors signs and forms.

Symbolism: S y m b o l i s m "n. A system of symbols or representations.

Symbolism: S y m b o l i s m "n. The practice of using symbols  or the system of notation developed thereby.

Symbolism: S y m b o l i s m "n. A combining together of parts or ingredients.

Symbolism: S y m b o l i s m "n. The science of creeds; symbolics.

Symbolist: S y m b o l i s t "n. One who employs symbols.

Symbolistic: S y m b o l i s t i c "a. Alt. of Symbolistical

Symbolistical: S y m b o l i s t i c a l "a. Characterized by the use of symbols; as  symbolistic poetry.

Symbolization: S y m b o l i z a t i o n "n. The act of symbolizing; symbolical representation.

Symbolize: S y m b o l i z e "v. i. To have a resemblance of qualities or properties; to correspond; to harmonize.

Symbolize: S y m b o l i z e "v. i. To hold the same faith; to agree.

Symbolize: S y m b o l i z e "v. i. To use symbols; to represent ideas symbolically.

Symbolize: S y m b o l i z e "v. t. To make to agree in properties or qualities.

Symbolize: S y m b o l i z e "v. t. To make representative of something; to regard or treat as symbolic.

Symbolize: S y m b o l i z e "v. t. To represent by a symbol or symbols.

Symbolized: S y m b o l i z e d "imp. & p. p. of Symbolize

Symbolizer: S y m b o l i z e r "n. One who symbolizes.

Symbolizing: S y m b o l i z i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Symbolize

Symbological: S y m b o l o g i c a l "a. Pertaining to a symbology; versed in  or characterized by symbology.

Symbologist: S y m b o l o g i s t "n. One who practices  or who is versed in symbology.

Symbology: S y m b o l o g y "n. The art of expressing by symbols.

Symbranchii: S y m b r a n c h i i "n. pl. An order of slender eel-like fishes having the gill openings confluent beneath the neck. The pectoral arch is generally attached to the skull  and the entire margin of the upper jaw is formed by the premaxillary. Called also Symbranchia.

Symmetral: S y m m e t r a l "a. Commensurable; symmetrical.

Symmetrian: S y m m e t r i a n "n. One eminently studious of symmetry of parts.

Symmetric: S y m m e t r i c "a. Symmetrical.

Symmetrical: S y m m e t r i c a l "a. Involving or exhibiting symmetry; proportional in parts; having its parts in due proportion as to dimensions; as  a symmetrical body or building.

Symmetrical: S y m m e t r i c a l "a. Having the organs or parts of one side corresponding with those of the other; having the parts in two or more series of organs the same in number; exhibiting a symmetry. See Symmetry  2.

Symmetrical: S y m m e t r i c a l "a. Having an equal number of parts in the successive circles of floral organs; -- said of flowers.

Symmetrical: S y m m e t r i c a l "a. Having a likeness in the form and size of floral organs of the same kind; regular.

Symmetrical: S y m m e t r i c a l "a. Having a common measure; commensurable.

Symmetrical: S y m m e t r i c a l "a. Having corresponding parts or relations.

Symmetrician: S y m m e t r i c i a n "n. Same as Symmetrian.

Symmetrist: S y m m e t r i s t "n. One eminently studious of symmetry of parts.

Symmetrize: S y m m e t r i z e "v. t. To make proportional in its parts; to reduce to symmetry.

Symmetrized: S y m m e t r i z e d "imp. & p. p. of Symmetrize

Symmetrizing: S y m m e t r i z i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Symmetrize

Symmetry: S y m m e t r y "n. A due proportion of the several parts of a body to each other; adaptation of the form or dimensions of the several parts of a thing to each other; the union and conformity of the members of a work to the whole.

Symmetry: S y m m e t r y "n. The law of likeness; similarity of structure; regularity in form and arrangement; orderly and similar distribution of parts  such that an animal may be divided into parts which are structurally symmetrical.

Symmetry: S y m m e t r y "n. Equality in the number of parts of the successive circles in a flower.

Symmetry: S y m m e t r y "n. Likeness in the form and size of floral organs of the same kind; regularity.

Sympathetic: S y m p a t h e t i c "a. Inclined to sympathy; sympathizing.

Sympathetic: S y m p a t h e t i c "a. Produced by  or expressive of sympathy.

Sympathetic: S y m p a t h e t i c "a. Produced by sympathy; -- applied particularly to symptoms or affections. See Sympathy.

Sympathetic: S y m p a t h e t i c "a. Of or relating to the sympathetic nervous system or some of its branches; produced by stimulation on the sympathetic nervious system or some part of it; as  the sympathetic saliva a modified form of saliva produced from some of the salivary glands by stimulation of a sympathetic nerve fiber.

Sympathetical: S y m p a t h e t i c a l "a. Sympathetic.

Sympathetically: S y m p a t h e t i c a l l y "adv. In a sympathetic manner.

Sympathies: S y m p a t h i e s "pl. "of Sympathy

Sympathist: S y m p a t h i s t "n. One who sympathizes; a sympathizer.

Sympathize: S y m p a t h i z e "v. i. To have a common feeling  as of bodily pleasure or pain.

Sympathize: S y m p a t h i z e "v. i. To feel in consequence of what another feels; to be affected by feelings similar to those of another  in consequence of knowing the person to be thus affected.

Sympathize: S y m p a t h i z e "v. i. To agree; to be in accord; to harmonize.

Sympathize: S y m p a t h i z e "v. t. To experience together.

Sympathize: S y m p a t h i z e "v. t. To ansew to; to correspond to.

Sympathized: S y m p a t h i z e d "imp. & p. p. of Sympathize

Sympathizer: S y m p a t h i z e r "n. One who sympathizes.

Sympathizing: S y m p a t h i z i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Sympathize

Sympathy: S y m p a t h y "n. Feeling corresponding to that which another feels; the quality of being affected by the affection of another  with feelings correspondent in kind if not in degree; fellow-feeling.

Sympathy: S y m p a t h y "n. An agreement of affections or inclinations  or a conformity of natural temperament which causes persons to be pleased or in accord with one another; as there is perfect sympathy between them.

Sympathy: S y m p a t h y "n. Kindness of feeling toward one who suffers; pity; commiseration; compassion.

Sympathy: S y m p a t h y "n. The reciprocal influence exercised by the various organs or parts of the body on one another  as manifested in the transmission of a disease by unknown means from one organ to another quite remote or in the influence exerted by a diseased condition of one part on another part or organ as in the vomiting produced by a tumor of the brain.

Sympathy: S y m p a t h y "n. That relation which exists between different persons by which one of them produces in the others a state or condition like that of himself. This is shown in the tendency to yawn which a person often feels on seeing another yawn  or the strong inclination to become hysteric experienced by many women on seeing another person suffering with hysteria.

Sympathy: S y m p a t h y "n. A tendency of inanimate things to unite  or to act on each other; as the sympathy between the loadstone and iron.

Sympathy: S y m p a t h y "n. Similarity of function  use office or the like.

Sympetalous: S y m p e t a l o u s "a. Having the petals united; gamopetalous.

Symphonic: S y m p h o n i c "a. Symphonious.

Symphonic: S y m p h o n i c "a. Relating to  or in the manner of symphony; as the symphonic form or style of composition.

Symphonies: S y m p h o n i e s "pl. "of Symphony

Symphonious: S y m p h o n i o u s "a. Agreeing in sound; accordant; harmonious.

Symphonious: S y m p h o n i o u s "a. Symphonic.

Symphonist: S y m p h o n i s t "n. A composer of symphonies.

Symphonize: S y m p h o n i z e "v. i. To agree; to be in harmony.

Symphonized: S y m p h o n i z e d "imp. & p. p. of Symphonize

Symphonizing: S y m p h o n i z i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Symphonize

Symphony: S y m p h o n y "n. A consonance or harmony of sounds  agreeable to the ear whether the sounds are vocal or instrumental or both.

Symphony: S y m p h o n y "n. A stringed instrument formerly in use  somewhat resembling the virginal.

Symphony: S y m p h o n y "n. An elaborate instrumental composition for a full orchestra  consisting usually like the sonata of three or four contrasted yet inwardly related movements as the allegro the adagio the minuet and trio or scherzo and the finale in quick time. The term has recently been applied to large orchestral works in freer form with arguments or programmes to explain their meaning such as the symphonic poems of Liszt. The term was formerly applied to any composition for an orchestra as overtures

Symphony: S y m p h o n y "n. An instrumental passage at the beginning or end  or in the course of a vocal composition; a prelude interlude or postude; a ritornello.

Symphyla: S y m p h y l a "n. pl. An order of small apterous insects having an elongated body  with three pairs of thoracic and about nine pairs of abdominal legs. They are in many respects intermediate between myriapods and true insects.

Symphyseal: S y m p h y s e a l "a. Of or pertaining to to symphysis.

Symphyseotomy: S y m p h y s e o t o m y "n. The operation of dividing the symphysis pubis for the purpose of facilitating labor; -- formerly called the Sigualtian section.

Symphyses: S y m p h y s e s "pl. "of Symphysis

Symphysis: S y m p h y s i s "n. An articulation formed by intervening cartilage; as  the pubic symphysis.

Symphysis: S y m p h y s i s "n. The union or coalescence of bones; also  the place of union or coalescence; as the symphysis of the lower jaw. Cf. Articulation.

Symphysotomy: S y m p h y s o t o m y "n. Symphyseotomy.

Symphytism: S y m p h y t i s m "n. Coalescence; a growing into one with another word.

Sympiesometer: S y m p i e s o m e t e r "n. A sensitive kind of barometer  in which the pressure of the atmosphere acting upon a liquid as oil in the lower portion of the instrument compresses an elastic gas in the upper part.

Symplectic: S y m p l e c t i c "a. Plaiting or joining together; -- said of a bone next above the quadrate in the mandibular suspensorium of many fishes  which unites together the other bones of the suspensorium.

Symplectic: S y m p l e c t i c "n. The symplectic bone.

Symploce: S y m p l o c e "n. The repetition of a word or phrase at the beginning and another at the end of successive clauses; as  Justice came down from heaven to view the earth; Justice returned to heaven and left the earth.

Sympode: S y m p o d e "n. A sympodium.

Sympodia: S y m p o d i a "pl. "of Sympodium

Sympodial: S y m p o d i a l "a. Composed of superposed branches in such a way as to imitate a simple axis; as  a sympodial stem.

Sympodium: S y m p o d i u m "n. An axis or stem produced by dichotomous branching in which one of the branches is regularly developed at the expense of the other  as in the grapevine.

Symposia: S y m p o s i a "pl. "of Symposium

Symposiac: S y m p o s i a c "a. Of or pertaining to compotations and merrymaking; happening where company is drinking together; as  symposiac meetings.

Symposiac: S y m p o s i a c "n. A conference or conversation of philosophers at a banquet; hence  any similar gathering.

Symposiarch: S y m p o s i a r c h "n. The master of a feast.

Symposiast: S y m p o s i a s t "n. One engaged with others at a banquet or merrymaking.

Symposion: S y m p o s i o n "n. A drinking together; a symposium.

Symposium: S y m p o s i u m "n. A drinking together; a merry feast.

Symposium: S y m p o s i u m "n. A collection of short essays by different authors on a common topic; -- so called from the appellation given to the philosophical dialogue by the Greeks.

Symptom: S y m p t o m "n. Any affection which accompanies disease; a perceptible change in the body or its functions  which indicates disease or the kind or phases of disease; as the causes of disease often lie beyond our sight but we learn their nature by the symptoms exhibited.

Symptom: S y m p t o m "n. A sign or token; that which indicates the existence of something else; as  corruption in elections is a symptom of the decay of public virtue.

Symptomatic: S y m p t o m a t i c "a. Alt. of Symptomatical

Symptomatical: S y m p t o m a t i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to symptoms; happening in concurrence with something; being a symptom; indicating the existence of something else.

Symptomatical: S y m p t o m a t i c a l "a. According to symptoms; as  a symptomatical classification of diseases.

Symptomatology: S y m p t o m a t o l o g y "n. The doctrine of symptoms; that part of the science of medicine which treats of the symptoms of diseases; semeiology.

Syn-: S y n - " A prefix meaning with  along with together at the same time. Syn- becomes sym- before p b and m and syl- before l.

Synacme: S y n a c m e "n. Alt. of Synacmy

Synacmy: S y n a c m y "n. Same as Synanthesis.

Synaeresis: S y n a e r e s i s "n. Alt. of Syneresis

Synagogical: S y n a g o g i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to a synagogue.

Synagogue: S y n a g o g u e "n. A congregation or assembly of Jews met for the purpose of worship  or the performance of religious rites.

Synagogue: S y n a g o g u e "n. The building or place appropriated to the religious worship of the Jews.

Synagogue: S y n a g o g u e "n. The council of  probably 120 members among the Jews first appointed after the return from the Babylonish captivity; -- called also the Great Synagogue and sometimes though erroneously the Sanhedrin.

Synagogue: S y n a g o g u e "n. A congregation in the early Christian church.

Synagogue: S y n a g o g u e "n. Any assembly of men.

Synalepha: S y n a l e p h a "n. A contraction of syllables by suppressing some vowel or diphthong at the end of a word  before another vowel or diphthong; as th' army for the army.

Synallagmatic: S y n a l l a g m a t i c "a. Imposing reciprocal obligations upon the parties; as  a synallagmatic contract.

Synallaxine: S y n a l l a x i n e "a. Having the outer and middle toes partially united; -- said of certain birds related to the creepers.

Synaloepha: S y n a l o e p h a "n. Same as Synalepha.

Synangia: S y n a n g i a "pl. "of Synangium

Synangium: S y n a n g i u m "n. The divided part beyond the pylangium in the aortic trunk of the amphibian heart.

Synantherous: S y n a n t h e r o u s "a. Having the stamens united by their anthers; as  synantherous flowers.

Synanthesis: S y n a n t h e s i s "n. The simultaneous maturity of the anthers and stigmas of a blossom.

Synanthous: S y n a n t h o u s "a. Having flowers and leaves which appear at the same time; -- said of certain plants.

Synanthrose: S y n a n t h r o s e "n. A variety of sugar  isomeric with sucrose found in the tubers of the Jerusalem artichoke (Helianthus tuberosus) in the dahlia and other Compositae.

Synapta: S y n a p t a "n. A genus of slender  transparent holothurians which have delicate calcareous anchors attached to the dermal plates. See Illustration in Appendix.

Synaptase: S y n a p t a s e "n. A ferment resembling diastase  found in bitter almonds. Cf. Amygdalin and Emulsin.

Synapticula: S y n a p t i c u l a "n. One of numerous calcareous processes which extend between  and unite the adjacent septa of certain corals especially of the fungian corals.

Synapticulae: S y n a p t i c u l a e "pl. "of Synapticula

Synarchy: S y n a r c h y "n. Joint rule or sovereignity.

Synartesis: S y n a r t e s i s "n. A fastening or knitting together; the state of being closely jointed; close union.

Synarthrodia: S y n a r t h r o d i a "n. Synarthrosis.

Synarthroses: S y n a r t h r o s e s "pl. "of Synarthrosis

Synarthrosis: S y n a r t h r o s i s "n. Immovable articulation by close union  as in sutures. It sometimes includes symphysial articulations also. See the Note under Articulation n. 1.

Synastry: S y n a s t r y "n. Concurrence of starry position or influence; hence  similarity of condition fortune etc. as prefigured by astrological calculation.

Synaxis: S y n a x i s "n. A congregation; also  formerly the Lord's Supper.

Syncarp: S y n c a r p "n. A kind of aggregate fruit in which the ovaries cohere in a solid mass  with a slender receptacle as in the magnolia; also a similar multiple fruit as a mulberry.

Syncarpia: S y n c a r p i a "pl. "of Syncarpium

Syncarpium: S y n c a r p i u m "n. Same as Syncarp.

Syncarpous: S y n c a r p o u s "a. Composed of several carpels consolidated into one ovary.

Syncategorematic: S y n c a t e g o r e m a t i c "a. Not capable of being used as a term by itself; -- said of words  as an adverb or preposition.

Synchondroses: S y n c h o n d r o s e s "pl. "of Synchondrosis

Synchondrosis: S y n c h o n d r o s i s "n. An immovable articulation in which the union is formed by cartilage.

Synchondrotomy: S y n c h o n d r o t o m y "n. Symphyseotomy.

Synchoresis: S y n c h o r e s i s "n. A concession made for the purpose of retorting with greater force.

Synchronal: S y n c h r o n a l "a. Happening at  or belonging to the same time; synchronous; simultaneous.

Synchronal: S y n c h r o n a l "n. A synchronal thing or event.

Synchronical: S y n c h r o n i c a l "a. Happening at the same time; synchronous.

Synchronism: S y n c h r o n i s m "n. The concurrence of events in time; simultaneousness.

Synchronism: S y n c h r o n i s m "n. The tabular arrangement of historical events and personages  according to their dates.

Synchronism: S y n c h r o n i s m "n. A representation  in the same picture of two or events which occured at different times.

Synchronistic: S y n c h r o n i s t i c "a. Of or pertaining to synchronism; arranged according to correspondence in time; as  synchronistic tables.

Synchronization: S y n c h r o n i z a t i o n "n. The act of synchronizing; concurrence of events in respect to time.

Synchronize: S y n c h r o n i z e "v. i. To agree in time; to be simultaneous.

Synchronize: S y n c h r o n i z e "v. t. To assign to the same date or period of time; as  to synchronize two events of Greek and Roman history.

Synchronize: S y n c h r o n i z e "v. t. To cause to agree in time; as  to synchronize the movements of different machines; to synchronize clocks.

Synchronized: S y n c h r o n i z e d "imp. & p. p. of Synchronize

Synchronizing: S y n c h r o n i z i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Synchronize

Synchronology: S y n c h r o n o l o g y "n. Contemporaneous chronology.

Synchronous: S y n c h r o n o u s "a. Happening at the same time; simultaneous.

Synchrony: S y n c h r o n y "n. The concurrence of events in time; synchronism.

Synchysis: S y n c h y s i s "n. A derangement or confusion of any kind  as of words in a sentence or of humors in the eye.

Syncitia: S y n c i t i a "pl. "of Syncytium

Synclastic: S y n c l a s t i c "a. Curved toward the same side in all directions; -- said of surfaces which in all directions around any point bend away from a tangent plane toward the same side  as the surface of a sphere; -- opposed to anticlastic.

Synclinal: S y n c l i n a l "a. Inclined downward from opposite directions  so as to meet in a common point or line.

Synclinal: S y n c l i n a l "a. Formed by strata dipping toward a common line or plane; as  a synclinal trough or valley; a synclinal fold; -- opposed to anticlinal.

Synclinal: S y n c l i n a l "n. A synclinal fold.

Syncline: S y n c l i n e "n. A synclinal fold.

Synclinical: S y n c l i n i c a l "a. Synclinal.

Synclinoria: S y n c l i n o r i a "pl. "of Synclinorium

Synclinorium: S y n c l i n o r i u m "n. A mountain range owing its origin to the progress of a geosynclinal  and ending in a catastrophe of displacement and upturning.

Syncopal: S y n c o p a l "a. Of or pertaining to syncope; resembling syncope.

Syncopate: S y n c o p a t e "v. t. To contract  as a word by taking one or more letters or syllables from the middle; as Gloster is a syncopated form of Gloucester.

Syncopate: S y n c o p a t e "v. t. To commence  as a tone on an unaccented part of a measure and continue it into the following accented part so that the accent is driven back upon the weak part and the rhythm drags.

Syncopated: S y n c o p a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Syncopate

Syncopating: S y n c o p a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Syncopate

Syncopation: S y n c o p a t i o n "n. The act of syncopating; the contraction of a word by taking one or more letters or syllables from the middle; syncope.

Syncopation: S y n c o p a t i o n "n. The act of syncopating; a peculiar figure of rhythm  or rhythmical alteration which consists in welding into one tone the second half of one beat with the first half of the beat which follows.

Syncope: S y n c o p e "n. An elision or retrenchment of one or more letters or syllables from the middle of a word; as  ne'er for never ev'ry for every.

Syncope: S y n c o p e "n. Same as Syncopation.

Syncope: S y n c o p e "n. A fainting  or swooning. See Fainting.

Syncope: S y n c o p e "n. A pause or cessation; suspension.

Syncopist: S y n c o p i s t "n. One who syncopates.

Syncopize: S y n c o p i z e "v. t. To syncopate.

Syncotyledonous: S y n c o t y l e d o n o u s "a. Having united cotyledonous.

Syncretic: S y n c r e t i c "a. Uniting and blending together different systems  as of philosophy morals or religion.

Syncretism: S y n c r e t i s m "n. Attempted union of principles or parties irreconcilably at variance with each other.

Syncretist: S y n c r e t i s t "n. One who attempts to unite principles or parties which are irreconcilably at variance;

Syncretist: S y n c r e t i s t "n. an adherent of George Calixtus and other Germans of the seventeenth century  who sought to unite or reconcile the Protestant sects with each other and with the Roman Catholics and thus occasioned a long and violent controversy in the Lutheran church.

Syncretistic: S y n c r e t i s t i c "a. Pertaining to  or characterized by syncretism; as a syncretistic mixture of the service of Jehovah and the worship of idols.

Syncretistic: S y n c r e t i s t i c "a. Of or pertaining to Syncretists.

Syncrisis: S y n c r i s i s "n. A figure of speech in which opposite things or persons are compared.

Syncytium: S y n c y t i u m "n. Tissue in which the cell or partition walls are wholly wanting and the cell bodies fused together  so that the tissue consists of a continuous mass of protoplasm in which nuclei are imbedded as in ordinary striped muscle.

Syncytium: S y n c y t i u m "n. The ectoderm of a sponge.

Syndactyle: S y n d a c t y l e "n. Any bird having syndactilous feet.

Syndactylic: S y n d a c t y l i c "a. Syndactilous.

Syndactylous: S y n d a c t y l o u s "a. Having the toes firmly united together for some distance  and without an intermediate web as the kingfishers; gressorial.

Syndesmography: S y n d e s m o g r a p h y "n. A description of the ligaments; syndesmology.

Syndesmology: S y n d e s m o l o g y "n. That part of anatomy which treats of ligaments.

Syndesmoses: S y n d e s m o s e s "pl. "of Syndesmosis

Syndesmosis: S y n d e s m o s i s "n. An articulation formed by means of ligaments.

Syndetic: S y n d e t i c "a. Alt. of Syndetical

Syndetical: S y n d e t i c a l "a. Connecting; conjunctive; as  syndetic words or connectives; syndetic references in a dictionary.

Syndic: S y n d i c "n. An officer of government  invested with different powers in different countries; a magistrate.

Syndic: S y n d i c "n. An agent of a corporation  or of any body of men engaged in a business enterprise; an advocate or patron; an assignee.

Syndicate: S y n d i c a t e "n. The office or jurisdiction of a syndic; a council  or body of syndics.

Syndicate: S y n d i c a t e "n. An association of persons officially authorized to undertake some duty or to negotiate some business; also  an association of persons who combine to carry out on their own account a financial or industrial project; as a syndicate of bankers formed to take up and dispose of an entire issue of government bonds.

Syndicate: S y n d i c a t e "v. t. To judge; to censure.

Syndrome: S y n d r o m e "n. Concurrence.

Syndrome: S y n d r o m e "n. A group of symptoms occurring together that are characteristic and indicative of some underlying cause  such as a disease.

Syndyasmian: S y n d y a s m i a n "a. Pertaining to the state of pairing together sexually; -- said of animals during periods of procreation and while rearing their offspring.

Syne: S y n e "adv. Afterwards; since; ago.

Syne: S y n e "adv. Late  -- as opposed to soon.

Syne: S y n e "conj. Since; seeing.

Synecdoche: S y n e c d o c h e "n. A figure or trope by which a part of a thing is put for the whole (as  fifty sail for fifty ships) or the whole for a part (as the smiling year for spring) the species for the genus (as cutthroat for assassin) the genus for the species (as a creature for a man) the name of the material for the thing made etc.

Synecdochical: S y n e c d o c h i c a l "a. Expressed by synecdoche; implying a synecdoche.

Synecdochically: S y n e c d o c h i c a l l y "adv. By synecdoche.

Synechia: S y n e c h i a "n. A disease of the eye  in which the iris adheres to the cornea or to the capsule of the crystalline lens.

Synecphonesis: S y n e c p h o n e s i s "n. A contraction of two syllables into one; synizesis.

Synedral: S y n e d r a l "a. Growing on the angles of a stem  as the leaves in some species of Selaginella.

Synentognathi: S y n e n t o g n a t h i "n. pl. An order of fishes  resembling the Physoclisti without spines in the dorsal anal and ventral fins. It includes the true flying fishes.

Synepy: S y n e p y "n. The interjunction  or joining of words in uttering the clauses of sentences.

Syneresis: S y n e r e s i s "n. The union  or drawing together into one syllable of two vowels that are ordinarily separated in syllabification; synecphonesis; -- the opposite of diaeresis.

Syneresis: S y n e r e s i s "n. Same as Synaeresis.

Synergetic: S y n e r g e t i c "a. Working together; cooperating; as  synergetic muscles.

Synergism: S y n e r g i s m "n. The doctrine or theory  attributed to Melanchthon that in the regeneration of a human soul there is a cooperation or joint agency on the part both of God and of man.

Synergist: S y n e r g i s t "n. One who holds the doctrine of synergism.

Synergist: S y n e r g i s t "n. A remedy which has an action similar to that of another remedy  and hence increases the efficiency of that remedy when combined with it.

Synergistic: S y n e r g i s t i c "a. Of or pertaining to synergism.

Synergistic: S y n e r g i s t i c "a. Cooperating; synergetic.

Synergy: S y n e r g y "n. Combined action

Synergy: S y n e r g y "n. the combined healthy action of every organ of a particular system; as  the digestive synergy.

Synergy: S y n e r g y "n. An effect of the interaction of the actions of two agents such that the result of the combined action is greater than expected as a simple additive combination of the two agents acting separately. Also synergism.

Syngenesia: S y n g e n e s i a "n. pl. A Linnaean class of plants in which the stamens are united by the anthers.

Syngenesian: S y n g e n e s i a n "a. Alt. of Syngenesious

Syngenesious: S y n g e n e s i o u s "a. Having the stamens united by the anthers; of or pertaining to the Syngenesia.

Syngenesis: S y n g e n e s i s "n. A theory of generation in which each germ is supposed to contain the germs of all subsequent generations; -- the opposite of epigenesis.

Syngnathi: S y n g n a t h i "n. pl. A suborder of lophobranch fishes which have an elongated snout and lack the ventral and first dorsal fins. The pipefishes and sea horses are examples.

Syngraph: S y n g r a p h "n. A writing signed by both or all the parties to a contract or bond.

Synizesis: S y n i z e s i s "n. An obliteration of the pupil of the eye.

Synizesis: S y n i z e s i s "n. A contraction of two syllables into one; synecphonesis.

Synneorosis: S y n n e o r o s i s "n. Syndesmosis.

Synneuroses: S y n n e u r o s e s "pl. "of Synneorosis

Synocha: S y n o c h a "n. See Synochus.

Synochal: S y n o c h a l "a. Of or pertaining to synocha; like synocha.

Synochus: S y n o c h u s "n. A continuous fever.

Synocil: S y n o c i l "n. A sense organ found in certain sponges. It consists of several filaments  each of which arises from a single cell.

Synod: S y n o d "n. An ecclesiastic council or meeting to consult on church matters.

Synod: S y n o d "n. An assembly or council having civil authority; a legislative body.

Synod: S y n o d "n. A conjunction of two or more of the heavenly bodies.

Synodal: S y n o d a l "a. Synodical.

Synodal: S y n o d a l "n. A tribute in money formerly paid to the bishop or archdeacon  at the time of his Easter visitation by every parish priest now made to the ecclesiastical commissioners; a procuration.

Synodal: S y n o d a l "n. A constitution made in a provincial or diocesan synod.

Synodic: S y n o d i c "a. Alt. of Synodical

Synodical: S y n o d i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to a synod; transacted in  or authorized by a synod; as synodical proceedings or forms.

Synodical: S y n o d i c a l "a. Pertaining to conjunction  especially to the period between two successive conjunctions; extending from one conjunction as of the moon or a planet with the sun to the next; as a synodical month (see Lunar month under Month); the synodical revolution of the moon or a planet.

Synodically: S y n o d i c a l l y "adv. In a synodical manner; in a synod; by the authority of a synod.

Synodist: S y n o d i s t "n. An adherent to a synod.

Synoecious: S y n o e c i o u s "a. Having stamens and pistil in the same head  or in mosses having antheridia and archegonia on the same receptacle.

Synomocy: S y n o m o c y "n. Sworn brotherhood; a society in ancient Greece nearly resembling a modern political club.

Synonym: S y n o n y m "n. One of two or more words (commonly words of the same language) which are equivalents of each other; one of two or more words which have very nearly the same signification  and therefore may often be used interchangeably. See under Synonymous.

Synonyma: S y n o n y m a "n. pl. Synonyms.

Synonymal: S y n o n y m a l "a. Synonymous.

Synonymally: S y n o n y m a l l y "adv. Synonymously.

Synonyme: S y n o n y m e "n. Same as Synonym.

Synonymic: S y n o n y m i c "n. The science  or the scientific treatment of synonymous words.

Synonymic: S y n o n y m i c "a. Alt. of Synonymical

Synonymical: S y n o n y m i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to synonyms  or synonymic; synonymous.

Synonymicon: S y n o n y m i c o n "n. A dictionary of synonyms.

Synonymist: S y n o n y m i s t "n. One who collects or explains synonyms.

Synonymize: S y n o n y m i z e "v. t. To express by a synonym or synonyms; to give the synonym or synonyms corresponding to.

Synonymized: S y n o n y m i z e d "imp. & p. p. of Synonymize

Synonymizing: S y n o n y m i z i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Synonymize

Synonymous: S y n o n y m o u s "a. Having the character of a synonym; expressing the same thing; conveying the same  or approximately the same idea.

Synonyms: S y n o n y m s "pl. "of Synonym

Synonymy: S y n o n y m y "n. The quality of being synonymous; sameness of meaning.

Synonymy: S y n o n y m y "n. A system of synonyms.

Synonymy: S y n o n y m y "n. A figure by which synonymous words are used to amplify a discourse.

Synopses: S y n o p s e s "pl. "of Synopsis

Synopsis: S y n o p s i s "n. A general view  or a collection of heads or parts so arranged as to exhibit a general view of the whole; an abstract or summary of a discourse; a syllabus; a conspectus.

Synoptic: S y n o p t i c "a. Alt. of Synoptical

Synoptic: S y n o p t i c "n. One of the first three Gospels of the New Testament. See Synoptist.

Synoptical: S y n o p t i c a l "a. Affording a general view of the whole  or of the principal parts of a thing; as a synoptic table; a synoptical statement of an argument.

Synoptist: S y n o p t i s t "n. Any one of the authors of the three synoptic Gospels  which give a history of our Lord's life and ministry in distinction from the writer of John's Gospel which gives a fuller record of his teachings.

Synosteology: S y n o s t e o l o g y "n. That part of anatomy which treats of joints; arthrology.

Synosteoses: S y n o s t e o s e s "pl. "of Synosteosis

Synosteosis: S y n o s t e o s i s "n. Union by means of bone; the complete closing up and obliteration of sutures.

Synostosis: S y n o s t o s i s "n. Same as Synosteosis.

Synovia: S y n o v i a "n. A transparent  viscid lubricating fluid which contains mucin and secreted by synovial membranes; synovial fluid.

Synovial: S y n o v i a l "a. Of or pertaining to synovia; secreting synovia.

Synovitis: S y n o v i t i s "n. Inflammation of the synovial membrane.

Synpelmous: S y n p e l m o u s "a. Having the two main flexor tendons of the toes blended together.

Synsepalous: S y n s e p a l o u s "a. Having united sepals; gamosepalous.

Syntactic: S y n t a c t i c "a. Alt. of Syntactical

Syntactical: S y n t a c t i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to syntax; according to the rules of syntax  or construction.

Syntax: S y n t a x "n. Connected system or order; union of things; a number of things jointed together; organism.

Syntax: S y n t a x "n. That part of grammar which treats of the construction of sentences; the due arrangement of words in sentences in their necessary relations  according to established usage in any language.

Syntaxis: S y n t a x i s "n. Syntax.

Synteresis: S y n t e r e s i s "n. Prophylaxis.

Synteresis: S y n t e r e s i s "n. Conscience viewed as the internal repository of the laws of duty.

Synteretic: S y n t e r e t i c "a. Preserving health; prophylactic.

Synteretics: S y n t e r e t i c s "n. That department of medicine which relates to the preservation of health; prophylaxis.

Synthermal: S y n t h e r m a l "a. Having the same degree of heat.

Syntheses: S y n t h e s e s "pl. "of Synthesis

Synthesis: S y n t h e s i s "n. Composition  or the putting of two or more things together as in compounding medicines.

Synthesis: S y n t h e s i s "n. The art or process of making a compound by putting the ingredients together  as contrasted with analysis; thus water is made by synthesis from hydrogen and oxygen; hence specifically the building up of complex compounds by special reactions whereby their component radicals are so grouped that the resulting substances are identical in every respect with the natural articles when such occur; thus artificial alcohol urea indigo blue alizarin etc. are made by synthesis.

Synthesis: S y n t h e s i s "n. The combination of separate elements of thought into a whole  as of simple into complex conceptions species into genera individual propositions into systems; -- the opposite of analysis.

Synthesist: S y n t h e s i s t "n. One who employs synthesis  or who follows synthetic methods.

Synthesize: S y n t h e s i z e "v. t. To combine by synthesis; to unite.

Synthesize: S y n t h e s i z e "v. t. To produce by synthesis; as  to synthesize albumin.

Synthetic: S y n t h e t i c "a. Alt. of Synthetical

Synthetical: S y n t h e t i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to synthesis; consisting in synthesis or composition; as  the synthetic method of reasoning as opposed to analytical.

Synthetical: S y n t h e t i c a l "a. Artificial. Cf. Synthesis  2.

Synthetical: S y n t h e t i c a l "a. Comprising within itself structural or other characters which are usually found only in two or more diverse groups; -- said of species  genera and higher groups. See the Note under Comprehensive 3.

Synthetically: S y n t h e t i c a l l y "adv. In a synthetic manner.

Synthetize: S y n t h e t i z e "v. t. To combine; to unite in regular structure.

Syntomy: S y n t o m y "n. Brevity; conciseness.

Syntonin: S y n t o n i n "n. A proteid substance (acid albumin) formed from the albuminous matter of muscle by the action of dilute acids; -- formerly called musculin. See Acid albumin  under Albumin.

Syphering: S y p h e r i n g "n. The lapping of chamfered edges of planks to make a smooth surface  as for a bulkhead.

Syphilide: S y p h i l i d e "n. A cutaneous eruption due to syphilis.

Syphilis: S y p h i l i s "n. The pox  or venereal disease; a chronic specific infectious disease usually communicated by sexual intercourse or by hereditary transmission and occurring in three stages known as primary secondary and tertiary syphilis. See under Primary Secondary and Tertiary.

Syphilitic: S y p h i l i t i c "a. Of or pertaining to syphilis; of the nature of syphilis; affected with syphilis.

Syphilitic: S y p h i l i t i c "n. A syphilitic patient.

Syphilitically: S y p h i l i t i c a l l y "adv. In a syphilitic manner; with venereal disease.

Syphilization: S y p h i l i z a t i o n "n. Inoculation with the syphilitic virus  especially when employed as a preventive measure like vaccination.

Syphilize: S y p h i l i z e "v. t. To inoculate with syphilis.

Syphiloderm: S y p h i l o d e r m "n. A cutaneous affection due to syphilis.

Syphilodermatous: S y p h i l o d e r m a t o u s "a. Of or pertaining to the cutaneous manifestations of syphilis.

Syphiloid: S y p h i l o i d "a. Resembling syphilis.

Syphilologist: S y p h i l o l o g i s t "n. One skilled in syphilology.

Syphilology: S y p h i l o l o g y "n. That branch of medicine which treats of syphilis.

Syphon: S y p h o n "n. See Syphon.

Syracuse: S y r a c u s e "n. A red wine of Italy.

Syren: S y r e n "n. See Siren.

Syriac: S y r i a c "a. Of or pertaining to Syria  or its language; as the Syriac version of the Pentateuch.

Syriac: S y r i a c "n. The language of Syria; especially  the ancient language of that country.

Syriacism: S y r i a c i s m "n. A Syrian idiom; a Syrianism.

Syrian: S y r i a n "a. Of or pertaining to Syria; Syriac.

Syrian: S y r i a n "n. A native of Syria.

Syrianism: S y r i a n i s m "n. A Syrian idiom  or a peculiarity of the Syrian language; a Syriacism.

Syriasm: S y r i a s m "n. A Syrian idiom; a Syrianism; a Syriacism.

Syringa: S y r i n g a "n. A genus of plants; the lilac.

Syringa: S y r i n g a "n. The mock orange; -- popularly so called because its stems were formerly used as pipestems.

Syringe: S y r i n g e "n. A kind of small hand-pump for throwing a stream of liquid  or for purposes of aspiration. It consists of a small cylindrical barrel and piston or a bulb of soft elastic material with or without valves and with a nozzle which is sometimes at the end of a flexible tube; -- used for injecting animal bodies cleansing wounds etc.

Syringe: S y r i n g e "v. t. To inject by means of a syringe; as  to syringe warm water into a vein.

Syringe: S y r i n g e "v. t. To wash and clean by injection from a syringe.

Syringeal: S y r i n g e a l "a. Of or pertaining to the syrinx; as  the syringeal muscle.

Syringed: S y r i n g e d "imp. & p. p. of Syringe

Syringes: S y r i n g e s "pl. "of Syrinx

Syringin: S y r i n g i n "n. A glucoside found in the bark of the lilac (Syringa) and extracted as a white crystalline substance; -- formerly called also lilacin.

Syringing: S y r i n g i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Syringe

Syringocoele: S y r i n g o c o e l e "n. The central canal of the spinal cord.

Syringotome: S y r i n g o t o m e "n. A small blunt-pointed bistoury  -- used in syringotomy.

Syringotomy: S y r i n g o t o m y "n. The operation of cutting for anal fistula.

Syrinx: S y r i n x "n. A wind instrument made of reeds tied together; -- called also pandean pipes.

Syrinx: S y r i n x "n. The lower larynx in birds.

Syrma: S y r m a "n. A long dress  trailing on the floor worn by tragic actors in Greek and Roman theaters.

Syrphian: S y r p h i a n "a. Of or pertaining to the syrphus flies.

Syrphian: S y r p h i a n "n. A syrphus fly.

Syrphus fly: S y r p h u s   f l y " Any one of numerous species of dipterous flies of the genus Syrphus and allied genera. They are usually bright-colored  with yellow bands and hover around plants. The larvae feed upon plant lice and are therefore very beneficial to agriculture.

Syrt: S y r t "n. A quicksand; a bog.

Syrtes: S y r t e s "pl. "of Syrtis

Syrtic: S y r t i c "a. Of or pertaining to a syrt; resembling syrt  or quicksand.

Syrtis: S y r t i s "n. A quicksand.

Syrup: S y r u p "n. A thick and viscid liquid made from the juice of fruits  herbs etc. boiled with sugar.

Syrup: S y r u p "n. A thick and viscid saccharine solution of superior quality (as sugarhouse sirup or molasses  maple sirup); specifically in pharmacy and often in cookery a saturated solution of sugar and water (simple sirup) or such a solution flavored or medicated.

Syrup: S y r u p "a. Alt. of Syrupy

Syruped: S y r u p e d "a. Moistened  covered or sweetened with sirup or sweet juice.

Syrupy: S y r u p y "a. Like sirup  or partaking of its qualities.

Syrupy: S y r u p y "a. Same as Sirup  Sirupy.

Syssarcosis: S y s s a r c o s i s "n. The junction of bones by intervening muscles.

Systaltic: S y s t a l t i c "a. Capable of  or taking place by alternate contraction and dilatation; as the systaltic action of the heart.

Systasis: S y s t a s i s "n. A political union  confederation or league.

System: S y s t e m "n. An assemblage of objects arranged in regular subordination  or after some distinct method usually logical or scientific; a complete whole of objects related by some common law principle or end; a complete exhibition of essential principles or facts arranged in a rational dependence or connection; a regular union of principles or parts forming one entire thing; as a system of philosophy; a system of government; a system of divinity; a system of botany or chemistry; a military system; the solar system.

System: S y s t e m "n. Hence  the whole scheme of created things regarded as forming one complete plan of whole; the universe.

System: S y s t e m "n. Regular method or order; formal arrangement; plan; as  to have a system in one's business.

System: S y s t e m "n. The collection of staves which form a full score. See Score  n.

System: S y s t e m "n. An assemblage of parts or organs  either in animal or plant essential to the performance of some particular function or functions which as a rule are of greater complexity than those manifested by a single organ; as the capillary system the muscular system the digestive system etc.; hence the whole body as a functional unity.

System: S y s t e m "n. One of the stellate or irregular clusters of intimately united zooids which are imbedded in  or scattered over the surface of the common tissue of many compound ascidians.

Systematic: S y s t e m a t i c "a. Alt. of Systematical

Systematical: S y s t e m a t i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to system; consisting in system; methodical; formed with regular connection and adaptation or subordination of parts to each other  and to the design of the whole; as a systematic arrangement of plants or animals; a systematic course of study.

Systematical: S y s t e m a t i c a l "a. Proceeding according to system  or regular method; as a systematic writer; systematic benevolence.

Systematical: S y s t e m a t i c a l "a. Pertaining to the system of the world; cosmical.

Systematical: S y s t e m a t i c a l "a. Affecting successively the different parts of the system or set of nervous fibres; as  systematic degeneration.

Systematically: S y s t e m a t i c a l l y "adv. In a systematic manner; methodically.

Systematism: S y s t e m a t i s m "n. The reduction of facts or principles to a system.

Systematist: S y s t e m a t i s t "n. One who forms a system  or reduces to system.

Systematist: S y s t e m a t i s t "n. One who adheres to a system.

Systematization: S y s t e m a t i z a t i o n "n. The act or operation of systematizing.

Systematize: S y s t e m a t i z e "v. t. To reduce to system or regular method; to arrange methodically; to methodize; as  to systematize a collection of plants or minerals; to systematize one's work; to systematize one's ideas.

Systematized: S y s t e m a t i z e d "imp. & p. p. of Systematize

Systematizer: S y s t e m a t i z e r "n. One who systematizes.

Systematizing: S y s t e m a t i z i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Systematize

Systematology: S y s t e m a t o l o g y "n. The doctrine of  or a treatise upon systems.

Systemic: S y s t e m i c "a. Of or relating to a system; common to a system; as  the systemic circulation of the blood.

Systemic: S y s t e m i c "a. Of or pertaining to the general system  or the body as a whole; as systemic death in distinction from local death; systemic circulation in distinction from pulmonic circulation; systemic diseases.

Systemization: S y s t e m i z a t i o n "n. The act or process of systematizing; systematization.

Systemize: S y s t e m i z e "v. t. To reduce to system; to systematize.

Systemized: S y s t e m i z e d "imp. & p. p. of Systemize

Systemizer: S y s t e m i z e r "n. One who systemizes  or reduces to system; a systematizer.

Systemizing: S y s t e m i z i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Systemize

Systemless: S y s t e m l e s s "a. Being without system.

Systemless: S y s t e m l e s s "a. Not agreeing with some artificial system of classification.

Systemless: S y s t e m l e s s "a. Not having any of the distinct systems or types of structure  as the radiate articulate etc. characteristic of organic nature; as all unicellular organisms are systemless.

Systole: S y s t o l e "n. The shortening of the long syllable.

Systole: S y s t o l e "n. The contraction of the heart and arteries by which the blood is forced onward and the circulation kept up; -- correlative to diastole.

Systolic: S y s t o l i c "a. Of or pertaining to systole  or contraction; contracting; esp. relating to the systole of the heart; as systolic murmur.

Systyle: S y s t y l e "a. Having a space equal to two diameters or four modules between two columns; -- said of a portico or building. See Intercolumniation.

Systyle: S y s t y l e "n. A systyle temple or other edifice.

Syth: S y t h "prep. adv.  conj. & n. Alt. of Sythe

Sythe: S y t h e "prep. adv.  conj. & n. See Sith Sithe.

Sythe: S y t h e "n. Scythe.

Syzygial: S y z y g i a l "a. Pertaining to a syzygy.

Syzygies: S y z y g i e s "pl. "of Syzygy

Syzygy: S y z y g y "n. The point of an orbit  as of the moon or a planet at which it is in conjunction or opposition; -- commonly used in the plural.

Syzygy: S y z y g y "n. The coupling together of different feet; as  in Greek verse an iambic syzygy.

Syzygy: S y z y g y "n. Any one of the segments of an arm of a crinoid composed of two joints so closely united that the line of union is obliterated on the outer  though visible on the inner side.

Syzygy: S y z y g y "n. The immovable union of two joints of a crinoidal arm.
